column8:
Ich konnte mich gar nicht mehr daran erinnern, dieses Spiel mal gespielt zu haben, tat ich aber offensichtlich.
Nun nach mehr als insgesamt 14h Spielzeit (davon nach Ã¼ber 8 Jahren) heute wieder ca. 2h, bin ich zu der Ãœberzeugung gelangt, dass dieses Spiel auf absolut verlorenen Posten steht.
Zum GlÃ¼ck weiÃŸ ich nicht mehr, was ich fÃ¼r diesen Titel bezahlt habe, im aktuellen Zustand wÃ¼rde ich jedoch sagen, mehr als 6 Euro wÃ¤re er mir nicht wert! Autsch!

Zum Spiel an sich:
Es lockt mit zahlreichen Elementen die ich von anderen Spielen mag, das Bausystem ist nicht perfekt aber Ã¤hnelt einem SimCity oder Ã¤hnlichen Titeln. Hinzu kommt der politsche Aspekt, man muss stÃ¤ndig Entscheidungen treffen und abwÃ¤gen.

Leider gestalltet sich das Bauen, wozu dieses Spiel eigentlich einlÃ¤d als sehr schwierig ohne Trainer etc.
Ohne wÃ¼rde ich bei diesem Spiel wahrscheinlich schon nach 10min die Flinte ins Korn werfen denn,
es ist quasie unmÃ¶glich irgend was zu bewegen, sei es neue Distrikte erstellen, bestehende beartbeiten oder was auch immer. StÃ¤ndig hast du die Wahl, mit deinem PrivatvermÃ¶gen IG (was du ohne Cheats quasie nicht hast) oder durch Votings deiner Ratsmitglieder der unterschiedlichen Partein zu dem zu kommen, was du eigentlich willst. Sie stimmen meist gegen den geplanten Schritt und somit belÃ¤uft es sich dabei, dass man Stunde um Stunde auf das immer gleich bleibdende Stadtbild starrt, da man ohne Zustimmung nichts machen kann. 

Schade eigentlich, auch ein Freebuild mode oder eine Funktion, bei der man sich selbst die Start und Zielbedingungen des Spiels setzen kann fehlt leider komplett. Die Kampangen und Szenarios sind freundlich gesprochen frustrierend.
Eine Schande ein derartiges Spiel in meiner Bibliothek zu haben!
Es hat sich nach Ã¼ber 8 Jahren so gut wie nichts am eigentlichen Spiel getan.

Guckt euch lieber Katzenvideos auf YT oder so an, da habt ihr mehr von!

[b]7/10 â€“ Good[/b]

This is a good game, I just wish they'd put a bit more of time and love into it. Talking about love, I can only ask you to try and give this game some love because it's really deserving if you like the genre.

Urban Empire is a unique blend of city-builder and political simulator, and while itâ€™s far from perfect, it definitely stands out in its own way.

[b]Letâ€™s start with the good stuff:[/b]

- The voice acting is actually really nice and adds personality to the game.
- There's a surprising amount of depth to city management, with real consequences for bad decisions, which I appreciate.
- The political system, though not flawless, forces you to think strategically and negotiate with parties to push your agendaâ€”at least until you're rich enough for it to stop mattering, except maybe during mayoral elections, where you do can get voted out otherwise.
- I love the era progressionâ€”both aesthetically and mechanically. Decisions like replacing gas grids with electricity city-wide actually feel impactful.
- District management is richer than you'd expect. You can add features like phone service without placing phone booths, or upgrade roads without traffic lights. It's cool, though admittedly shallow in execution and not as smooth as it could be, making upkeep hard to manage and progress difficult. I think that's the big reason why many people bounce off the game.

[b]Now, the not-so-good:[/b]

- The game badly needs a better tutorial. Key mechanics like traffic, happiness x taxes, and political goodwill are barely explained.
- I had no idea there were different victory types until I checked the achievementsâ€”this is never explained.
- Upkeep is brutal in the early game. Not expanding usually means going into the red, forcing you to grow faster than you might want, messing with compact city planning, so much that you can't really take advatange of public service ranges.
- Performance sucks in the late game, especially in Era V.
- Endorsing is shallow.
- The character backstories and roleplay options feel hollow. Even playing as a conservative family doesn't change the fact that social reforms (like rights for women/LGBT/children) are always beneficial, so youâ€™re never incentivized to roleplay against them.
- The zoning demand system is kind of broken when you have a lot of districts. High demand doesnâ€™t always lead to logical expansions, which can cause stagnation.
- The game could really use some fresh mechanics introduced in later erasâ€”something like Twin Cities or Party Spying. It would make era progression feel more meaningful and dynamic.

Despite all this, there's a solid, very ambitious game underneath. It just needed a bit more polish, explanation, and some optimization love.

If you're into political strategy and want a city-builder that tries something different, give Urban Empire a shot. It might surprise youâ€”as long as youâ€™re willing to forgive its rough edges.

column8:
Kann das extrem negative Echo nicht nachvollziehen. Ja, das Spiel wirkt an manchen Stellen noch unsauber und es gibt gar manchen Gamebreaking Bug. Im Grundsatz ist das Spielkonzept aber durchaus innovativ, komplex und bei Erfolgen sehr befriedigend (aber mit Arbeit versehen, Datenbanken analysieren, Stellschrauben minimal anpassen, Risiken eingehen oder wieder RÃ¼ckzieher machen). Mir fÃ¤llt auch kein anderes Spiel ein, welches eine recht realistische StÃ¤dtebausimulation mit den VorgÃ¤ngen von Parteienpolitik schlÃ¼ssig verbindet. Da ich beruflich selber Stadtplaner bin, kann ich bestÃ¤tigen, dass der StÃ¤dtebau-Teil akkurat (wenn natÃ¼rlich auch vereinfacht) abgebildet wird. 

PrÃ¤sentation, Gameplay, UI etc. erinnern dabei etwas an die "goldene" Zeit vergleichbarer Simulationen in den 90er und 2000er Jahren. Insbesondere die Grafik haut natÃ¼rlich niemanden um. Ich halte es aber fÃ¼r zweckmÃ¤ÃŸig und authentisch.
column9:
I can't understand the extremely negative response. Yes, the game still seems sloppy in some places, and there are even a few game-breaking bugs. Fundamentally, however, the game concept is quite innovative, complex, and very satisfying when you succeed (but it requires work: analyzing databases, adjusting parameters slightly, taking risks, or backing out). I can't think of any other game that coherently combines a fairly realistic city-building simulation with the workings of party politics. As a city planner myself, I can confirm that the city-building part is portrayed accurately (albeit simplified).

The presentation, gameplay, UI, etc., are somewhat reminiscent of the "golden" era of comparable simulations in the 90s and 2000s. Of course, the graphics in particular won't blow anyone away. But I consider it functional and authentic.

column8: I do think there is fun to be had playing the game and that is why I recommend it but I also agree that there are lots of problems with it. Because of all the bad reviews which again I do think raise valid points I only dared get it on a big discount because I was very curious to try it out. And after just a couple playthroughs I do think the game has a very interesting and enjoyable concept, it could have been a great game really if it was just a little bit better balanced. Unfortunately the game is simply too punishing. You have to raise money in order to build improvements to keep the population happy to keep them productive and raise more money. It's a simple loop and it is actually quite enjoyable and interesting in the beginning, the game throws you different situations and options to make each playthrough a little different. The problem is that the upkeep of the improvements quickly becomes too expensive to maintain. So what you do is you raise taxes. Council will not let you raise taxes too high however (and it's a good thing they don't let you because it would choke your economy, the council is actually pretty smart and most of the time following along with it rather than opposing it too strongly is a good strategy). If you start defying council too much it will lose you political goodwill with the different parties... and then you risk getting voted out and game over. So it's very easy to get stuck in little depressions and recession downward spirals and then you're not progressing and you have to spend a full era just rebuilding your economy to start progressing again and what should have been fun and rewarding instead becomes agonizing and frustrating. So do expect to get disappointed if you get it and just enjoy the bittersweet taste of what could have been a great game.

The game is really frustrating. The main focus of the game - the political play is actually fun. But Politics are dependant on material conditions - on the economy - and economics system is... really half baked.
It is not giving you nearly enough information to make informed choices. And RNG determines the outcome almost more than the player does. So you easily can have 2 runs where you make identical decisions, but in one run your economy prospers and in another run crashes and burns.Simply because a randon event failed to pop up in time.

column8:
I really wanted Urban Empire to be a different game than it was. 

First some positives: The UI is really beautiful (although difficult to navigate) and everything looks pretty great overall until you try to move the camera around. I loved the concept of needing to manage political factions that morph, wax and wane over time! I also really enjoyed the core mechanic of managing player-defined districts. Some really cool ideas.

Sadly, it falls a little short. The game runs fitfully, and I'm not using a potato. Camera operations are annoying and limited in a way that affects gameplay sometimes. There isn't a lot of explanation or exposition, which makes it hard to learn things. Some game elements (like the tech tree) are so unorthodox that it took me a several plays to figure out how they worked.

Still, the cool parts are cool enough that I do recommend test-playing this and refunding if it isn't for you at all. I don't regret the 30+ hours I've put in, and while I probably won't return to it any time soon, I have fond memories of playing.

column8:
Only a slight dislike because the game has so much potential (has a great fundamental idea) but the game lies to you in terms of how the game actually works along with other inconveniences explained below.

For example, the game will tell you that you need to keep your people happy and that will make you more money. Unfortunately, that is not true the services and infrastructure you build has no impact on the income from your districts. Also, having an unintuitive indicator like lower sales demand being red when it is actually a good thing, quality of life issues like not having a skip vote button, auto save timers (monthly, yearly, before elections, etc.), not auto saving before elections which you could lose and the last auto save be 5+ years earlier (~5-10 min. irl time), none of the city data that it gives you is explained in the game or in the manual.

It's hard to play a game when you can't trust the game to give you accurate information.

Unfortunately, that is not true the services and infrastructure you build has no impact on the income from your districts. Also, having an unintuitive indicator like lower sales demand being red when it is actually a good thing, quality of life issues like not having a skip vote button, auto save timers (monthly, yearly, before elections, etc.), not auto saving before elections which you could lose and the last auto save be 5+ years earlier (~5-10 min. irl time), none of the city data that it gives you is explained in the game or in the manual.

It's hard to play a game when you can't trust the game to give you accurate information.

column8: En espaÃ±ol por favor!

This game has a lot of interesting elements and aspects to it, that I have never seen in another game of this type.  I just really like the political element, where you have to politic with the various factions to get votes.  That's very realistic.

The learning curve is definitely steep, and it is easy to push forward with a lot of what a player might believe are 'good to have' governmental/city/social changes, policies and funding bills that can quickly eat up your budget and put you into a death spiral towards bankruptcy; thus it is critical to pace yourself, and even more critical is to not push hard with all the factions on every bill that comes before you and the council.  If you do that, you will ultimately alienate the council and when it comes time that you REALLY do need their help, they won't be responsive.  saying, "you owe me one, you owe me one, you owe me one", will result in, "no, we don't, we already helped you again and again and again, go away". 

Instead, just like in real life, you must pick and choose which bills are important and critical to get passed by the council, and either delay or ignore the others.

There are other players that have gone in to detail on how to successfully manage city growth & budget, so I won't dive into that.  

Finally, It is important to keep in mind that you are managing a city in a lesser developed country.  It is not imperative that every district in your town have all the most modern amenities.  If some parts of town do not have a natural gas grid, or still use cobblestone or dirt roads, but installing such infrastructure will wreck your budget going forward, then don't do it.  For example, I live in the heart of downtown Atlanta; i recently learned that 100 years ago (1920's), all the streets north of my building were unpaved dirt roads.  Electricity was installed in the area in the 1940's and the first streetlights were installed in late 1950s!  Your budget must be constrained by what your tax base can support, not what looks pretty.  

Self restraint is the hardest aspect of the game.  Modernizing your city and implementing social equality must be paced against what the people demand vs what is 'nice to have'.  Master that and you will find the game a rewarding experience.

Easily my favorite political/city management game, hands down.  If you're looking for Urban Planner games, play Cities Skylines.  If you want to play mindless dystopia, try Workers and Resources Soviet Republic

column9: The game has a cool theme with the city council, family, and events related to it... and that's the only positive thing about it. In any normal game, the player develops the city by building something, earning more and more, and so on. Not here. Here, building anything always results in losses. Besides, if you do nothing, your income plummets anyway. Because it does. And of course, the game won't tell you why businesses in the city are failing. What good is it to you? Did you invent something? Great. You just made the situation worse instead of better. On top of that, the game is blatantly misleading. It says something "supports businesses," but it doesn't. You don't see any effect other than increased spending. Or it says it increases demand by... -5%. So it decreases demand? What's going on? Why is the economy in this game so screwed up? And then there's the city council. Their decisions are often very strange. You lose money every month, but they won't let you increase taxes anyway because there's still money in the city coffers. And even if the treasury is bursting at the seams and everyone in town loves you, they'll still vote against you in the elections... Sigh... I just don't get it. Either things are going well and it's all good, or for no reason at all, the game puts you in a hopeless situation. Whatever you do (or don't do), it'll only get worse. And the worst part is, you don't know why. And you're left staring at the monitor, unable to do anything because either there's no money, the council is against you, or there's a sudden economic crisis or something. You lose the desire to play. I don't recommend it.

column8: Das es ein politisches System gibt.

I love this game, but it just feels like not enough time was put into this game. The city-building feels very simple, and linear. You build your city by dragging a grid to make a district, so your cities don't feel very unique or organic. It feels like the same game every time you play, and that's such a shame, because It's a great concept. I still play the game occasionally, but I wish they had put more time into it. Maybe a sequel could add the much needed depth to the game.

column8: Great idea. I really wanted to like it. Terrible execution. The game is horribly unbalanced once you adopt the political views of a teenager. Making the "right" choice has nothing but benefits. Making the "wrong" choice has nothing but consequences. Need more money because you've never balanced a budget in your life? That's okay, you can just increase taxes indefinitely. The citizens are happy to fork over their salary, car, house, dog, children, arm and leg so that you can build that new neighbourhood.

Ich habe das Spiel schon lÃ¤nger auf der Festplatte. Kurz zu mir ich stamme noch aus der Lochkartenzeit und spiele schon ziemlich lange. Zu Urban Empire. Ein sehr unterschÃ¤tztes und verkanntes Spiel. Vorneweg...eine der wichtigsten Tipps...speichern...kleine Entscheidungen Treffen...geduldig beobachten und bei einem Misserfolg zum Speicherstand zurÃ¼ckkehren. So wird das schwierige Spiel beherrschbar. Ein weiterer Tipp, die BÃ¼rger immer 1 bis 2 Punkte hÃ¶her besteuern als die Industrie. Mit Geduld wÃ¤chst das ganze und wirft Gewinn ab. Die Gefahr liegt im Ãœbermut. Ein Spiel fÃ¼r Beobachter...mit Geduld.
column9: I've had the game on my hard drive for a while. A little about me: I'm from the punch card era and have been playing for quite a while. Regarding Urban Empire: A very underrated and misunderstood game. First of all...one of the most important tips...save...make small decisions...watch patiently, and return to the save point if you fail. This makes the difficult game manageable. Another tip: always tax citizens 1 or 2 points more than industry. With patience, the whole thing grows and generates profits. The danger lies in overconfidence. A game for observers...with patience.

column8:
Das Spiel gefÃ¤llt mir gut, hat allerdings auch noch Potential nach oben. Das Tutorial ist sehr knapp gehalten, wodurch man mehrere AnlÃ¤ufe braucht, um die Spielmechanik richtig zu verstehen. Aber auch dann kann eine Fehlentscheidung das Ende der Karriere bedeuten, wodurch es nicht langweilig wird. Obwohl ich schon 40h gespielt habe, sind mir Feinheiten immer noch nicht bewusst, also wie ich gezielt einzelne Gruppen wie die Mittelschicht oder Elite zufriedenstelle und die Unterschicht eher aus meiner Stadt raushalte. Obwohl die Ãœbersetzung ins Deutsche gut gelungen ist, ist die Voransicht vieler Ereignisse undurchsichtig. Man bekommt mit Symbolen angezeigt was die Auswirkungen der Entscheidung in welchem Bereich sein sollen, allerdings kann man die Symbole nur schwer zuordnen.
GrÃ¶ÃŸtes Manko ist die fehlende Optimierung des Spiels im Endgame. Vermutlich brÃ¤uchte man einen NASA Computer um das Spiel gegen Ende ruckelfrei zu spielen. Ã„nderungen der Grafikeinstellungen auf praktisch null mit Reduzierung der AuflÃ¶sung (Alt+Enter um wieder Vollbild zu haben) bringen eine Besserung der Performance. Das Problem ist wohl bekannt, aber es gibt keine LÃ¶sung. Dadurch werden die letzten 40 Jahre im Spiel sehr anstrengend. Anstatt seine aufblÃ¼hende Stadt zu betrachten und sich Ã¼ber die Kleinigkeiten in der Umgebung zu freuen, ruckelt entweder alles vor sich hin oder man muss sich mit niedrigsten Einstellungen und nur noch wenigen Rucklern begnÃ¼gen.
Trotzdem ein spaÃŸiges Spiel. Ein zweiter Teil der alles noch mal optimiert und neue Inhalte hinzufÃ¼gt oder Inhalte besser verzahnt, kÃ¶nnte ein Top-Seller Titel werden.

column8:
Hay pocos juegos de cuyas reseÃ±as no puedas fiarte...., pero este, en mi opiniÃ³n estÃ¡ muy infravalorado. La reseÃ±a es muy negativa porque estÃ¡ en inglÃ©s, pero el juego estÃ¡ muy chulo, lo de votar cada decisiÃ³n que quieras tomar en tu ciudad es una mecÃ¡nica que nunca habÃ­a visto y que estÃ¡ muy lograda.

Vale que estÃ¡ en inglÃ©s pero para cualquiera que sepa una base de ingles y buscando 4 palabras que no entiendas, se puede jugar perfectamente. Si tu nivel de inglÃ©s es medio, juegas perfectamente, ademÃ¡s si has jugado a otros citybuilders, la parte de construir la ciudad, los servicio, etc, es como en todos, marcas una zona con los distritos y se construye sola. 

En fin, a mi me ha gustado y francamente no veo la necesidad de hacer un master en inglÃ©s para jugarlo, solo un poquito de voluntad y un pelin del traductor de google.

No te lo recomendarÃ­a en dos casos:

1.- Que no sepas nada de inglÃ©s, porque vas a estar mÃ¡s traduciendo que jugando.

2.- Que tus ganas de traducir un poco, sean nulas.
column9:
There are few games whose reviews you can't trust... but this one, in my opinion, is seriously underrated. The review is very negative because it's in English, but the game is very cool. Voting on each decision you make in your city is a mechanic I'd never seen before, and it's very well done.

Okay, it's in English, but for anyone who knows a basic level of English and can search for four words you don't understand, it's perfectly playable. If your English level is intermediate, you'll play perfectly. Also, if you've played other city builders, the city-building, services, etc., part is like all the others: you mark an area with the districts, and it builds itself.

Anyway, I liked it, and frankly, I don't see the need for a master's degree in English to play it. You just need a little willpower and a bit of Google Translate.

I wouldn't recommend it in two cases:

1. If you don't know any English, because you'll be translating more than playing.

2.- That your desire to translate a little is null.

Bon, j'ai forcÃ© pour donner une chance au jeu mais rien Ã  faire, mÃªme des annÃ©es aprÃ¨s. Le jeu offre une simulation d'urbanisme et de politique dans une ville visiblement lÃ©gislativement indÃ©pendante, mais malgrÃ© tout Ã  l'intÃ©rieur de l'Empire d'Autriche et de sa juridiction ( ou un truc du genre ).

Bref, niveau city builder, c'est trÃ¨s vide. Il suffit de selectionner une zone et le quartier prendra forme dedans de lui mÃªme, et des fois, c'pas trÃ¨s logique le rÃ©sultat. On est pas sur city skyline..
Ensuite, une fois tout les quartiers posÃ©s (j'le fais en dÃ©but de partie histoire d'Ãªtre tranquille), il y a uniquement les services Ã  positionner au fur et Ã  mesure de la partie. Ensuite, place Ã  la gestion, ce qui devrait Ãªtre top, est enfaÃ®te complÃ©tement chaotique. Les lois, le budget, les taxe, les dÃ©crets, tout doit Ãªtre fait via un Conseil Municipal. MÃªme si l'idÃ©e est bonne, c'est rÃ©pÃ©titif et loin d'Ãªtre dynamique. Les partis sont trÃ¨s flou, s'attirer leur sympathie est trÃ¨s alÃ©atoire.

Le plus grand problÃ¨me du jeu, c'est de ne savoir aucune consÃ©quence possible de nos choix. On rajoute le gaz dans ce quartier ? On va connaÃ®tre le cout, mais pas les bÃ©nÃ©fices apportÃ©s au quartier.. Pour pouvoir financer votre ville, les taxes doivent Ãªtre en continuelle augmentation, du coup mes industries payent 70% de taxe mais tout va bien.

Bref, c'est n'importe quoi et on avance au pif total. Vive la politique les yeux bandÃ©s, mais lÃ  c'est un non pour moi.

column8:
Not really a city builder not really a deep political game either.  If it was not for the Optimization I would never have written a review.  While some of the crashing issues were resolve the game has an issue after the third issue as frame rates drop and the game becomes unresponsive at times.  Long loading into the game, more so than games with anti cheat. Long save game loading... 

Since this game is prone to techinical issue I would avoid it, if those issues do somehow get fixed then remember this is not a very deep game and only a casual city planner / political game where the numbers really don't matter as it too easy to stay in office and strong arm the council.

Excellent political simulation on an urban level! Like Power & Revolution for cities.  
Despite simple techniques, there is a lot to learn, and achievements, like providing electricity before 1900, or finally shutting down the gas infrastructure a few years later, feel like a great accomplishment.

Oh, and screw the Steam reviews, I bought the game 4 years after release because the reviews were so bad.... What a bunch of bullshit.

 The best way to progress through this game is to find a trick and pass all your decissions through the political parties that are inside the towns council... you need to use demand threat appeals etc to gain control over the decissions...its like someone is behind the scenes and has sent hes secretary to do the dirty job in this new build town...the decissions most of the time are already in place...you just need to find a way around them and thats about it...the games goes on and on about how to manipulate the council parties you dont do anything else you get occassionaly tasks that pop up that gives you some kind of abilities that you can use to presure in your favor some other tasks in the future...if you are a good tactical mind you will find your way around easily...if this is fun? No. so conclusion is this for some players only oh i bet ya it is...is it strategic no. it is not.. IT IS A CUNNING GAME. that doesnt allow you any other moves except tohse that it itself provides to you...pretty PATHETIC.

column8:
I had been waiting much of time to buy this game.
When I finally got it and start playing, I notice that it was not really enjoyable.
THE IDEA IS AMAZING.
You are the mayor of a city through couple of centuries, acting like in other city building games ike Skylines etc.
However you dont have unlimited power but there is City Counsil you need to pursade, 
and in addition a family dynasty to take care.
And politics change through time.

So the idea is great (it kind of reminds Tropico, as it is Calypso game).
BUT
the exacution is boring.
The developers claim about replayability but...nope!

column8:
There is not much intelligence in the AI when determining if you are running at a profit or loss. 

At one point I was making +25k a month, the next thing I decide to add a harbour to increase commerce and guess what happens, I skydive all the way to -17k a month, unbelievable.

Furthermore we voted and it was agreed minors should not be working, then about 100 years later, we need to vote on this same issue for it to be illegal. Should the vote this time to be whether we want to make it legal again since we already made it illegal 100 years ago?

column8:
Wow, die Rezensionen sind ja nicht so gut gelaufen. Aber Last euch davon nicht unterkriegen.

Ernsthaft, lÃ¤sst euch von den krassen Rot um mich herum nicht das Spiel madig reden.

Ja, technisch ist es nur mittelmÃ¤ÃŸig, aber das ist fÃ¼r mich okay. Ich erwarte ja auch kein AAA Titel von einem kleinen Studio, das in einem ganz anderen Genre aktiv ist. Wer danach sucht, soll zu den groÃŸen Studios gehen oder Batterien kaufen. Verstehste? Wegen AAA. Fand ich lustig.

Die Erwartungshaltung ist das Problem. Wer hier einen fetten Titel erwartet, wird maÃŸlos enttÃ¤uscht werden. Wer sich aber darauf einlÃ¤sst, hinter die Mechaniken zu schauen, wird interessante Intentionen der Entwickler finden. Auch wenn viele Funktionen im Spiel nicht gut genug gebalanced wurden, will doch jede Funktion eine Aussage treffen. Beispielsweise stÃ¶rt mich der Zufallsgenerator fÃ¼r Ereignisse und Reaktionen auch, aber Ã¼berlegt Mal: In der Politik ist es auch oft GlÃ¼ck, ob deine Aktion eine positive Reaktion bekommt. Es ist nicht alles von dir abhÃ¤ngig in der Welt. Genauso die fehlenden Informationen. Du bist kein Gott, sondern ein popeliger Typ im Anzug. Bis vor wenigen Jahren war es normal, dass die Regierung eigentlich keine Ahnung hat, wie die exakten Daten zu einem Thema aussehen, weil es gar keine MÃ¶glichkeiten gab, diesd Daten zu erheben. Gute Politiker definierten sich durch ihre Expertise, auch ohne genaue Daten handlungsfÃ¤hig zu sein. Genau das wird von dir abverlangt. Willkommen im PrÃ¤imformationszeitalter.

Ich kann verstehen, wenn jemand die ganze MittelmÃ¤ÃŸigkeit als spielstÃ¶tend empfindet. Wenn du ein wirklich spiegelglattes Gameplay brauchst, ist es nicht dein Spiel. Ich verbinde mit diesem Spiel aber den Anfang von meinem Philosophiestudium. Vor allem die ersten Zeitalter haben mich umgehauen vom Setting. Wir leben selbstverstÃ¤ndlich in heutigen Denkmustern und dieses Spiel forderte mich in meinem Denken auf allen Ebenen heraus. Und das hat mir sehr gut gefallen.

Deswegen reite ich mit meinem Pferd am Bahnhof vorbei und denke: ZÃ¼ge werden sich niemals durchsetzen.
good game

There's a lot review about the most important thing to know about Urban Empire, but once more:

[b] Urban Empire is a game, where You are the Mayor, who needs to manage he city. [/b] 

If you"re looking for another city builder, the new SimCity, then it's not your game.

But if You love the Tropico-like games, or looking for some city manager game, then it's a very good choice.

I'm shocked to see so many negative reviews of this game. It doesn't say it was trying to be Cities Skylines or SimCity. 
This game is exactly what it says it is, and it has an interesting a fresh take on a city strategy game. 

I started playing this game a few years ago, and it is a really good game overall.

column8: Its one those times where a game tries to be too many things and succeeds at little, The city building part of it is barely workable and very limited. The political sim part is ok but a lot doesn't really make sense and there is a sense of some RNG in the whole thing. Also its not terrible overall but it did not keep my attention and when my save was deleted nothing drew me back. There is so much better in either genre and I'm sure there there are better city/political sims that do this much better. On this games best moments its just OK but mostly drugery.  For what it is suppose to be you have so little control . If you are curious like I was wait for a sale otherwise there are so many better choices.

column8: ä¸å¥½ç©ï¼Œåˆ«ä¹°

Game-Breaking Bugs

I was enjoying the game up to the point when I researched Business Delegations, but there is no Delegation View button. This is due to some other tech not being researched yet, which allows this Delegation View to activate. 

Warning to everyone: Do not research Business Delegations until other techs allow for the Delegation View to happen (I think it's Twin-Cities). The game cannot proceed otherwise. 

Would not recommend due to how much progress i've lost - this game is 3 years old, these should've been fixed.

column8: This game does not make sense from many aspect. It wants to be different from the others, like SimCity or Cities skylines and so on... But the realization of the new ideas are just simply bad. City council will refuse all of your expansion ideas if your balance is in the red, but will approve nearly anything if it is in the green. You can raise taxes in the beginning with quickly going into the red spending area, and then build nearly unlimited number of districts afterwards. If you try to follow the tutorial, then you will have bad luck: stagnation and/or bankruptcy comes very easily. It is not that the game is difficult, if you know the mechanics (maximum taxation in the beginning, then build districts quickly), then you can have quite a big settlement easily. Otherwise, it is just a misery.

column9: The tutorial is completely limited, many parameters have no clear impact or explanation, and the political system is completely useless. District information is also uninformative. There's no in-game information or help. You'll never know what you're doing wrong. Even if you win, you'll win by pure chance, with no idea how you did it. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

Die negative Kritik an dem Game ist maÃŸlos Ã¼bertrieben. Hier treffen "Sim City" und "Die Gilde 2" aufeinander, ohne aber an eins der Games ranzukommen. 
Man plant seine Stadt, muss fÃ¼r Ã„nderungen vor den Rat und hat dort diverese MÃ¶glichkeiten, seine Entscheidung durchzudrÃ¼cken. 
Macht Laune fÃ¼r zwischendurch!

Where to start.  This is not a city builder.  It's a "political" game.  And not a particularly good one at that.  Voting is very basic.  Parties have a "happiness" bar.  Whenever you want to do *ANYTHING* you either need to have them be already be happy and have it be something they already want to do, or you force them to vote the way you want which makes them less happy and harder to convince in the future.  Eventually you run into a situation where you either run out of money and can do nothing or you can no longer get anything done because everyone is pissed at you and will vote against anything you propose.  The tutorial is useless for explaining how to manage this long term as it basically forces you to piss everyone off AND run out of money.

Quatre dynasties c'est bien, mais comme on finit par faire voter les mÃªmes lois pour les mÃªmes raisons Ã§a semble trÃ¨s inutile.

column8: This game was very memory intensive. Once it loaded up the tutorial was well designed. The idea was alot more promising then the game play. I was hoping to experiment with different play styles. Unfortunately this game skews to requiring high taxes and doesn't seem to model the effects of policies that well. Experimented with trying a small state approach - but basically the parties in power rarely think that way so essentially becomes tedious to try different approaches. Got boring then very quick. For the price definitely not worth it.

So I got this game because I liked the concept and thought it would be cool - while that's true the implementation is god awful. I don't enjoy talking poorly about games, to the contrary I always comment only when I have something positive to say, but after the second age there is literally no way to balance anything or keep your little empire running. If the devs had actually played the game through once or twice then this may have been averted but I honestly can't see them having done this, the game works awesomely through the first age or so but falls apart so quickly.

A game for a leader, not for a God.
All in all this is quite a good game if you understand what it is. So be warned: this game is not a typical citybuilding game and it's not that intuitive either. You're not God in this game, you're supposed to be the mayor of your city! This means that you can not just randomly arrange your city without consequences. You'll have to make logical political decisions about your city instead ... meaning you'll have to please your citizens and political collegues with the setup of your city or they won't endorse your next decision, service or quarter and even upgrades for every district. This aspect of having to deal with opposition and how the different districts interact can sometimes feel like a bother. It might slow down the pace for you but you'll have to consider when you play your political cards or you become a tyrant in the opinion of your councel, and eventually end up stuck with no cooperation whatsoever and  having "nothing to do but watch everything fall apart". Of course you'll hate this game then. The political and economical aspect however does make this game a lot more realistic than traditional citybuilders. Having said that you do still have partial freedom to spend your own income however you want. You might want to save your own funds for emergencies though because for the whole of the rest of the counsel you'll have to make sense somehow with the layout of your city and find the compromizes, for example to collect the taxes needed to survive the next economic crisis or boom, all set in a sandbox historical timeframe. When it all works out for you this game is quite enjoyable though and not nearly half as bad as some think it is.

column9: Too simple, no real sense of purpose. Residential taxes are 90% (it could be 100%, but I'm a good mayor, so I'll just let it go), and industrial and commercial taxes are 2% (mainly because I disagree with tax exemptions). It's too much money, and they'll approve anything you want to build, but they won't let you be mayor! You've worked hard for over a hundred years, but now someone else owns the city. Do you even think that makes sense? You ask the political party for something, but they won't tell you. Your decisions are passed unanimously, but they won't let you be mayor. If I weren't in that Caribbean island nation, I'd have wiped you out long ago!

If you always wanted to experience boring council meetings first hand, Urban Empire got you covered. The political machinations of this so-called city ruler are presented way too dry to elicit any other response than eye-rolling. While the part about building a city and researching new technologies is way more fun, there simply isnâ€™t enough feedback for players to penetrate the gameâ€™s intricacies. With only a few, small maps to build on, Urban Empire makes a poor case for itself.

One of the worst games I've ever played. Really repetitive, not at all stimulating and above all, still the same mechanics after 10 years in the game. Additionally, you build add-ons to your city after it has been approved. However, personalities change and party positions don't always stay so rigid and it is focused on policy half the time.

I demand a freakin refund from the creators!

Nette Idee nur schlecht umgesetzt. Die Nachfrage nach den gebieten steigt erst auf hÃ¶chststand und sekunden spÃ¤ter schon im minus ohne etwas getan zu haben. Alles wandert ab und man macht nur minus. SpaÃŸ gleich null

The TL;DR version is below.

I did try to like the game. But is rather un-innovative.
You create a district, which is a combination of 3 zones like in SimCity (industrial, economical and housing). You can divide it by %, but by default it's 60% housing, 10% econ and the rest industrial.
You can, like in other games, add buildings to service the needs, eventually upgrade the districts and it's density etc.

The main thing about the game - political choices. Basically to do most of the things, you need to convince the ever increasing ammount of parties. They listen to you when you use convience options, like pleads or threats.

Only - there doesn't really matter which you use.
And secondly - as long as you have money and don't want to pull a bill that will put you in the red too much, they will agree to most things.

Even further - getting services for your districts will ruin you. So you just cash in on them and only get the ones that boost industry.
Than once you have enough cash, you just build another district. Rinse and repeat.

REPEAT is the key word in the game. While you do upgrade researches, most of the things seem rather passive, with other upgrades beeing simply too expensive to be viable at all. Electricity should in theory make your rich right? But in practice it doesn't translate that way.
But brushing that aside (you eventually can afford the stuff later if for whatever reason you want it), nothing ever changes.
The city doesn't feel alive at all. Everything is a made up stat with no consequence. Only cash generation matters. You don't do anything almost.

There is only voting. Which is even more repetetive! All you do is move the parties on a slider, with same options every time...

It begins rather ok-ish, but the more you play the game, the more tired you become and less rewarding it gets.

During the campaign the main character changes to it's progeny, but that happens from era to era, changing your portrait and few passives... There are some scripted bills that reflect on the changes in history, like child labour, women's rights, etc. and they seem to be scripted - on first go everyone just opposes them and you have little change to win, later no matter what everyone simply has a change of hearth and supports it... It's entirely pointless and only exists for flavour, giving you the illusion of having some part in it.

_____________________________________________
TL;DR VERSION:

It's boring.

_____________________________________________

column8: Meine Meinung zu diesem spiel ist Zwiegespalten,einerseits ist es ein tolles Konzept und hat gute Ideen,andererseits ist es nicht gut umgesetzt.Nach einigen Stunden ist es halt immer das Gleiche.30 Euro sind viel zu teuer.

[h1] This Game is the best thing I have ever played, here is why you should ignore the comment section... [/h1]

This game isn't being given the credit it deserves. The council is NOT AT ALL annoying unless you want to propose a fucking train station while 2 million dollars in debt, I'm glad the game doesn't give you a debt limit before automaticly ending the game, it put political penalties that would behave just like THE REAL WORLD. I love how amazing the political and economic systems are and how in depth they have created them and connecting the systems to affect each other. When I bought this I expected the worst, not knowing the devs and ususally the type to listen to the people, but I now have one of the greatest games in my steam library and I think you should too. For all the salty dipshits that downvoted this game, Why? As I see it, this should be at the top of the strata charts

OF COURSE should we build a railway OF COURSE. I fail to see any real challenge thus far

The game is enjoyable for one playthrough, and as much is really only worth it by costing a considerable discount. I paid about five bucks for it and feel content with that. There is no handholding in the game, and you really have to figure out stuff on your own, but with that said, it is still more shallow than one would expect which is just an odd dichotomy. The game is also slow to start and crashes unexpectedly, but luckily there are autosaves for every few years. I would say save your money for something like Diplomacy 3  or donate money to an actual candidate running for office because either one is a more enjoyable practice in politics than this game.

column8:
Urban "Empire"...Well, either the game has a terrible tutorial or I dunno, every party in the game just wants to fuck me over, because building a train station or a police station is apparently the intention of the devil and opposed to the death, meaning the game can't even progress to anything. I get that it's supposed to be tougher to get things approved, but this goes against all common sense. The way to "sway" votes is also absolute bullshit. You can either plead, demand or threaten. This is not how the world works, especially the sub-options make no sense either. It feels like gambling.

Now...all of that might be forgiven if the city building was fun...but it isn't. You can't build anything yourself. You just "lay out" districts. How big is the district supposed to be? No idea. It's not like you can change it later on. Building stuff like police stations or clinics...or any "service" building like schools requires to overwrite existing automatically placed business, industry or residential buildings. And of course the stupid city council has to approve it. Nah...sorry, I don't have the patience for this.
column9:
Urban "Empire"...Well, either the game has a terrible tutorial or I dunno, every party in the game just wants to fuck me over, because building a train station or a police station is apparently the intention of the devil and opposed to the death, meaning the game can't even progress to anything. I get that it's supposed to be tougher to get things approved, but this goes against all common sense. The way to "sway" votes is also absolute bullshit. You can either plead, demand or threaten. This is not how the world works, especially the sub-options make no sense either. It feels like gambling.

Now...all of that might be forgiven if the city building was fun...but it isn't. You can't build anything yourself. You just "lay out" districts. How big is the district supposed to be? No idea. It's not like you can change it later on. Building stuff like police stations or clinics...or any "service" building like schools requires to overwrite existing automatically placed business, industry or residential buildings. And of course the stupid city council has to approve it. Nah...sorry, I don't have the patience for this.

Was not as horrible as I expected according to the bad reviews. This game kept me so well entertained for a few days that I did not touch anything else on my computer. Good enough for a recommendation I guess, with a big "BUT...".

I like the omnipresent problem of weighing up cost and benefit of every single action in this game. However, what I do not like at all is that the game content forces biased leftist ideas down your throat practically during the whole game. I would have wished for a more unbiased approach and different problem solutions here. Unfortunately, communist ideas are glorified all the time while more conservative approaches are demonized all the time. This is also the reason why the game loses all of its magic after one playthrough since it lacks any replayability value. However, for one playthrough, it is fun. 

Please note, that I only spent 6 â‚¬ for the game. I would not spent more than 10 â‚¬ for it. And I may also add that I missed the completely bugged game release years ago.

column8:
This game is shallow in the city building aspect. But it makes up for it with regard to decision making around the political system. It's a nice idea, hybrid type game which doesn't quite work and hence I guess the majority of negative reviews come from. 
So far for me, I've put in 23 hours play time which I regard as borderline for a game worth buying. It doesn't make me want to head back into playing it. Though I feel there is just enough there to not give it a negative review. It has something a bit different which these days is good.
6/10

column8: Would be nicer, given the players role, to be more engaged in city activities. Additionally, ordinances should be added to allow the control of building designs, types of industries, etc.

column8:
The best federal simulator of all time. Lose your mind trying to get s**t done and be constantly blocked by councils, politicians and pretty much anyone while drowning in debt.

Urban Empire is basically Tropico without power. The main reason why it is so unfuriatingly un-fun is based on the fact that the mechanics are almost as deep and complex and convoluted as real life municipal politics, which makes this an awesome simulation, in a way.

Never before did I lose my mind so much while still being unable to stop keep hurting my very soul by continuing to play this.

Seriously though, this definitely does not deserve all the hate it's getting. It's not Simcity, you have no power to randomly build stuff and every single plan you have will take forever to scheme your way through the local politics and council decisions. In a way, it's more like "The Guild" than any building game.

I'm guessing most of the people who downvoted this expected a new city builder, which this is clearly not and then were frustrated about that very fact.

It's actually quite enjoyable if those mechanics are something you're looking for. Personally I had a blast with this for quite a while.

column8: Hey, das spiel an sich ist mega gut gemacht nur ich wÃ¼rde mich freuen wenn man eine eigene Stadt mit selbst vorgegebenen Geld spielen kann oder nach einer Epoche ein eigenen Charakter aussuchen kÃ¶nnte und man es solange spielen kann wie man will sprich auch in der zukunft

This game sounds interesting when you read the game description and even appears to be interesting when you start playing it. The combination of city builder throughout the ages and a political simulation with a municipal council sounds like a great idea. 
The result however is unfortunately disappointing. The city builder aspect of the game is quite simplistic and cannot compare with other city building games out there when it comes to depth and options. The political aspect on the other hand which apparently was to be the main selling point of the game appears interesting at first but it soon becomes apparent that it can be easily manipulated and "abused". Your council will accept almost anything you propose if you have a positive cashflow while it will refuse almost anything if your budget is in the red. 
In the end the entire experience of the game is quite shallow and boring.

column8:
Das Spiel ist bei weitem nicht so schlecht, wie es die Reviews vermuten lassen. Klar, man hat bei weitem nicht so viele Freiheiten wie bei Stadtbausimulationen wie Cities Skylines oder so freien politischen Lauf wie bei Tropico. Aber das Konzept ist halt auch ein anderes. Man ist BÃ¼rgermeister und leitet das Parlament einer vom Volk gewÃ¤hlten Regierung. Man schlÃ¤gt Gesetze und Steuern vor und je nach dem wie man politisch angesehen ist bei den Parteien, hat man halt mehr oder weniger Erfolg bei der Umsetzung von Gesetzesvorhaben.

Ich kann nicht verstehen, warum so viele Jammern Ã¼ber den Schwierigkeitsgrad. Ja, bei meinem ersten Versuch fand ich es auch noch schwer, nicht ins finanzielle Minus zu geraten. Aber schon beim zweiten Versuch hatte ich damit keine Probleme mehr. 

Es gibt ein paar nervige Bugs (zB kann ich nicht nachvollziehen, warum meine Unternehmen einen Mallus von 20% auf "Nachfrage" erhalten, wenn ich einen Bahnhof baue. Ich glaube da wurde ab und zu mal Mallus und Bonus vertauscht. Aber scheinbar nur auf der GUI. Spielmechanisch scheint die Umsetzung korrekt zu sein). Aber ich habe nach 8h Spielzeit keine Showstopper gefunden.

Die Kampagne ist recht langzeitmotivierend und abwechslungsreich. Ab Era 3 wird es etwas eintÃ¶nig, weil man bis dahin eigentlich gut vorgesorgt hat und nur noch reagieren muss auf politische und gesellschaftliche VerÃ¤nderungen.

Alles in allem wÃ¼rde ich dem Spiel 7 von 10 Punkten geben.

Der Preis von 30â‚¬ ist allerdings schon ziemlich hoch. Ich habe einen Key fÃ¼r 5â‚¬ bekommen. Ich denke, der gerechte Preis liegt fÃ¼r dieses Spiel bei 15-20â‚¬.

column8: Dieses Spiel ist sehr herausfordernd und frustrierend. Was gut bei einer Dynastie lÃ¤uft, muss noch lange kein Allheilmittel fÃ¼r die anderen bedeuten. Entgegen der sonstigen Bestrebungen bei einem Aufbauspiel ist es bei Urban Empire durchaus lohnend einfach einmal nichts zu tun und vielleicht noch ein Spieljahr oder zwei anzuwarten, bis die endgÃ¼ltigen Entwicklungen durchschlagen. Ganz sicher kein Titel fÃ¼r Gelegenheitsspieler, jedoch durchaus fesselnd, wenn man die ersten HÃ¼rden bewÃ¤ltigt habt.
column9: This game is very challenging and frustrating. What goes well for one dynasty is by no means a panacea for the others. Contrary to the usual aspirations of a city-building game, it's definitely worth doing nothing in Urban Empire for a while and perhaps waiting another year or two for the final developments to take effect. Certainly not a title for casual players, but certainly captivating once you've overcome the initial hurdles.

Ende 2016 kam ein priview Lets Play zu diesem Spiel raus. Ich habe mir das Lets Play angeschaut und mir hat das Spiel gefallen. Als es anfang 2017 rauskam war es mir allerdings noch zu teuer weshalb ich es irgendwann aus den Augen verloren habe,
Jetzt habe ich es wÃ¤hrend dem Herbst-Sale auf Steam gesehen wie es auf 7,99 Euro reduziert war. Da habe ich natÃ¼rlich sofort zugeschlagen. 
Leider musste ich feststellen, dass ich es nach mehreren AnlÃ¤ufen nicht geschafft habe eine stabile Wirtschaft aufzubauen obwohl ich mir sogar ein Tutorial angeschaut habe das in Zusammenarbeit mit dem Publisher realisiert wurde. Ich habe alles mÃ¶gliche versucht, trotzem nehmen meine Finanzen nicht richtig zu und sie sinken immer wieder ab. Mal lÃ¤uft es richtig gut, doch auf einmal machen deine Unternehmen auf unerklÃ¤rliche Weise schlapp und du rutschst extrem ins Minus. Investitionen wie ein bahnhof oder Gasleitungen helfen der Wirtschaft auch nur mÃ¤ÃŸig auf die SprÃ¼nge. Man muss dauernd aufs Geld achten und ist mit nichts anderem beschÃ¤ftigt. Das ist richtig langweilig. Schaden, denn das Spiel hat mit seinen historischen und politischen Inhalten vielpotenzial das man leider nicht nutzen kann weil nie das Geld da ist. Bei meinen Recherchen musste ich feststellen, dass nicht nur ich diese Probleme habe, sondern die Kritiken die ich gesehen habe waren grÃ¶ÃŸtenteils eben aus diesen GrÃ¼nden negativ. Selbst die Gamestar hat diese Kritikpunkte aufgegriffen.
Dieses Spiel hat ein gutes Konzept und eine gute Idee dahintern, leider ist es nicht spielbar. Ich habe also 7,99 Euro und viele Stunden in denen ich mich mit dem Spiel auseinandergesetzt habe in den Sand gesetzt. Eigentlich sollte ich dafÃ¼r von den Entwicklern Schadensersatz verlangen, fÃ¼r das Geld und fÃ¼r die verlorene Zeit. Immernoch 30 Euro dafÃ¼r zu verlangen ist Ã¼brigens eine Frechheit, denn das Spiel ist in diesem Zusatand nicht mal die 7,99 Wert die ich bezahlt habe.

Urban Empire is a very interesting amalgamation of different game genres which doesn't quite find its place. 

I think most people bought this game hoping for a 'deeper city builder' and were disappointed they got a city-based Democracy series inspired product. Make no mistake, this game is a resource management simulator. The resources just happen to be forms of 'happiness' such as 'security' and 'health', cash, and political capital derived from interactions with various competing political factions.

The game is fine, but either it was marketed to the wrong demographic, or simply people who bought the game didn't quite understand the place the game fills. This is not an earth shattering game, but it is a shame that it was received so poorly. I think with some care and re-balancing the game could have been much better than it has been left, however it doesn't make business sense to invest time into something the customers have generally written off.

I'd be very interested to see what could be made using this idea for a political simulation in future. This is a unquestionably a niche genre. The Soundtrack is fantastic.
column9:

column8: Most enjoyable game. I was a bit worried about all the negative reviews and comments but I really like playing this game. You have to like the genre of course but it sucks you in if you open up to it as it creates a nice atmosphere. Some miner bugs and the camera control feels awkward but nothing disturbing. For some strange reason the game does use al lot of memory and it takes a very long time to load a game. The full price is however way to high and I would strongly recommend waiting for a serious discount before buying it.

column8:
Don't buy this game.  Avoid.
Itâ€™s not worth the asking price, whatsoever.  If you must get it, I recommend you pay as little as possible.

Keep in mind, this is a political simulator masked as a city building game, with an incomplete feel.  If this interests you, then keep reading.  I wanted to like this game and played it over 100 hours, but I strongly dislike it.

Here is why I strongly dislike it:
1) Entirely imbalanced game mechanics at all stages; early-, mid-, and late-game.  At best, consider this game at midway Beta-level test development, requiring a significant rebalance, not ready for prime time.  Itâ€™s abandoned by the development team, and therefore they'll never fix its problems.
     Some sillier examples are: [spoiler] you can successfully avoid ever installing running water or a sewer system in densely populated areas; never establish a police station anywhere and achieve better security from just a fire department, even in a population of over 90,000 people, yet install Police call-boxes everywhere to improve (the perception of?) security; drive on the same gravel road from the 1800â€™s until the end of time with no traffic controls; but muh air-conditioning and recycling center are non-negotiable. [/spoiler]  This doesnâ€™t even scratch the surface of more serious imbalances.

2) Grossly lacks meaningful associations of most causes & effects.  The player may be offered or restricted from certain choices of action without indication of any particular outcome(s).  Likewise, negative and positive unexpected events frequently occur with no indication of how or why, which could allow the player to respond accordingly.  Since the game frequently prompts the player to choose an action but it withholds or obstructs useful information regarding any anticipated outcome (Hint: outcomes are not what you may first think), the player frequently makes blind choices and passively accepts their outcomes.
     For example, one moment your adversarial political parties oppose you; and for reasons unknown within the algorithm, your adversariesâ€™ opinions change.  But the player canâ€™t know why, which offers no opportunity to learn.
     Another example, the tax revenue may fall with no useful data explaining why, though the player must react and fix the unknowable problem to avoid losing the game.
     The development team defends this game design as typical life in politics.  I contend that truly random, inexplicable behavior doesnâ€™t mimic sane real life.  Furthermore, when a political leader makes decisions lacking any practical knowledge of cause & effect, that is unfettered incompetence and cannot make for an enjoyable simulator or satisfying game play.

3) Usable data are delivered to the player in an unusable fashion.  Data are presented as pages and pages and more pages of tables of simple numbers with vague descriptions.  These numbers are a mere granular snapshot of whatâ€™s happening within the game at that moment.  Unless the player has extraordinary ability to memorize pages of numbers and compare these pages within oneâ€™s mind as time passes (or manually record every number to an external spreadsheet and transform the game into a data-entry simulator), I contend that alternatively these data ought to be delivered as graphs to display event trends.  Otherwise, decision-making defaults to simple guesswork to manipulate particular numbers.

4) The tutorial is sorely lacking.  It guides you through only the initial actions of the game, and leaves most mechanics unexplained.  It focuses on delivering a narrative about people & places that have no practical use.  It won't equip you to develop any strategy to progress.  This you must learn through trial & error, in unclear, uninformative, un-enjoyable ways.  Itâ€™s like groping through a dark room for the correct lever to pull among a sea of other levers, where many levers are certain self-destruct mechanisms not identifiable as such, which essentially tricks the player into poor choices.
     You could search outside of the game for serendipitous explanations by watching random Let's Play videos or optimistically trawling online forums.  I donâ€™t consider these suitable game documentation or enjoyable.

5) Beware anytime the tutorial is not yet satisfied with the completeness of your actions, it will silently prevent you from saving your game's progress.  The solution would be to complete the outstanding action; but if done at an undesirable moment (is very likely), you will effectively sabotage any successful strategy you may have had.  If you do not perform the action but also need to shut down the game, you must forfeit all unsaved game progress.  I discovered the communityâ€™s recommended workaround is to not begin the game with the tutorial, since itâ€™s optional, but that seems rather self-defeating in purpose.

6) The player can too easily enter into a death spiral that has no recovery.  Since many in-game events occur by inexplicable chance or wonky causes, without useful help to respond, you can somewhat expect to lose the game and need to start over.  If you aren't making obvious successful strides or somehow lose a lot of momentum,  I recommend to quit the game and start over.  Save yourself time and frustration.  Even if you knew what particular choice(s) you could make to a recovery, there remains an artificial â€œgame clockâ€, as it were, that will restrict your opportunities to make these choices and may shut you out from recovery.   That is, until you discover how to keep the game perpetually afloat, even when it defies reality. 

7) The game play follows a prescribed underlying political narrative, which is a reflection of the development teamâ€™s political biases that shine throughout the game.  These biases tend to artificially limit or punish the player if the player makes political choices that contravene these biases. If the player does not align with the narrative, the player will definitely lose the game.  Be aware this is NOT a sandbox game where the player can legitimately explore different playing styles to reach a satisfying outcome.

8) The English text often distracts because itâ€™s unnecessarily wordy, suffers from awkward or incorrect word choice, grammatical errors, etc.  For example, the game offered a choice of actions that I improperly understood because the instructions were too ambiguous.  I guessed my best action according to what I anticipated the game wanted of me (see my earlier comments about the gameâ€™s political biases).  Though I did correctly guess what political bias the game expected of me, the game punished me hard because I chose the incorrect course of action that it wanted from me.

9) The game offers a highly detailed, animated 3D model of the city map that has no useful benefit to the game.  It fact, since its function was so poorly optimized, the 3D map serves only to drag down your computer's performance, and does so ever increasingly without end as the game progresses.  Your frame rate will noticeably dip and stutter no matter how powerful your computer, especially during late-game (I progressed beyond the year 2188 and performance became almost unplayable though my computer is plenty powerful).  To what end?  This game is nothing more than reading dialogs and tables of numbers with some basic animations and still-images included for flair.  A still city map viewable from an even higher elevation would have been more useful.

10) The tech progression tree is presented in an arbitrary order with no indication of negative consequences from particular choices.  The tech tree can unwittingly be navigated in a â€œwrongâ€ order, locking out critical elements of progress when you need them, leaving you no choice but to delete your game and start over.  (See my earlier comment about an artificial â€œgame clockâ€.)

11) Bugs and more bugs.

Iâ€™ll end it here.  Congratulations if you read everything.  I could add more, but I have other ways Iâ€™d prefer to spend my time.

column8: åƒåœ¾æ¸¸æˆã€‚æ²¡æœ‰å¯ç©æ€§ï¼Œå¾ˆä¸€èˆ¬ã€‚

A unique entry in the strategy genre, Urban Empire incorporates many great ideas into a solid political simulator. Your goal is to hold your esteemed position and grow your influence over severaly generations of your family dynasty. You will be deciding on the direction of the city by dealing with the varying and evolving political parties, forging alliances and making rivals as you progress. The one caveat that must be understood upfront is that in order to enjoy this game you must not go into it believing that it is primarily a city builder, like SimCity, Cities: Skylines, or Tropico. It is first and foremost a political simulator with city building being one of the aspects that you deal with during the course of it.

Progression in the game is quite interesting. Every generation has its own narrative choices to make, some of them affecting the political landscape, some affecting the physical city, and some personally affecting your character and their family. Replayability is enhances as there are several families to choose from which all have their own unique family members, personal stories, strengths, and weakness.

Each era has its own set of political parties that you must deal with. At first, there are few and they are relatively easy to balance. As times goes on these parties split into varying ideologies, new parties form, and old parties die off. Each party has its own set of values and expections for your actions and the choices that you make will impact your relationships with them. Good luck pleasing them all, though, as just like in the real world, they are often seeking resolutions on the issues that directly oppose one another. 

Now onto the elephant in the room, the city building. The city building in Urban Empire is actually quite deep and engaging. However, it's very much a slow burn and you engage in it a fraction of the time that you would with a more directly city building oriented game. Each expansion is a political ordeal and is done in district-sized chunks. Adding a new neighborhood can be a challenge as can adding street lights, quality roads, and even utilities to an already existing one. These can be complicated by your current standing with the political parties who, en masse, have the power to utterly veto any changes that you seek to make if you're slipping up in your political game. 

Urban Empire is a game that I have thoroughly enjoyed. It is not a city builder in the classic sense and I believe that's why so many have reviewed it negatively. It does not resemble what you are expecting if you go into it with that mindset and the game will seem slow-paced and overly challenging. I do not recommend it to those specifically looking for a Cities: Skylines experience. However, I very much recommend it to those willing to go into it with an open mind as they will be able to find an excellent, deep political experience with a unique combination of mechanics and narrative choices that I have yet to find anywhere else.
column9:
A unique entry in the strategy genre, Urban Empire incorporates many great ideas into a solid political simulator. Your goal is to hold your esteemed position and grow your influence over severaly generations of your family dynasty. You will be deciding on the direction of the city by dealing with the varying and evolving political parties, forging alliances and making rivals as you progress. The one caveat that must be understood upfront is that in order to enjoy this game you must not go into it believing that it is primarily a city builder, like SimCity, Cities: Skylines, or Tropico. It is first and foremost a political simulator with city building being one of the aspects that you deal with during the course of it.

Progression in the game is quite interesting. Every generation has its own narrative choices to make, some of them affecting the political landscape, some affecting the physical city, and some personally affecting your character and their family. Replayability is enhances as there are several families to choose from which all have their own unique family members, personal stories, strengths, and weakness.

Each era has its own set of political parties that you must deal with. At first, there are few and they are relatively easy to balance. As times goes on these parties split into varying ideologies, new parties form, and old parties die off. Each party has its own set of values and expections for your actions and the choices that you make will impact your relationships with them. Good luck pleasing them all, though, as just like in the real world, they are often seeking resolutions on the issues that directly oppose one another. 

Now onto the elephant in the room, the city building. The city building in Urban Empire is actually quite deep and engaging. However, it's very much a slow burn and you engage in it a fraction of the time that you would with a more directly city building oriented game. Each expansion is a political ordeal and is done in district-sized chunks. Adding a new neighborhood can be a challenge as can adding street lights, quality roads, and even utilities to an already existing one. These can be complicated by your current standing with the political parties who, en masse, have the power to utterly veto any changes that you seek to make if you're slipping up in your political game. 

Urban Empire is a game that I have thoroughly enjoyed. It is not a city builder in the classic sense and I believe that's why so many have reviewed it negatively. It does not resemble what you are expecting if you go into it with that mindset and the game will seem slow-paced and overly challenging. I do not recommend it to those specifically looking for a Cities: Skylines experience. However, I very much recommend it to those willing to go into it with an open mind as they will be able to find an excellent, deep political experience with a unique combination of mechanics and narrative choices that I have yet to find anywhere else.

column8:
Ich hatte hohe Erwartungen an das Spiel. Eine SimCity Version bei der man tatsÃ¤chlich afu die Politik RÃ¼cksicht nehmen muss. Es klang sehr vielversprechend.

Leider wie so oft bei Kalypso Games. Das Wirtschaftssystem ergibt Ã¼berhaupt keinen Sinn, man weiss nie warum man grad in die Miesen kommt und wie man gegensteuern kann.

Gleichzeitig gibt es keinerlei Cheats mit denen man zumindest den finanziellen Teil Ã¼berbrÃ¼cken kann um wenigstens die Politik zu spielen.

Selbst wenn ich die Stadt vollkommen primtiv gehalten habe, kein Strom, kein Wasser, nix, war immer in der zweiten Generation Schluss. Einmal hab ich es in die dritte Generation geschafft um da sofort zu scheitern.

Alles in allem, rausgeworfenes Geld und es ist klar warum Kalypso dieses Spiel nicht weiter entwickelt.

Not as bad as the reviews would suggest. It's fun for maybe a couple playthroughs. No sandbox, four campaigns (which are scripted), four scenarios, and that's it. No mods, not even any DLC. There is zero optimization, so even though the game looks like a 2012 remaster of a 2004 game, it runs at sub-20 FPS on my mid-high range PC. You'll get a solid 50 in the early game, but once you have four districts built it's all downhill from there. Gameplay-wise, the game looks really hard until you learn how to pull the political parties to your side, then the game is so easy you'll never have a problem doing anything. It's worth $7.50, it's a solid experience if you want something different, just keep your expectations on the floor and you'll have some fun.
column9: Not as bad as the reviews would suggest. It's fun for maybe a couple playthroughs. No sandbox, four campaigns (which are scripted), four scenarios, and that's it. No mods, not even any DLC. There is zero optimization, so even though the game looks like a 2012 remaster of a 2004 game, it runs at sub-20 FPS on my mid-high range PC. You'll get a solid 50 in the early game, but once you have four districts built it's all downhill from there. Gameplay-wise, the game looks really hard until you learn how to pull the political parties to your side, then the game is so easy you'll never have a problem doing anything. It's worth $7.50, it's a solid experience if you want something different, just keep your expectations on the floor and you'll have some fun.

I bought this game awhile back and played it for some time, wasnt impressed then, but dissappointed now. This game was rather quickly dumped, last development was mid last year "free DLC update" thats it. The game is unpolished, buggy, mid-end- game is slow (I have an GTX 1080Ti and I would constantly get 8fps) and worst of all, not worth the money. I kinda feel like I got ripped off. I did kinda like the idea of politics and etc.. but its too raw, but I could see potential in that. But, if you are reading this and see "Mostly negative" and are still considering to buy it, then goddammit DONT. Buy Cities: SKylines with a few DLC-s and its still worth more of ur money and a better gaming experience.  

3/10

Played this a bit from a sale unassociated with Steam.  It is comical and fun, as most stated it is more of a political game than a city builder.  If you have enough cash you can circumvent the vote.  

It would be a good educational game and especially for parents that explained the birds and bees...and now have to explain sodomy.

Ich glaube, dass ich schon ziemlich engagiert bin, was Aufbau- und Politiksimulationen angeht. Ich bin also keiner derjenigen, die ein Spiel doof finden, weil es kompliziert ist oder keine ganz so schÃ¶ne Grafik hat oder nicht beim ersten Versuch durchzuspielen ist. Im Gegenteil. Mir ist klar, dass man sich in solche Spiele teils auch reinbohren muss. Aber Urban Empire ist einfach nicht gut. Was schade ist, weil ich die Grundidee sofort sehr mochte. Aber es ist einfach nicht gut.

Mein Hauptargument ist, dass die Balance des Spiels einfach zu kippelig ist. Eine einzige Fehlentscheidung kann bedeuten, dass das der komplette Durchgang verloren ist. Beispiel: Man investiert in eine bestimmte Infrastruktur (Bahnhof, Gasleitungen o.Ã¤.) zum falschen Zeitpunkt. Das bedeutet relativ schnell das finanzielle Ende, weil die laufenden Kosten mE viel zu hoch angesetzt sind bzw. sich diese Investitionen praktisch Ã¼berhaupt nicht in zusÃ¤tzliche Unternehmensansiedlungen, hÃ¶heren Steuern o.Ã¤. auszahlen. Das ist erstmal eines: Unrealistisch. Und das ist ja schonmal ein ziemlich schwerwiegender Vorwurf an eine Simulation. Ich habe wirklich viele AnlÃ¤ufe gebraucht und zig Userberichte gelesen, um eine Stadt halbwegs zum Laufen zu bekommen, die nicht sofort wieder abschmiert. 

Vollends unspielbar wird Urban Empire aber durch die Epochenwechsel. Von einem Tag auf den anderen erhÃ¶hen sich die AnsprÃ¼che der Stadtbewohner komplett (Auch unrealistisch). Man muss also in der Vorepoche fÃ¼r die nÃ¤chste planen und UnterhaltungsgebÃ¤ude, Polizei- und so weiter bauen, was aber eigentlich nicht geht, weil man finanziell so enorm eingeschrÃ¤nkt ist bzw. auf so dÃ¼nnem Eis lÃ¤uft. Eine Investition zu viel - und die Einnahmen- Ausgabenseite ist unrettbar dahin. 

Die Idee mit den dynastischen Geschichten ist ja auch echt nett. Aber auch hier: Es funktioniert nicht. Die Story ist so extrem linear, dass man die Meldungen im vierten Anlauf nur noch wegklickt. Es ist auch kaum erkennbar, ob die "Entscheideungen", die man in der Storyline zu treffen hat, ernsthaft einen Unterschied im Aufbau der Stadt machen. 

Letzter Punkt: Was das Spielkonzept ja besnders machen soll ist die politische Balance in der Stadt. Politische Parteien, die - je nach Epoche aber auch Situation in der Stadt - dem Wandel unterworfen sind. Auch eine schÃ¶ne Idee - aber vÃ¶llig stumpf umgesetzt. Hat man Geld, stimmt der Stadtrat allem zu. Hat man keines, lehnt er alles ab. Bei den gesellschaftspolitischen Entscheidungen ist - Ã¤hnlich wie bei den Investitionen und sonstigen Kennzahlen -- vÃ¶llig unklar, welche Auswirkungen sie worauf haben und wie das im voraus oder im RÃ¼ckblick einzuschÃ¤tzen ist. Warum sich Wirtschaftsansiedlungen und Konjunktur nach oben oder nach unten bewegen und ob und wenn wie sich das auf Steuereinnahmen auswirkt, ist mir bis zuletzt nicht klar geworden. In der ANleitung findet man zu all diesen Spielkonzepten auch null Hinweise.

Ich habe im Netz natÃ¼rlich auch Leute gefunden, die weiter gekommen sind. Keine Ahnung, ob das ggf. vor irgendwelchen Updates war. Ich jedenfalls bin echt kein Aufbausimluations-Newbie aber ich fÃ¼r meinen Teil hab genug von dem Spiel und kann es nicht empfehlen. Nochmal: Schade. Vielleicht kommt ja ein neuer Versuch mit einem Urban Empire II

column8:
Also zu allererst muss ich erstmal sagen , dass ich total Ã¼berrascht von diesem Spiel bin. Ich habe es durch den Gamestar Magazinkauf dazu bekommen und dachte mir zu allererst das es irgendein langweiliges Spiel wÃ¤re, allerdings wurde ich positiv Ã¼berrascht . Es ist was anderes als man sonstige Spiele dieser Art gewÃ¶hnt ist. Es ist alles etwas politischer gehalten als bei anderen Aufbauspielen daher wÃ¼rde ich schon fast sagen hat es etwas von Strategie da man immer gut durchdenken muss wie man seine Stadt auf lÃ¤ngere Sicht plant.

Da muss ich aber auch leider zu den Kontras kommen. Was momentan noch sehr enttÃ¤uschend ist, ist das gegen Endgame fast schon Midgame das Spiel auf hÃ¶heren Grafikeinstellungen sehr sehr ruckelig wird und das trotz guter Hardware! Nach mehrfachen recherchieren fand ich auch raus das ich nicht der einzige mit diesem Problem bin. Grafik runtergestellt und es ist einigermaÃŸen Spielbar, jedoch wÃ¤re es wirklich wÃ¼nschenswert wenn dies schnellsmÃ¶glich behoben wird, da dies sehr Schade fÃ¼r das Spiel wÃ¤r.

Mein persÃ¶hnlicher Fazit ist , dass ich dieses Spiel sehr mag. Ich habe nicht erwartet das es mich die Nacht so lang wach hÃ¤lt wie gewisse AAA Spiele es taten . Ich mag das System dahinter es ist einfach etwas anderes. Klar es ist etwas unkomplizierter was den Aufbau betrifft und es gibt einem nicht so viel MÃ¶glichkeiten wie in anderen gewissen Spielen. Dennoch finde ich hat es einen persÃ¶hnlichen Touch vorallem durch dieses Politiksystem was einem auch klar zeigt das man in diesem Spiel nicht der "Gott" sondern der "BÃ¼rgermeister" ist . Daher finde ich ist es sehr realisitschen gehalten ebenso wie die Epochen Ã¼ber die Zeit und das Forschungssystem. Daher gibt es von mir definitiv einen Daumen hoch , dennoch sollte das Mid/Endgame umbedingt gepatcht werde da es sonst irgendwann unspielbar wird!

Very good but not for beginners!!!

Urban Empire is an economic history strategy build m up.

If you expect something like simcity you probably are frustrated cos you cant build buildings like you want.

Paradox makes mavels strategy games. and so it is ...

you learn a lot about the last 200 years in Europe from the view of a founding city

its a challange and for more advanced economic strategy players ...

From my perspective an awesome game in a line of very good srategy games by Paradox!!!

Dont forget it has a saving function. Use it before you start new projects in your city.

The many negative reviews are not justified except you just whated to build a fancy city.

If you have played Europe Universal you might know the difference between Paradox Strategy Games

and othes ...

Rock it
