column8:
In general? Loved the idea but execution is poor as only it could be. 

Community was enthusiastic for this game. I myself was very positive upon release and seeing Dev team interest in bugs being reported. Game required a lot of additional work but it seemed we will make it better. However sweet beginning lead to bitter end. 

Devs basically abandoned the game. Amount of bugs and issues (with optimalization in late faze making game unplayable as priority) that would require significant work most likely made them jump of the ship and pretend this game did not exist.

Taking this into consideration and absolutely unforgivable behavior of Kalypso I suggest being very cautious when thinking about buying their game. In case of Urban Empire I feel cheated and if I didn't give the game some credit hoping for improvement I would definitely request refund from steam. 

Don't buy it. At current state it is unplayable and way overpriced. It is not worth more than 5-6$ with quality you get.

The game could be good, but the way it is now is just down right unejoyable, which i really hate to saying being I had such high hopes for this game.

column8:
Nach Grand Ages die nÃ¤chste absolute EntÃ¤uschung von Kalypso... so langsam bin ich mit dem Publisher mehr als durch!

Das Spiel bietet von der Grundidee ein riesen potenzial und ichhabe mich bereits mehrere Stunden dabei gesehen meine Stadt Ã¼ber die Jahrhunderte weg zu optimieren... Die umsetzung fÃ¼hlt sich aber wie ein free2play game fÃ¼r ein Tablet an. Nach 15 Minuten werden die Klicks mega repetiv und  eintÃ¶nig. Eine Mechanik zu knacken braucht man nicht zu versuchen denn die gibt es schlicht nicht! Ich habe immer wieder und weider versucht einen Zugang zu diesem Spiel zu finden, andere Strategien ausprobiert und bin trotzdem nie dahinter gekommen was fÃ¼r auswirkungen meine Handlungen denn jetzt genau haben. Ein Beispiel: Einen Distrikt mit Strom zu versorgen kostet ein heiden Geld (allerdings kein Krafwerk o.a.) es ist aber schlicht nicht ersichtlich welchen positiven Effekt das ganze auf das Viertel hat. Es sind zwar welche angegeben, der Distrikt wÃ¤chst und generiert aber EXAKT! genau das gleiche Einkommen wenn man den Strom weglÃ¤sst. 

Mit Urban Empire und Grand Ages habe ich fast 100 tacken an ein Studio verballert das wirklich absolute Scheis QualitÃ¤t abliefert! Ich bin mit Kalypso absolut durch und Urban Empire lÃ¤sst sich hÃ¶chstens fÃ¼r eine Alterklasse bis 10 empfehlen die lust hat rumzuklicken...
column9:
After Grand Ages, the next absolute disappointment from Kalypso... I'm slowly getting beyond fed up with this publisher!

The game's basic idea has enormous potential, and I've already spent several hours optimizing my city over the centuries... However, the implementation feels like a free-to-play game for a tablet. After 15 minutes, the clicks become incredibly repetitive and monotonous. There's no point in trying to figure out a mechanic because it simply doesn't exist! I've tried again and again to find a way into this game, tried different strategies, and still never figured out what the exact effects of my actions are. For example: Supplying a district with electricity costs a ton of money (but not a power plant or anything like that), but it's simply not clear what positive effect this has on the district. While some are specified, the district grows and generates EXACTLY the same income if you leave out the electricity.

With Urban Empire and Grand Ages, I wasted almost 100 bucks on a studio that delivers absolutely terrible quality! I'm completely done with Kalypso, and Urban Empire is only recommended for ages 10 and under who enjoy clicking around...

A good try but falls well short of the mark especially at the price for sale instore.  It's kind of a mix of Democracy and Sim Societies with the problems indemic in those two games multiplied together.  The demand ratio system is buggy, infrastructure options double up rather than upgrading.  Costings are near impossible to afford in the time periods and if you want to keep playing past Era V eventually the environment rating drops into the negatives no matter what.  I paid $60 AUD for this as I bought it from a store, definitely about $40 too much, especially since when I installed it off the disc I had to essentially uninstall it and download it from Steam to get it to work.  If I'd bought it on Steam I'd have asked for a refund.  I should've put the money towards something else.  Next game from this publisher I think of buying I'll definitely test try first.

column8: I was really looking forward to this game after watching Writing Bulls Lets Play. But the game has some of the bugs he was mentioning in his Lets Play and if u try to make sense on what desicion is the right one in every situation, you will be frustated by the "random" game response. You can just influence every political party the same way. You can build industry and the left wing supports you, while the party of the worker does not, even if there are not enough jobs. The idea is great, its just the implementation which seams to be pretty random and not at all realated to "real world potics".

Schade um diese gute Spielidee.
Mich stÃ¶rt vorallem ein wichtiger Punkt und zwar das Geld und dessen Ausgewogenheit.
Leider ist man stÃ¤ndig irgendwie im Minus. Schon der kleinste Entschluss kann einem, trotz genauen Ã¼berlegen, die Haushaltskasse sprengen. Einnahmen gehen fÃ¼r mich vÃ¶llig unnachvollziehbar plÃ¶tzlich ins Minus. So schnell kann man nicht handeln oder sich wieder erholen damit die Einnahmen erneut sprudeln.
Ist man im Minus blockiert der Stadtrat alles was man irgendnur mÃ¶glich machen mÃ¶chte damit die Stadt leben kann. Ab diesem Zeitpunkt kann man das Spiel vergessen. Es langweilt ab da nur noch weil man ohnehin weiÃŸ, dass man bestimmte oder gar alle Entscheidungen im Stadtrat nicht durchbekommt.
Entweder man startet neu oder verliert schnell die Lust daran, da sich diese Misere, warum auch immer, stÃ¤ndig wiederholt.

Update 19.03:2017:
Ich hab es endlich geschafft. Ich bin in Epoche 3 angekommen ohne pleite zu gehen. Allerdings hat meine Stadt 1930 zum Teil noch kein Licht, Abwasser oder eine PflasterstraÃŸe. Ist das so gewollt?
Nun ja das sei vielleicht einem (meinem) schlechten Management geschuldet.
Nun da das Geld endlich sprudelt stÃ¼rzt dafÃ¼r plÃ¶tzlich das Spiel stÃ¤ndig ab.
Warum aufeinmal? Das Spiel lief in Epoche 1 und 2 problemlos durch. Jetzt friert es komplett ein nachdem eine neue Erfindung auszuwÃ¤hlen ist. Beenden lÃ¤sst es sich nur noch Ã¼ber den Taskmanager. NatÃ¼rlich ist der Spielfortschritt dadurch verloren.

Also mir reicht es nun endgÃ¼ltig. Da auch kein Patch mehr zu erwarten sein wird, der diese und andere Probleme behebt, werde ich das Spiel nun gepflegt deinstallieren und getrost vergessen.

column8: Alright, I was really excited for this game's release and had been waiting for months, the first hour of gamplay was fun. After that, it just got very repetitive. I kept just putting things up for a vote, passing them or not, then moving on. Some reviews may say that it is not bad, but it is no where close to the then $35 i paid for it. The original gameplay with one family, took about 2 hours in total to reach the end game and win. Also, city hall almost never lets you pass a train station.

Nach einigen Stunden bemerkt man jedoch, dass es nur darum geht Geld zu verdienen und andere Aspekte wie Zufriedenheit kaum eine Rolle spielen (wenn man mÃ¶chte kann man sogar die Steuern auf 50% anheben).
Sofern man genug Geld in der Staatskasse hat, wird alles vom Rat abgesegnet.
Hinzu kommt noch, dass der Rat sehr statisch wirkt und kaum Abwechlung bietet bei der Beeinflussung von Parteien und den AntrÃ¤gen.
Ferner wird man in eine politische Ecke gedrÃ¤ngt, da die konservativen grundsÃ¤tzlich fast alles ablehnen und die linken alles annehmen.

Meiner Meinung nach lohnen sich die 45â‚¬ auf keinen Fall,zumal das Spiel kaum geupdated wird.

I rarely review games due to extreme apathy, but I had to make an exception this time. I cannot recommend this game as much as I'd like to and I really would like to be able to. I loved the idea behind this, and as soon as I heard about it, I knew I had to try it. This is the sort of game I had been waiting for and I wish more developers would bring out games along these lines. I have, however, been left extremely disappointed by this developer and the game that has been released. There has been little to no reaction to the community response and there has been one or maybe two patches since release. Neither of these patches have focused on the big problems within the game. I've given it around 33 hours, and until a major patch gets released, I'm not going to give this game any more of my time. The numerous bugs and shallow game play are just not worth bothering with. It would also be nice if the game actually had tooltips and told you how to play.
Reborn Games are going on my blacklist of developers I will avoid in future.

column8:
*Yawn*  
There is no replayability in this game.  Actions have only a positive or negative impact.  No complex decision making is required.  Max out LGBT Rights...no backlash from the church.  Max out workers rights...no backlash from upper class.  There is no balancing act.  Happieness of the population is so easy, and never stands in the way of progress.  

The entire goal of this game is to create a super tolerant socialist state as soon as possible.  The game takes you down the same predictable path. 
No real forks in the roads that you can take your nation to an industrial powerhouse or a hippy commune.
No events that will shake up the landscape enough to reverse the path.  

I've played 24 hours, and have no desire to play again.

column8:
Wie wir alle, wurde auch ich wohl von dem ungewÃ¶hnlichen Gameplay gelockt, das Urban Empire zu bieten haben soll und tatsÃ¤chlich wurde ich nicht enttÃ¤uscht. TatsÃ¤chlich ist Urban Empire ein Aufbauspiel mit Geschichte. Wir mÃ¼ssen unser DÃ¶rfchen aus dem vorletzten Jahrhundert aufbauen und es bis in die Gegenwart fÃ¼hren. Uns erwarten viele Entscheidungen, die wir treffen mÃ¼ssen. Vor allem aber das Abstimmen der Parteien, fÃ¼r viele Schritte, die wir beschlieÃŸen mÃ¼ssen ebenfalls durchlebt werden. Erst bei einer Mehrheit, kÃ¶nnen wir GebÃ¤ude genehmigen lassen, bis hin zu ganzen Stadtviertel. Viele Nebenevents halten die Stimmung aufrecht und ein ungewÃ¶hnlich groÃŸer Forschungsbaum lÃ¤sst uns bis in die nahe Zukunft, Dinge erforschen, die unserer BevÃ¶lkerung und damit unserer Stadt guttun. Ein StÃ¤de-Aufbau-Simulator wie Cities Skylines aber mit mehr Tiefgang und realistischeren Gegebenheiten, in der wir als BÃ¼rgermeister eben nicht einfach drauf los bauen und Geld ausgeben kÃ¶nnen, sondern immerzu uns mit den Parteien gut stellen mÃ¼ssen und unsere Finanzen im Augen haben mÃ¼ssen. 

Das klingt alles sehr innovativ, geradezu genial und das ist es tatsÃ¤chlich auch. Leider stecken aus meiner Sicht die Probleme ganz wo anderes und zwar das was unter der Haube sich befindet.

Trotz zugegeben kurzer Spielzeit, sind mir einige Dinge aufgefallen, die mich dazu veranlassen, keine Empfehlung auszusprechen. Zumindest als ich gestern mit jemanden Ã¼ber das Spiel redete, habe ich klar gesagt: â€Die MÃ¤ngel hat das Spiel. Damit musst du rechnen. Empfehlen kann ich es nicht aber schlussendlich ist es deine Entscheidungâ€œ 
Doch woher kommt diese Nicht-Empfehlung?

Das erste was mir schon einen DÃ¤mpfer versetzt hat, sind sporadische AbstÃ¼rze beim starten des Spiels. NatÃ¼rlich ist das nun relativ. Bei jemand anderem lÃ¤uft das Spiel vielleicht ohne Probleme aber die Absturz-HÃ¤ufigkeit, wenn man sich umhÃ¶rt ist dann doch ein verbreitetes PhÃ¤nomen, so das der Verdacht naheliegt, dass man diesen Kritikpunkt doch dem Spiel zuschreiben kann. Die AbstÃ¼rze ereigneten sich meist beim Ladebildschrim, beim Spielstart oder beim Laden des Spielstands. Auch die wenigen Patches, die dazu kamen, Ã¤nderten daran leider nichts. Zumindest nicht bei mir.

Das NÃ¤chste, was mir aufgefallen ist, war das Tutorial oder besser an einer Stelle, in der ich PlÃ¶tzlich keine weiteren Informationen bekommen habe, was ich tun soll, weil ich aus versehen einen Schritt gemacht habe, der nicht vorgesehen war und damit ein Game-Break entstand. Das nagt am Elan, da man bereit ist, das Spiel zu lernen. Zudem wurde mir das System der Abstimmung bzw der Beeinflussung der Abstimmung, nicht nahe genug erlÃ¤utert. Ich hatte gefÃ¼hlt im Tutorial allgemein noch viele Fragezeichen Ã¼ber dem Kopf.

Die Grafik. Ja, wieder so etwas Subjektives aber fÃ¼r meinen Teil, spreche ich mich da dann doch dafÃ¼r aus, das ich schon deutlich stimmungsvollere Aufbauspiele gespielt habe und ich spreche nicht von der Textur-QualitÃ¤t z.B. sondern von der Lebendigkeit. Die HÃ¤user und StraÃŸenzÃ¼ge sehen gut aus und sind hÃ¼bsch texturiert, doch fÃ¤llt einem schon nach kurzer Zeit auf, das irgendwas an der Spielwelt merkwÃ¼rdig wirkt. Sie bewegt sich nicht wirklich. Die Lebendigkeit eines Dorfes oder einer ganzen Stadt fehlt. Die Leute die auf den Gehwegen laufen, Viel mehr Verkehr auf den StraÃŸen, Baume die sich im Wind bewegen. BÃ¼rger die vielleicht zumindest dargestellte TÃ¤tigkeiten nach gehen. Mehr Details auf den StraÃŸen und in der Umgebung fehlen. Gerade bei so einem Spiel, wÃ¤re ein Detailgrad eines Annos sehr stimmungsvoll gewesen. Alles im allem, haben wir eine schÃ¶ne Welt, die aber irgendwie mehr ein starres Modell, als eine lebendige Stadt simuliert. 

Gerade da wÃ¤re noch zu erwÃ¤hnen, das leider Events oder gewisse GebÃ¤ude oder Stadtviertel-Verbesserungen keinen Einfluss auf die Optik oder der Lebendigkeit haben. Es ist immer gleich viel los oder weniger, dem entspreche
n. 
Der Kamerawinkel ist auch leider nicht wirklich gÃ¼nstig und man sucht immerzu nach mehr Ãœbersichtlichkeit. ZurÃ¼ck gezoomt reicht nicht aus, um einen guten Ãœberblickt Ã¼ber die Stadt zu bekommen.

So gut das mit dem Realismus auch ist, mit dem Abstimmen usw, halte ich das System fÃ¼r zu wenig vertieft. Irgendwie wirkt mir das Ganze zu simpel. Auf der anderen Seite, finde ich persÃ¶nlich es gar nicht so toll, bei jeder Aktion den Parteirat zu Rate ziehen zu mÃ¼ssen. Das ist etwas, was nicht so ganz bei der Beschreibung des Spiels durchklang. TatsÃ¤chlich macht mir dieses System, beim selber Spielen keinen SpaÃŸ und das hÃ¤tte ich wirklich nicht gedacht. Vor allem bietet es keine wirkliche Abwechslung und man klickt mehr schon durch, als sich mit der Wahl auseinander zu setzten.

Zusammengefasst:
Urban Empire ist ein innovatives Spiel, das wirklich tolle AnsÃ¤tze fÃ¼r ein Aufbauspiel oder StÃ¤dte-Simulator mitbringt. Das Durchschreiten durch mehrere Epochen der Entwicklung finde ich interessant und kÃ¶nnte wirklich vielleicht in anderen Spielen als Ansatz weiter vertieft werden. Leider finde ich die Verzahnung, der viele innovativen Elemente, nicht gelungen und technische schwÃ¤chen verdÃ¼stern das Bild zunehmend. Unter der Haube: Technisch schwÃ¤chelt das Spiel mit sporadischen AbstÃ¼rzen und deutlichen Fps-EinbrÃ¼che. Vom Design schwÃ¤chelt das Spiel in der Lebendigkeit der Spielwelt und der merkwÃ¼rdigen Kamera-Perspektive. Spielerisch bieten die innovativen Gameplay-Elemente zu wenig Abwechslung und lÃ¤sst sich schnell durchschauen. Die Abstimmungen werden so mehr zu einer Last, als dass sie wirklich Spannung erzeugen.

Zum Ergebnisse komme ich damit, dass ich das Spiel nicht empfehlen kann, im Anbetracht dessen, dass der Preis viel zu hoch und die Leistung zu gering. Der hohe Preis wird dem Spiel nicht gerecht. Ich Empfehle dafÃ¼r mehr auf einen Sale zu warten.

column8:
So... I read the reviews and thought 'nah it can't be that bad'.

It is. Believe the reviews. The choices you make seem to have very little impact and the causality of 90% of the statistics peppered throughout are not remotely explained. There's no mapping as to what actions favour which parties or inclination of any real difference to your character's influence around it.

I ultimately gave up on my second attempted playthrough because it seemed nigh impossible to actually fathom out how to progress or improve anything in any meaningful name.

Extremely overpriced game ! I got it on sale for 19 euros and i still feel it's too much for it.. Very clunky and busy interface (overly complicated) and it really does not bring much new to the table. The graphics are the only thing that i like and they are not that great anyway..

Instead of this i would buy Tropico 3, Tropico 4 or even Tropico 5 and i will get so much more in return than this game.

2019 edit: game looks still very clunky and unfinished in many areas. Annoying UI.

Do not buy.

column8: This game is fantastic.  I will admit, it has a large learning curve.  The creator of this game made an excellent new genre of City Building, Real Time Strategy, and Turn based gaming.  I have been playing city builders since the original Sim City.  This game has all of the fun of those games, with an added element of politics.  You must learn to work with, and destroy, the political parties to get the things you want passed.  This makes it a very realistic game, and fun once you get the hang of it.

column8:
Great promises, but disappointing.

Politics as a new focus in a city builder/manager? Great! - I love city-simulators, played them for 20+ years...


I will refrain from listing any pros, as the cons far outweigh any pros and until fixed, I would strongly recommend your money to be spent elsewhere!

Summary:
Lack of control
Tedious and repetitive political mechanics
Abysmal performance issues
Waiting and frustration guaranteed - for the majority of the time.

Elaborating the cons:

1. Political part is tiresome and repetitive: 
Sadly the game is poorly executed, as every action requires a vote, however realistic that might be, it means that changes takes ages: All your city districts takes a vote to change, which quickly becomes tiresome and repetitive. Imagine you want to roll out electrical grids in your entire city, before you are done you will have spent 20 years tediously modifying a district, waiting on the vote and repeat. 
My recommendation:
Perhaps some unlockable ability that a mayor can modify within certain thresholds before it triggering a vote or a similar mechanic, or at least removing the constriction that only one "modify district" vote can be active at a time. Perhaps increase political interaction, such as more access to voting groups, ability to do campaigning (both for mayor elections and city council) and the ability to choose a political party, as well as interaction with other cities such as trade or infrastructural connections - not just the horrible "twin cities" mechanic that is currently the only inter-city interaction available. 

2. Info and theory crafting in this game is so bad it hurts: 
You can, if you look into city statistics get info about traffic congestion, but the consequences of traffic congestion are not apparent. Need for certain zoning such as industry or housing seems important but after 15+ hours I still havent worked out exactly hot to satisfy it, perhaps because changes happen so slow that I have moved on to trying alternatives before the initial attempts effects kick in. Similarly it is not clear what exactly the different citizen parameters do to the game, health, security and happiness etc. all seem important, but as long as they stay in the green they donâ€™t have apparent modifiers to the city.. (?) I would love some percentages and modifiers show here and there.

3. Performance issues are by far the worst I have ever experienced: 

I just upgraded my graphics card, and even on lowest settings, speed 2 (out of 3 speed settings) still lagged - I spent about 10 hours on one play through, which was a pain. Granted, I maxed out my city size, but that should really not be an issue. If you want to avoid performance issues, try keeping your city at 1/4 of max size or so (Fun isn't it?).

4. Combined with the above, the lack of control and info and the bad performance, the game just becomes painfully boring and frustrating. The last 100 years of gameplay was, for me, just setting to the max speed and answering every vote that showed up until the game was over.

Zuerst mÃ¶chte ich sagen das dieses Spiel sehr Stimmungsvoll ist und die Idee  innovativ und Interessant ist, auÃŸerdem hab ich mich sehr darauf gefreut und versucht es zumÃ¶gen.
Obwohl ich ein groÃŸer fan von Wirtschafssimulationen , Politsimulation und StÃ¤dtebauern bin kann ich dieses Spiel nicht empfehlen.
Der Grund dafÃ¼r ist einfach : Langeweile 
Wie ich schon erwÃ¤hnt habe ist die Idee gut leider aber schlecht umgesetzt.
Das durchbringen von Politischen ideen und Bezirksplanungen ist mit einer postivien bilanz so einfach das es nicht nÃ¶tig ist Ã¼berhaupt sein politisches Kapital bei den Parteien zu investieren (die StaatrÃ¤te stimmen allem auÃŸnahmlos zu solange das man in grÃ¼nen Bereich Finanzbereich ist).
Das macht das grundprinzip dieses Spiel leider herausforderungslos.
Was die Bilanz betrifft ist es leider kaum mÃ¶glich ins Minus zurutschen.
Nach kurzer Spielzeit fand ich heraus das es am einfachsten ist einfach die ganze Karte in der ersten Epoche mit Bezirken zuzubauen (die Parteien winken es ohne einischen meiner seits sowieso durch). Was die schwierigkeit in den restlichen epochen leider komplett entfernt.Ich hoffen das in Zukunf durch patches oder DLCs (was leider wieder etwas Kostet) die schwierigkeit und dadurch der spass im spiel erhÃ¶ht wird.
Fazit ist um den Preis (40â‚¬) kann ich diese spiel leider nicht empfehlen.

Man ist ja vom Fullprice-Kundennepp der groÃŸen Anbieter inzwischen Einiges gewÃ¶hnt, aber was Kalypso sich hier geleistet hat, schlÃ¤gt dem FaÃŸ die Krone ins Gesicht. Mit einer Graphik auf Win-98-Level (fÃ¼r Railroad-Tycoon 2-3 wÃ¤r's OK gewesen), einer unintuitiven Steuerung (angefangen mit dem "rechte Maustaste zum Kartenverschieben" bis zu den ganzen komischen MenÃ¼s), absolut nicht vorhandenen LokalisierungsbemÃ¼hungen und wenig verheiÃŸungsvollem Gameplay hat mich das Ganze schon nach einer halben Stunde komplett abgetÃ¶rnt.
Was hier innovativ sein soll, weiÃŸ ich auch nicht: Versprochen hatte ich mir eine Mischung aus Skylines, Tropico, Anno und Eur. Univ/Victoria, vielleicht mit einem Tick Democracy. Was ich aber sehe, ist seltsames Gespawne wenig kreativer GebÃ¤udetypen, die Ã¼berhaupt nicht zum Lokalkolorit der Story passen. Auch die Fiktion von Politik, die hier gespielt werden soll, ist unintuitiv und hat weder etwas mit historischen Vorbildern zu tun noch mit einer nachvollziehbaren Idealwelt Ã  la Stellaris & Co. Kurz: Das Ganze ist eine Frechheit, und ich frage mich, wie so groÃŸe Titel wie Patrizier, Port Royale und Tropico in einer derartigen EnttÃ¤uschung enden kÃ¶nnen. WÃ¤re der Titel von 2002 oder so herum, wÃ¼rde ich nichts gesagt haben auÃŸer "Like it or leave it". Aber heutzutage?

Idee absolut super, versprochen wurde eine Politiksimulation mit Abwechslung, aÃ¼ÃŸeren EinflÃ¼ssen und Elementen einer Aufbausimulation, allerdings wurde das nicht wirklich geliefert. Der Aufbau der eigenen Stadt ist sehr begrenzt und es bietet sich keine groÃŸe Abwechslung im politischen Bereich, man muss praktisch gesehen die ganze Zeit auf das gleiche warten. Es gibt kaum Ã„nderungen und nach 1,4 Stunden hatte ich auch schon jegliche Lust verloren auf das zuvor so sehr gehypte Spiel. Ich kann es deswegen absolut gar nicht empfehlen.

Meine Vorfreude bei Urban Empire war zunÃ¤chst hoch.
Vom Gameplay erinnert er zunÃ¤chst an eine Mischung aus Cities: Skylines/Tropico und Demokratie 3. 
Nach ca. 30min zeigt sich ein kompetentes Bild. Die Events sind abwechslungsreich & vielfÃ¤ltig und die Ratsabstimmungen meist nachvollziehbar.
Was mich stÃ¶rt ist die Perfomence des Spiels. Es lÃ¤uft bei mir mit einer sehr geringen FPS-Zahl und hÃ¤ngt sich alle 15min auf. Wenn man nicht zwischendurch regelmÃ¤ÃŸig speichert, dann kann das einen ziemlich aufregen. Die optionale Einstellung des Autosave hat bei mir bisher noch nicht funktioniert.
Seid Release hat sich fÃ¼r mich nichts geÃ¤ndert. FÃ¼r diesen hohen Preis wÃ¼rde ich noch nicht empfehlen Urban Empire zu kaufen.

Ein paar Details zu meinem Rechner:
OS: Windows 8.1
Prozessor: Intel-Core i5
RAM: 8GB

Gamestar hat das Spiel getestet und ist unter anderem zu folgendem Ergebnis gekommen: "Urban Empire ruckelt dann auch auf starken Rechnern."
Quelle: http://www.gamestar.de/spiele/urban-empire/test/urban_empire,53676,3308255.html

column8:
Wonder why so many people hate this game? There's a long winding answer. 

Urban Empires was origonally marketed as having the following game play niches.

1) It it was a decent city-building strategy game. 
2) It had a political aspect: you would have to manipulate the political parties and make deals to pass key legislation. 
3) It would have a branching plot over multiple generations that would tell the story of both your family and the city. 
4) Your choices would effect how the story plays out.

And the game doesn't do ANY of these things well, at all. Many of people who bought this game felt that they were lied to about the type of game play

"Ok, so it doesn't meet it's promises. How did it fail? Why is it a bad game specifically?"

1) The Mechanics of the City Building Part are neither interesting nor challenging.

The city building is not difficult or interesting enough for hardcore strategy players.... once you figure out that you don't actually need to improve any aspect of your city. Just slap down districts and a couple schools for brainpower. Rely on institutions and edicts to raise stats. Maybe drop a school or PD department or two as you need it. That's it. You don't need to build anything else unless it's in the hard negatives.

The political management means very little other than "you can't do unpopular things' with damned little (if any) way of making things unpopular/popular. it's not like you can forge alliances against other parties or try and play people off against one another, and even if you did, it's not like you have to for 99% of the edicts you could pass. 

Combined, this means that the game doesn't offer any interesting srategic challenge once you figure out the above. You'll figure out what you need to do, you'll do it, and there's no changes to that strategy and no challenges to it.


2) The User Experience is AWFUL

There are a ton of controls and fiddly bits of the district but you can safely ignore them most of the time. That's actually a good thing, becuase the tutorial and user interface are so opaque that I have no idea what the advatnage or costs are for doing anything (except my experience from playing the game that tells me that any given upgrade is probably not worth it) and it's not clear HOW to do anything, and when it is, you'll be marveling at how complicaed it is to do it.

Do you need to have residenital with your commercial zone to make it work? Maybe? It doesn't tell you. Commerical zones seem to populate when you build straight commercial districts, so I guess? Is this more or less effective than normal? Maybe?

Gas, electricity and water raise the efficency of companies in the district. How much? How much will it cost in maintenence? I dunno. Increasing roads reduces traffic, buying public transport increases "transit points". What do they do? I have no idea! There's like 30 seperate submenus for each district as well.

If this was something like a difficulty curve, it would be one thing, but a lot of these mechanics genuinely doesn't seem to matter at all. It's not just that these are hidden, opaque mechanics, they are hidden and useless mechanics, and they are the only things you can really do. For example, the bonuses from sister cities don't seem to do anything worth mentioning. It's just another tech that provides a tiny, pointless bonus that won't matter all that much. 

This makes the late game really, painful once you start unlocking stuff in age 2-3. Say you want to upgrade a district. You have to make all your changes in a single pass, because you can only alter one district at a time. This involves muliple submenus with a variety of options, a ton of optional buildings to place down, zoning sliders, and you doing this over 20-30 districts. Did I mention you can only change one district at a time because it requires a vote that takes 3 months to organize? 

This adds up to make the game REALLLLLy slow when it gets big. This is compounded by another issue...

2B) The game slows your PC to crawl in mid/late game

I don't mean micromanagement, I mean the game LITERALLY slows to a crawl, with no way to increase the rate beyond the barely adequate max speed from earlier eras. I was running max speed in era 3, and it was moving about as fast as 'normal' speed from era 1. Combined with the micromangement issues, playing the mid to late game becomes a tedious grind.

* Note - This was on early builds in 2017. It may have changed.


3) The Game has no story, narrative, and sucks at worldbuilding. 

The game sucks at telling a story, and does a poor job of making me feel like my character matters, my family matters, or the city matters. This wouldn't normally be a dealbreaker for a sandbox city sim, but Urban Empire was specifically marketed as gigantic, branching, multi-generational epic ranching story. And it just doesn't deliver anything close to that. 

The actual decision points are rare and far between, and decisions have little narrative impact. Even major historical events barely qualifying as an an afterthought or a newspaper article. 

Example:  Oh look, the empire has rebelled and is now a republic. Oh look, it's WWI. Oh look, it's WWII.  You don't interact with the other families or personalities in the city. You don't pick whether you side with the Axis or Allies. You don't have any big event trees to worry about. The only thing the choices seem to do is give you a few different character traits that mean very little. Woohoo?

The parties are hilariously random and fickle. I've had hard-right Christians support abortion, Communists deny worker rights, and Pacifists support violent nationalists. There's usually no reason or sense behind their decisions.

The whole thing ends up taking away any idea that the game takes place in a world that exists. I don't mind game mechanics breaking a narrative immersion or being unrealistic, but this level of failure represents a basic lack of effort on the part of the designers to deliver any kind of emotional impact to the game.

4) Nothing you do really matters. 

The main points combine to create a game that makes me feel that nothing I do has any meanigful impact. I had researched video games shortly after the 1900's, apparently somehow running in a city that had a power plant but no actual electrical grid. Nothing feels different about my city.

Nothing looks different at any point, the game doesn't really feel very different from Era 1 to Era 3 (as far as I got).  The story just sort of shows up as a multiple choice question that will affect a few character states, but I don't feel any sort of control over the narrative, nor does it in any way feel like a naturally evolving story with compelling characters (there aren't really any characters).

Fun Factor 

There are a lot of heavily flawed games that are actualy kind of fun (hell, this is why Kalypso is still in business), but this isn't one of them: the flaws aren't endearing, or even tolerable, and the game lacks any of the character that made games like Tropico fun.

To sum up:
There's no real story (despite that being a touted feature). 
The game's not immersive enough to suck you in. 
The game's not challenging enough to make you think about it very deeply for very long. 
There are no campaigns to finish beyond the first, and I couldn't even bring myself to do that, because the game had slowed itself to a crawl by the time I was hitting the modern era.

Verdict: This game was sold as an an city and political dynasty simulator, and ended up being a crappy city simulator and utterly failing to simulate the political or dynasty part.

I'd only buy this game at VERY deep discount (like $5, or in a Humble Bundle). There are tons of strategy games that are cheaper and better than this. Every aspect of the game is mediocre (at best) with no outstanding features I can see providing any real niche appeal.
column9:
Wonder why so many people hate this game? There's a long winding answer. 

Urban Empires was origonally marketed as having the following game play niches.

1) It it was a decent city-building strategy game. 
2) It had a political aspect: you would have to manipulate the political parties and make deals to pass key legislation. 
3) It would have a branching plot over multiple generations that would tell the story of both your family and the city. 
4) Your choices would effect how the story plays out.

And the game doesn't do ANY of these things well, at all. Many of people who bought this game felt that they were lied to about the type of game play

"Ok, so it doesn't meet it's promises. How did it fail? Why is it a bad game specifically?"

1) The Mechanics of the City Building Part are neither interesting nor challenging.

The city building is not difficult or interesting enough for hardcore strategy players.... once you figure out that you don't actually need to improve any aspect of your city. Just slap down districts and a couple schools for brainpower. Rely on institutions and edicts to raise stats. Maybe drop a school or PD department or two as you need it. That's it. You don't need to build anything else unless it's in the hard negatives.

The political management means very little other than "you can't do unpopular things' with damned little (if any) way of making things unpopular/popular. it's not like you can forge alliances against other parties or try and play people off against one another, and even if you did, it's not like you have to for 99% of the edicts you could pass. 

Combined, this means that the game doesn't offer any interesting srategic challenge once you figure out the above. You'll figure out what you need to do, you'll do it, and there's no changes to that strategy and no challenges to it.


2) The User Experience is AWFUL

There are a ton of controls and fiddly bits of the district but you can safely ignore them most of the time. That's actually a good thing, becuase the tutorial and user interface are so opaque that I have no idea what the advatnage or costs are for doing anything (except my experience from playing the game that tells me that any given upgrade is probably not worth it) and it's not clear HOW to do anything, and when it is, you'll be marveling at how complicaed it is to do it.

Do you need to have residenital with your commercial zone to make it work? Maybe? It doesn't tell you. Commerical zones seem to populate when you build straight commercial districts, so I guess? Is this more or less effective than normal? Maybe?

Gas, electricity and water raise the efficency of companies in the district. How much? How much will it cost in maintenence? I dunno. Increasing roads reduces traffic, buying public transport increases "transit points". What do they do? I have no idea! There's like 30 seperate submenus for each district as well.

If this was something like a difficulty curve, it would be one thing, but a lot of these mechanics genuinely doesn't seem to matter at all. It's not just that these are hidden, opaque mechanics, they are hidden and useless mechanics, and they are the only things you can really do. For example, the bonuses from sister cities don't seem to do anything worth mentioning. It's just another tech that provides a tiny, pointless bonus that won't matter all that much. 

This makes the late game really, painful once you start unlocking stuff in age 2-3. Say you want to upgrade a district. You have to make all your changes in a single pass, because you can only alter one district at a time. This involves muliple submenus with a variety of options, a ton of optional buildings to place down, zoning sliders, and you doing this over 20-30 districts. Did I mention you can only change one district at a time because it requires a vote that takes 3 months to organize? 

This adds up to make the game REALLLLLy slow when it gets big. This is compounded by another issue...

2B) The game slows your PC to crawl in mid/late game

I don't mean micromanagement, I mean the game LITERALLY slows to a crawl, with no way to increase the rate beyond the barely adequate max speed from earlier eras. I was running max speed in era 3, and it was moving about as fast as 'normal' speed from era 1. Combined with the micromangement issues, playing the mid to late game becomes a tedious grind.

* Note - This was on early builds in 2017. It may have changed.


3) The Game has no story, narrative, and sucks at worldbuilding. 

The game sucks at telling a story, and does a poor job of making me feel like my character matters, my family matters, or the city matters. This wouldn't normally be a dealbreaker for a sandbox city sim, but Urban Empire was specifically marketed as gigantic, branching, multi-generational epic ranching story. And it just doesn't deliver anything close to that. 

The actual decision points are rare and far between, and decisions have little narrative impact. Even major historical events barely qualifying as an an afterthought or a newspaper article. 

Example:  Oh look, the empire has rebelled and is now a republic. Oh look, it's WWI. Oh look, it's WWII.  You don't interact with the other families or personalities in the city. You don't pick whether you side with the Axis or Allies. You don't have any big event trees to worry about. The only thing the choices seem to do is give you a few different character traits that mean very little. Woohoo?

The parties are hilariously random and fickle. I've had hard-right Christians support abortion, Communists deny worker rights, and Pacifists support violent nationalists. There's usually no reason or sense behind their decisions.

The whole thing ends up taking away any idea that the game takes place in a world that exists. I don't mind game mechanics breaking a narrative immersion or being unrealistic, but this level of failure represents a basic lack of effort on the part of the designers to deliver any kind of emotional impact to the game.

4) Nothing you do really matters. 

The main points combine to create a game that makes me feel that nothing I do has any meanigful impact. I had researched video games shortly after the 1900's, apparently somehow running in a city that had a power plant but no actual electrical grid. Nothing feels different about my city.

Nothing looks different at any point, the game doesn't really feel very different from Era 1 to Era 3 (as far as I got).  The story just sort of shows up as a multiple choice question that will affect a few character states, but I don't feel any sort of control over the narrative, nor does it in any way feel like a naturally evolving story with compelling characters (there aren't really any characters).

Fun Factor 

There are a lot of heavily flawed games that are actualy kind of fun (hell, this is why Kalypso is still in business), but this isn't one of them: the flaws aren't endearing, or even tolerable, and the game lacks any of the character that made games like Tropico fun.

To sum up:
There's no real story (despite that being a touted feature). 
The game's not immersive enough to suck you in. 
The game's not challenging enough to make you think about it very deeply for very long. 
There are no campaigns to finish beyond the first, and I couldn't even bring myself to do that, because the game had slowed itself to a crawl by the time I was hitting the modern era.

Verdict: This game was sold as an an city and political dynasty simulator, and ended up being a crappy city simulator and utterly failing to simulate the political or dynasty part.

I'd only buy this game at VERY deep discount (like $5, or in a Humble Bundle). There are tons of strategy games that are cheaper and better than this. Every aspect of the game is mediocre (at best) with no outstanding features I can see providing any real niche appeal.

I actually enjoyed this game---it's a bit different than other city builders I play. I have to think through decisions---build another district? Or repave the existing ones. Then there's the costs. Nothing's free. It's closer to real life than people think (in the real world, I do this kind of planning. It's probably why I still play city players.)

I haven't yet experienced any of the bugs, although some of the spellings are odd. A copy editor should have run through the game before release.

Other than that, I'm having fun playing.

I actually enjoyed this game---it's a bit different than other city builders I play. I have to think through decisions---build another district? Or repave the existing ones. Then there's the costs. Nothing's free. It's closer to real life than people think (in the real world, I do this kind of planning. It's probably why I still play city players.)

I haven't yet experienced any of the bugs, although some of the spellings are odd. A copy editor should have run through the game before release.

Other than that, I'm having fun playing.

column8: Ich war richtig heiss als ich von dem Spiel erfuhr. Ich orderte es vor und hatte eine Vorfreude wie schon ewig nicht mehr. Dann als das Spiel endlich downloadbar war wunderte ich mich schon das es nur mickrige 1,5GB gross war obwohl mehr angepriesen war. Nungut dachte ich mir, das ist nicht unbedingt wichtig. Ich fing an zu spielen und lernte relativ schnell was das Spiel von mir erwartete damit ich erfolgreich bin. Und damit fÃ¤ngt es an das das Spiel dumm ist, keinen Spass macht, und eigentlich einem keine kreative Freiheit lÃ¤sst. Das dieses Spiel mehr auf Politik ausgelegt ist als auf die Grafik aktzeptiere ich sicherlich, auch wenn die Grafik Fehler beinhaltet, aber egal. Was ich allerdings nicht aktzeptiere ist die Tatsache das ich gezwungen werde wie ein GrÃ¼ner oder Linker zu denken. Ich darf nicht irgendwelche Fantasien spielen. Das Spiel zwingt mich in die grÃ¼ne oder rote Ecke. Ich muss also Punkte abarbeiten und habe eigentlich keine grossen Freiheiten. Dann kommt noch das beste von allem dazu. Das Spiel kommt als Alpha heraus und Patche kennt man nicht. Ich kenne Spiele die es wirklich Ã¼bertreiben wo fast tÃ¤glich Patches raus kommen (ARK), aber hier passiert Ã¼berhaupt nichts, Geld eingesackt und leckt mich. Kalypso hat jetzt einen weiteren zufriedenen Kunden der mit Sicherheit niemehr von Euch was kaufen wird. Ihr habts vergeigt, so einfach ist das. Ich empfehle dieses Spiel nur zu kaufen wenn man es zu einen Preis von 4,99â‚¬ bekommt, alles dadrÃ¼ber ist zuviel.

A politcial city builder of sorts that tries a new approach. 

Unfortunately both the city building aspect and the political apsect of the game are quite shallow, leading to an unengaging, and somwhat of a bland experience.

A nice idea that was let down by flawed design, mediocre gameplay and performance issues.

You can watch my full impressions here https://youtu.be/IrUcsGgoY6o

column8: Quinze minutes de jeu !  : Bof, bof et rebof ! Je m'attendais Ã  beaucoup mieux ! Le graphisme est basique, on ne comprend pas trÃ¨s bien la mÃ©canique du jeu et au final on s'ennuie trÃ¨s rapidement !

I thought that this game would be both wide (with city building) and deep (with politics) but the game doesn't really seem to do either particularly well. The cities practically build themselves with little strategic demands from the player and politics get repetitive as you need the council to approve anything you want to do and most of the time, they're going to approve it.   I'm very disappointed in this game. It has a lot of potential but it doesn't seem like the devs are going to fix it. I'll update this review if the game improves

I'm astonished to see this game only has 46% positive. I think this is one of my favorite games to come out recently. The dynamics are unique, at least as far as anything I have played goes, and I really enjoyed them. Unfortunately, I think this is a niche game.

I had a brief look at some of the gripes and complaints. Most of them center around "not having control." Well, that's just the thing, folks. In politics, mayor or not, you DO NOT have all the control. At best, you have some sway and a bully pulpit to try and influence things. I think what these folks are looking for is Yet Another Simcity and I have news for those people: This ain't it.

To the company that makes this game, I'd say please do not be dismayed. The direction you are going in makes sense and does actually produce a fun game. It is unfortunate that so many people here don't enjoy it but I think that largely is because they were expecting something else entirely.

I enjoy politics in real life and that is what attracted me to this game. I really, REALLY hope the devs continue to work on it and update because in spite of this measley 46% rating, I honestly think the game is awesome and definitely fun. It's just unfortunate that so many people who were expecting something else decided to brigade the game's Steam rating. 

I saw a mention of graphical resolution problem to which I cannot speak, but that is certainly fixable. I have had no such performance of graphical problems, but I have an I7 6700K, 32GB of 3000MhZ RAM, and a Seahawk GTX 1080, so you know, I damn well better not have any issues, lol!

Anyway, great game. A really good political simulator, NOT so much a city simulator. It is definitely something different and I really enjoy the crap out of it. =)

THIS GAME absolutely does NOT DESERVE the RED LETTERS OF AWFUL RATING you're seeing. First thing first. Also, YOU'RE RIGHT. CAPSLOCK FOREVER. ANYWAY...

I can't believe this game got a negative review because a bunch of complete fucking gamer morons couldn't handle the fact this had some lightweight parliamentary mechanics built into.

So return it you unbelievable fucking whiners. That's not the right way to whine about stuff at all! Watch me next time! 

Nah, but it's a great game. It does something not nearly enough devs are trying to do which is government and political simulation. Nationstate, larger and smaller. I am so incredibly driven nigh on fucking mad because for the longest I've had a fairly detailed idea the creation of just such a game. Of course, I know the fine nuance of game development like I do higher math(sz). Wa wait no rather, like I DON'T HAVE A GOODAMN CLUE ABOUT anything in excess of basic bitachi wee-pre-algebra and multiple attempts to learn further have rendered hella bust so.... Ok well anyway the point is how it is maddening to have an idea that I can tell has something to it unlike a lot of the shovelware i see on steam lately and to not be able to get it out of my damn head. Like how can that ego of mine fit out here in the wild but wee ol very special project can't? Reality is a fucking rhino-cock choker for change man.

It's a good game. Ah, this one for the review or whatever I mean. Mine too but well just cue a frustrated intermittent volume increase of cursing for the next few moments.... and try this one.

I promise if congress/parliamentary mechanics determining a lot of stuff you can and cant do sounds like it has the potential to make things interesting, get this.  What a shame people couldn't love it proper.

WHOOOOOOOOOOOOOOPS ALREADY WROTE THAT. 

THIS GAME IS FANTASTIC. IGNORE THE WHINERS. IT RUNS FINE ON MODERN HARDWARE AND WORST CASE SCENARIO RETURN IT QUICKFAST BADDA BING. IT IS SO WORTH A TRY TOO IF YOU WANNA DEVELOP SOMETHING LIKE IT BECAUSE IT HAS A LOT OF WORTHWHILE TRICKS TO SEE FOR YOURSELF.

You fail to realize WHY we hate the game.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hun I grasp why you hate it just fine but if you wanted a city builder go play a city builder leave a game that's trying to do something fresh the all hell ALONE and not review bomb it. That is lame shit. How many fucking city builders are there on Steam? Christ, someone does something new and they catch all this fucking shit for it and well gee why is originality so hard to come by? Well that kinda attitude definitely factors. Not you personally, but that attitude, amplified, en masse towards things that take something typical and make it fresh.

Props to the dev. Take every whining negative review bomber as a compliment. Ya'll had the right idea. Go scope out how Suzerain is killin' it. Pretty big departure but that role in simulation has real promise.

Regards to ya, Katherine. I hope you found one to suit right disagreements and such aside. =o)

The main idea of this game is quite interesting, managing a city as a mayor. You are not an absolut ruler and have to convince your council to vote in favour of most of the decision you are making, all the decrees and almost anything that is expenses related. The first playthrough is interesting enough and you get to choose a dynasty for different playstyles. But this is where the games is lacking a lot. Playing a second time, even with a different dynasty, will feel exactly like the first playthrough. There is not many different way to play the game and all of them feels the same, if you want to succeed until the end you will most definitely have the make the same choice in every play again and again.
So, if you don't want replayability and are ok with playing the game once then go ahead but at least wait for a sale. If you are expecting a city simulator with more in-depth control and tweaking, then forget it. You're going to play it once and forget about it and go back to better city simulator.

column8:
The concept of this game is great - the execution is lacking.

I wanted a game that focussed on the politics of running a city - playing factions against each other, ensuring that you had a plurality of support even if upset some groups. This is not that game. The march of progress is predetermined, and your actions have a negligible impact on it. More to the point, your prior actions count for nothing - council elections ignore your impact on the city, and there is not even the prospect of asking for a quid-pro-quo from an ally to get something you want - if their initial inclination is to oppose a proposal your only option is to beg, taunt or threaten them into submission, at the expense of your previous months of friendship.

The game has many, many numbers...but no feedback. If your city is making a loss, there is no indication why, and the city-builder-lite approach means that you have no practical way of solving the deficit anyway, short of exploiting a glitch in the game's logic.

I suspect a very large percentage of players are like me - they played once, got the "End of the Line" achievement, and have no desire to play again. Which is a shame - this promised to be the game this niche was waiting for, but failed to deliver.

2/22 edit: The image of this game sums it up. "See all these buildings? That's what Cities: Skyline's has. As for me? Ehh..." He's doing some sort of given up expression. It sums up my thoughts on this game entirely.

Man, where do I even begin with this game?

I wanted to love it so much after watching Youtube videos and playthroughs; this game looked amazing after watching several hours of them. Sadly, I don't think I've ever been burned as hard as I have been with this game more than any other game I've ever preordered in my entire life, including Spore. Yes. Including Spore.  I've tried to give this game some breaks, but...

Let's bulletpoint this.

1: Any resolution other than your native monitor resolution and the game will dull the colors immensely. Also, forget trying to play this game at anything above 1080p, because you'll get graphical errors that make all of your buildings white and blue. Also, kiss any framerate stability out the window, despite owning a GTX 1080. It's been three weeks since release, and no fix. Unexcuseable.

2. You feel like you have no control over anything, that everything you do doesn't matter, and by the end, you stop caring. You can see there's this whole economy ticking behind your industries and businessess, but you can't decide to help paper or barbershops directly or anything of the sort. You just place huge districts down and hope things work out. City council edicts are just passive boosts to your entire city that you just idly click on to make things easier.

3. I really must stress the lack of control. What does heavy traffic do to harm your city? Don't know, because unlike Cities Skylines it just gives you vague 'maximum traffic usage' numbers. How does it damage my economy? What can I do to make lumber or movies a better industry in my town? No idea! A lot of the time you're just waiting months to do minor adjustments to districts for... boredoms sake?

4. Your city looks boring as heck. Roads? All grids. Industries? I guess film industries, car factories, and lumber mills all look the same and I just didn't know about it. Don't you remember when film studios had smoke stacks? I sure don't! So forget having any major control on how your city looks, or putting it on a hill, or anything of the sort. It's just flat land. Remember Germany being flat? Guess we're in the Netherlands now.

You know, I could go on, and on, and on. About how the music repeats every ten minutes; how you really have to zoom in on max settings to even see people walk about; how despite the cool as heck technology tree is broken because you can be 30, 40, 50 years ahead of modern tech if you abuse it. This game made me not care about my city, what I was doing, and why I was doing it. That's the nail in the coffin for any simulator. I just don't see anything they could do to fix this game. It's just... not fun. And it depresses me saying that. 

I wouldn't recommend this game, even if it went on sale from 40 dollars to 5 dollars. It just feels... like some major spark is missing. Cities Skylines absolutely destroys this game, and still stands as the best city builder to date. Go get that, and like two hundred mods, and watch a day pass by. Oh, and they aren't even sure this game will get modshop support now. Heck, Tropico 5 is still an excellent choice for those who want something more local and flavorful. To me, I should have bought the new Skyrim instead of this. This is literally, the biggest disappoint in gaming in years to me. I wanted to love this game... but I can't. The concept screamed epic, the execution... souless.

Updated this review 2/14/17, since a lot of you liked it, apperently.

Resumiendo el anÃ¡lisis se podrÃ­a decir que Urban Empire es una gran idea en un no tan "gran" juego.

Hace aÃ±os que pensÃ© en la idea de tener un Simcity donde antes de poder colocar las nuevas calles tuvieras que someter el proyecto a la aprobaciÃ³n del ayuntamiento, por eso la idea, por fin, me pareciÃ³ fantÃ¡stica. Poco despuÃ©s me llevÃ© cierta desilusiÃ³n cuando descubrÃ­ que las posibilidades que nos iba a ofrecer el juego sobre el diseÃ±o de nuestra ciudad iban a ser prÃ¡cticamente nulas, pero las semanas de espera siguieron avanzando y poco a poco iban llegando otras noticias que no pintaban nada bien, el juego no iba a estar en espaÃ±ol, volvÃ­an a insistir en el fallido y errÃ³neo planteamiento de las eras, el protagonista serÃ­a nuevamente un personaje perteneciente a una saga familiar. En fin, ciertos desaciertos nada esperanzadores. 

Pasaron las semanas y llegÃ³ el estreno del juego. Se confirmaron las faltas que ya conocimos y se evidenciaron algunas nuevas. El juego es excesivamente cerrado, te guÃ­a por la historia que te ofrece y no te deja margen de maniobra (casi llega a volverse monÃ³tono). La genial idea de que tÃº seas un alcalde ajeno al sistema de partidos polÃ­ticos no tiene sentido ni correspondencia con la realidad, los alcaldes reales pertenecen a un partido polÃ­tico y ganan elecciones y otras veces las pierden y tienen que estar en la oposiciÃ³n. 

En el apartado tÃ©cnico, respecto a la jugabilidad, un sistema de cÃ¡mara que es un desastre, tiene una enorme sensibilidad (aunque lo pongas al mÃ­nimo) y la camara se mueve para todos lados.

Para terminar (ya por soÃ±ar), a poco que se hubieran esforzado un poquito mÃ¡s podrÃ­an haberle aÃ±adido un workshop donde hubiÃ©semos podido aÃ±adir nuestros propios mapas, nuestros propios personajes o incluso nuestras propias propuestas polÃ­ticas.

AÃºn asÃ­, a pesar de todo, por la originalidad del concepto y porque soy un fanÃ¡tico del gÃ©nero, aunque muy tÃ­midamente, recomiendo la compra de este juego. Eso sÃ­, si no sois unos fanÃ¡ticos como yo, esperaos a alguna oferta.

Au premier abord, le jeu se prÃ©sente comme un city builder teintÃ© de politique. Les quelques let's play vus sur YouTube me laissait une bonne impression (mais Ã©tant donnÃ© qu'ils Ã©taient tous sponsorisÃ©es, j'aurais dÃ» voir l'anguille sous la roche). En fait, ce jeu est une Ã©norme boÃ®te noire qui ne vous explique absolument rien. Tellement qu'on ne trouve aucun guide ou documentation sur le web car les joueurs semblent avoir tous du mal Ã  comprendre les mÃ©caniques de ce jeu (et moi donc !). Vous faites des choses, proposez des lois, amÃ©liorez des quartiers sans trop savoir ce que Ã§a reprÃ©sente vraiment Ã  part la symbolique que l'on se fait (droit de vote des femmes, ok, mais Ã§a impacte quoi aprÃ¨s dans le jeu ???). Contrairement Ã  l'Ã©crasante majoritÃ© des city builders, il n'y aucun graphique pour rendre compte de l'Ã©volution et comprendre ce qu'il se passe. Tout juste il y a quelques chiffres bien obscures qui ne sont qu'une photographie Ã  l'instant T (essayez de lire et noter Ã  la main les statistiques chaque mois, la montagne du FUN!). Tout est obscure dans ce jeu ! TantÃ´t vos revenus vacillent dans le rouge sans prÃ©venir, sans que rien d'autres ne semblent Ãªtre apparu. Ce jeu, par ailleurs, ne pardonne pas la moindre erreur. Si vous vous retrouvez dans le rouge, c'est le cercle vicieux vers la banqueroute et la non-rÃ©Ã©lection de votre candidature. column9:
Don't buy it. The design is utterly illogical. The government's economy relies entirely on tax rates. Developing technology and investing in infrastructure won't even make the city richer; it only increases your expenses. If you run into a deficit, the parliament won't raise taxes, and the citizens' money will dwindle. All you've previously invested in benefits and infrastructure will be wastedâ€”you can only watch and wait for death. The gameplay is abysmal! There's absolutely no control required! You simply raise taxes, mindlessly buy land, and then stare blankly at the screen, because any action you find interesting or feasible will likely result in failure. You just watch. Every scene and every mayor is boring, because no matter which scene or mayor you choose, you just stare blankly. Besides the different map shapes, different news reports, and different party names in parliament, there's nothing special and no strategy.

This crappy game isn't very graphically impressive, the system requirements are quite high, and it's ridiculously expensive! There's no need to buy this boring game just for the official Chinese version and online ads.

All i want to do is play this game and finish a complete campaign.

Its fucking impossible! Dont get me wrong its a ton of fun to grow your city and add services but theyre completely unsustainable! It just doesnt make sense that a city can't support something so simple as running water for everyone without taxes being at 25%!

If the finance portion of the game was fixed either allowing loans or development grants or something.  I do recommend this game for the first 2 eras as they are easy, but when youre forced to have cobblestone streets in the 1970 with nothing but gaslamps in a few districts and no one having running water its a bit ridiculous. Especially considering this game is supposed to take place in Europe, not sub-saharan africa.

I really wanted to like this game... if i could give a neutral recommendation i would. Had lots of potential, but seems to be incomplete. Just missing something.  The effects of technology research to actual city growth are extremely disappointing. You basically have to destroy an entire district for any results in taxes/production. Really cool concepts and maybe after a patch or extra DLC, it'd be worth a go. 
Bottem line, Wait for 50%+ sale.

Schlechte Grafik, ein Tag-Nachtmodus der nervt und sich nicht abschalten lÃ¤sst, ein Rat der grundsÃ¤tzlich alles ablehnt was die Stadt vorwÃ¤rts bringen kÃ¶nnte usw. Das Spiel macht wirklich keinen SpaÃŸ. Man hat Ã¼berhaupt keinen Handlungsspielraum, das ganze erinnert eher an eine Handy-App fehlt halt nur die Werbung.
Das Geld ist rausgeschmissenes Geld. Ich bin wirklich ein Fan von City-Building-Games, aber Urban Empire ist leider extrem langweilig, frustierend und der SpaÃŸfaktor strebt gegen Null. Schade.

I was very excited about this game coming out since it seemed to take away my least favorite part of City-Builder gameplay: laying down every single street and water pipe and powerlines etc... In this regard the game delivered on this expectation very well. Urban Empire is aimed at the political side of managing a city and hence it allows you to be the mayor and relieves you of the burden of also being the town engineer, subcontractor, and surveyor. This is a big plus for me and I enjoy how easy it is to build new districts and have control of the contruction of the city without being bothered by many small details.

However, I cannot recommend this game primarily for three reasons:

Firstly, most of the edicts, proposals, and laws that are voted on by the City Council are rather one sided. With rare exception, most of the laws/edicts only have good benefits for your city and no negative consequences (sometime not even with any monetary expense either). The edicts that do have a negative consequences often are very minimal negative effects and are greatly outweighted by the positive effects. 

This leads to the political gameplay feeling very linear: Its like you are an omniscient mayor who knows that all of your ideas are great and they will all have good outcomes and your task is simply to get these nitwits on the city council to realize how good all these edicts and laws are for everyone and vote for them. I find that this leaves the feeling that the gameplay and strategic element is lacking. I would much rather have stronger positives and negatives for each edict. This will greatly improve this aspect of our city but it will also cause equally big problems in this other regard. I think it would also lead to the city feeling more specialized and have a uniqueness to it from one playthrough to the next.

Secondly, this games lacks a good guide to the numbers behind the game and understanding why money or happiness is climbing or falling is often not clear and so making strategic decisions becomes frustrating because unseen variables appear to be affecting your city in unpredictable ways.

Thirdly, you lose goodwill with politcal parties most anytime you encourage or cajole or persuade them how to vote on a particular issue. But apart from some random events, there isn't any consistent way to gain their goodwill. So when your goodwill is low, the only solution is to just talking to the parties until the goodwill rises back up to a normal level. My problem with this is that it ignores the whole deal-making and compromising side of politics. While its true political parties often become strongly divided from each and will not have much goodwill for the other party. At other times two rather different parties will come to an agreement to work together towards some mutual goal and will build up mutual goodwill to build up a stronger political bloc. If this game had some element of negotiating between parties or building up goodwill through consessions and compromise, then it would feel like an accurate political simulation.

Overall, Urban Empire successfully delivers a macro-level city building experience free of all the messy and frustrating detail work that most other city builders require. Unfortunately, the onesidedness of most of the edicts and laws as well as the inablility to cooperate and build up goodwill with political parties makes the game feel scripted and most cities feel the same as the last city you built.

I was very excited about this game coming out since it seemed to take away my least favorite part of City-Builder gameplay: laying down every single street and water pipe and powerlines etc... In this regard the game delivered on this expectation very well. Urban Empire is aimed at the political side of managing a city and hence it allows you to be the mayor and relieves you of the burden of also being the town engineer, subcontractor, and surveyor. This is a big plus for me and I enjoy how easy it is to build new districts and have control of the contruction of the city without being bothered by many small details.

However, I cannot recommend this game primarily for three reasons:

Firstly, most of the edicts, proposals, and laws that are voted on by the City Council are rather one sided. With rare exception, most of the laws/edicts only have good benefits for your city and no negative consequences (sometime not even with any monetary expense either). The edicts that do have a negative consequences often are very minimal negative effects and are greatly outweighted by the positive effects. 

This leads to the political gameplay feeling very linear: Its like you are an omniscient mayor who knows that all of your ideas are great and they will all have good outcomes and your task is simply to get these nitwits on the city council to realize how good all these edicts and laws are for everyone and vote for them. I find that this leaves the feeling that the gameplay and strategic element is lacking. I would much rather have stronger positives and negatives for each edict. This will greatly improve this aspect of our city but it will also cause equally big problems in this other regard. I think it would also lead to the city feeling more specialized and have a uniqueness to it from one playthrough to the next.

Secondly, this games lacks a good guide to the numbers behind the game and understanding why money or happiness is climbing or falling is often not clear and so making strategic decisions becomes frustrating because unseen variables appear to be affecting your city in unpredictable ways.

Thirdly, you lose goodwill with politcal parties most anytime you encourage or cajole or persuade them how to vote on a particular issue. But apart from some random events, there isn't any consistent way to gain their goodwill. So when your goodwill is low, the only solution is to just talking to the parties until the goodwill rises back up to a normal level. My problem with this is that it ignores the whole deal-making and compromising side of politics. While its true political parties often become strongly divided from each and will not have much goodwill for the other party. At other times two rather different parties will come to an agreement to work together towards some mutual goal and will build up mutual goodwill to build up a stronger political bloc. If this game had some element of negotiating between parties or building up goodwill through consessions and compromise, then it would feel like an accurate political simulation.

Overall, Urban Empire successfully delivers a macro-level city building experience free of all the messy and frustrating detail work that most other city builders require. Unfortunately, the onesidedness of most of the edicts and laws as well as the inablility to cooperate and build up goodwill with political parties makes the game feel scripted and most cities feel the same as the last city you built.

Actually an interesting game to play, just a bit difficult, although after playing it for a couple of hours, I can finally say that the learning curve is not too steep as I previously thought.  You can pick and research technologies which may unlock edicts and certain services to improve the city life for your civilians, becareful, it can be incredibly easy to go into debt and eventually be voted out by other political parties, use your 'good will'' wisely ,use it too much, will make them hate you and will be impossible for you to pass your edicts and laws.  


UPDATE:-
I cannot recommend this game anymore
they need to update this game, patch it up. I wish I did not buy this , it had a lot of potential though

column9:
The game's theme is novel, breaking with the typical city-building genre by incorporating politics. I feel like it's a lot like a book, with our mayor as the protagonist. We can manipulate political parties to adjust taxes, suppress them, and bring unbearable hardship to the people, thereby increasing our own income and funding the city's development. Alternatively, we can be a good mayor who cares for the people, lowering taxes to improve people's well-being and boost party support, but the city's development will lag behind. In politics, there's no such thing as absolute trust, fairness, or justice; only the impact we leave on future generations. I support the gameplay of this game. While I'm not particularly hopeful about the graphics, I can only say it's pretty standard. Our K-Shop has broken with the traditional city-building game formula and set a new precedent, which I find truly commendable. Perhaps the landscape of city-building games will change from now on.
If so, I hope so.
Finally, do you want to be a strong-arm politician using politics as a weapon, or someone who cares about public opinion and leaves a lasting legacy? I want you to join the Urban Empire and create endless possibilities!
(The above opinions are entirely personal and represent only my perspective.)

column8: I want to love this game, I really do, it has great potential and it is fun to play around with.  There are currently only four families to play as and this seems very lacking. I think those that wrote negative reviews need to rethink their opinion.

You need to sink some serious planning to do well in this game.  

When I first played this, there were a number of annoying things mentioned in th emany negative reviews.  Many have been fixed and I dont doubt this game will get better BUT....

I just got voted out after my second election but it took 8+ ? hours to get to that point .....

You  have to pay attention before putting an edict up for vote,,, there are a number of things going into your success on the vote,,,,not just hammering the plead , demand,  or threat buttons...  these can help you but a lot mor to it than that....

I admit when I first played I thought ..ok , not much too this, THEN I read the reviews and was like "bummer" BUT I was wrong.and so are many of the reviews,,,,,

AND if they put a little effort into it...U.E. has serious potential....

I really want to like this game but the way it currently plays is both frustrating and obfuscated. It really is a city builder game with a very awkward "Do not pass go" Council screen passing for the difference between Builder and Ruler. Ultimately it starts getting in the way. It needs to be streamlined to be less offensive to the continuing gameplay.

Then there's the mechanics of how and why your city grows or doesn't grow. Very few of the factors are fully explained to the point where you can comprehend them and utilise or react to them properly. A very slight change to your city perhaps even a change to just the city's potential and not even to it's physical nature (e.g. upgrade a district to potentially have higher density buildings) and suddenly everyone might move out sending you into a debt spiral you can never recover from.

Then there are story-driven decisions you have to make (will you the Major endorse X or Y etc). Some of them reveal their consequences in terms of modifications to various stats and some of them don't. There appears to be no rhyme or reason for the latter.

The game is also pretty poor on the graphical front. Ignore the lovely close-ups in the trailers. You'll never be looking at your city like that and even if you do take a moment to zoom in it really isn't impressive in the flesh. As your city grows so does your frame-rate slow. Even on a massively overclocked i7 and watercooled 1080GTX it tanks completely as the city gets larger. Eventually it crashes raising the ghost of a possible memory leak.

column8:
Extremely promising game. I really, really wanted to like it. You take charge of a city and have to manage building it in your vision and the views/votes of the political parties.

The UI is terrible (Red means lower, Green means higher, regardless of good or bad) or unclear (-5% demand for a product means the business needs 5% less to stay profitable?!?!) 
Has a lot of potential, but really needs to be patched up.

Cities Skylines trifft Democracy 3 - das jedenfalls habe ich von Urban Empire erwartet.
Im Ansatz wird auch beides, Politik und StÃ¤dtebau, nachvollziehbar und clever miteinander verbunden indem man in kaiserlichem Auftrag eine Stadt grÃ¼nden darf. 
Das passiert zu Beginn des 19. Jahrhunderts und erstreckt sich bis ins Jahr 2020. Auf Wunsch kann man weiterspielen allerdings ohne Neuerung durch Fortschritt und Entwicklung.

Fazit:

Ich habe den Kauf trotz der Negativpunkte nicht bereut, kann den Titel dennoch nicht uneingeschrÃ¤nkt empfehlen. 

Urban Empire kann weder mit Cities: Skylines noch Democracy mithalten. Das will und muss es aber auch nicht.
Es findet oder erschafft eine Nische und verbindet die beiden Themen geschickt. 
Die Basis des Spiels ist grundsolide, ich hatte hie und da meinen SpaÃŸ und es hat ein Wochenende gut unterhalten. Leider fehlt es dem Titel an Feinschliff und Tiefe um auf lÃ¤ngere Zeit zu unterhalten. 

Der Titel unterhÃ¤lt fÃ¼r gut 20 Stunden, wem das fÃ¼r den veranschlagten Kaufpreis genÃ¼gt der kann bedenkenlos zugreifen. 

Wirklich wÃ¼nschenswert wÃ¤re aus meiner Sicht Workshop Tools fÃ¼r die interessierte Community. Ich denke mit deren KreativitÃ¤t wÃ¤re hier noch die ein oder andere Spielstunde mÃ¶glich.

Abschliessend mÃ¶chte ich folgendes loswerden:
Hat es eine negativ Empfehlung verdient? Nein!
Warum? Weil es kein schlechtes Spiel ist.
Es fehlt an einigen Sachen aber es ist spielbar und das vom ersten Tag an. 
Ja es hat meine Erwartung enttÃ¤uscht. Aber die waren auch sehr hoch.

Und wenn man Kalypso und Reborn eines nicht vorwerfen kann dann ist es Intransparenz.
Es gab zig Lets Plays (u.A. von Writing Bull ) im Vorfeld und auch Live Streams bei denen man sich einen ausfÃ¼hrlichen Eindruck machen konnte.

DIeses Spiel ist nicht zu empfehlen da es nicht um die versprochene Politiksimulation handelt sondern um eine Warterei zwischen SteuererhÃ¶hung und krichend langsamer Implementierung von den Infrastrukturverbesserungen.

Die drei Karten sin lieblose Klotze die sich nicht nennenswert unterscheiden, vor allem da die in den Kartenbeschreibung so hervorgehobene Herausforderung der Hafen und Bahnhofplatzierung ganz und gar "Wurscht" ist da Instutionen ihre Boni der ganzen Mapp zur VerfÃ¼gung stellen. Hier haben anscheinend die Mitarbeiter nicht mit einander geredet. 

Die Lieblosigkeit merkt man z.B. auch am kleinen Manko der unpassenden Zitate bei der Erfindungswolke. Wer bei Gaslampen plÃ¶tzlich Ã¼ber GlÃ¼birnen redet wirkt werder clever noch charmant. Leider folgen Ã¤hnliche FlÃ¼chtigkeitsfehler.

DIe sogenannte Politik ist eher hintergrÃ¼ndig. Ohne Takitk und mit nur 4 MÃ¶glichkeiten mit den Parteien zu agieren fÃ¼hlt es sich doch sehr eintÃ¶nig an.

Auch die Charakter bzw. Familienwahl merkman nur anhand der zugeschnittenen Events die das persÃ¶nliche leben der gerade gespielten Figure betreffen.

Interface und verstÃ¤ndlichkeit der ganzen Symbole ist wirklich schlimm. Wenn jeder Knopf und jedes Symbol mit Unterschiedlich designten Tooltips kommt oder diese einfach komplett fehen. Kommt man sich doch sehr merkwÃ¼rdigvor. Einziger Nutzen wÃ¤re als Beispiel wie man es nicht machen sollte.

Die Idee ist ansich sehr intresant und war auch der Hauptgrund der mich zum Kauf bewegt hat. Leider fehlt hier vieles um das Konzept Interesant zu machen. Mehr interaction mit den Parteien durch MÃ¶glichen Beitritt, Bestechung und aktiver Wahlkampf fÃ¼r diese in der BevÃ¶lkerung wÃ¤re ein wichtiger Schritte gewesen. Auch politische Funktionen wie Garrymandering und Propagander fehlen leider. Gerade wenn man so viele Themen wie Frauen, LGBT, Umwelt, Arbeits und Unternehmensrechte anschneidet wÃ¤re es schÃ¶n wenn das Spiel einen nicht auf Grund der Boni nicht vortweg in eine Richtung treibt sondern man mit Unteschiedlichen Haltungen experimentiern kÃ¶nnte. 

Es ist schade um die Idee aber leider keine gute Umsetzung
