Nicht wirklich viel zu tun und naja... viel zu wenig das man machen kann...

Urban empire is a very niche game, despite of its marketing and initial price tag that suggested a quasi-AAA title. It decides to go against the critically acclaimed Cities Skylines, and it endorses Tropico's political system more than ever before. Why am I endorsing the game? They are going in a certain direction that games don't usually go - and as far as I am concerned, I like it because it's a difficult road and not many players nowadays enjoy the city-building + politics combo. Big time. And I think innovations need to be endorsed, promoted and helped.

That's Calypso for you. They make awesome niche games focused on the city building+politics combo that just get better - first Tropico, now Urban Empire. It's just all about time - they decided to stop being lazy, go on the politics road and keep it up.

If you dont like to read, then watch me ramble for 20 minutes or so: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p7V4S5lNWj4

Lets take a look at the good.

GOOD:

1. The politics system really helps the game. It wrenches the control out of the player's hands, and while others would complain, I find it the best positive thing in the game. This is MFing real life. Political parties have their own views, their own agendas, their own principles, and try as you might, a mayor can only do so much. Ok, short of being the Green Arrow, I guess...
2. They have chosen the perfect setting - the second half of the 19th century, when things really started kicking into high gear for the humanity as we know it - all over the world. I am very happy they did it.
3. The different maps provide different challenges, and the player needs to plan for that. I like it.
4. The replayability is good in my book. I have played 2 maps with 2 different families and it felt like a different game. Was it just me carrying over my experience of the first game? I don't think so. While the setting is relatively similar, playing to the strengths of your family is a big deal and enforces a number of different playstyles. And speaking about playstyles...
5. Playstyles differ, and work. So far in my games, I managed to create a workers' paradise, where the lower class pays almost nothing in taxes, and in my other game I managed to create a technocratic society where everyone contributed and went tech crazy. I can see so much potential for roleplay here. I love it. I could say more about the system, but the female part of the humankind will hate me, and I'd rather not, because I am very much into women, as they represent the better part of our society!
6. Last, but not least, the city does indeed change because of your actions, which is really nice to see. Whether it will be the buildings, the street light, hell, even the amount of people walking the streets, it's still a very welcome change from a player's perspective.

Good, good, good. But there is bad, and it's a lot. 

1. The game is easy. You will most likely be able to win it in the first go, especially if you already have some experience with city builders and how they work
2. Prestige, while being an awesome thing, is used improperly in my opinion. It needs to be family/mayor based, and not accumulated throughout the entire game. Or at least make it so that you can't use it to overrule mayor elections - because no matter how bad you lose, you can still use prestige to stay in power. While the cost to stay in power does rise, if you are remotely good at this type of game you will win, and still sit on a very hefty amount of prestige. And about that...
3. I just wish that Calypso will endorse the fact that gamers do like challenge. So far their city/politics games have been extremely gamer-friendly. It's like playing XCOM, losing the mission, getting everyone killed, but have a itty bitty little button in the corner of the screen that says "Spend 10 Supply to win" and by a snap of Q's fingers everyone is alive and all's good. Welp...
4. Invalid district shape shouldn't have been considered as a game option, and district shapes should have been completely overhauled - especially in the types of maps the developers created. All those corners do not help the district building, people, especially in the way you made it. Inexperienced people will sometimes forfeit a huge chunk of the playing area just because of your "regulations". Thanks, but no thanks.
5. Being a niche game, it promises more that people expect. I don't like it, as it misrepresents many, many things. The devs made it sound like it's Cities Skylines with a political system - which is something everyone will buy, and bite into - and be bitterly disappointed.
6. Again, last but not least, there are bugs. I, myself posted a screenie in which an event cause the game to bug and got me like 7 million debt in a tick, even though I was easily in the positive amounts of cash influx - this immediately affected my game, as it reduced my ability to play the way that I wanted, and forced me to cheat (meaning raise a ton of taxes, and the parliament agreed easily, which also helped me later on) - which is a bad thing. Of course, don't get me started on the frame rate drops... Thank God I am a gamer since 1998, which mens I don't really pay attention to that, and it doesn't bother me much - but I know for a fact that it ticks a ton more people to no end.

Time to interject before the conclusion...

You might have noticed that I didn't talk about the graphics, the sound, etc. They are ok and do the game justice. What I am trying to say with this review, is that, even by endorsing this game, Calypso need to step up their game and understand where the industry is at. It's about time they introduced multiple difficulties in an appropriate, and dare I say MEANINGFUL fashion. It's time to get out of their shell and do the proper thing. I know for a fact that they have the capability to do so, as they have proven in with the tropico series and this very game, Urban Empire - they just need to do it in their next game, or they will always be the niche dev that makes good games for specific audiences, but never great games.

Conclusion:

I am endorsing the game because I am having great fun with it, and because I believe that the developers have what it takes to step up their game and make the next cities skylines with a politics system. It may happen or not - but it is hard for me not to get by the fact that I am having lots of fun playing Urban Empire, and that I find each family to pose different challenges - and as some of you might know, I judge my games by game hours vs value - and to me, this one sure as hell merits it. Each play-through lasts about 8 hours, and with 4 families, varying political systems, and roleplaying to boot, it easily overgrows its money value. Want to make an city where women do nothing else but give birth to kids to prolong lineages? You can! (and did you just see me contradict myself?! I bet you did, as far as positive 5 is concerned...) Want to make the ultimate balanced society? You can! Want to be the best modern society? You sure as hell can! I absolutely love the amount of options this game gives me, and for that - I thank it! Do you? That's a question you need to answer for yourself.
column9:
Urban empire is a very niche game, despite of its marketing and initial price tag that suggested a quasi-AAA title. It decides to go against the critically acclaimed Cities Skylines, and it endorses Tropico's political system more than ever before. Why am I endorsing the game? They are going in a certain direction that games don't usually go - and as far as I am concerned, I like it because it's a difficult road and not many players nowadays enjoy the city-building + politics combo. Big time. And I think innovations need to be endorsed, promoted and helped.

That's Calypso for you. They make awesome niche games focused on the city building+politics combo that just get better - first Tropico, now Urban Empire. It's just all about time - they decided to stop being lazy, go on the politics road and keep it up.

If you dont like to read, then watch me ramble for 20 minutes or so: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p7V4S5lNWj4

Lets take a look at the good.

GOOD:

1. The politics system really helps the game. It wrenches the control out of the player's hands, and while others would complain, I find it the best positive thing in the game. This is MFing real life. Political parties have their own views, their own agendas, their own principles, and try as you might, a mayor can only do so much. Ok, short of being the Green Arrow, I guess...
2. They have chosen the perfect setting - the second half of the 19th century, when things really started kicking into high gear for the humanity as we know it - all over the world. I am very happy they did it.
3. The different maps provide different challenges, and the player needs to plan for that. I like it.
4. The replayability is good in my book. I have played 2 maps with 2 different families and it felt like a different game. Was it just me carrying over my experience of the first game? I don't think so. While the setting is relatively similar, playing to the strengths of your family is a big deal and enforces a number of different playstyles. And speaking about playstyles...
5. Playstyles differ, and work. So far in my games, I managed to create a workers' paradise, where the lower class pays almost nothing in taxes, and in my other game I managed to create a technocratic society where everyone contributed and went tech crazy. I can see so much potential for roleplay here. I love it. I could say more about the system, but the female part of the humankind will hate me, and I'd rather not, because I am very much into women, as they represent the better part of our society!
6. Last, but not least, the city does indeed change because of your actions, which is really nice to see. Whether it will be the buildings, the street light, hell, even the amount of people walking the streets, it's still a very welcome change from a player's perspective.

Good, good, good. But there is bad, and it's a lot. 

1. The game is easy. You will most likely be able to win it in the first go, especially if you already have some experience with city builders and how they work
2. Prestige, while being an awesome thing, is used improperly in my opinion. It needs to be family/mayor based, and not accumulated throughout the entire game. Or at least make it so that you can't use it to overrule mayor elections - because no matter how bad you lose, you can still use prestige to stay in power. While the cost to stay in power does rise, if you are remotely good at this type of game you will win, and still sit on a very hefty amount of prestige. And about that...
3. I just wish that Calypso will endorse the fact that gamers do like challenge. So far their city/politics games have been extremely gamer-friendly. It's like playing XCOM, losing the mission, getting everyone killed, but have a itty bitty little button in the corner of the screen that says "Spend 10 Supply to win" and by a snap of Q's fingers everyone is alive and all's good. Welp...
4. Invalid district shape shouldn't have been considered as a game option, and district shapes should have been completely overhauled - especially in the types of maps the developers created. All those corners do not help the district building, people, especially in the way you made it. Inexperienced people will sometimes forfeit a huge chunk of the playing area just because of your "regulations". Thanks, but no thanks.
5. Being a niche game, it promises more that people expect. I don't like it, as it misrepresents many, many things. The devs made it sound like it's Cities Skylines with a political system - which is something everyone will buy, and bite into - and be bitterly disappointed.
6. Again, last but not least, there are bugs. I, myself posted a screenie in which an event cause the game to bug and got me like 7 million debt in a tick, even though I was easily in the positive amounts of cash influx - this immediately affected my game, as it reduced my ability to play the way that I wanted, and forced me to cheat (meaning raise a ton of taxes, and the parliament agreed easily, which also helped me later on) - which is a bad thing. Of course, don't get me started on the frame rate drops... Thank God I am a gamer since 1998, which mens I don't really pay attention to that, and it doesn't bother me much - but I know for a fact that it ticks a ton more people to no end.

Time to interject before the conclusion...

You might have noticed that I didn't talk about the graphics, the sound, etc. They are ok and do the game justice. What I am trying to say with this review, is that, even by endorsing this game, Calypso need to step up their game and understand where the industry is at. It's about time they introduced multiple difficulties in an appropriate, and dare I say MEANINGFUL fashion. It's time to get out of their shell and do the proper thing. I know for a fact that they have the capability to do so, as they have proven in with the tropico series and this very game, Urban Empire - they just need to do it in their next game, or they will always be the niche dev that makes good games for specific audiences, but never great games.

Conclusion:

I am endorsing the game because I am having great fun with it, and because I believe that the developers have what it takes to step up their game and make the next cities skylines with a politics system. It may happen or not - but it is hard for me not to get by the fact that I am having lots of fun playing Urban Empire, and that I find each family to pose different challenges - and as some of you might know, I judge my games by game hours vs value - and to me, this one sure as hell merits it. Each play-through lasts about 8 hours, and with 4 families, varying political systems, and roleplaying to boot, it easily overgrows its money value. Want to make an city where women do nothing else but give birth to kids to prolong lineages? You can! (and did you just see me contradict myself?! I bet you did, as far as positive 5 is concerned...) Want to make the ultimate balanced society? You can! Want to be the best modern society? You sure as hell can! I absolutely love the amount of options this game gives me, and for that - I thank it! Do you? That's a question you need to answer for yourself.

column8:
This game was a big disappointment to me. It had promise, but as it's done with the past Tropicos, Kalypso fails to deliver.

First off, you are herded towards adopting certain decisions, you can say no and oppose, but it will eventually be brought back up and it will be more and more impossible to allow for a reform to pass. And if you look at these decisions with anything but a roleplaying or contrarian mind, you will have NO reason not to support them. 

The Von Pfilzens are traditional aristocrats, that's who I played as, yet when some reforms against my own ideals came up, I saw there were no downsides to them, it was all raw benefits. If there were any downsides, they were easily crushed by the potential benefits. So what did I actually get out of playing the Von Pfilzens instead of another family? Little more than their starting modifiers which barely did anything interesting as is.

In Tropico games you had options on how you wanted to build your city, even if its consequences were limited. From a capitalist paradise, to a communist utopia, to a fascist dictatorship in the later games. You tended to go towards the communist path, but the choice was still there. In this game it is nowhere to be found.

Second, what happens around the world NEVER affects what happens in your little bubble province/city of Swarelia/Kaisershafen. In fact, when you pass certain reforms the entire country you're in suddenly decides to do so too. Shouldn't the world be affecting me? All I get is some newspapers. The entire nazi war machine might just cross over Swarelia and I wouldn't even notice outside of one or two events and a newspaper telling me.

Third, you are forced into a democracy. As ideologies like communism and fascism rise, you are still forced to get elected by the parliament in the 3rd Era. Not cool, in a game like this you could easily represent your rise to power through the two totalitarian ideologies and maybe do some politicking for the entirety of Swarelia to join up with you. Hell, at first glance you'd think they'd do something like this considering there are two families that literally scream fascist and communist in your ears. 


Now let's leave the wasted potential behind and look at the gameplay:

It's boring and bland. That's what defines this game. When new technologies pop up you tick a new checkbox in a district and wait for the vote with 100% support to pass, do this for every other district all the time to keep it competitive. Lay down some dumb buildings to keep people's happy numbers up. They're not gonna starve or revolt, they'll vote you out if you don't do it right, so everything is fine.

The politics game, well: Rack up goodwill points with parties, and when you want to get something passed you use one of three options to make them support the edict. Parties have no personality, no real members, they're just in a Left-Right Conservative-Liberal x-y axis which makes them support an edict or the other more. You'll always want to get the same stuff passed, since it's what brings in bonuses that'll keep the city afloat. You'll sometimes get events that pretend to give parties some character, but they are usually without real consequence, and will only give you more nice guy points with the parties, that's all.

And yes, there is little else to the gameplay.


To conclude: It's not a bad game per se, but it is in no way worth the price for it. It has no meat, and what little meat you can find is barely edible. This game would need a complete revamp to be entertaining for more than one or two hours, but knowing how Kalypso works after years of following their Tropico games, it won't happen.

Have a good day and thanks for reading.

[h1]A novel game, with an interesting premise, and little handholding (which appeals to me).[/h1]

Govern a city for 200 years, across 5 generations, and attempt to achieve one of 5 victory conditions (ie ala Civilization). Seems like a fairly vanilla premise, until you account for the fact that you do not have absolute power to implement anything.

Much/most of what you seek to do will require city council support (via a vote mechanic)  before implementation. Within the council you will deal with a variety of party blocks, representaing a slew of political idealogies, that vary by era. Party support for your proposals, depends upon their ideology/core values, the current economic situation, their relationship with you, and player initiated political interaction (plead, demand, threaten).

[h1]The game sports a variety of other features, to keep the gameplay interesting, including : [/h1]
[*] Tech tree (progress cloud), 
[*] Emergent events (multiple choices, choices can vary, results influenced by the conditions/charactersitics of your city/mayor), 
[*] City/district planning (location, zoning, infrastructure, etc), 
[*] Municipal service implementation (police, church, clinic, school, etc),
[*] Large scale works (ie railway, port, university, etc), 
[*] Economic planning (taxes, service funding, economic edicts, employment), 
[*] Governance (state laws, and edicts), 
[*] Citizen welfare (social life, health, education, fun etc), 
[*] Mayoral elections (start in 3rd era, a loss results in end
[*] Progress narrative told through events, newspaper clippings, tech etc.
[/List]

Plenty to do in the game, but little prompting to do it. If you are averse to being proactive (in a gameplay sense) or deducing the "why" behind a given in game result, then UE will quickly become frustrating for you. The game treads a fine line between deliberately obfuscating mechanics for the sake of immersion/depth, and not providing enough feedback on mechanics that really should be made available.  IMO it does not always get this mix right. Some of this is by design, but some is merely a lack of polish and will hopefully be corrected in time.

[h1]In short, a different take on an established genre (ie city buidling/governance), engaging for those that appreciate depth. Let down by late game performance issues, at times a lack of feedback, and noticeable incidences of primarily polish type bugs (missing tooltips, etc). [/h1]

[h1]For me it is refreshingly novel, both engaging and fun, if at times a little frustrating/perplexing. I recommend it.[/h1]

column8:
This is a strange one.

A mix of almost impenetrable mechanics, terrible UI, beautiful graphics, incredible atmosphere, intriguing plot, and strangely addictive gameplay.

It is not for the faint-hearted and took me over a week to start to understand how the deep game mechanics even work. That said, it is a really fascinating game, and one in which i became oddly invested in. There's something really satisfying about seeing your city grow and prosper, whilst you slowly introduce more and more technology and social changes.

As I said, a very atmospheric simulation, which I have spent over 41 hours on since release.

BUT....do not buy this game expecting it to be anything like a normal city builder - it is certainly not that.

Also, do not expect to understand the mechanics without reference to youtube videos. they are obscure to say the least. This issue is made much worse by the worst UI choices I have ever seen....improving profitability is expressed by a Negative number, highlighted by a red text box! Red=good in this game apparently. 

But, if you can stomach these issues, the game is really satisfying, and overall, worth the purchase, if only to experience a whole new Genre of game.

column8: Promising but flawed. Very little feedback on what is happening and the effects of your policies. Many aspects of the game are not documented at all. Could be good with some tweaking but not a 30$ game.

column8: I got this game refunded.  I am a fan of the tropico serie, civ and the like.  This game as a massive performance drop after 2nd era (check youtube, lots of reviewers with high end PCs reporting the problem), not patched in two weeks.  Also, I find this game boring and repetitive.  It looks like a great game, but it is not, in my opinion.  Not worth 45$

Vivement des mods :)

Don't buy this game. It's a nice idea that you have to pass almost every decision you make through a parliament-eske vote. But that is it. Repetitive mechanics kill any feeling of 'playful experimentation' from the beginning. This game excels at that.

I've read a comment from the developer that the player shall continue their experience further so that they can learn the true potential of this game. But, the longer you play the slimmer are your chances to get this game refunded. Really, as of now this game appears to be the same kind of vaporware/ripoff as No Man's Sky. I have no trust left for this kind of "trust me, my game is nice" developers charging a full price.

I'd rather pay 20$ for a Cities Skylines add-on featuring some city parliament which naturally limits your god-like mayorial powers than paying 45$ for THIS.

Useless game software  -- won't load saved games. When I contacted the game developers they referred me to Microsoft links that had nothing to do with my computer's software and did not solve the saved game problem.
  
 After a few weeks the game stopped running at all. Kalypso assured me that it could never have run on my computer (a false statement on Kalypso's part, since the game did run for many hours). 
  
 So I wasted my money on this game and can't recommend that others buy anything from Kalypso due to their unhelpful "tech support".

column8:
I really like the idea of Urban Empire. Trying to balance power in a parliament while building up your (city) empire is a great premise.

And the game starts of well enough. The graphic is nice and appropriate. The basic economy seems logical and interactions with the parties are clear to handle. Scripted events give additional flavor and decision.
You can plan out your city, grow and advance.
Later eras increase the complexity step by step.

But with more time with the game I cannot help but feel, that there is something fundamentally amiss.
It's not easy to pinpoint. There is not the one obvious thing that is broken. It feels like the game is obfuscating its issues, maybe unintentional. It definetly lacks in clarity. It does not feel that the developer had a clear user experience in mind. The interface is clunky, not very ergonomical and in some aspects not appropriate. Why are there no map overlays for coverages by infrastructure or services? That is the standard in city builders since years.
Even worse is the instruction on the game inner workings. Explanations are lacking or confusing.

In the end I wonder whever my decisions have any significant impact at all. It feels meaningless.

Nach knapp 5 Stunden Spielzeit musste ich leider feststellen, das der komplette Inhalt des Spieles absolut garnicht zusammen harmoniert.
Die Entscheidungen im Rat kommen wirrkÃ¼rlich und haben mit der momentanen Situation im Spiel nichts gemein.
Die Einnahmen und Ausgaben schwanken stÃ¤ndig extrem, ebenso schwankt die Zufriedenheit und das Verlangen der BÃ¼rger so dermassen das man Ã¼berhaupt nicht in der Lage ist angemessen zu reagieren!
Ohne Politische und bauliche einwirkung schwanken alle Parameter stÃ¤ndig extrem hin und her.

Die monatlichen Ausgaben fÃ¼r alles was man bauen,erschliessen kann, stehen absolut nicht im Einklang zu den Einnahmen.
Zumal die einzige Einnahmequelle nur die Steuern sind.
Dazu kommt das , dass Partei/Abstimmungssystem absolut verwirrend reagiert.
Es ist auch komischer weise immer die GrÃ¶sste Partei die gegen einen Stimmt.

Gute Idee, mehr als bescheidene Umsetzung !

Die Idee einer Stadtentwicklung, die stark durch Politik und Forschung beeinfluÃŸt wird, halte ich fÃ¼r sehr gut.
ABER 
- Bei politischen Entscheidungen kann man die Konsequenzen oft nur raten oder sie ausprobieren und dann neu laden.
- Autosave Intervall viel, viel, viel zu selten und nicht einstellbar
- Politische Entscheidungen sind zeitlich nicht angepasst, man erhÃ¤lt z.B. einen Nachlass von 25% auf die Dienstleistung   Post, in Epoche 1, fast am Anfang. Die Post, kann man aber erst in Epoche 2 bauen, wenn man sie erforscht hat.
Also erst Jahre spÃ¤ter !!
- Abstimmungen des Stadtrates werden zu gefÃ¼hlten 95% nur durch der Finanzlage der Stadt beeinfluÃŸt !
SteuererhÃ¶hungen werden bei negativer Stadtkasse durchgewunken und Dienstleistungen bei passender positiver Stadtkasse.
- Einnahmen erziehlt man ausschlieÃŸlich Ã¼ber Steuern !
 Also einfach, gleich am Anfang, Steuern rauf auf Max., die anderen Parteien einfach mehrfach bedrohen, bis sie "Ã¼berzeugt" sind und schon hat man erstmal mehr als genug Geld !
Meiner Erfahrung nach die beste und einzige MÃ¶glichkeit.

Mein Fazit :
Man hat, wie so oft, das GefÃ¼hl, das Spiel ist Ã¼berhaupt nicht getestet worden bzw. es wurde NUR auf Bugs getestet und NICHT auf Spielbarkeit, passende Kurzinfos, Motivation und logische ZusammenhÃ¤nge !
SOWAS erwarte ich bei einem 10â‚¬ Grabbeltischspiel, aber nicht bei einem Preis von Ã¼ber 40â‚¬ !
Leider gibt es von dieser Art Spielen mehr und mehr. Bringt wohl das schnelle Geld ?!!
ALSO bitte FINGER WEG und Geld fÃ¼r was besseres sparen !!
Sonst wird es bald nurnoch solche Spiele geben !

This is a really cool split off of a typical city simulation game. The fact that you have an era and technology tree along with political parties can be a bit overwhelming, however it's something that makes this game great and different from what you see in normal games.

column8:
Viel Erwartet, wenig bekommen.
Urban Empire, reizt einen Spieler nicht wirklich. !Spielzeit 16,5 Std!
Die Karte ist viel zu klein, um eine groÃŸe Stadt zu errichten. Das BaumenÃ¼ erinnert an die erste Version von SimCity (wenig Spielraum).
Hat man einmal Minus gemacht, streikt der Stadtrat. Sie stimmen gegen alle Erweiterungen der Stadt, obwohl diese machbar wÃ¤ren und sogar Geld in die Stadtkasse bringen. Der Ablauf ist immer gleich. Egal welche Familie man auswÃ¤hlt. 
Jede hat zwar ihre StÃ¤rken und SchwÃ¤chen aber diese sind nur minimal sodass sie fÃ¼r das eigentliche Spiel irrelevant sind.
Die Ein,- Ausgaben hat man schlecht im Auge, da keine Details aufgelistet werden, sondern nur Ein.- und Ausgaben gesamt angezeigt werden. 

Ich habe es immer nur bis ins Jahr 1950 geschafft, da in jede BÃ¼rgermeisterwahl gegen mich gestimmt worden ist.
Ich finde die Schwierigkeitsstufe deshalb etwas zu hoch. Diese kann man ebenfalls nicht einstellen. 

Die Grafik ist eher LowBugdet mÃ¤ÃŸig. Es erinnert nichts an die Grafik von Tropico und Co. 


Fazit:

Pro:
- Nette Aufmachung
- Demokratische Abstimmung im Rat

Kontra:
- Schlechte Grafik.
- Zu schwierige Level.
- Stadtrat stimmt nicht immer wie angezeigt (25 Pro / 11 Kontra = Antrag abgelehnt).
- BaumenÃ¼ zu vereinfacht (Kein Frairaum fÃ¼r den Spieler).
- Stadtmap zu klein / 3 Karten zur Auswahl
- Upgrade der Stadtviertel zu umstÃ¤ndlich (Jedes Stadtgebiet muss einzelnt Verbessert werden).
- Immer nur einen Antrag im Rat mÃ¶glich.
- Beeinflussung der Parteien hat keinen Einfluss auf die Stimmabgabe.
- Stadteinnahmen schwanken zu stark  von Monat zu Monat.
- Zu viele Wirtschaftskrisen / geringe MÃ¶glichkeit am Anfang Geld zu verdienen.
- Zu wenig Einfluss auf die Finanzen der Stadt
- Spielreiz geht sehr schnell verloren.

Urban Empire hat vielleicht das Potenzial ein gutes Stadtaufbauspiel mit demokratischem Hintergrund zu werden.
Aber momentan ist es leider einfach nur Geldverschwendung.

Sry, da bleib ich lieber bei Tropico =D

Terrible game, no fun, hassle, repeptetive overpriced stick to tropico. THIS IS A LOAD OF BOLONY PEOPLE COMPLETE RIPOFF  - IN MY OPINION btw I only write reviews when the games really bad and this is the first review ive ever written.

column8:
I really wanted to like this game and have played 5 games but it has no depth and is way to hard.
You start out, you make a good of money and think your doing great so you start adding police stations, schools and theatres etc and also electricity, gas and sewers but they don't enhance your citizens lives visibly or increase money made in any way. 

I have made it to age 3 on 4 occasions but everytime i start heamorrhaging money as citizens demand more services. If you provide, you lose massive amunts of money. If you don't you get voted out. 

Another irk is that building's don't change/grow over time. They just look the same as 1890 and 1930.
The game is simly too hard, lags riduculously once you reach age 3, and feels pointless.
All services are far too expensive. You install electicity as it says it helps business, the same goes for water pipes and phone lines but then businesses continue going bankrupt and you continue to lose money.

Kalypso need to put some serious work into fixing this.

I bought this game based on my love of previous games created by the developer. It falls short in all aspects of their previous games. It is not a city-builder, you click and drag and the "city" builds itself. The political angle they were going for sounds really cool but it is more of a hassel when actually using it. A lot of potential and fun could be there but sadly is not.

column8:
TLDR; Political bias, price, restricions, and hollowness ruin the game


*POTENTIAL RUINED*


It's a real shame because i wanted to like this game a lot. I love city builders like Cities: Skylines or sim city. Then adding the political twist! Wow sounds great... Right?

Well it just asn't executed correctly in my opinion. Everything feels hollow as all the choices you make almost mean nothing. It's just a balancing act of numbers, I never feel like I'm interacting with a real council, we don't even know the party leaders' names. 

Futhermore, this game basically forces you down the lefty root which is very, very frustraiting. Before I got this, I was exited. I wanted to be the local Hitler, ruling over all my people with brutality. But nope, there is almost no role playing. You are always forced down the same root of Fenminism, LGBT and all that stuff. And of course, there is no negatives at all for voting for them, but only positives. Even if you wanted to vote against LGBT rights, your council will probably put it through anyway. It's a real shame that the Devs put their political bias ahaead of a fun political game.

Big shame :(

However, Kalypso are known for pushing out 4 Â£20 DLC's for all their games so don't you worry! If you want an average game, you'll only have to fork out another Â£80 to them until you may actually have fun for a game which you already payed Â£35 for! (Feels more like a Â£10 indie game)


Dont buy!

3.5/10

[h1]Urban Empire[/h1]

Urban Empire is a game that promises to combine a great city builder with deep political roots. Does it stands up to its claims or buries itself in the ground, letâ€™s find out:

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]

Urban Empire is a game which tells you about the game that it was meant to be, not the one it actually is right now. A game with good city building mechanics like Cities: Skylines and having deep political mechanics like Crusader Kings II has been a dream game for many of us. To some extent, Urban Empire is a showcase of such a game.

 It starts off with style and intrigue. You choose one of the four races which are going to rule the city. All four of them are given proper backdrop and their lore differentiates them from one another perfectly. One might be a dictator type civ which believes in forcing rules on people to run the city peacefully while another is one which excel with communicating people but are relatively newer in politics and  does not have much clue what is going on. These strengths and weaknesses of the four races help you get invested in the start of Urban empire. After selecting one of these races, you can choose who is going to be the leader of the family and who are you going to play as. Till this point, Urban Empire makes you care about these factions and their leaders but it starts to falter when it comes to actual city building.

What we enjoyed about 2015â€™s Cities: Skylines and city builders of such quality are non existent here. Building and managing your cities are confined to some very simple mechanics . You place a district on the map, manage the cost it takes to maintain the district and bam youâ€™re done. There is little to no customization about this aspect of the game, a thing which sticks out as an open wound.

 The cash flow you get for building these districts is pretty nice and you donâ€™t need to worry about running out of cash until late into game when industrial revolution and such comes into play. The cities you build do not feel like actual cities which you built but more like cities which were made by themselves when you ordered. No managing of roads or actual in depth city building is present here.

What is the saving grace of the game and more or less the selling point is the political system. It is far more deeper than the city building mechanics and offer some challenge. As you move further in the game, factions start to split up and cause mayhem. You can select how your successor is raised and how they control the dynasty in the next era. It is not without its faults though.

 While the political system offers challenge and inserts some character in its dynasties, it is way too repetitive. You cannot expect to replay the game and see drastic changes from your first playthrough. Political parties more or less behave the same and do not offer anything different.

 You donâ€™t want to pay price for a retail game and then expect such short replayabilty from a game of a genre which is known for its replayable games. There are also some really long sections in the game where it feels like a monotonous affair without much achievement. The tutorial present in Urban Empire is also very short and does not introduces you to some of the major mechanics in the game. While Urban Empire has an interesting political system, just do not expect it to be on par with games like Crusader Kings or Europa Universalis. A lot of bugs and crashes also dampen the experience of the game. It constantly crashes to desktop or back to menu which deletes your progress constantly and makes it a frustrating experience.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]

Urban Empire impresses with its visuals. From the get go, you are introduced to a clean UI in the main menu. The faction logos and leaders are represented really well visually and shine throughout the game. The cities are dense and full of small details. They look good and are vibrant in nature. Colours pop out at you while you building and managing cities and the events, while plenty, never clutter up the screen to provide a pleasent gaming experience.

[h1]Sound[/h1]

One Word: Excellent. What Urban Empire doesnâ€™t show in its gameplay, it shows it in its sound design. From the ambient and epic soundtrack to the tense build up in the courts, Urban Empire provides solid sound design which compliments its visual design very well.

[h1]Overall:[/h1]

Urban Empire promises much and falls flat. From the bland city building aspect to the somewhat interesting but ultimately repetitive political system, Urban Empire never reaches up to the hype it creates itself. If it was a game which was released for a cheaper price and less promises, I wouldâ€™ve recommended trying it. But at a price like this, I expect more from a game. It needs polish and deeper systems. I would recommend getting this game at a sale where you can test it out for yourself but not in its current state.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]

Intriguing political mechanics

Solid visuals and sound design

[h1]Cons:[/h1]

Bland city-building

Repetitive in nature

Plenty of bugs

[h1]Rating: 45/100[/h1]


This review was brought to you by SaveorQuit. For more amazing reviews, previews and gaming news visit: [url=http://saveorquit.com/]SaveorQuit[/url]

It's sad... I had so high expectations and was awaiting a challenging, logical game with good mechanics.

What I got is a game, which didn't reach the potential of the script - and that's just sad.

I don't care much about the graphics, but when a game is so boring, I at least fant to be facinated by nice and logical graphics, simulation and animation - this is not the case.

I think if paradox made this game, it would have become outstanding - just look how the mechanics work in EU 4! That's the way you design a complex game!

The game feels like a cheap Free 2 play game... I wouldn't buy (and play) again. (played for about 1 hour, then deleted).

3/10

Fairly hard learning curve, and you currently aren't able to save during the "tutorial," which takes upwards of a few hours (god forbid you need to leave your house at some point in the day...). Overall, it feels as though the game wasn't quite field-tested enough before release, and certainly needs continual patching.

Since release, we've already seen a few patches, mostly fixing random, small bugs, rather than the larger problems in the game, such as lack of maps/map diversity, only having 4 families (character groups) to choose from, and the extremely disproportionate cost of things like infrastructue and amenities such as theatres to income potential. In addition, even if you play the tutorial to the end, a lot of the basic game mechanics go essentially unexplained, such as the importance of district infrastructure, density/spread, and how employment/business bankrupcy works.

It's definitely a good game, with a lot of potential, and I do recommend picking it up if it goes on sale, but it's not a must-have. With time, and a dev team that cares about fixing it, Urban Empire could definitely be a game to rival the great city-sims of the gaming world.

column8:
The concept is great, one I have often thought about and I give the developer kudos for trying to deliver it.  I feel like it will get to a better point soon with the patches.

The pros:
Voting and party goals are clear, persuasion seems pretty well done.
Reactive events based on city conditions are nice.
City advancing through time is pretty good as well.
Simulation is pretty deep in most places.
Historical accuracy seems pretty good.

The cons:
UI has missing tooltips, confusing tooltips, tons of information about stuff but does a poor job explaining what those numbers mean.  Very hard to figure out why businesses are doing well or poorly.
Social class seems tied strictly to education, too much education in your town and you run into a shortage of working class people and your businesses suffer from lack of efficiency, too little education and you run into a shortage of middle class people and your businesses suffer from lack of quality.  Could use some flexibility to let working class step up as managers and let middle class do manual labor and migrate classes that way.  An end game tech automation does help quite a lot to alleviate the problem of over education
District infrastructure... districts are expensive, infrastructure is expensive, and the benefits of infrastructure except for roads is so minor you can safely ignore building any.  Service buildings give so much more effect per cost.
Edicts generally have a fixed cost, so for a large city they can give huge boosts for almost no cost.  Somehow you can end up helping the poor for 10k a month with 10k poor in your city and they all end up with +20 cash to spend in your shops generating money from thin air.
Tax those people!  Taxing people doesn't seem to hurt them much at all, just keep raising the rates.  Not being able to afford basic goods isn't a problem as long as you can visit that nice library.  Businesses seem to react properly to taxes, but people really don't seem to care too much.  They also don't seem to mind being unemployed either.

Mixed:
The game is hard, I love that, but I'm sure many people don't.  Part of the difficulty is the poor UI, which is bad, but the balance of a lot of things makes it fairly difficult until you figure out how to exploit the things that aren't quite balanced right.  That said, the game really could use difficulty options.  There is a fairly organic difficulty based on how fast you try to grow/advance your city and going for the different win conditions, but the lack of any kind of difficulty setting is kind of strange.

After all that negative why am I recommending this game still?  I think it has potential.  It reminds me of older simulation games that are deep, complex, and challenging.  I feel like a bit of balance, polish, and tooltips could really improve the game.  I had a lot of fun playing it despite its flaws.  I'm one of those weird people who end up not liking a game with 99% positive reviews and likes a lot of games with mixed reviews.
column9:
The concept is great, one I have often thought about and I give the developer kudos for trying to deliver it.  I feel like it will get to a better point soon with the patches.

The pros:
Voting and party goals are clear, persuasion seems pretty well done.
Reactive events based on city conditions are nice.
City advancing through time is pretty good as well.
Simulation is pretty deep in most places.
Historical accuracy seems pretty good.

The cons:
UI has missing tooltips, confusing tooltips, tons of information about stuff but does a poor job explaining what those numbers mean.  Very hard to figure out why businesses are doing well or poorly.
Social class seems tied strictly to education, too much education in your town and you run into a shortage of working class people and your businesses suffer from lack of efficiency, too little education and you run into a shortage of middle class people and your businesses suffer from lack of quality.  Could use some flexibility to let working class step up as managers and let middle class do manual labor and migrate classes that way.  An end game tech automation does help quite a lot to alleviate the problem of over education
District infrastructure... districts are expensive, infrastructure is expensive, and the benefits of infrastructure except for roads is so minor you can safely ignore building any.  Service buildings give so much more effect per cost.
Edicts generally have a fixed cost, so for a large city they can give huge boosts for almost no cost.  Somehow you can end up helping the poor for 10k a month with 10k poor in your city and they all end up with +20 cash to spend in your shops generating money from thin air.
Tax those people!  Taxing people doesn't seem to hurt them much at all, just keep raising the rates.  Not being able to afford basic goods isn't a problem as long as you can visit that nice library.  Businesses seem to react properly to taxes, but people really don't seem to care too much.  They also don't seem to mind being unemployed either.

Mixed:
The game is hard, I love that, but I'm sure many people don't.  Part of the difficulty is the poor UI, which is bad, but the balance of a lot of things makes it fairly difficult until you figure out how to exploit the things that aren't quite balanced right.  That said, the game really could use difficulty options.  There is a fairly organic difficulty based on how fast you try to grow/advance your city and going for the different win conditions, but the lack of any kind of difficulty setting is kind of strange.

After all that negative why am I recommending this game still?  I think it has potential.  It reminds me of older simulation games that are deep, complex, and challenging.  I feel like a bit of balance, polish, and tooltips could really improve the game.  I had a lot of fun playing it despite its flaws.  I'm one of those weird people who end up not liking a game with 99% positive reviews and likes a lot of games with mixed reviews.

After some discussions in the community forums, I've copied my review/comment - I might change this once a few bugs are fixed.

Just as a mid-game review and some context: I got the game for free as a gift. I casually mentioned seeing this game from a sponsored youtube pre-release let's play copy to a friend, and they bought it for me. I feel bad, because I wouldn't have paid for this myself. 

Currently would not recommend and here are my reasons
- encountered at least one graphical bug, I have a GTX1080 on a new rig, running everything Ultra at 4K 60fps fine, but then there are these weird glitches:
http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198042237959/screenshot/97226806231905121

- silly game breaking save bug: most people play games with a tutorial on. The first time you play this game, I guarantee you most players will not have $2m to buy the Train Station when it pops up in the tutorial. At which point, because there's an active tutorial quest, you can't save. Sure you can go into negative and beg the emperor for money, but most people playing for the first time don't want to throw their city into debt. Perhaps it was bad luck on my part, but I had the graphical glitch happen at that time too. Didn't know what to do, so wanted to save, quit and re-load. But couldn't save, so just gave up and restarted with tutorial off after reading through work-around on the forums

- as other people have mentioned, the game does not explain a lot of the concepts in the game. You have to either cross your fingers or trial-and-error your decisions. This isn't that the game is hard, it just isn't streamlined and doesn't provided you enough information to be a political simulator OR a city builder. Why does that party hate you? I have no idea. I can only guess and try to enact some of the policies they want. Increasing the density of my district will increase upkeep by 100K+, what are the benefits? 

- beyond not having enough information, some of the wording is very strange. Perhaps it's because the dev team's first-language isn't English? For example, -5% sales demand is a good thing. This is a bit counter intuitive, as decrease in sales demand is usually bad for an economy especially when inflation is not a concept in the game. Also an example of one policy says "mild punishment for sodomy". In fact, this policy is to have MILDER punishment for sodomy, rather than saying let's punish sodomy mildly as the policy name implies.

- when there should be information but it doesn't show. When a proposal pops up, sometimes (shoudl be all the time) you can hover over the options and it will show you what the effects will be, as an example, one policy will pop up and it'll have 3 options. You might be able to hover over none, 1, 2, and very rarely 3 of the options. This seems unintentional, and some of the effects and proposals don't line up with the flavour text. 

- immersion: the cost scaling is a bit ridiculous; it costs a LOT of money to install street lamps and pave roads. Upkeep is also ridiculously expensive, to the point that I'm now in Era 3, 1930s and I have districts which still have dirt paths and no lights. I can afford a train station, but I can't afford to pave the roads.

BUT. If you can get past all these, the base idea behind the game is pretty fun. Balancing the political ideologies (left/right, liberal/conservative) as well as a little bit of roleplaying a family of mayors, allegiance to the Empire or independence, and balancing personal finances is quite unique. The broken parts of the game (other than the graphic bugs), can be avoided once you've played the game a few times through and know what to avoid, or in the case of not knowing what a decision will do, you can pretend it's real life and not know the outcomes of your decisions beforehand. Hopefully the game does get patched, but I whole heartedly agree, we shouldn't expect to wait for a patch before a game is recommended.

column8:
Guiding a city through 200 years of development while you wheel and deal to stay in power sounds fantastic. Unfortunately this just doesn't live up to the concept. You spend most of your time waiting for technology to develop, pushing through edicts that don't seem to ever have any real downsides and occassionally updating your districts with new infrustructure that will most likely send you into bankrupcy.

The scale and scenario just don't seem right, it's more town neighbourhood management rather than city management, a bigger city with less control would have actually been more interesting and would then make more sense as to why every area needed to be plugged into the grid seperately. There's alot of stats showing which districts are voting  which way but if there's a way influence this significantly i haven't found it. Also each era wipes out these trends and replaces them without any seemily coherent logic.

Lastly there's just alot of rough edges to this game, tooltips that occassionaly tell you what will happen with a choice but not always. A storyline that's meant to be about each of these ruling families in the city but which seems completely disconnected from the rest of the game (and very under-baked). 

Hopefully other developers take this concept and run with it because there's definitely something here, unfortunately this just doesn't feel like anything other than a good concept.

column8: After several games of total puzzlement I got it. It's a game about keeping your powder dry, choosing when to apply leverage to the politians, choosing when to use your own funds to make changes... if you want a light city builder, this isn't for you. It's in depth, it's for players that like playing the long game.

I'd say that the overall concept of the game is great, however, it failed to deliver (for now). I feel that the game should most definitely be in Early Access. There seems to be a lot of stuff missing as well as multiple ongoing issues with what is already released. Furthermore, the game seems to be EXTREMELY taxing on my system, which it shouldn't given what little seems to be running. At times it's pulling way too much RAM as well as utilizing 100% of my GPU. For the size of the map and the relatively limited options presented in the game, it's hard to understand why the game is so taxing. 

Overall I would NOT recommend purchasing the game until they fix the current issues with it.
column9:

This is a game based on a great idea and that have the basic feature of a promising game. It's clearly not finished. There is many thing to add and to correct. 
First, the pace. After a fey playthrough, I feel that science is going a bit weirdly. When I was at the 4th age, evens talked about computer, but my city was still without electricity... An other time, I arrived in the 60' without having upgraded any road or anything... 
Second, party act a bit weirdly and unpredicably. There is no clear link between district and election of one or another party. I wanted to have a very egalitarian city, with no "upper class" district with more services... and there was none... but I wasn't able to see if it has any effect in the election... and there is absolutely no info about the relation between the population and the party...
Third, I felt in many games that I even had no effect of the party themselves. I wanted to be close to one and he was rejecting me for no reason...
Forth, and it was noted in many review, the policies are not clearly organised on party lines...

Still, I recommend the game, because the idea is good, it is still fun and, like the game from paradox like Europa Universalis and Crusader kings, I have hope that it's just a vanilla game on wich will be built many DLC that will make this game great again! ;)
column9:
This is a game based on a great idea and that have the basic feature of a promising game. It's clearly not finished. There is many thing to add and to correct. 
First, the pace. After a fey playthrough, I feel that science is going a bit weirdly. When I was at the 4th age, evens talked about computer, but my city was still without electricity... An other time, I arrived in the 60' without having upgraded any road or anything... 
Second, party act a bit weirdly and unpredicably. There is no clear link between district and election of one or another party. I wanted to have a very egalitarian city, with no "upper class" district with more services... and there was none... but I wasn't able to see if it has any effect in the election... and there is absolutely no info about the relation between the population and the party...
Third, I felt in many games that I even had no effect of the party themselves. I wanted to be close to one and he was rejecting me for no reason...
Forth, and it was noted in many review, the policies are not clearly organised on party lines...

Still, I recommend the game, because the idea is good, it is still fun and, like the game from paradox like Europa Universalis and Crusader kings, I have hope that it's just a vanilla game on wich will be built many DLC that will make this game great again! ;)

column8:
Pros: .Theres alot of gametime experimenting with different strategies and figuring out what works best

Cons: .The most profitable industry is one with no infastructure. If you have 100% industry districts and upgrade, you'll make less money.

.Each change in era causes massive changes. I was doing great then it changed to era 4. commercial demand shot up, industry and residential plumeted, happiness and goodwill took a hit and there was nothing i could to to win.

.Tutorial only hits the tip of the iceberg of what you need to know. eg. efficiency is determined by happiness of lower and working class, and quality is determined by elites and middle class. Commercial can take care of most of you citizens demands if your taxing is right etc...

.Pricetag. Even if these issues were resolved, this game is only worth $30

Don't get me wrong, I am not one of those people who is giving a negative review because I suck at it. I have had very successful cities. The balance and other aspects of this game just make no sense.
column9:

Don't get me wrong, I am not one of those people who is giving a negative review because I suck at it. I have had very successful cities. The balance and other aspects of this game just make no sense.

column8:
Had high hopes, but overall this game just seems lackluster. You spend WAY too much time waiting on "Counting Votes..." screen. Even when the outcome is obvious, [i]every single decision[/i] in the game has to be voted on by the council; that much is fine, but having to wait at a "Counting Votes..." screen for all 60+ members to vote every single time is painstakingly boring. 

Moreover, after 3 playthroughs, I never felt like I got a grasp on how the economy works at all. It wasn't self-evident in the slightest, and I could never get a stable cashflow, and I was clueless as to what was going wrong.

On two of my playthroughs, I couldn't even make it to the end of the game. One in particular was frustrating because all the different citizen needs/desires on the "wheel of life" were all positive. I was making everyone happy (and had a huge treasury reserve with a positive cash flow) and suddenly the council voted me out as mayor... which immediately ends the game. These kinds of interactions where stuff doesn't go as you'd expect and there's just no way to make sense as to why things are happening that way, plague the game. There is a tutorial mode, but it doesn't do a good job at explaining the underlying economy, supply/demand, or any of that.

Additionally, the political simulation seemed like it was on rails. The council would recommend something, like "Ability for citizens to form corporations" and the vote would fail. The next month, they'd suggest it again, and the vote would fail... this would go on for [b]years[/b] and every time it pauses your game and you have to watch the "Counting Votes..." screen.

As for feeling like I was my own mayor... I was really disappointing in how that worked, probably from my own lack of understanding how the game was designed. I thought that [b]I[/b] could be a mayor, but in this game that's not the case. Rather, you play already created characters, with their own backstories and agendas. You can make small tweaks here or there, but I was saddened by the lack of customization, for lack of a better work, which kept me from feeling immersed in the sim.

column9: Halfway through the game, the tutorial prompted me to choose a new technology tree, but I had already clicked on the technology. Then I couldn't complete the tutorial and couldn't continue. If I didn't continue with the technology, I couldn't complete it either. It formed an endless loop, and I couldn't save. More than an hour of my life was wasted like this!!!

column8:
This game is refreshingly new, and deep. At the beginning of the game you are the emperors nominee, meaning that you easily can force your will through the council. But as time passes, the more complex political landscape gets to you. Do you cling to your personal values, at the risk of alienating the powerful Christian Democratic party? What if you use all your political powers to stop the 10-hour workday, to protect your income, you risk beeing left helpless at the mayoral elections, and being voted out of office.

I see people compare it to Civilization and Democracy III. It is clearly way better than Democracy III, but it is to different from Civilization to make the comparison. Further, if you think that this is the vanilla version(and it is awesome!), things are only going to get better! (remember the launch of Sim-City anyone?)

column8:
I love the game concept, but the whole experience is destryoed by several factors:
1. The devs forgot to add an option for wether you want "full-screen" or "windowed". Now, after I changed the graphics for the first time, I for some reason got permanent windowed mode, which is VERY annoying..
2. The game does not support Magic Mouse AT ALL! It only reacts to the scrolling about 20 % of the time, which makes a great mouse useless in Windows.
3. I got a high-end computer, still the graphics is very choppy, about 15-20 frames/sec on medium settings (got 3.0 ghz i7 with 16gb of rams).

Please fix these issues to make the user experience much better. As for now, this is a totally unplayable game for me :/

[h1]EnttÃ¤uschend[/h1]

[b]Wo ist die Herausforderung?[/b]

Angefixt von einigen Let's Plays und der AnkÃ¼ndigung eines neuen Spielkonzepts, habe ich mir das Spiel mit Release zugelegt. Als Liebhaber von Aufbau-, Strategie- und WiSim Spielen, hat es mich sehr gereizt Urban Empire zu zocken. Die Spielidee fand ich Ã¤uÃŸerst Interessant. Allerdings kam recht schnell die ErnÃ¼chterung, um nicht zu sagen Langeweile. Das Spielprinzip ist sehr einfach. 
[b]Achtung Spoiler[/b] Solange man Geld hat und ein positives monatliches Einkommen, kann man machen was man will, man bekommt so gut wie jede Verordnung durch den Stadtrat. Danach verwaltet man nur noch. Klickt sich von Verordnung zu Verordnung. Schraubt ein wenig an Steuern und Finanzierung. Dazu am Anfang auf Bildungspunkte achten und man erforscht in Rekordzeit neue Technologien. So kommt es vor, dass man schon in den 1950ern den Laptop einer Parteiabgeordneten ausspioniert.

[b]Apropos Parteien[/b]
Es wird einem zwar angezeigt, wo die Partei steht (links-liberal, recht-konservativ etc), aber so richitg interessiert es die Parteimitglieder nicht. Sie sind ziemlich leicht zu beeinflussen und weichen von der Parteilinie recht schnell ab. Hauptsache man hat genÃ¼gend Wohlwollen, was recht schnell zu erreichen ist. Ich habe genau 1x mal meine Spionage ausgespielt, aber auch nur um zu testen, wie sich das verhÃ¤lt.

[b]Stadtentwicklung?[/b]
Wie schon angemerkt, ist das Spielkonzept sehr einfach gehalten. Die ersten 100 Jahre gibt es eine groÃŸe Nachfrage nach Industrie, was historisch ja auch korrekt ist. Man baut dann einfach an die StadtrÃ¤nder seine Industriebezirke. Allerdings wird sich am Bedarf nix Ã¤ndern. In meiner ersten Partie als "Shuysky" habe ich alles erforscht, war immer Pro-Technologie, aber die Stadt hat sich nicht von einer Industrie- zu einer Dienstleistungsstadt weiterentwickelt. So war auch noch 2030 der Industriebedarf enorm hoch und meine 6 Industriebezirke rauchten frÃ¶hlich vor sich hin. Ich musste in knapp 200 Jahren, bei keinem Bezirk die Zoneneinteilung verÃ¤ndern.

[b]Fazit[/b]
Nach 18 Stunden war ich mit meiner ersten Familie durch die 5 Epochen geritten. GroÃŸe Herausforderungen sind mir dabei nicht begegnet. DafÃ¼r ist das Spiel zu Eindimensional und linear. So ploppen immer die gleichen Ereignisse zur gleichen Zeit auf, egal welche Familie man spielt. Das kann man gut bei den diversen Let`s Plays vergleichen. Solange sich am Spiel nichts dramatisches Ã¤ndert, fehlt mit die Motivation es noch mal mit einer anderen Familie zu spielen.
Eine wirklich nette und spannende Idee wurde fÃ¼r mich leider nicht zufriedenstellend umgesetzt und es hat keinerlei Langzeitmotivation und Wiederspielbarkeitswert. DafÃ¼r ist der Preis recht ordentlich und dÃ¼rfte einige AbzÃ¼ge beim Wohlwollen einbringen.

column9: isnt what i paid for

column8:
In a nutshell, while I did enjoy this game enough to give it a positive, it certainly deserves the MIXED reaction.

At a glance, Urban Empire is a city builder, but is billed a "city ruler". This is kind of true in some ways, but the actual mechanics behind the political side are very, very shallow. The general premise of the game is that you have to manage a town across 200 years, from the Industrial Revolution to modern times, while juggling the personal lives of your family thorugh decision-based events that don't really affect the game much, but add some flavour.

The appeal in the game is, as with many city builders, figuring out how to do it right. There's satisfaction in getting a good cashflow, seeing happiness go up and optimising your districts. There's enough there to keep you hooked if you know the basics of not crashing your economy.

The problem is that the game has VERY POOR player feedback. It doesn't really set you in the right direction - in fact, the in-game tutorial tips set you up to fail right away. There is a sore lack of tooltips, and many icons simply don't make sense at a glance. The exact relationship between residential, commercial and industrial demand is not made clear to the player. The underlying mechanics do seem solid, but they're not presented in a meaningful way to the player. As a result, it's very easy to make a poor decision and put yourself into an economic doom spiral.

This is the main reason why most people dislike the game. The interface does not tell you what you want to know and need to know, nor are you given any guidance when your city begins to decline and you have no idea what you did or how to fix it.

If you put in enough time to "guess" what you're meant to do to stay in the green, then you reach that level of contentedness, but there are other problems.

The game seriously lags in later eras. The game speed slows down dramatically, even on powerful PCs.

The political system is easy to beat. There's no need to do any of the political subplot events. Have enough money and goodwill and they'll past nearly every (good) law you bring up. The fact that EVERYTHING you do has to go through the council vote is extremely tedious when 99% of your decisions are guaranteed to pass provided you don't do anything stupid. I do wish there was a more streamlined way to get through the game without having to bring up the Council screen every few seconds.

Overall, while I found the game fun enough, the lack of guidance and feedback for the player is an instant-quit for many.
column9:
In a nutshell, while I did enjoy this game enough to give it a positive, it certainly deserves the MIXED reaction.

At a glance, Urban Empire is a city builder, but is billed a "city ruler". This is kind of true in some ways, but the actual mechanics behind the political side are very, very shallow. The general premise of the game is that you have to manage a town across 200 years, from the Industrial Revolution to modern times, while juggling the personal lives of your family thorugh decision-based events that don't really affect the game much, but add some flavour.

The appeal in the game is, as with many city builders, figuring out how to do it right. There's satisfaction in getting a good cashflow, seeing happiness go up and optimising your districts. There's enough there to keep you hooked if you know the basics of not crashing your economy.

The problem is that the game has VERY POOR player feedback. It doesn't really set you in the right direction - in fact, the in-game tutorial tips set you up to fail right away. There is a sore lack of tooltips, and many icons simply don't make sense at a glance. The exact relationship between residential, commercial and industrial demand is not made clear to the player. The underlying mechanics do seem solid, but they're not presented in a meaningful way to the player. As a result, it's very easy to make a poor decision and put yourself into an economic doom spiral.

This is the main reason why most people dislike the game. The interface does not tell you what you want to know and need to know, nor are you given any guidance when your city begins to decline and you have no idea what you did or how to fix it.

If you put in enough time to "guess" what you're meant to do to stay in the green, then you reach that level of contentedness, but there are other problems.

The game seriously lags in later eras. The game speed slows down dramatically, even on powerful PCs.

The political system is easy to beat. There's no need to do any of the political subplot events. Have enough money and goodwill and they'll past nearly every (good) law you bring up. The fact that EVERYTHING you do has to go through the council vote is extremely tedious when 99% of your decisions are guaranteed to pass provided you don't do anything stupid. I do wish there was a more streamlined way to get through the game without having to bring up the Council screen every few seconds.

Overall, while I found the game fun enough, the lack of guidance and feedback for the player is an instant-quit for many.

column8:
It was fun, but definitely not worth it. There are so many limitations, it's hard to know where to start.

I find working with the city council to be fun, interesting, and definitely a high point in the game. Though, they could use a bit of tweaking since after awhile, they'll agree to any tax hike.

The worse part of the game is the actual gameplay - you can't do a whole lot except build more districts and upgrade them one at a time. The economy also needs some serious tweaking since building districts is the only way to get more money. And don't even think about offering infrastructure for your people or you'll run out of money.

I think this game could be a lot better if a few additional dynamics were added:
1. Talking to concern citizens who would like your to grant permits, endorse their business, or to mingle with them (parties, balls, etc)
2. Some ability to deal with the press would be a nice change of pace. How your interactions impacts your relations with the city council
3. More district control - would make this a way better game. Instead, all I can determine is density and zoning
4. Interactions with the outside world - The Emperor requests you to take in refugees? Crime issue? Things that an actual mayor has to deal with?

In any case. The game is a great concept - but it's too limited, too plain, and just not worth the money. Maybe wait for it to go on sale or something.

column8: Giocato molte piÃ¹ ore di quelle descritte nel mio profilo (spesso gioco offline e forse quel "tempo di gioco non viene conteggiato), lo consiglio per gli amanti del genere simulazione/gestionali come me. Forse un po ostico all'inizio per via della lingua per noi itialiani che nella maggior parte dei casi leggiamo/conosciamo e abbiamo un inglese "scolastico" o  non perfettamente fluido. Se viene rilasciata una patch con LINGUA ITALIANA il gioco prenderebbe una fetta piÃ¹ grande di pubblico. Capisco la grandezza dei mercati esteri che vendono piÃ¹ che in Italia, ma fa veramente impressione vedere quasi sempre all'inizio del rilascio dei giochi che sono presenti il RUSSO E persino IL CINESE, mentre dobbiamo confidare in qualche brava squadra di ragazzi italiani per trovare su internet la nostra amata lingua nazionale.
column9: I've played many more hours than I've listed in my profile (I often play offline, so that "playtime" might not count). I recommend it for simulation/management game lovers like me. It might be a little difficult at first because of the language, especially for Italians who mostly read/know English and have "school-level" or less-than-fluent English. If a patch with ITALIAN LANGUAGE is released, the game would attract a larger audience. I understand the size of foreign markets, which outsell Italian, but it's truly shocking to see RUSSIAN and even CHINESE almost always appear at the start of game releases, while we have to rely on some talented team of Italians to find our beloved national language online.

column8:
UPDATE: Nach mehreren Fixes und Updates seitens der Spielemacher, habe ich Urban Empire nochmal ausprobiert. Fazit: JA, es ist technisch spielbarer geworden. NEIN, die Kernprobleme zu Schwierigkeit und Benutzerfreundlichkeit sind meines Empfindens nach nicht gelÃ¶st. Es ist immer noch zu schwierig eine funktionierende und florierende Gemeinde zu erstellen, da Dienstleistungen weiterhin zu teuer, Stadtviertel-Verbesserungen ebenfalls weiter zu kostpsielig, BÃ¼rger zu anspruchsvoll und der Stadtrat zu hinderlich sind. Weiterhin bleibt man phasenweise vÃ¶llig machtlos der Ki der Parteien ausgeliefert und glotzt auf eine mehr oder weniger ansehnliche Siedlung herab, die nichts mit den Screenshots und Versprechungen der Macher gemein hat.

Alter Review steht untenan. Ich empfehle das Spiel weiterhin nicht.

____________________________________________________________________________

EnttÃ¤uschend. Ich hatte so gehofft, dass dieses Spiel gut wird- zumal ich mich erst mit dem Support auseinandersetzen musste, weil mein Kauf nicht klappte und die Bearbeitung des Problems sich mit dem Release Ã¼berschnitt.

Wo liegen die grÃ¶ÃŸten Probleme?

-Die Parteien handeln vÃ¶llig schwachsinnig. Mal entsprechend ihrer eigentlich zu vermutenden Ãœberzeugung, mal vÃ¶llig gegenlÃ¤ufig- da lehnt auch gerne mal eine Arbeiterpartei Arbeitsschutzgesetze ab. oder die Gesamtheit der Parteien stellen sich gegen ein Volksbegehren (beispielsweise die Forderung nach einem Theater, das sich die Stadt problemlos leisten kÃ¶nnte).

-Das Aufwerten der Stadtviertel ist so dermaÃŸen teuer, dass es einen entweder ruiniert, oder man es lieber gleich lÃ¤sst. Problem nur, dass ohne diese Verbeserungen das "Wheel of Life" stÃ¤ndig nur Minuswerte in Sachen Zufriedenheit prÃ¤sentiert. Die herrlichen Stadtansichten von den Screenshots sind so gut wie unmÃ¶glich zu erarbeiten- mir ist immernoch schleierhaft, wie andere das hinbekommen. 

-Die Entwicklung der Wirtschaft ist nicht nachvollziehbar. Teilweise stehen Fabriken einige Jahre voll im Saft, um dann ohne Vorwarnung en gros pleite zu gehen und wiederum jahrelang pleite zu bleiben.
Bei Gewerben sieht es genauso aus. Um den Unternehmen beider Wirtschaftszweige jedoch zu helfen, mÃ¼sste man die Stadtviertel upgraden- das fÃ¼hrt uns zurÃ¼ck zu Punkt zwei.

-Das Stadtwachstum stagniert 90% der Zeit und man kann kaum etwas dagegen tun.
Kein Mensch oder Unternehmen will in die Stadt ziehen? Tja- Pech. Warum das so ist? Was geht dich als BÃ¼rgermeister das an?

-Das Spiel scheint insgesamt zu schwer und dadurch werden Motivation und Flow gestÃ¶rt. Wenn man zwei Drittel der Zeit in einer stagnierenden Stadt sitzt, die kaum Geld erwirtschaftet, der Rat verrÃ¼ckt spielt und einem nur Steine in den Weg legt, verliert man irgendwann die Lust am Spiel. 

-Die Epochen sind zu kurz- zumindes die frÃ¼hen. Es ist der selbe Fehler, der schon das Potential von Tropico 5 verschleuferte. Mag sein, dass fÃ¼r manche Casual-Player die Spieldynamik dadurch kÃ¼nstlich erhÃ¶ht wird, aber den StÃ¤dte-Sim-Liebhaber stÃ¶rt das eher.

-Die politischen Ãœberzeugungen der Entwickler machen ein wirklich "freies" Spiel nicht mÃ¶glich. Man kann nicht- ungeachtet der tatsÃ¤chlichen politischehn Ãœberzeugung im Real-Life- einfach mal als Konservativer, Royalist oder GemÃ¤ÃŸigter spielen, da man im ersten Falle immer "grausam" ist, der Verbleib beim Kaiserreich oder der Einfluss auf dessen Erhalt reiner Schein und das Schicksal des Reichs bereits vorherbestimmt ist und man in letzterem Fall kaum HandlungsmÃ¶glichkeiten zur VerfÃ¼gung hat.

Das sind nur einige der Punkte, auf die ich bisher gestoÃŸen bin. Es macht mich traurig und wÃ¼tend zugleich, denn das Spielprinzip hat Potential. Die Entwickler sollten dringend an einer Ãœberarbeitung werkeln, sonst kÃ¶nnen sie dieses Spiel getrost abschreiben- ebenso sÃ¤mtliche potentiellen DLCs. FÃ¼r den Preis von 44 Euro ist es geradezu eine UnverschÃ¤mtheit.
Das Spiel ist kompliziert, zu schwer und- was wohl das Schlimmste ist: Langweilig und frustrierend.

Schade.
column9:
UPDATE: After several fixes and updates from the game developers, I tried Urban Empire again. Conclusion: YES, it has become technically more playable. NO, the core problems regarding difficulty and usability have not been resolved in my opinion. It's still too difficult to create a functioning and thriving community, as services remain too expensive, district improvements too costly, citizens too demanding, and the city council too obstructive. Furthermore, at times, you remain completely powerless, at the mercy of the parties' AI, staring down at a more or less respectable settlement that bears nothing in common with the screenshots and promises made by the developers.

The old review is below. I still don't recommend the game.

____________________________________________________________________________

Disappointing. I had so hoped this game would be goodâ€”especially since I had to deal with support first because my purchase failed and the resolution of the issue overlapped with the release.

What are the biggest problems?

-The parties act completely foolishly. Sometimes in accordance with their supposed beliefs, sometimes completely contrary to them â€“ a labor party even occasionally rejects labor protection laws, or all parties oppose a popular initiative (for example, the demand for a theater that the city could easily afford).

-Upgrading neighborhoods is so expensive that it either ruins you or you're better off not bothering at all. The only problem is that without these improvements, the "Wheel of Life" constantly presents negative happiness scores. The beautiful city views from the screenshots are virtually impossible to recreate â€“ I'm still baffled by how others manage it.

-The economic development is incomprehensible. Factories sometimes operate at peak performance for a few years, then go bankrupt en masse without warning, and then remain bankrupt for years.
It's the same with businesses. However, to help businesses in both sectors, the city districts would have to be upgraded â€“ which brings us back to point two.

-City growth stagnates 90% of the time, and there's little you can do about it.
No one or business wants to move to the city? Well, tough. Why is that? What does that have to do with you as mayor?

-The game seems too difficult overall, and this disrupts motivation and flow. If you spend two-thirds of your time in a stagnant city that barely generates any money, the council goes crazy, and only throws obstacles in your way, you'll eventually lose interest in the game.

-The eras are too short â€“ at least the early ones. This is the same mistake that squandered the potential of Tropico 5. It may be that this artificially increases the game dynamics for some casual players, but it's more of a nuisance for city sim enthusiasts.

-The developers' political convictions make a truly "free" game impossible. You can't simply play as a conservative, royalist, or moderateâ€”regardless of your actual real-life political persuasionâ€”because in the former case, you're always "cruel," remaining in the Empire or influencing its preservation is purely an illusion, and the fate of the empire is already predetermined. In the latter case, you have hardly any options available.

These are just a few of the issues I've encountered so far. It makes me sad and angry at the same time, because the gameplay has potential. The developers should urgently work on an overhaul, otherwise they can safely write off this gameâ€”as well as all potential DLCs. For the price of â‚¬44, it's downright outrageous.
The game is complicated, too difficult, andâ€”worst of allâ€”boring and frustrating.

What a shame.
