Bisher nicht zu empfehlen, viel zu langweilig, nicht mehr als City Skylines o.Ã„.
Der Stadtrat ist ein netter Einfall, der aber kaum was bringt, da er eh allem zustimmt. Wenn man Miese macht, stimmt er fast jeder SteuererhÃ¶hung zu, wenn man im Plus ist, kann man bauen/Ã¤ndern was man will. Die Forschung kommt mir nicht sehr Einfluss nehmend vor da man pro Epoche locker alles erforschen kann. Es kann natÃ¼rlich sein, dass ich die "KomplexitÃ¤t" nicht ganz verstanden habe, was erforschte GebÃ¤ude etc angeht, das liegt aber dann wenn am bescheidenen und einem Tutorial, was in dem Fall dann einfach nicht tiefgreifend genug ist. Die BedÃ¼rfnisse der BevÃ¶lkerung lassen sich locker hoch halten und es steht nirgends geschrieben, warum es wichtig ist welche Partei die Wahl gewinnt etc. Es mag bei knappen Abstimmungen eine Rolle spielen, davon hatte ich aber bisher zu weniger als das es mich interesiert hÃ¤tte, welche Partei wieviele Sitze hat.

Dann kommt hinzu dass man nicht bei allen Ereignissden den Tooltipp bekommt, was man bei welcher Auswahl bekommt., sondern nur ab und zu mal. Da sollten sich die Entwickler auf eine Linie festlegen.

Ich bereue es schon fast es mehr als 2 Stunden gespielt zu haben um meine 40 Euro nicht zurÃ¼ckerstatten lassen zu kÃ¶nnen.....

Dieses Spiel hat masives Potenzial, aber ich merke das die Entwickler entweder keine Ahnung von Politik und City-Builder haben, oder sich einfach zu wenig Zeit dafÃ¼r genommen haben.

Ich nenne nun GrÃ¼nde warum ich dieses Spiel nicht empfehlen wÃ¼rde:

[u]Politik[/u]

-Es ist einfach nur langweiliges Gewarte auf ein Gesetz wo sie sowieso zustimmen werden.
-Die Parteien handeln meiner Meinung nach sehr fragwÃ¼rdig

[u]Nachfrage[/u]

-Sie reagiert sehr seltsam bis garnicht, obwohl ich nach der Nachfrage baue sinkt sie garnicht. Bezirke kann man bauen wie man will, sie entweder steigen sie trodzdem und sinken danach garnicht mehr.

[u]Finanzen[/u]

-Die Dienstleistungen sind mit so hohen mit Ausgaben eingestellt das man keine MÃ¶glichkeit hat sich Zeitlich anzupassen.
Strom, Gas ja sogar Wasserleitungen lassen sich sogar in den modernen Zeiten nicht bauen.

[u]Bugs[/u]

-Es kommt vor das sich das Spiel plÃ¶tzlich auf Englisch umstellt.
-Ã–fter bin ich im BaumenÃ¼ festgehangen
-(Siehe Nachfrage) Nachfrage verbugt sich auch nur

[u]Preis-Leistung[/u]

Selbst auf Keyseiten finde ich die Preise zu teuer fÃ¼r die erbrachte Leistung des Spiels. Es ist sehr eintÃ¶nig selbst fÃ¼r den Pre-Order Preis gewesen, und ich hab immer noch nicht verstanden was das Pre-Order DLC macht.

Sobald die Kriterien Ã¼berarbeitet und verbessert wurden, wÃ¼rde ich mir das Spiel nochmal antun

column9:
The replay value of this game is roughly the pre-sale price, plus one decimal point.
I thought it was a more immersive version of SimCity, but once I started playing, I realized it was just a mini-game full of threats and flattery against various political parties.
You want to experience city planning? Sorry, that's not available. The smallest building unit is the neighborhood, and even the roads are left to the computer's default, crooked and irregular. Even if you want to fine-tune the layout of residential, commercial, and industrial zones, sorry, you can only adjust the proportions of each zone, and you can't control where they appear in the neighborhood.
You want to experience urban development? Sorry, that's not available either. No need to pull up a network of pipes, just click on each neighborhood, which is so boring... Can't I have a unified city-wide plan, unified funding, and unified construction?
As for the rest, what else is there to play? Wait, wait until time passes, new technology is developed, and then, maybe, new laws will be passed. Initiate bills, and flatter each party every two weeksâ€”and that flattery doesn't offer anything new; it's been the same two options for centuries...

I can only say that its playability is about the same as a mobile game, even worse than many excellent mobile games.

The only bright spot is probably the built-in Chinese language...

Summary: Don't fall for it!

column8:
Hey guys, I have played this game for quite some hours now and these are my thoughts about the game.

At first the game is really promising. The concept is great and I was really looking forward to it.

First problems first, the game is badly optimized I cannot get through the second part of the game (lag). I have read the forums and this seems to be happening a lot to people. So if you do not have a good pc do not buy the game at this moment.

Then in my first playthroughs I was really struggling getting the hang of the game mechanics. It was a decently challenging game and I liked it. But after like 10-15 hours I knew exactly how to play the game. 

So for me now this game is way to easy, after only 15 hours of playtime I know exactly what to do.
Then it also seems that there is only one way to rule, if you want to succeed. (liberal - progressive thinking)
Furthermore convincing the council seems to be a big part of the game, however if you build your districts correctly and research in a smart way they will allways vote yes. It comes down to wether you have a positive tax rate.'
With my playstyle, I got up to 750k + tax rate per month, 40000 citizens, WOL happiness 9-10 and I almost finished all era 3 inventions being at the end of era 2. At this moment I cannot continue due to the lag.

At the current stage of the game it was not worth the 40 euros.

To improve the game they should focus on:
- optimalization
- adding a layer of depth
- more pathways to succes
- in depth politics (more agenda of the parties, instead of just needing good taxes)
- more trade offs for being progressive - liberal
- more benefits for not moving forward

This would greatly improve the game.

At the moment I am almost done playing this game, and 35-40 hours of gameplay for 40 euros just does not cut it.

I hope this review gives some help in making a decision.

column8: I had great anticipation for this game. And its sad to see how they made a bad city builder, with repetetive political voting. The game could have been so much better. Its slowpaced and boring, and I dont understand how things are supposed to work, if you raise taxes nothing happends to demande of the different zones.. Weird. I understand its political, but it would be nice with some other features aswell. I hope they do something with the game, it has great potential!

column8: Ein klarer Fehlkauf. Ich hab die Kampagne an einem Nachmittag einmal durchgespielt und Ã¼berhaupt kein Verlangen es nochmal zu tun. Man hat keinen wirklichen Einfluss auf das Stadtbild und generell klickt man immer nur zwischen Stadt und Stadtrat hin und her, und das wird nach kurzer Zeit einfach nur langweilig. Ach hat das Spiel nichts mit dem Handeln eines BÃ¼rgermeisters zu tun. Die meisten Entscheidungen betreffen eher die Politik einer Regierung und wÃ¼rden im wahren Leben niemals von einem BÃ¼rgermeister entschieden werden. Auch habe ich nicht das GefÃ¼hl, dass irgendeine Entscheidung einen Einfluss auf das Stadtbild hat. Echt schade, dass so wenig aus einer tollen Idee gemacht wurde.

column9: Really Awesome Concept Game but totally fail to deliever on the gameplay and filled with bugs.

column8:
I have been playing city sims since the first Sim City. I generally enjoy Kalypso products, but this title comes up short in several areas:

1. Balance: It does not truly allow alternate paths to city politics. Want to build a facist or communist state? Good luck.

2. Mechanics: Too much click this, click that.

3. City Customisation: No dense commercial areas. You can build a "Manhattan" or the like, just a mixed commercial/residential zone.

4. Graphics:  Vanilla. The end game residential and commercial buildings looke exactly alike, except for a little out of place sign atop the commerical buildings. do they expect modders to do the work?

5. Replayability: Do it once, it's pretty much done.

All this outweighs the great concepts in the game. Maybe I'll come back and check on it in 3 months, or maybe I'll play Skylines. In any event, cannot recommend.

column8: æ°¸è¿œè®°ä½ï¼ç§‘å­¦æ˜¯ç¬¬ä¸€ç”Ÿäº§åŠ›ï¼ä½ æ•¢ä¿¡æˆ‘1994å¹´å°±å®Œæˆäº†arå’Œç‰©è”ç½‘å—ï¼Ÿ

This game has a fun concept and I bought it on-sale because the setting was intriguing. I want very much to like this game but I can't really recommend it in it's current state. For all the data the game apparently provides, there is no intuitive way to understand why businesses are failing or what the city needs to grow. If there are any lists or charts of improvements, I can't find them. It's maddening that there is apparently no city-map view to see where you've placed service buildings or to see, at a glance, which districts have which infrastructure installed, the zoning layout, or anything you would expect.

Finally, and this is what prompted my review, the game is still quite glitchy. I cannot load any of my saved games - uninstalling and re-installing did not work. Not very enthralled to have spent precious hours off from work to play a game I cannot finish. Ambitious idea that I wanted to love, but I think I'll go buy City: Skylines now.
column9:
This game has a fun concept and I bought it on-sale because the setting was intriguing. I want very much to like this game but I can't really recommend it in it's current state. For all the data the game apparently provides, there is no intuitive way to understand why businesses are failing or what the city needs to grow. If there are any lists or charts of improvements, I can't find them. It's maddening that there is apparently no city-map view to see where you've placed service buildings or to see, at a glance, which districts have which infrastructure installed, the zoning layout, or anything you would expect.

Finally, and this is what prompted my review, the game is still quite glitchy. I cannot load any of my saved games - uninstalling and re-installing did not work. Not very enthralled to have spent precious hours off from work to play a game I cannot finish. Ambitious idea that I wanted to love, but I think I'll go buy City: Skylines now.

column8: æ¸¸æˆåšå¾—ä¸é”™ï¼Œä½†å‘ç°äº†ä¸€ä¸ªç‘•ç–µï¼Œåœ¨åŸå¸‚æ•°æ®ä¸­çš„è¡Œæ”¿åŒºçš„æˆäººæ˜¾ç¤ºä¸ºæ‰¿è®¤ï¼Œå¸Œæœ›åšå‡ºä¿®æ”¹ã€‚

Sadly, I cannot reccommend this game. There's many reasons but I'll keep it brief. 

The way this game sells itself as a political/city builder hybrid is true to an extent, except that each aspect is way too shallow. 

First the city building, or lack thereof. You only really build service buildings - schools, police stations, clinics, etc. - and you are stuck building your city using a district mechanic, which involves just clicking and dragging over an area. The roads and zones are automatically done for you. There's much more to say but if you're looking for a city builder - don't look here. 

Secondly, and most disappointingly (as I knew the city-builder aspect was second fiddle to this part) the political simulator is just not good, at all. The parties are hard-wired to rise and fall depending on the eras, so no matter what decisions you make - there will be the same parties. 

The political decisions themselves wreak of a liberal, socialist bias. The game sort of forces you to adopt progressive policies because the benefits are simply all positive and there's no counterbalance to give you pause for not adopting it. There's literally no reason to play with a conservative minded playstyle, you will be far behind somebody who just adopts all the progressive policies as they become available. 

I had high hopes for this game, but I have to say it's one of the most disappointing purchases I've ever made.
column9:
Sadly, I cannot reccommend this game. There's many reasons but I'll keep it brief. 

The way this game sells itself as a political/city builder hybrid is true to an extent, except that each aspect is way too shallow. 

First the city building, or lack thereof. You only really build service buildings - schools, police stations, clinics, etc. - and you are stuck building your city using a district mechanic, which involves just clicking and dragging over an area. The roads and zones are automatically done for you. There's much more to say but if you're looking for a city builder - don't look here. 

Secondly, and most disappointingly (as I knew the city-builder aspect was second fiddle to this part) the political simulator is just not good, at all. The parties are hard-wired to rise and fall depending on the eras, so no matter what decisions you make - there will be the same parties. 

The political decisions themselves wreak of a liberal, socialist bias. The game sort of forces you to adopt progressive policies because the benefits are simply all positive and there's no counterbalance to give you pause for not adopting it. There's literally no reason to play with a conservative minded playstyle, you will be far behind somebody who just adopts all the progressive policies as they become available. 

I had high hopes for this game, but I have to say it's one of the most disappointing purchases I've ever made.

column8:
Though it feels unfinished, I thoroughly enjoyed the game.  Mostly because it wasn't always apparent what was happening on the surface, it required digging into and tracking the data available in the menus in order to build a succesful metropolis.

The polical aspect of the game is unfinished (hopefully..) after the 3rd era I could find no point in fighting to figure out how to appease the parties.  Instead you can just let the partys do there thing and save up your prestige to overrule them when they vote you out of office. 

I would definitely recomend this to anyone who enjoyed The Guild II, and Democracy III!

column8:
Also irgendwie komisch. Man kann das Spiel beenden und ein Ziel erreichen , wenn man GAR NICHTS macht. Ob die Parteien fÃ¼r einen Stimmen wollen oder nicht ist irgendwie vollkommen willkÃ¼rlich. Einmal muss man Fordern oder Drohen und bei der nÃ¤chsten Wahl sind fast alle Parteien fÃ¼r einen, obwohl man Ã¼berhaupt nichts gemacht hat. Weder irgendwelche wichtigen Entscheidungen noch was anderes.  Genauso gehen auch ohne Wirtschaftskrise Unternehmen kaputt und das fÃ¼r JAHRE!!!! Nachdem sie fast 10 Jahre platt waren , sind auf einmal neue da und halten genau 6 Monate, in denen sie Geld bringen, danach wieder fÃ¼r JAHRE platt..... ich versteh den Sinn des Ganzen nicht. Wenn man versucht richtige StraÃŸen, Unis , Polizei, Stromnetz, Telefon und und und zu bauen, sind die Kosten sooo enorm hoch, das ich nicht weiÃŸ, wie man das Finanzieren soll. Ich war immer pleite und konnte nichts mehr machen.  Bin mal gespannt wie es WB im Lets Play ausgeht. 
Ich habe mir etwas anderes unter dem Spiel vorgestellt. Man sitzt nur im StadtratmenÃ¼ und iss am Rumklicken, aber bauen ist nicht. LEIDER.

Viel SpaÃŸ Euch beim Ausprobieren.

When I first read about this upcoming game many months ago, I thought this was going to be a dream of mine come true, a hybrid between Cities in Motion, Tropico, Cities Skylines, and Civilization, a city and development planner with a strong historical perspective. Unfortunately, I experienced a sobering jolt to reality when the game was finally released. Mouse control is a nightmare, laggy and jerky, and with the keyboard (the usual fall-back for cases like this, cf. CiM2) it's not much better, too few zoom levels, too many new windows open up where you have to click okay every time, the gameplay is repetitive, there is no alluring atmosphere, no special mood that makes you feel something ... I really wanted to like this game, and the games I listed above may have set very high standards. But even though I don't think I am very demanding, I regret to have to say that this game has been a huge disappointment to me. I am not certain whether future updates may be able to improve the situation greatly, but I will not give up hope, especially with the developers coming across as being really competent as well as likeable in their videos.

column8:
As someone who is obsessed with government simulation and strategy games, I saw this game and immediately pre-ordered it. I watched numerous videos of gameplay and it appeared to be just my cup of tea. Upon release, and several hours of playtime, I feel as though I've had my fill, not $34 worth, but a fill. 

The initial era is perhaps the most enjoyable portion of the game, it feels busy, turbulent, just as you begin your cityâ€”in other words, it feels as though you are truly engaged in creating a city, executing its policy, improving infrastructure, et ceteraâ€”however after the inital issues are settled, it slows down significantly. Oftentimes you find yourself barely making enough money to pay for simple improvements like gravel to cobblestone roads, and virtually never are able to increase taxes unless the deficit is immense, and even then it can be a struggle. By about era IV, you end up focusing less on improving and expanding your city through public works projects and legislation, and far more on simply hoarding goodwill so that you can sway the parties each time a mayoral election comes around (perhaps it's user error, or perhaps simply a reflection of the reality of politics?). 

Though at first I noticed a trend towards more left-wing parties and policies having a sort of inevitable quality to them (which, mind you, I do not mind being a very liberal/left-wing person myself), the reality of it is that no matter how much you support these parties (such as supporting their legislation or merely being cordial to them), they almost always end up stabbing you in the back by the time elections come aroundâ€”I've found myself having no other choice than to threaten the parties in order to remain in office by the later eras.

On the more technical aspects, the game itself is good-looking (though draw distance is far shorter than it should) and the graphics, though perhaps not revolutionary, are fitting, and the visuals do not leave me disappointed in the slightest. The game runs very smoothly on my PC (despite it not being necessarily a ultra-powerful machine) on the highest settings. Overall, I have encountered no game-breaking bugs or issues that have ruined the gameplay simply because of developer error. On that same note, responding to pop-up events is in many ways taking a shot in the dark, as the impacts of the decisions aren't known until after it has been made (though truthfully after some playtime one can guess to a point the impacts they will have), and if I would request a specific addition to be made to the game, it would be to add the statistics to the decision screen so that more informed decisions can be made. Additionally, I would like to see difficulty settings and/or different gamemodes that cater to players' different playstyles or fortÃ©s, or merely adjustable/toggleable settings for campaigns that can add diversity to each playthrough, something that I believe would be a welcome addition, especially taking into account how repetitive and grinding the game can become as early as 1-2 hours into a campaign. Being as this focus more specifically on political aspects of governing a city, I might also recommend a system be put in place that would allow a player to create their own party, that way they could fight to pass their own policies and work to elect their own councilmembers rather than be limited to merely courting the leadership and membership of other parties which may or may not help fulfill the mayor's agenda. Though the political aspects of this game are a refreshing change for a "city builder/ruler," they could use more fleshing out, as it feels very disconnected and two-dimensional in its current state.

Long story short, Urban Empire is an interesting and rather ingenuitive approach to the age-old city builder genre, however it is executed in a way that feels shallow and repetitive to experienced and newcomers to the genre alike. I will likely play this game more, nevertheless, and look forward to future updates and DLC, though I hope that the developers will heed the input of the community and release a significant amount of free content to improve upon a regrettably barebones game. As previously stated, I am someone who plays strategy/simulation games all the time, I love the idea, and the game is far from bad as some other reviews have stated, but it needs more draw and replay value to keep even the most battle-hardened strategy gamers coming back for another playthrough, and quite honestly I am on the cusp of recommending to that demographic in particular, but widespread appeal to people not as weird as me is, unfortunately, lacking.

Final conclusion: amazing concept, needs more work.

6/10

column8: Dieses Spiel ist eine Frechheit. Es ist unfertig, nicht gut gebalanced und dazu noch sehr hardwareintensiv bei gleichzeitig eher durchschnittlicher bis schlechter Grafik. Ich hatte viele Hoffnungen in das Spiel und habe angesichts des Preises deutlich mehr erwartet. Ich warte noch auf eine Antwort des Steam Refund.

Awesome concept but the game... eh. 

(would put a sideways thumb but there's no "eh" option)

Here are some ways you could improve the game and some thoughts.
1.	I can overrule a mayoral race (Thatâ€™s just silly)
2.	Be able to gain favor points with parties other than by waiting or destroying blackmail. (Like by donating to the parties with personal funds or by asking them what policies they want passed)
3.	Creation of â€œBillsâ€ a collection of policies. 
a.	Reason 1: If there are 12 policies I can pass (Have the funds and are favored by most) I should be able to group them and pass them at one time.
b.	Reason 2. If party A and B are opposite on the political spectrum and party A wants a policy but party B wonâ€™t let it pass, then group it with something party B wants. (You know like real politics)
4.	Higher Density shouldnâ€™t cost so much money. Why does allowing heavier density cost so much money? Higher density = more people = more in taxes.
5.	More income methods than taxes would be nice.
6.	District size limits is annoying because there are areas that seem large enough but arenâ€™t and are just empty areas. At least let me make it a national park or something.
7.	City wide implementation. (If Iâ€™m able to implement a service in each district and have the income, and funds then I shouldnâ€™t have to go through each district and have to wait on a vote that will pass no matter what.)
8.	More and better cause and effects. (Why is electricity so expensive and costly to maintain? Wouldnâ€™t it be costly to implement then give me a revenue from selling electricity that would offset maintenance?) 
9.	Is there no National Government? There should be actual effects of being a city within a national government. (For example If the national government joined/sided with the USSR I shouldnâ€™t be able to be twin cities with San Francisco and Private ownership would decrease or something like that. And if you donâ€™t like being a part of the Country maybe secede or join another country and have a way and effects of doing so) 
10.	Am I not in a Political Party? This relates mainly to later eras but shouldnâ€™t I be in a party since Iâ€™m a mayor?
11.	Political Campaigning for policies and the mayoral race. (For example, if I campaigned for a policy but it was still voted down, but the people â€œdemandedâ€ for it I could overrule it without a negative effect and the parties who voted against it would see a drop in members)

column8:
So far, I have 21 hours in Urban Empire. I really want to like it, but it needs some fixing. Some of the points I'm bringing up have probably been brought up, and I have noticed that the developer is paying attention to the reviews, so they may already be working on fixing the issues. Anyway, I need to share the things I have reacted to.

1. The FPS
When my city was growing bigger and bigger, I noticed a drastic drop in FPS. My PC can handle many demanding games without any major issues, but for some reason it doesn't work here. I tried lowering the graphics setting as low as possible to try to fix it, but the problems remained. In my case, my city was around 70.000 inhabitants and sometimes the FPS went below 10 FPS. I'm wondering if it's at all possible to get higher than 60 FPS in-game, because it feels like an FPS lock. I wouldn't have a problem with that if it ran at 60 FPS the entire game, but it doesn't.

2. Lack of clear information
From the get go, I was really confused with all the information that was given to me. I still have trouble finding information about different things, however that may be my fault. One thing is really bugging me whenever you resolve an event and get bonuses to some of the different aspects (social life, happiness, security etc.): sometimes you get an indication to what is affected in what way when you hover over with your mouse indicator, other times it doesn't. Also, there are times when text is missing in dialogue windows. It feels very inconsistent and should be considered for a patch.

3. Repetitive events
Whether it's about the sucurity in a district, the circus coming to town, or getting criticism from a local journalist, many events show up one too many times during your ruling. So many times, in fact, that you could learn what option to choose to get the best result every time. If they would be reused after the end of time victory I wouldn't mind, but as of now it's a little too repetetive.

4. Consequences?
My first game I learned about the concequenses of having low goodwill towards many of the parties. But as soon as I just focused on districts and kept an eye on the taxes, I could cruise through the game without having to worry about anything political. Well, apart from the majoral election. I was so nervous the first couple of times, but as time went on I barely had to appeal to any parties to make it through to the next period. Maybe a higher difficulty setting option could be in its place.

Then there are features I would like to be included, such as:
- Being able to control where the RCI zones are placed in a district
- Going backwards in modifying a district without having to cancel the entire modification to fix something you want to change (it's really bugging me)
- Being able to zoom out even more than is possible at the moment, I want to see my entire city in all it's glory (granted if I can run it with the highest graphics setting)

To be clear, I really want to like it. I'm really close to liking it. I have played some city simulators before, and even though they are fun I really want this concept city ruling to be great. After patching I think this game has great potential. I really like that the developer are keeping an eye on the feedback and wish them the best of luck in making this game the best it can possibly be.

As of now, I can't fully recommend Urban Empire. I want to, but I can't. I sort of like it, I want to really like it. It's not a terrible game, but it's not a great game yet.

EDIT: Ignore what I said about going backwards in modifying a district. Turns out that I was blind and missed that feature.

column9: The price is a bit high.... I've lost my patience to play it. As a city management game, it's still pretty good. I've played it several times, with the same ending but different stories. As a game from 2017, it's obviously not that good. Overall, I'm a little disappointed.

column9: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

column8: It feels like a streamlined city builder which I like (not a fan of drawing out roadways). The political aspect adds an interesting perspective on the genre.  The game has many pitfalls that are hard to get out of, but not usually impossible.   The political system could be a little more in depth, it seems like it follows a perticular path with little deviation.  It's at the least an interesting experience, but I do like this game

æ—¶è¿‡å¢ƒè¿ï¼Œæ¸¸æˆå‘å¸ƒåˆ°ç°åœ¨HOTFIXåå°±æ²¡æœ‰åç»­äº†ï¼Œå¼€å‘è€…å¯èƒ½å·²ç»æ”¾å¼ƒäº†è¿™ä¸ªæ¸¸æˆçš„åç»­å¼€å‘ï¼Œå¤ªé—æ†¾äº†ã€‚åªèƒ½ç”¨æ¯«æ— è¯šæ„å»å½¢å®¹äº†ã€‚

[h1][b]NOT QUITE THERE (YET)[/b][/h1]

I love city building games.  I love politics.  I should love Urban Empire.

Urban empire starts wonderfully exciting.  To start, it has open territory to place your districts, a council to influence, and support from the emperor to get you going.  The game remains fun while you create and grow your first couple of districts and through the entire first era.  As the game goes on each era becomes more and more repetitive, and the errors in and problems with the game become more apparent.

Based on price and experience, for now, I have to give this game a thumbs down.  However, it is my sincerest hope that mods and patching will really improve both the primary experience and the replayability of Urban Empire.  I want to love the game, and I think I can if they take a good hard look at what city building combined with politicking can fully offer.

[h1]WHAT I LIKE[/h1]
1.  The premise of growing a city through political wrangling.

2.  The option of the families; though I wish there were a few more of them from which to choose.

3.  The politicking of the council and the parties.

[h1]WHAT I DON'T LIKE[/h1]
1.  Decision tool tips:
[list]
[*]In many cases there aren't any tool tips.
[*]When there are tool tips: I don't need the game to say, â€œIf you click here you will get a 5% bonus to X.â€  I don't like static numbers in a game that's supposed to be based on humans and politics; however, there should be a tool tip that states, â€œIf you select this option you should see a small boost to your economy.â€
[*](Additional note:)  After which you may see a -1% to 5% modifier to... whatever.  Put some small/subtle human nature/failure randomizing to personalize it more.  We already have failed assassination attempts, why can't we have false math (aka: spin). 
[/list]

2.  Fluff/story-based decisions out or order - (notional example, but consistent with the point):
[list]
[*]1850:  Your baby is born with a disease, what do you do?
[*]1855:  Daddy tells you to get married.
[*]1857:  You get married.
[*]1860:  You have no children and this worries the city.
[*]1861:  You have your first child.
[/list]

3.  Replayability is lacking.  In my experience:
[list]
[*]Progressive agenda issue (for the era) proposed multiple times, even if vote fails or overruled.  Conservative policies (for the era) are one-and-done.  This makes it very difficult to play the von Pflizen family true to their lore.  Both the council and the populous should be a bit more randomized every play though.  Maybe one time I play and the city leans toward liberal policies, and the next time they are more puritanically religious and conservative.  This would allow for more replayability.  
[*]All families should be able to win based on their ideals.  Populist or Liberal Western ideals shouldn't be the only path to victory.  If I want to run the city as a Facist, Communist, Republican/Tory, Democrat/Labour, Green, Pacifist, Libertarian, Anarchist, Theocracy, or whatever I should be able to.  When I played as 'me' the game was basically on easy mode.  When I tried to play a role, I barely got past Era III each time; and always failed in Era IV.
[*]I am NOT accusing the developers of having a political bias, but my experience is that populism and generally liberal policies make for a well functioning city.  It's a self-imposed hardmode to play any other way. 
[/list]

4.  Lots of lag at endgame.
[list]
[*]Whether it's on the city map or even in the city council starting in Era IV the game becomes very, very laggy.  There's no point in even moving the camera over my city unless fully paused, and waiting 3-5 seconds for a button click to register is not... ideal.
[/list]

5.  Bad spelling grammar:
[list]
[*]I'm not too worried about this, and I'm by no means perfect, but it should be noted that they could use a better English editor to fix the numerous spelling and grammar errors.
[/list]
column9:
[h1][b]NOT QUITE THERE (YET)[/b][/h1]

I love city building games.  I love politics.  I should love Urban Empire.

Urban empire starts wonderfully exciting.  To start, it has open territory to place your districts, a council to influence, and support from the emperor to get you going.  The game remains fun while you create and grow your first couple of districts and through the entire first era.  As the game goes on each era becomes more and more repetitive, and the errors in and problems with the game become more apparent.

Based on price and experience, for now, I have to give this game a thumbs down.  However, it is my sincerest hope that mods and patching will really improve both the primary experience and the replayability of Urban Empire.  I want to love the game, and I think I can if they take a good hard look at what city building combined with politicking can fully offer.

[h1]WHAT I LIKE[/h1]
1.  The premise of growing a city through political wrangling.

2.  The option of the families; though I wish there were a few more of them from which to choose.

3.  The politicking of the council and the parties.

[h1]WHAT I DON'T LIKE[/h1]
1.  Decision tool tips:
[list]
[*]In many cases there aren't any tool tips.
[*]When there are tool tips: I don't need the game to say, â€œIf you click here you will get a 5% bonus to X.â€  I don't like static numbers in a game that's supposed to be based on humans and politics; however, there should be a tool tip that states, â€œIf you select this option you should see a small boost to your economy.â€
[*](Additional note:)  After which you may see a -1% to 5% modifier to... whatever.  Put some small/subtle human nature/failure randomizing to personalize it more.  We already have failed assassination attempts, why can't we have false math (aka: spin). 
[/list]

2.  Fluff/story-based decisions out or order - (notional example, but consistent with the point):
[list]
[*]1850:  Your baby is born with a disease, what do you do?
[*]1855:  Daddy tells you to get married.
[*]1857:  You get married.
[*]1860:  You have no children and this worries the city.
[*]1861:  You have your first child.
[/list]

3.  Replayability is lacking.  In my experience:
[list]
[*]Progressive agenda issue (for the era) proposed multiple times, even if vote fails or overruled.  Conservative policies (for the era) are one-and-done.  This makes it very difficult to play the von Pflizen family true to their lore.  Both the council and the populous should be a bit more randomized every play though.  Maybe one time I play and the city leans toward liberal policies, and the next time they are more puritanically religious and conservative.  This would allow for more replayability.  
[*]All families should be able to win based on their ideals.  Populist or Liberal Western ideals shouldn't be the only path to victory.  If I want to run the city as a Facist, Communist, Republican/Tory, Democrat/Labour, Green, Pacifist, Libertarian, Anarchist, Theocracy, or whatever I should be able to.  When I played as 'me' the game was basically on easy mode.  When I tried to play a role, I barely got past Era III each time; and always failed in Era IV.
[*]I am NOT accusing the developers of having a political bias, but my experience is that populism and generally liberal policies make for a well functioning city.  It's a self-imposed hardmode to play any other way. 
[/list]

4.  Lots of lag at endgame.
[list]
[*]Whether it's on the city map or even in the city council starting in Era IV the game becomes very, very laggy.  There's no point in even moving the camera over my city unless fully paused, and waiting 3-5 seconds for a button click to register is not... ideal.
[/list]

5.  Bad spelling grammar:
[list]
[*]I'm not too worried about this, and I'm by no means perfect, but it should be noted that they could use a better English editor to fix the numerous spelling and grammar errors.
[/list]

column8:
I've played two sessions ending in two rage quits. I seriously doubt the developers have even played their own game from start to finish, without using cheats. Which is a claim supported by their own screenshots. Notice when they show the screenpic of the tier IV research tree. The portray is of the second in line of the Russian banker dynasty. The year is 1826, they have 12 in research power. Yet they have research almost the entire tier IV tree. Which is literally impossible without cheating since every time the era changes, so does the guy/woman ruling your family, with merely 12 in research power you won't even have been able to leave the second era. Let's completely ignore the fact that they are losing money in 6 out 8 pics where you can actually see their stats. We shall move on to my personal experience.

First I played as the Sant'Elias which was a "progressive" family with their minds on science and research. I call bullshit on the claim of being progressive, since I ended up becoming a mad scientist after losing my wife while she gave birth to my daughter, who became an estranged feminist, since apparentaly nobody likes a guy electricuting dead bodies in hope of raising the dead.

Second time I played was as the Russian bankers, since the main problem with the first playthrough was a lack of funds. At the third era the city was making around 114k every month. To suddenly go to a -80k because of the era change. No matter what I did or how I would have played it differently. Around era IV you will want to table flip this bitch into oblivion because it makes so little sense how your city can make a fortune one month to later lose that fortune in a matter of a year. Also what frustrated me was that the bankers where more progressive and science orianted then Sant'Elias. Which renders the Sant'Elias family as completely useless.

I tried very hard to like this game since I see where they want to go with this. To emphasize on governmental management between different parties rather then city building. People telling you that this is not a city builder game is talking out of their asses. You begin with a nice open space, and your actions will lead to a shitty city being built. With definition on SHITTY! You build the city based on districts and can place "special buildings and infrastructure" These buildings are special indeed, since they suck up all city funds and leave you with little to no prosperity..

No matter what your political tactics are, whenever the era changes from III to IV you'll end up with nothing more then pulling your hair off your head because: "New times brings new demands." And those demands are everything against what you, the empire and ultimately the city represents, and it will punish you so severe that you won't leave your bedroom for a week.

The research tree is nicely visualized but the benefits are to small. It's only function is to mock you...

Infrastructure hardly brings any benefits, with hardly, I mean none.. Just loads of extra costs.

The growth of the city is your responsibility. The other parties are mainly there to fuck with every decision you make. (which simulates IRL quite well actually) They won't help you at all with any costs that is demanded from the city. They don't build anything of "value" like schools or other instituations that will be demanded in the future. Personally, you will be forced to do so.

Early game is quite fun, late game will test your faith in mankind, because the whiny peasants will want more rights. Work less and everything should be free is basically what they are demanding. Leaving the city without funds to do fuck all.. Even though they where voting for 8h work shifts, their children was still forced to work 10h in factories... That should give you a nice picture of what the psychology is behind these peasant scums..

Forget water pipes, sewer pipes, electricity... Forget road infrastructure, never research human rights research because it will fuck you and the city over big times. Besides, those rights will trickle in no matter what you do anyway. Just research industry related stuff and the ability to spy on other parties. Use that to blackmail the other parties asses so you can remain in office until the nightmare is over. GG.

I give this game an extra point because I became Frankenstein. I will however remove that point because there where no monster in the end to snuggle hug.

If this game does anything, it shows how impossibly fucked mankind is because of liberal decisions. 
Also, pro tip: Don't ban porn. You'll need some material to frustrate mastrubate to after you've played this game. >:(

There's an official Chinese version with Chinese dubbing. Kudos to the developers for their commitment to Chinese players.

But what the hell is this? Oppose, oppose, oppose. These factions would rather live in a city without water, electricity, police, or entertainment. It's totally unplayable!

column9:
Reading the comments, I feel like you're playing a different game than I am.

I suggest not focusing too much on cash. This game is about cash flow. Just make sure your assets and liabilities are under control. At critical moments, do more monitoring and get the mayor's funds up and running.

EDIT:  After weeks and weeks of promised patches and upgrades, this one gets demoted to probably my most disappointing PC purchase of the 21st century on a dollar-for-dollar basis.  Frankly I'm not sure where or how they can fix this mess other than bending over and letting folks who paid full price kick them square in the rear end.   That's probably a much simpler solution than trying to make a game out of this.   In the end, you get to watch a city grow and pass some resolutions which have little to no bearing on the outcome.  

This game is so terrible that it has ensured that I will never purchase from this developer or publisher again without waiting for reviews which clearly demonstrate the design wasn't pushed to market despite not being a game.    And even then, they'll need to offer  a big discount to help me get some of my money back that I wasted on this turkey.  Come to think of it, I now wish I had used this money to buy turkey instead of this, though both the bird and this game can put you to sleep.

My original review continues below and it's still valid.

______________________________________________________________________



Overall, I have to give it a thumbs-down.   A very wide idea with very little depth.  Essentially you build up goodwill and then spend it on things that are important for you to pass.  But that idea ends up feeling half-baked at best.

The economics of the game are also way off.  Want to install street lamps?  You greedy bastard!   Want to have an asphalt road? You wasteful pig!  What's that?  You want phone service?  What the hell is wrong with you; we cannot afford that!

If the developer re-dials the economics to make upgrades more balanced (not "easier", just more balanced), it would help this game out a lot.

A beautiful idea which set very high expectations but did not deliver. Urban Empire is a city ruler with mediocre city building aspects and ungratifying political aspects. The game is a disappointment given that it is coming from Kalypso Media which has experience building simulation games. The game feels unfinished and overlypriced in its current form.

In this review I give some comparisons to Tropico 5 as that came from Kalypso too and had some very basic elements of politics.

Pros:
* Despite the heavy drawbacks, there are some good elements and innovations in this game. The game introduces the concept of council politics and how to influence to get votes. 
* The random events in the game are funny at times and have interesting choices.
* The concept of era's is well thought off and compliments the research system. The idea that the next generation of family comes on with the change in era is very good. It makes the game feel more realistic.
* This list is hard to think off

Cons:
* There is very little replay value as the game is very linear. In addition, there isn't much creativity required. Unlike traditional city builders which does bring replayibility due to the creative aspect of it, this game focuses on making decisions rather than designing. How many times will one play the same game to pass the same edicts and build the same service buildings? The map doesn't change drastically and there isn't a different way of ruling things. 

* In real world, central to politics is how you stay in power and campaign for your election. There is no concept of campaigning in this city ruler whose main theme is politics !? Even Tropico 5 had a basic political campaign where you had to promise changes that you would do if you win the election. In its current form, the election just seems like a repetitive boring hindrance that is placed to end your game than to provide any meaning. There is even no concept as promising other parties to vote in favor for their agendas.  

* The political parties just seem to be there to vote yes/no. They have absolutely no other function in the game. As an entity you can plead/demand/threaten them to vote in your favor(whether mayor elections or changes that you propose), but vice-versa never happens. I have played 4 eras and never once did any other political party plead/demand/threaten me for a change. I would like to see more changes in politics - if as a mayor I don't promote their agendas then I would face opposition in the next election.

*  There is no personality to the political parties that you deal with. They are just emotionless simulated entities that as a player you never connect with. They have their party description as to what they should be but other than that they lack everything of what a real political party is. They never propagate their agendas in media. They never interact with the player except few random events.. As a personal example - Edict to ban prostitution was not supported by Christian Democratic Party openly. Rather they were shown as Yellow in the Red/Yellow/Green spectrum of their support. How does that make sense? How can a party based on religion be indifferent towards something they claim immoral.

* The game displays a lot of data in tabular format that should be graphical. In a simulator, one should be able to see trends and effects for the decisions made. 

* The data that is provided in game is meaningless. I should be able to see how many people are in favor gay marriages for example or want a new church in their district. Rather we get tables of detailed data that I cannot comprehend what to do with.

* The simulation in game seems unrealistic too. After playing for 80 years in game and having only built 1 church in a city of 8 districs, I am seeing christian democratic party win the elections 3 times in a row. Shouldn't the lack of churches reduce the religious followers over time? Shouldn't people get less attached to religion? No data to see this, and utter confusion as to why a certain party is winning so many seats in the council. There is no demand from people prior to elections 

* The game is way too overpriced at 40$. The city building aspect is very basic and some mobile games have more features. The political aspects are a good start but feel rather unfinished. Past games from Kalypso like Tropico had some better political simulation aspects. The game has occasional bugs too and the UI doesn't seem complete either. No exit to desktop option? Save game freezes the entire game for couple seconds? City building area is too restrictive..
column9:

column8:
This is the first game I have ever returned on Steam.  I wanted to like it, I played several games as different families, tried several strategies to no avail.  After more than 10 hours played the glaring deficiencies could no longer be overlooked.  The economy makes little to no sense, it felt like whoever designed the economy had only a passing familiarity with how economics work.  Very frustrating.  
As for the politics, there is no real feeling of agency as a player.  There is a general trend towards Liberalization(i.e. Women's /Gay Rights) which the player either goes along with, or if you try to buck the trend you get stuck voting over the same edicts time after time.  
Ultimately I felt like my time played boiled down to just watching bars progress.  Waiting for a vote, which was a foregone conclusion, come up for a vote.  It felt pointless, so much so that in my final game I didn't even feel like trying to get reelected.  The last thing this game had to offer was a defeated screen.

column9:
This game lacks depth. All the ideas are treated superficially. Once you find a way to maintain a positive budget, the concept of voting disappears; the players all more or less agree with you.

It's a shame; the initial idea is very good, but you might as well play The Guild, which is much more comprehensive.

Very specialized game which is NOT for everyone. 
If you're not interested in politics, history, education, managing, you probably do best when avoiding this game.
Probably fit only to casual players.
Very badly optimized - you should have very good procesor and RAM to experience smooth game.

Definitely not recommendable at the moment...
Game lags big time as soon as your city gets bigger, and more parties are in the council...
and there are so many little bugs:
- missing text where it still says [enter city] instead of the city name
- losing about 200k income every time i change era
- Parties propose laws (i.e. lower taxes f poor - communist party) and oppose it themelves
- interactions with the parties are very little - goodwill recovers never
- the demand for zones doesn't really depend on taxing (raise taxes - business boom)
- the events can come up more than once (might happen to you that one event repats itself 3-4 times in 6 years)
-> this are by far not all the bugs...
->WORST: i can't load my savegames anymore since the about 1930s...

KALYPSO SHOULD HAVE TAKEN ANOTHER MONTH OR TWO TO FINISH THIS GAME! this is early-access level

[b]This game is a fascinating mess .. I really want to like it but I can't recommend it in its current form. And even if it worked as intended, it's far too expensive for what you get.[/b]

[h1](+) Genuinely new concept[/h1]

It deserves top marks for its ideas: it's NOT a city builder, but rather a political simulator in a city builder's skin. The whole game involves proposing legislation and taking it to the city council, where you employ political tricks to get what you want. This part of the game is immensely satisfying: working with or against political parties to get your laws passed and then seeing the effects of that in-game is what gives you the biggest thrill.

[h1](-) No cause and effect[/h1]

Unfortunately, almost every other aspect of the game needs major work. The biggest problem is the lack of clear cause and effect. Despite a very busy UI, you're never quite clear on what your actions wil do. The developers have defended this on discussion boards by saying it's a realistic depiction of politics, but this is a cheap cop-out. The fault lies in the confusingly messy and random UI which sometimes gives tooltips and sometimes doesn't, the badly translated stats  (e.g. what's "sales demand" or "vote process?), and the lack of obvious links between many factors in the game (e.g. density and infrastructure). In addition, some of the events are downright contradictory: I sided with the progressive Young Swarelian Party to decrease taxes on students, but the legislation that was enacted increased said taxes by 5%.

[h1](~) Lack of polish[/h1]

Some of the game, e.g. the family/map selection screens, is beautiful; the rest is laggy and glitchy, even on powerful rigs. There's currently a very bad memory leak which results in major slow down in the latter third of the game. Even when settings are optimised, the main map screen looks dated. This would be much less of an issue if the gameplay problems were fixed.

TLDR; Push buttons, threaten people, wait for money. 

The game itself is very shallow. There really isn't much to do appart from threaten council members when they don't agree with buidling a park.  Balancing income and expenditures is near immpossible. I found myself threatning council members constantly to raise taxes, resulting in party members losing trust in me which meant I had to threaten them again to vote for me in the elections.

The population sizes seems disproportionate to the scale of the city. For the whole 200 years, with around 14 districts, the population never rose above 6000.

The game mechanics don't make sense. In the year 2000, all my districts still had gas powered lights, no public transport and no water grid. Citizens don't seem to care.

Wieder einmal habe ich den Fehler gemacht ein Spiel aufgrund meiner persÃ¶nlichen Erwartung im Vorverkauf zu bestellen. Der Schuss ging wieder mal nach hinten los. Hier die ErklÃ¤rung wieso ich Urban Empire nicht empfehlen kann:

Es geht nur ums Geld, solange man im Plus ist und die monatlichen Einnahmen passen, hat man keine Probleme irgendetwas nicht durchzusetzen. Im Plus zu bleiben ist eig. nicht sehr schwer. Kommt man ins Minus werden einfach die Steuer erhÃ¶ht oder wenn die Einnahmen zu gering sind einfach ein neuer Bezirk erstellt. 

Die Parteien sind absolut zufÃ¤llig und keine Herausforderung. PlÃ¶tzlich tauchen AntrÃ¤ge automatisch auf, z.B. dass die Leute Gewerkschaften grÃ¼nden mÃ¶chten oder die Wahlen geheim sein sollen. FÃ¼r mich als BÃ¼rgermeister und der Stadt hat es nur Vorteile, ich stimme zu und der Antrag geht zum Parlament. Auch alle Parteien, egal ob rechts, links, mitte, grÃ¼n, blau, rosa, schwarz, rot haben nichts dagegen, was Geschichtlich und den Orientierungen nach keinen Sinn macht.... Und das geht bei fast jeder Abstimmung so. Ich habe in meinen 4 Stunden nur eine Abstimmung nicht geschafft und das war ein Upgrade des Hafens, da dieser zu Teuer war. Ein Jahr auf Geschwindigkeit 4 abgewartet und ein paar Tausend mehr auf dem Konto war es auf einmal kein Problem mehr. 

Das Spiel ist einfach zu seicht, ich habe gehofft ein anspruchsvolles Wirtschafts- und Politikspiel zu bekommen. Aber im Grunde ist es nur ein Mix aus Die Gilde und Cities Skyline. Aber so einfach, dass ich lieber bei den zwei anderen Spielen bleibe.

Nach 4 Stunden habe ich dann aufgegeben, denn es kam nichts Neues und es war nur immer ein dÃ¤mliches geklicke, bei dem oft nicht mal klar war was fÃ¼r Auswirkungen meine Entscheidung hat, denn auch Jahre spÃ¤ter ist einfach nichts passiert. Weder die Epochen Ã¤nderten daran etwas noch die zufÃ¤lligen Entscheidungen oder das angebliche Weltgeschehen im Hintergrund.

Falls die Entwickler nicht extrem viel Inhalt und mehr Herausforderungen nachliefern kann ich von dem Spiel nur abraten. 

NACHTRAG NACH RÃœCKMELDUNG ENTWICKLER:
Ich bin Ã¼berrascht und erfreut sogar vom Entwickler eine RÃ¼ckmeldung zu bekommen. Dann werd ich dem Spiel demnÃ¤chst noch etwas mehr Zeit geben und hoffe es wird in den nÃ¤chsten Epochen noch spannender, wÃ¼rde mich auf jedenfall freuen. Sollte es mich doch noch Ã¼berzeugen, werde ich auch mein Review abÃ¤ndern.

column9:
Actually, when I saw the Chinese promotional material, I had the same reaction as everyone else. "How dare they release a Chinese version, with Chinese voice acting?" The promotional tone was quite grand. Didn't our famous elder also start out as the mayor of Shanghai? (Sorry, I've been getting a little naive without realizing it.)

After playing, I initially got into the municipal system, arguing with council members and promoting good proposals. But like many newbies, I probably focused on city infrastructure and welfare measures, accidentally running a huge fiscal deficit and ending up dead, or getting ousted mid-game for offending other parties.

Later, I looked up some so-called strategy guides on the forums and discussed them with others, realizing how seriously flawed this game is!

Fuck! A city can live happily without water or electricity!

For this game, imagine reaching the fifth era, getting your finances right, then doing nothing else, just idle, tweaking technology, playing around during the mayor election, and casually dealing with incidents that arise, trying to maintain a profit. Then you finish the game.

Is this really the original intention of the development team? Don't you want us to experience the thrill of being a mayor? Don't you want us to balance managing the city's internal affairs and finances with a complex web of interest groups? And then use all sorts of machinations to achieve our goals, ultimately for the city itself. While the game's core focus is whether you can rule the city, building a city without water, electricity, and where people live in complete boredom is just plain stupid.

Personal suggestions: 1. At least the infrastructure needs to be revamped. You're just building water and electricity for a village, and the entire city's finances are doomed?
2. The tax system. What city has a perpetually rising tax rate and still has people insisting on moving there?
3. I suggest implementing a "minister" system. After all, what's a mayor without some minions? You can use your minions to do more things, like assassinate the party leaders you hate, bribe them, and even help you manage the city.
That's all for now. My suggestions may sound silly to you, but they're at least the voice of a gamer.

column8: I bought this game full of excitement and was unpatiently waiting for the download to end. Then I started, played some time and I can just say what others already said. There comes a Point where you just keep your Budget in plus and the rest you wait and watch for other parties to act. Even though the City itself is beautiful and you see every improvement you do on infrastructure, services and so on, it's not 45â‚¬ worth. Think twice when buying this or wait for a discount.

Fun the first couple of hours but then becomes very repetitive. After a while all you do is select from the same dialogs when dealing with the political parties over and over again. There is a very limited city builder included, but all you can do is select the size of the district, its composition and municipal services. So why bother at all with this builder when you basically cant use it for anything?  It may have been a great idea for a game, but the final result is disappointing. Also it is far too expensive. Right now it costs 75% of CIV 6, but the content in this game is very little compared to CIV 6. Unfortunately I can not recommend this game.

Urban Empire ist die Mischung aus einem RPG und einem Strategiespiel im Gewandt einer StÃ¤dtebausimulation. Als Teil einer Dynastie ist es die Aufgabe eine Stadt (und ein Land) zur BlÃ¼te zu fÃ¼hren, neue Technologien zu erforschen und mÃ¶glichst lange an der Macht zu bleiben.

Bester Moment:
2006: ich klammere mich an die Macht, mit allen Mitteln. Ich drohe, ich flehe, ich lasse im MÃ¼ll des Stadtrats wÃ¼hlen. Mal spiele ich Information der Presse zu, mal erklÃ¤re ich dem Kollegen, dass er diskreter vorgehen muss, wenn er gerne ins Bordell geht. Seine Dankbarkeit ist mir bei der nÃ¤chsten Wahl gewiss. Obwohl ich nie so werden wollte wie meine VorvÃ¤ter, die diese Stadt mit eiserner Faust regiert haben, wird mir klar, dass es mir schon lange nicht mehr um das Wohl der Stadt und der Menschen hier geht. Es geht nur darum, die nÃ¤chste Wahl zu gewinnen. MÃ¼sste ich dafÃ¼r jemanden tÃ¶ten â€“ ich wÃ¼rde es tun. Francis Underwood aus House of Cards wÃ¤re stolz auf mich. 

Schlimmster Moment:
1854: Was passiert hier Ã¼berhaupt? Ich habe drei Distrikte, eine Schule, ein paar StraÃŸenlaternen und ein groÃŸes finanzielles Problem. SteuererhÃ¶hung kann helfen, vermute ich. Der Stadtrat entscheidet dafÃ¼r, aber niemand will mehr hier leben. Zu teuer, nicht gut genug. Zu unsicher die StraÃŸen, aber eine Polizei darf ich nicht bauen. Zu ungesund, aber ein Krankenhaus darf ich nicht bauen. Zu langweilig, aber ein Theater darf ich nicht bauen. Ich habe PlÃ¤ne fÃ¼r einen Bahnhof vorliegen und die eines Hafens, aber der Stadtrat sperrt sich. Ich kÃ¶nnte all mein politisches Kapital aufwenden; aber wofÃ¼r? Damit ich wieder in die Schuldenfalle tappe? Kein Interesse. Stattdessen, schaue ich auf das Modell einer Stadt, die fÃ¼r mich, keinen visuellen Reiz besitzt. Null Wuselfaktor, keine Brillanz. Zum gefÃ¼hlten zehnten Mal wird im Stadtrat einen Beschluss zur Legalisierung der HomosexualitÃ¤t besprochen, zum gefÃ¼hlten zehnten Mal wird er mit 95% Mehrheit abgelehnt. Die Zeitung berichtet. Ich wÃ¼rde gerne etwas zum besseren Ã¤ndern, aber das Spiel gibt mir keine Hilfestellung wie ich das kÃ¶nnte. Stattdessen bin ich in einem verwalterischen Alptraum ohne Handlungsspielraum gefangen, den Kafka so hÃ¤tte beschreiben kÃ¶nnen. Ich kann wenigstens neu starten - K. konnte das nicht.
Warum tue ich mir das an? 

Nur kaufen bei hoher Frustrations-Toleranz.

Oh dear. I pre-ordered this game the moment I heard of it. What a great concept! Whenever I played SimCity or Cities: Skylines I always thought - 'something's missing'. Mayors are not dictators; they're constrained by constantly changing political circumstances and harassed by often viscious opposition parties. So a city game with the political element sounded ideal. Unfortunately I don't think I've ever been more disappointed by a game.

The developer clearly had a great idea but then struggled to realise it. The result is a flat, one-dimensional game that offers no depth either as a city builder or as a political simulator. The city building bit is ridiculously simplistic - drag and drop your district and, boom, you're done. The political simulation is equally simplistic. You want something? Ask the City Council for it and then 'influence' the parties - i.e. perform the same repetitive clicks over and over again - until they let you have it. It's too easy.

The different parties have no depth to them. I don't get the impression of dealing with a complex, roiling mass of confliciting political ambition like an actual city council would be. You don't even get to know the names of the party leaders - which is odd as the game is supposedly character-driven. They're just sort of... there. The bias towards socialist policies is also obvious and irritating.

Game mechanics are frustrating, too. The only thing you can really do to actually build your city, apart from place districts, is place services. These are crazy expensive so you can't place many and rather than their effectiveness being tied to how many people can reach them on the street - like most services in Cities: Skylines for example - there's a ridiculous radial influence that just leads you to bunch everything in the centre where it will reach more people.

Graphics, too, are poor. There isn't a feeling of a living, breathing city but of a dull, slow collection of pixels.

I could go on but in short - save your money (also - Â£35!!! Jog on). My only hope is that now this idea is out there, some other developer will turn it into a worthy game.

The bias towards socialist policies is also obvious and irritating.

Game mechanics are frustrating, too. The only thing you can really do to actually build your city, apart from place districts, is place services. These are crazy expensive so you can't place many and rather than their effectiveness being tied to how many people can reach them on the street - like most services in Cities: Skylines for example - there's a ridiculous radial influence that just leads you to bunch everything in the centre where it will reach more people.

Graphics, too, are poor. There isn't a feeling of a living, breathing city but of a dull, slow collection of pixels.

I could go on but in short - save your money (also - Â£35!!! Jog on). My only hope is that now this idea is out there, some other developer will turn it into a worthy game.

column8:
So... you want to play Sim City + The Guild? You're in the right place.

I've only finished my first full play through. I started once before and realized I had not set myself up for success very well.

In the early stages, it seems you want to nail down getting some districts up. Things must be at least somewhat large for your city to make income. You definitely want your city to have money. The politicians are very reluctant to let you do just about anything if you don't have money in the bank for it.

I think some people are disappointed because their vision was just a little different than what the game is. One aspect of this is the way I hear some people describe the game as basically on rails. Those criticisms range from choices having no affect at all to revisionist history not being possible.

I think the game has more depth than people are immediately aware of. I also think making it through will be a challenge.

There is some degree of "riding waves" here. I wouldn't say things are on rails because it isn't such a fair criticism since I'm pretty sure there are tons of different rails. The trick is getting your train on different tracks. You control technology, so you have decent control over what edicts hit the table. You can also sway public opinion so that different parties gain and lose public favor.

I made it up to the third era but was voted out of office.

The game definitely forces choices, but it seems this is very intentional design. The game isn't always about steering the ship exactly where you want. It's more about looking at the available options and making the best choices at the time so that you have more power to steer somewhere you want.

I think the game is good, and there are still three other houses I haven't tried yet. At somewhere around $2/hr, I'd definitely say it's worth it.

They do need to address performance issues, however. The game doesn't seem to be able to handle a whole city. I have a fairly good rig and it is sluggish with pretty much all graphics options turned off. Maybe lowering the resolution would help more, but really?

è¿™æ¸¸æˆå…¥åŒ…+1å§

A city builder with teeth. Finally. I won't sugar-coat it: there are flaws. The simulation underlying the mechanics is obtuse and REALLY needs more info exposed to the player while in-game, but a few hours playing with it will tell you a lot. Just don't expect to "win" on your first, second, or even third attempt. It also needs more agency on the part of the AI - the city council can stop you from doing things, but rarely does anything that would benefit the city itself. I'd like to see them propose districts on their own to help out stuck players, because it's easy to get into a situation where you're bankrupt and unable to advance, and there's only one gameplay event that helps with this. 

I'd also like more maps, more variety of history events for the various families (or even a random family altogether), and an ahistorical mode to help replayability. But as the game is, currently, it's still fun and worth the price.

So far so good. My only issue is the periods of time when Im doing nothing with the game sitting at 4x speed, perhaps there could be more micromanaging to occupy time in between votes etc...also it doesnt feel as much like a city-builder (i.e Tropico) as I would like, I would say its definitely worth it if depending on price of the game and future content. Kalypso usually has lots of DLC content which will hopefully increase the depth and replayability. Ill definitle keep checking back in.

column8: Had some fun in the 1st era but once got to era 3 was getting really bored, not much to do and found myself more just clicking along and not caring to upgrade the city anymore. The tax rates are broken as you can have it extremely high and the city goes on just fine. Game seems to have a memory leak as you have to restart it in the later era or it lags and the simulation starts to break. Finding my city income go back and for 100k each day for no real reason and there isn't anything to show why that is happening

I wanted to like this game, but it did not catch my interest after 30 minutes of play. The process of getting anything approved is tedious and the infrastructure installation in the districts is arcane at best. The tutorial and the UI are terrible. I requested a refund after an hour played.

just watching the city grow.

column8:
This is a painful review for me to write, but I am going to give this game two thumbs down. This game is awful. I want it to be good so badly. It is such a frustrating game that is fun to play through the first era, then everything after is miserable. Quick breakdown of how every game has gone for me:

1. Start game and build city that has lots of income and happiness through the first era

2. Second era begins and happiness requirments instantly change with no time to comply

3. Reduced happiness kills your economy so that you have no income. 

4. No income results in less happiness, and the political parties will not support you on anything that could save your city.

5. Now that you cannot add any infrastructure to your city, it falls severely behind and the third era pops into action and it is game over.

Idk how many games I have played now, and how many different approaches I have taken to growing my city, but they have all failed. I have played the tutorial, and even through following the tutorial the same exact disasters happened. It hurts to play this game. Every start feels like the begining of something great, only to turn into something that is so frustrating that you want to put a hole through your computer screen. Devs... fix this. I understand that you want to make something new and you did a good job of that, but your game is not fun. It feels like you are trying to set people up for failure in your game. Why is it that a single service costs the total amount that an entire district of majority industry and commerce can make? Why is it that to add one level of development it is significantly more than an entire city with 5 prospering districts incomes combined? Try this, when adding infrastructure to districts, lets have it give an actual visable impact on the economy that benefits the player.

It is such a frustrating game that is fun to play through the first era, then everything after is miserable. Quick breakdown of how every game has gone for me:

1. Start game and build city that has lots of income and happiness through the first era

2. Second era begins and happiness requirments instantly change with no time to comply

3. Reduced happiness kills your economy so that you have no income. 

4. No income results in less happiness, and the political parties will not support you on anything that could save your city.

5. Now that you cannot add any infrastructure to your city, it falls severely behind and the third era pops into action and it is game over.

Idk how many games I have played now, and how many different approaches I have taken to growing my city, but they have all failed. I have played the tutorial, and even through following the tutorial the same exact disasters happened. It hurts to play this game. Every start feels like the begining of something great, only to turn into something that is so frustrating that you want to put a hole through your computer screen. Devs... fix this. I understand that you want to make something new and you did a good job of that, but your game is not fun. It feels like you are trying to set people up for failure in your game. Why is it that a single service costs the total amount that an entire district of majority industry and commerce can make? Why is it that to add one level of development it is significantly more than an entire city with 5 prospering districts incomes combined? Try this, when adding infrastructure to districts, lets have it give an actual visable impact on the economy that benefits the player.

column8:
In a year this will be the best city building game this decade. All of the tools are there for Urban Empire to be the political sim of our dreams, and luckily all of the data the team needs is in the history of cities that already exist. 

A short list of things I would love to see (apologies if they are in the late game, posted this at around 6 hours played):

[list]
[*]Issuing bonds on city debt
[*]City council understands that it costs money to create a functioning district. An industrial/commercial district will make more money if employees can pour a glass of water. 
[*]Companies developing suburban areas (res/comm mix) frequently take on the cost of linking new subdivision infrastructre to utilities. That would be good. 
[*]City owned utilities producing revenue. 
[*]Waste removal/landfills as utility/institution
[*]Political promises to parties in exchange for votes
[*]Early membership in parties
[*]More options from the bully pulpit. I should be able to shame the Communists publicly for not giving women the vote. 
[*]Mayoral campaign control and budgeting
[*]Private-public partnerships (by now you should know I'm Canadian)
[*]Light rail/subways
[*]Mineral royalties from provincial governments
[*]Federal transfers/grants
[*]Sales/luxury/sin taxes (more than liquor and tobacco. I want people to pay taxes on their candy)
[*]Hydro-electric power
[*]Bidding on government contracts
[*]Sex scandals ;)
[/list]

The great part is, this all seems easily possible with this design. I can't wait.

[list]
[*]Issuing bonds on city debt
[*]City council understands that it costs money to create a functioning district. An industrial/commercial district will make more money if employees can pour a glass of water. 
[*]Companies developing suburban areas (res/comm mix) frequently take on the cost of linking new subdivision infrastructre to utilities. That would be good. 
[*]City owned utilities producing revenue. 
[*]Waste removal/landfills as utility/institution
[*]Political promises to parties in exchange for votes
[*]Early membership in parties
[*]More options from the bully pulpit. I should be able to shame the Communists publicly for not giving women the vote. 
[*]Mayoral campaign control and budgeting
[*]Private-public partnerships (by now you should know I'm Canadian)
[*]Light rail/subways
[*]Mineral royalties from provincial governments
[*]Federal transfers/grants
[*]Sales/luxury/sin taxes (more than liquor and tobacco. I want people to pay taxes on their candy)
[*]Hydro-electric power
[*]Bidding on government contracts
[*]Sex scandals ;)
[/list]

The great part is, this all seems easily possible with this design. I can't wait.

still buggy for a game with so little depth to its concepts. problems scale through time, but complexity does not. need more parks? build more parks. need more money? just raise taxes, doesnt matter on who, as parties dont differentiate.

there is also a push towards certain policies, where certain playstyles just dont work. you either keep enacting progressive policies and raising taxes with pretty much no penality, or you do nothing.  I was hoping this would have more depth and a little more consequences for actions.


Also Im not much of a fan of the load times even on an SSD, or the fact the three games I've started have all broken due to bugs while trying to load save games.

column8:
YOU ALWAYS END UP IN DEBT. 

The AI parties can be pretty terrible. When I'm facing budgetary deficits in the last era they reject the infrastructure measures that are actually designed to save money on infrastructure spending (Like converting transport to automated) in each district. Why would the parties vote against something that would cost-costs at no expense to the people in the district?! As a result I just ended up going into debt pretty quickly with no way of reducing costs, despite the economic boost from all the business edicts and edicts that help citizen income on private companies.


Also, it would be better if there was a  to when newer upgrades and ordinances are available, as it can be cumbersome and tiresome to keep checking which update.
