17/6/10
According to the current situation, I don't think this game will fulfill its potential. And obviously, the team didn't pay much attention to the players' feedback. They only treated us seriously at the very beginning of the sale. And now... you know what happens.

------

This game had the potential to be a great work based on its conception. But, for now, it merely remains as a potentially good game. Really hope that the developers and the community will continue to improve, fulfill, and extend the game's content. This game deserves to be a masterpiece!!!!!! Recommended for its potential even now.
------

I started keeping an eye on this game about six months ago. Although the European pre-order price was not cheap, I ultimately pre-ordered it just before release. After playing for a few hours, I can only say that if you're not a die-hard fan of strategy-simulation games, it's best to wait and see the quality of the DLC, or buy it when it's on sale.

This game shouldn't be a city-building sim, but a municipal strategy sim. From the very beginning, what captivated me about this game was its concept: a municipal simulation. According to the promotional material, players no longer play the role of an omnipotent, hands-on God, but rather simply a mayor, a living, breathing person struggling through the treacherous political game while striving to realize their ideals. Players shouldn't worry about which roads can be turned or whether several districts are neatly arranged; what awaits us in the game is the conflict, struggle, and peace between different classes and groups. A complex web of events, woven together by historical changes, natural processes, and the whims of human nature, tests how players can survive the turbulent political landscape, perhaps even reach the pinnacle of their lives (marrying an emperor/empress?), and ultimately leave their mark on the rise and fall of their nation and the people of the world.

How could a game with such an idea not be exciting? However, judging by the finished product, it's only that concept that excites.

If nothing else, the most important aspect of a game centered around politics (and its interplay with economic, cultural, and social factors) is its content, or, to put it simply, its logic and details! Portraying the complex social life and interpersonal relationships at the turn of times is key to the success of this type of game. Therefore, as a "city political strategy simulation," the developers didn't focus on a completely open sandbox mode like games like SimCity or Cities: Skylines. Instead, they sought to recreate social life within a unique historical context through a scripted setting, allowing players to immerse themselves in it and, within limited freedom and established goals, experience the operation of the city's political system, economic and cultural changes, conflicts of class interests, and the struggle for political power. Expressing political logic through plot progression is undoubtedly a wise choice.

However, the developers don't seem to have put enough effort into staying within their chosen boundaries. The similarly themed Democracy series demonstrates how conflicts of interest, class divisions, and factional struggles complicate the game of political decision-making. To vividly portray this process and every aspect of it requires detailsâ€”plenty of them. While Urban Empire paints a decent picture, it fails to fill it with sufficiently rich and profound content. In other words, since you already have a script, could you please make it more detailed and comprehensive? What we see in the game is a loosely constructed interaction between vote counts and other metrics like party favorability, public happiness, and budgets. Beyond their different names, logos, and political affiliations, the various parties seem to leave little lasting impression. The various families available to players don't differ significantly in gameplay or plot progression. Worse still, aside from the differences in the game's text, the game's winning objectives are incredibly simple, and the methods employed are incredibly monotonous, making it a game where you can literally "win without effort." Furthermore, even if it's considered a landscape simulator, the dark, grimy industrial towns of the early 20th century don't seem to compare to the picturesque island scenery. Furthermore, the game's artwork and sound effects are merely passable.

Overall, the development team seems to have struggled to balance freedom and gameplay. This is primarily due to a lack of content and detail, as well as flawed game logic. If subsequent DLC can continue to enrich the gameplay, or if mods are available for player customization, I believe this game still has the potential to become a masterpiece.

Finally, the game's localization work is commendable. The quality and dedication are both satisfying (although there are a few bugs, it's clear the game's developers are diligently addressing them). However, this review is meant to encourage everyone to put aside the urge to "like it because it's in Chinese" and to calmly reflect on the game's inherent issues.

Finally, I hope the game's developers will take players' feedback seriously and continue to improve. Of course, DLC is welcome, but it shouldn't be too expensive!!!

column8:
I'm completely hooked, one of my favourite political/builder simulators. While it can not compete with the likes of Cities Skylines regarding city managment the political aspects are right up my alley.

A must have in my library.

This would be a good game if it would give you more feedback on your decisions.
Right now, you do something and it might have a positive or negative effect you can guess why but you never know or find out. This is the most confusing city sim I ever played!

column8:
Schade. 

Ein Spiel das eigentlich SpaÃŸ macht geht dann doch schnnell der Athmen aus, bzw. man wird tot geschlagen. 

Habe jetzt mehrere, ich glaube 8, Partien gespielt. Die spÃ¤teren gehen deutlich schnller , da man die Ereignisse oft kennt, da unterscheiden sich die Familien nicht sehr voneinader. Leider kamen immer wieder mehrere Bugs auf. Und dann ist das Spiel meiner Ansicht nach Bock schwer fÃ¼r Einsteiger. Denn ohne Taktiken (Die man dann im achten Versuch langsamkennt; aber die Ereignisse dann eben auch) hat man keine Chance. Am Anfang heiÃŸt es also Bezirke spamen, was auf den ersten Blick nicht ersichtlich ist. 

Hat man dann doch ein gutes Polster angelegt, sowohl am Rad des Lebens, bei den KontosÃ¤nden und beim Saldo, und auch viele Institutionen gebaut, kommt die dritte Epoche. Ab hier beginnt das Spiel eigentlich erst, da man nun BÃ¼rgermeisterwahlen hat. Problem nur, dass hier wohl die Entwickler aufgehÃ¶rt haben zu arbeiten. Zumindest die Bugs werden irre viel. Zum Beispiel die oben gennaten Wahlen. Man kann Sie teilweise nicht anklicken und beeinflussen. Sie sie dran, kann man nur durch klicken des Play-Pfeils auf sie zugreifen. 

Aber das ist noch das kleinere Problem. Meist hat man gar keine Chance sie zu gewinnen, da sich die Oben genannten Werte extrem verschlechtern. So sackt das Saldo meist von 400 tsd plus auf 100 tsd ab. Geht ja vielleicht noch. Problem ist nun die Sadtkasse .. Dort habe ich auf einmal ein Defizit von meist Ã¼ber 35 MIO (Und das mind. in 3 Spielen bis jetzt und IMMER beim Laden.) Und das kann man dann mit dem Saldo nicht mehr reparieren, bis die nÃ¤chste Wahl ansteht, da auch die Parteien keine SteuererhÃ¶hung mÃ¶chten. 

Am Ende bin ich nur einmal weit in die dritte Epoche eingetaucht, bis mich das Spiel auch in diesem Savegame GAMEOVER setzte und meine Stadtkasse plÃ¼nderte. Und einiges mehr.
Die Hotfixes sind lÃ¤cherlich im Gegensatz zu der groÃŸen Bugdichte des Midgames. 

LEIDER nur bis zur Epoche III spielbar und somit einfach kein fertiges Spiel. (Wie erwÃ¤hnt, kein Einzelfall.) 

Deswegen ganz klar auf Patches etc. warten. Noch NICHT kaufen. UNFERTIG. Wieder MAl.

UPDATE: 

Konnte inwischen das Savegame retten. Am Anfang der 3. Epoche einfach Steuern max. erhÃ¶ht. (Ging einfach ohne Probleme. Komisch.) Dann war natÃ¼rlich der Witz auch dahin, da ich so viel Geld hatt, das ich erst im Jahr 2018 wieder Ã¼berhaupt einmal minus hatte. Also auch verbuggt. 
Dazu kamen viele bekannte Performance Problme im Endgame. 
Weiterhin Idee super, umsetzung naja.

Would not purchase at this time.  Minus all the bugs that I will assume will eventually get crushed which make the game currently unplayable (vanishing money, etc) the entire premise is BS and the developers really made zero attempt to hide their political biases.  The game promised a political (mayoral) city builder but honestly there is only one acceptable path forward if you want to "succeed" at the game, Progressivism.  You try and run any economic or political method and the game becomes either impossible or near so to play even if real life says otherwards.  Not asking the same difficulty all the way through but the game is so biased as to make it unfun, ditto terminology for example, i.e. "Relax minor sodomy laws" isn't +1 GLBT rights as GLBT rights A) Weren't a city issue and B) the term didn't even exist until the 1990's basically.  Nobody gave a flying !@#$% about GLBT rights in era 1 or 2, at best you should say "Gay rights" or even "homosexual rights".  Also decisions should matter, i.e. there should be positive aspects to rejecting gay or women rights (because there are in real life) and their should be negatrive aspects to approving them (ditto) though we can hem and haw over the percentages, point is games like this should offer tradeoffs as no measure is 100% positive, most aren't even majoirty positive.

Figure out what you want to make this game and then make it that way because right now it's just a Progressive wet dream if they were God to show everybody else the errors of their way.
column9:
Would not purchase at this time.  Minus all the bugs that I will assume will eventually get crushed which make the game currently unplayable (vanishing money, etc) the entire premise is BS and the developers really made zero attempt to hide their political biases.  The game promised a political (mayoral) city builder but honestly there is only one acceptable path forward if you want to "succeed" at the game, Progressivism.  You try and run any economic or political method and the game becomes either impossible or near so to play even if real life says otherwards.  Not asking the same difficulty all the way through but the game is so biased as to make it unfun, ditto terminology for example, i.e. "Relax minor sodomy laws" isn't +1 GLBT rights as GLBT rights A) Weren't a city issue and B) the term didn't even exist until the 1990's basically.  Nobody gave a flying !@#$% about GLBT rights in era 1 or 2, at best you should say "Gay rights" or even "homosexual rights".  Also decisions should matter, i.e. there should be positive aspects to rejecting gay or women rights (because there are in real life) and their should be negatrive aspects to approving them (ditto) though we can hem and haw over the percentages, point is games like this should offer tradeoffs as no measure is 100% positive, most aren't even majoirty positive.

Figure out what you want to make this game and then make it that way because right now it's just a Progressive wet dream if they were God to show everybody else the errors of their way.

I started this game full of hope... which this game drowned in a shallow puddle.

Video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I8-jOM1KkPk

Text:
As always, watch the video for a much more detailed analysis. 

Urban Empire looks pretty - that much is uncontested. The various time periods, design choices and distinct detail in every nook and cranny ooze personality. From character art to research screen, everything looks fantastic. It also has pretty good PC Performance with no dips below 60 at any time and smooth gameplay on any level of zoom.

Sadly, this performance is achieved in part by just having almost no simulation of life in the town. Street look empty, sounds are subdued when available and everything just moves at a snails pace that doesn't really fit with the "month per tick" cycle of the game. 

But, it's not the visuals that make this game bland... It's the gameplay. Between having very limited information (that has almost no detail or depth) and very limited control over the city building that makes it for a very hands of and very frustrating experience. Not being able to assign districts directly, and not being able to build your infrastructure beyond a "draw a box, call it a district and yay" is not that fun and more than that ... everything is ridiculously expensive that keeping a solid balance is nigh on impossible... oh and keeping your economy running doesn't matter anyhow, there are no consequences

Also, the expected political gameplay boils down to a sliderbar with a score on top. The expected depth of political gameplay or intrigue really never shows up and all voting boils down to is how often you've done one of 3 random events.

Also, almost anything is put to the vote, but by and large the parties don't really oppose you in any way. With neither real counter plays or divergences in ethics being apparent in their per-vote look at things. And nothing you do will have any long or even mid term impact.

Overal a shallow experience that fills a few hours before you crave either City building or Political gameplay, and it provides neither in any real way.

Die Spielmechanik ist zum groÃŸen Teil fÃ¼r den Spieler nicht nachvollziehbar.

Das Tutorial ist eher mangelhaft und erklÃ¤rt einem lediglich das HUD aber nicht das Spiel.

FrÃ¼her oder spÃ¤ter kommt man an den Punkt in dem man einen Fehler macht, ins Minus rutscht und das meist aus GrÃ¼nden die schier unerklÃ¤rlich sind... Dann beginnt die AbwÃ¤rtsspirale...Die Parteien im Rat schlagen stÃ¤ndig SteuererhÃ¶hungen vor... Ein oder Zwei mal kann man das verhindern, zerstÃ¶rt aber damit seine Reputation und kann dann beim dritten mal nichts mehr entegegensetzen... Dann wandern die Einwohner und die Industrie ab und wieder kommt der Rat mit der SteuererhÃ¶hung um die Ecke weil die Bilanz ja wieder negativ ist... Game Over!

Eine Entscheidung zu treffen wie man am besten auf die zufÃ¤lligen Ereignisse reagiert ist vÃ¶llig unmÃ¶glich da man nie vorher erfÃ¤hrt welchen Effekte eine Entscheidung auf das Spiel hat. Das erfÃ¤hrt man immer erst wenn man geklickt hat und dann ist es zu spÃ¤t.

Ich habe es auch noch nie geschafft dass der Satdtaufbau und das anpasssen der Bezirke mit dem Forschungsfortschritt mithalten kann. Das kÃ¶nnte auch daran liegen dass die Epochen viel kurz sind um alles zu "schaffen" was man in den einzelnen Epochen so erleben kann.

Im groÃŸen und ganzen ist die Idee hinter dem Spiel sensationell, aber einfach nicht gut umgesetzt. Ich hoffe insgeheim auf viele VerÃ¤nderung durch Updates.

Aber im Moment kann ich definitiv keine Kaufentscheidung geben.

column8:
Right now I voting that this game gets a no vote from me.  I don't really have that many issues with the game but I would like it if there was a correct way of governing that wasn't completely leftist.  For example if I raise taxes to 100% people shouldn't have money anymore.  I know that is an extreme example but there really isn't a reason to lower taxes in this game like there would be in real life.  Or if there is it should say it.  Also for liberal ideas which grant more rights it should be possible to lose the vote rather than getting an overwhelming majority of people in the council that always forces the issue.  Stuff like this gives an illusion of choice.  You could try it differently but the game forces you into a direction.  I wonder if the personal views of the devolper caused for this to happen because it seems to be a trend in other games like this as well(anything involving politics seem like they are try to teach you the correct way to think).  

Also there still are bugs.  For example when you vote for a new mayor it doesn't tell you how the people are actually going to vote after you use your goodwill.  The screen just stays the same and doesn't change.  Also as I am writing this the blackmail feature doesn't work anymore.  Tooltips.  I would be nice if the game had them for more things other than having you click on an option and hoping you make the choice you wanted to.

Lastly I don't like the save system.  Right now it isn't a problem but what if in the future I would like to say start another game.  The saves don't really seem to be ordered that well.  Of course I haven't tried deleting saves yet so I don't know how different it would be.

Anyway just some thoughts on the product.  I'm pretty sure it could be fixed with patches but right now stuff like this takes a lot of the fun out of it.

column8: I was really looking forward to this game. The concept has potential. Unfortunatly, the execution is disapointing. There isn't much to do: you designate a district within which the little people can build; you adjust taxes; you issue edicts and then (the main point of the game) you go to the senate chamber and vote on your choices. Before the vote takes place, you have the opportunity to influence the parties. This is it. The whole purpose of the game... and it's so simplistic. It should have been marketed as a casual game, because there is very little depth. I managed to go long stretches without having to convince the parties... which means the game kind of plays itself for long stretches.
column9: I was really looking forward to this game. The concept has potential. Unfortunatly, the execution is disapointing. There isn't much to do: you designate a district within which the little people can build; you adjust taxes; you issue edicts and then (the main point of the game) you go to the senate chamber and vote on your choices. Before the vote takes place, you have the opportunity to influence the parties. This is it. The whole purpose of the game... and it's so simplistic. It should have been marketed as a casual game, because there is very little depth. I managed to go long stretches without having to convince the parties... which means the game kind of plays itself for long stretches.

The game is fantastic. Grow your city and society through development, laws, edicts; no "cookie cutte"  city blocks. Develop your chacater through random events, influence the city council...the joy of effecting the world through indirect control of policy and development. Awesome!

Despite the resemblance to other city-builders such as SimCity and Cities: Skylines, Urban Empire is first and foremost a political simulator.  You play the role of mayor of a city located in the fictional nation of Swarelia and you'll be responsible for guiding your city through five different time periods, from the industrial revolution to the modern era.  Like the city-building games mentioned before, you will oversee the growth and development of your city, zoning residential, commercial and industrial districts as well as adding service buildings (police stations, hospitals, churches, etc) and issuing edicts.  However, you do not rule with absolute authority - the decisions you make are subject to approval by the city council.  The council is made up of multiple parties, each with their own agenda, so it may be necessary to appease the voters order to get them to see things your way.

Here is a quick run down of the pros and cons of this game.

PROS:

- Good quality graphics - any changes are visually displayed on the city view screen such as adding street lights or upgrading roads from dirt to cobblestone, etc.

- Extensive tech tree that allows you to upgrade your city in a variety of ways.

- Detailed statistics screens on a variety of subjects.

- Game features multiple dynasties to play as, each with their own strengths and weaknesses, adding some replayability to the game.

- The political wheeling and dealing you engage in is quite fun.

- Detailed tutorial that offers advice as you play the game.

CONS

- Some of the statistics can be a little confusing.

- The UI is not the friendliest.

- While the tutorial is detailed, it can also be intrusive at times.

- There aren't that many maps to play on.

- Gameplay can feel repetitive at times, I suspect the developer is looking to flesh this out with DLC.

- The city-building aspect is a little basic.

CONCLUSION

Overall, it's a fun game that's not without its flaws.  If you enjoy city-builders, but are looking for something a little bit different, I think you will like this.

A difficult game to review because it's very difficult to tell whether it's fun or not. It's also very difficult to tell just about anything happening in your city. I very much enjoyed the opening half-hour, getting involved in city politics, forming likes and dislikes towards certain parties that opposed the type of city I was trying to create, and unlocking different services for the first time.

This quickly fizzled out when I advanced to era II and wanted to try to stimulate my industrial areas to provide taxes to further improve my existing districts, and I realised I had no idea how businesses actually work. Sales demand is counterintuitive (lowering it is...Better?), extra sales, efficiency, quality, and lots of nice other words that the game fails to explain the significance of. After some prodding, raising and lowering business tax and keeping track of the finances of certain businesses I've managed to work out the general gist of how things work, and yet I still feel woefully underinformed about what policies to implement regarding the industrial and commercial sectors, and consequently have little intution about what to build in my residential districts. 

Is the economy growing or shrinking? I'unno.
Is my city business friendly? I'unno.
Should I take steps to improve conditions for doing business, or can they handle a 2-3% rise in taxation? I'unno.

And it's a game where information is key, half of the difficulty comes from an irritatingly unhelpful UI. Which is just unacceptable for a game considered to be in a finished and playable state. 

So, I'd suggest saving your money for now, at least until one of the great sages among us have figured out how to play it and post a guide, because it promises to be quite fun in the moments of clarity you experience from time to time.

Grudgingly, 4/10.

I have put several hours in this game, but out of the 8.3 hours most of those took place where I was AFK. I was very excited for this game to come out, it is right in my wheelhouse for games that i love to play. Unfortunately, Urban Empire falls way short of my expectations. The game is incredibly boring and does not feel like a finished product. This is not a $40,00 game, If you have some interest I would recommend waiting till a 50% off sale, and do not go afk for hours. After one-hour you will be returning the game.
Disappointing experience - I would not recommend.
Im sure after many DLC's (which Kalypso is notorious for) the game will be average and they will have $80 of your hard earned money.
Steam should be ashamed that they let their customers be taken on a game of such poor quality.

column8:
So much potential, so much disappointment.

This is not a 'city builder' in any sense of the phrase.  It is not a 'city ruler' either.  It's a stare at a map with very minimal interaction until you have to go and vote in the city council.

I wanted this game to be fun - it's a unique concept to add the politics into a city game.  It simply isn't.  It's boring and tedious.

And as I'd 'played' it beyond two hours - to try to give it a chance, I can't even get my money back due to Steam's ridiculous refund policy.

Save your time and money - avoid this game.

This game seems to have been rushed to publication. A great number of spelling and also grammatical errors in the english version certainly hints at that, as well as severe memory leaks in endgame which make the experience very laggy. 

I like the concept of the game and I like its challenges. However, the voting system that allows the player to stay in office - or not - seems arbitrary. All of a sudden parties who like you and who you have positive standing with will vote against you. It is a frustrating aspect that makes re-starting a scenario a burden instead of an enjoyable prospect to play the game with a new focus. 

I do enjoy the game and would like to recommend it at this point, but it would not be a heartfelt recommendation.
column9:
This game seems to have been rushed to publication. A great number of spelling and also grammatical errors in the english version certainly hints at that, as well as severe memory leaks in endgame which make the experience very laggy. 

I like the concept of the game and I like its challenges. However, the voting system that allows the player to stay in office - or not - seems arbitrary. All of a sudden parties who like you and who you have positive standing with will vote against you. It is a frustrating aspect that makes re-starting a scenario a burden instead of an enjoyable prospect to play the game with a new focus. 

I do enjoy the game and would like to recommend it at this point, but it would not be a heartfelt recommendation.

column8: The game is fairly limited and has much potential in the future. I haven't ran into any bugs at the moment, but there seems to be plenty of bugs. I really enjoy the game so far, and the game does need a lot of work, but this could become a great game in the future. I recommend the game, purely because the larger the community, the more we can discuse weaknesses and potential improvements.
column9: The game is fairly limited and has much potential in the future. I haven't ran into any bugs at the moment, but there seems to be plenty of bugs. column8:
An interesting idea, shallowly created and poorly executed. That's really all I can say for it. The political aspect seems to be a crapshoot which encourages you to essentially not engage with it because trying to will almost always result in all of the political parties hating you, while not engaging with it will have them all basically rubberstamp whatever services and districts you wish to place down. 

Beyond placing distrcts and services, there really isn't anything to the game. Not worth it's stated price-tag.

column8:
Idea behind the game is very good. However the game itself is NOT.
They should have spend more time on developing it to perfection. Also need to mention that its keeps crashing almost every time! Not worth buying it at all.

I was a great mayor, surplus of money, citizens were happy and healthy. Then one day it all changed. One political party fractured into many parties as technology advanced and our people grew entitled and selfish. Resulting in the communist party.

The communist party latched onto my success as a mayor and then pushed all other parties that supported me away, then had the audacity to vote me out of office, destroying all of my political support. I lost the game because I let the communists fester. I can't remember the last time I have actually seen a 'Game Over' screen. Probably Dark Souls.

Trump is just now in office and he's making video games great again!

Communism, not even once.

10/10 would grow a successful empire for the communists to subvert agian.

column9: All game mechanics are clearly explained in the creators' manual, which is available in Russian. If you're willing to read and understand it, you'll forget about other city-building games in a couple of hours. My main complaint about the creators is the lack of a coherent tutorial system within the game itself. But this is a problem with many challenging games, including Hearts of Iron from Paradox.

column8:
Das Spiel bietet auf jeden Fall ne Menge SpaÃŸ. Es ist eine Kombination aus Tropico, SimCity und den Forschungsaspekten von Civilization, gepaart mit der Stadtsrat-OberflÃ¤che.

Bugs habe ich auch festgestellt, sind aber nicht der Rede wert. Allerdings hat das Spiel noch ne Menge Potenzial. Es gibt fast in allen Bereichen des Spiels Kleinigekeiten, die man verbessern kÃ¶nnte. Das Nervigste ist, find ich, dass man den Kamerawinkel bzw. -zoom nicht so ausrichten kann, dass man die ganze Stadt im Blick hat.

tl;dr it plays like a really basic city builder that delays construction when you've gotten into the swing of things. This should be early access at best, it needs loads of refining to be anywhere near what they have been showcasing.

It's 1960, my people are quite happy with my governing of the city, there's no water lines, sewage pipes or electric anywhere within the city. Despite this the Television business is booming, not sure how my people intend to watch the TV's, but I can't judge them.
The roads are still the same old dirt roads from the 1800's everyone is happy to drive around their cars on this with minimal traffic problems.
The communist party is quite happy for me to raise tax on the working class and lower it for the elite.

The game boasts having an indepth political system where you need to battle with different parties to make changes, but there's no point at all in picking favourites to buddy up with as all relations with these parties will reset back to 0 after a couple of years. So you can generally treat them how you want.
City expansion only becomes a problem if you have both a low income and low funds in the account, as then all parties will try to block all decisions you make. However if you're sitting there with a few hundred k in the bank, they will generally green light everything you want to do, like build an electrical power plant purely to export the power it creates.
The parties as well are not really sticking to what you think they would, you will quite often see the conservatives pushing for social equality with the progressive sides trying to block these movements, and as mentioned before, communists liking to tax the working class high.

The people in your city are quite happy to live with no water, electric or gas supplies. You can add these services to districts, but you get no return for doing so, people won't pay extra for them, so you're just throwing money away. They do claim to "boost companies" but again, increasing the sales of companies in your city doesn't actually do anything for your own income.

The rpg story elements hardly do anything for the game, you can choose one of 4 families with different back stories and ideas towards governing. All switching between these really does it decide which events you're going to get, and they will be the same ones each time at the exact same time, you get a few outside of this, like parties wanting to make you honourary members etc. but they're mostly meaningless. 
Your character has traits, cruel, soft, opitmist etc. again, mostly meaningless. You might get the odd event pop up with a response option blocked due to lack of x trait, but refering back, your traits and what you say on these windows rarely matters.

Until elections come around, you don't need to make your citizens happy at all. No chance of an uprising due to lack of healthcare, policing, leisure or anything at all. You can quite happily ignore all the demands of your citizens until the ability to vote comes along, and you can even try to prevent that for an extended time.

Small aesthetic thing that bothers me. Why can I see loads of cars driving around my city when I've not even researched them yet. Also why do all the houses and shops have lights on at night if there's absoloutely no electrical grids in the city.

The game had some great ideas with the whole political thing, you can even blackmail parties, but they just don't mean anything towards running the city. You can spend the entire game never having to speak to any of them apart from suggesting changes to the city and waiting for them to agree on it.
And the fact that you can have a city with 0 utilities and everyone is ok with that bewilders me, but then you can't afford to give them to the entire city anyway.

column8:
Good game. An interesting political and economical simulator.
+ Reasonably difficult, you can be voted out in eras 3-5 if you're on bad terms with the political parties
+ Depicts the history in an interesting way, you can feel the world changing over time
+ Keeps you invested in the game, presents the player with challenges even in the late game (for me it was actually the hardest party-wise in the late game)
- Hard to understand the reasons behind what is happening at times (e.g. persistent low residential demand, constant influx of lower class citizens). Tooltips like the ones in Victoria 2 would be welcome. Many things may be not evident, like what exactly the tax rate does, I think at least an explanation would be good in such cases.
- Some things that you expect would happen, don't. E.g. people moving between the districts or preferring particular ones
- Watch your RAM and save frequently on the later stages, the game crashed to desktop for me around year 2010, for some other people too (8GB RAM)

All in all, I spent the weekend playing the game and had good fun, in my opinion that makes the game deserve a good recommendation despite some issues which may or may not be resolved later.

In its current state, I can not recommend it. After playing a while this game looks more like a Early Access title than a finished game.
Most negativ and frustrating factors:

-- Massive lags in later epochs ( beginning in about epoche III ) even with my high end PC ( Skylake i7 and GTX 1080 ) and even with only medium graphic settings. Last 2 epochs are so laggy that they really make just no fun. You play them only through so you did it at least once.
-- Certain calculations are buggy. For Example you can save and just load the same game and you can have a total different happiness and/or monthly income.
-- Its totally unclear how different decisions impact economy. And sometimes decisions just take no effect. For axample: I built a harbour. In one a game, this was a huge boost tho the industry and on another nothing happend at all. That lack of infromation is frustrating.
-- Bugs... I just mention two obvious ones:
                -  Game crashed multiple times while loading saved games or while starting the game.
                - After leaving to the main menu, some menu points were english but my settings were german.
column9:
In its current state, I can not recommend it. After playing a while this game looks more like a Early Access title than a finished game.
Most negativ and frustrating factors:

-- Massive lags in later epochs ( beginning in about epoche III ) even with my high end PC ( Skylake i7 and GTX 1080 ) and even with only medium graphic settings. Last 2 epochs are so laggy that they really make just no fun. You play them only through so you did it at least once.
-- Certain calculations are buggy. For Example you can save and just load the same game and you can have a total different happiness and/or monthly income.
-- Its totally unclear how different decisions impact economy. And sometimes decisions just take no effect. For axample: I built a harbour. In one a game, this was a huge boost tho the industry and on another nothing happend at all. That lack of infromation is frustrating.
-- Bugs... I just mention two obvious ones:
                -  Game crashed multiple times while loading saved games or while starting the game.
                - After leaving to the main menu, some menu points were english but my settings were german.

column9:
The Chinese localization is indeed high quality. There are a few bugs, and the optimization is a bit poor. Even the lowest setting in the later stages can cause lags. Is it really my computer?

In the early stages, basically don't worry about setting up buildings, facilities, or infrastructure. Otherwise, you'll lose a lot of money. Fortunately, the people won't rebel against you (I once raised the tax rate to 95%, and the people didn't react at all...).

The service scope of facilities in the mid-to-late stages is incredibly large, so there's no need to rush to build.

As long as you're not losing money and have a lot of money, you can build anything.

With money, you can basically ignore political parties and do whatever you want, except for bills.

When you have money, the only obstacles political parties pose to you are re-election and the implementation of some bills. Re-election can be withdrawn, so it's not a problem.

The game has two aspect.  The city council politics play and city builder.  The city council part is shallow and incomplete.  The city builder part, however, does offer a lot of depth and novel ideas.  The negative reviews calling otherwise probably does not understand the game.  It is hardly their fault though.  This game is so poorly designed on representing mechanism information to player.  The shallow tutorial barely explains the UI and interface.  And even if you bother to read the game manual, it still fail to uncover mist on some of the most important mechanisms like how social mobility works.  The catastrophic failure of presenting mechanism information to player effectively made it more of a puzzle game rather than a sim game.

Rants aside, the game does have some novel design such as people's needs can be served by private sector or public sector.  And you can choose to collect a lot of tax and serve people directly, or use policy to guide the private sector to do that.  The two path apparently repesents two different modern political ideaology and was supposed to interfere with the city council politics system.  However, the mechanism behind this is more complicated than it sounds and, again, is barely explained, reaping all the potential fun off it.

In conclusion it is very hard to have fun with this game even if you are a veteran of city builder game and is willing to read the manual word by word.  But do take a look at the game manual to see if you think it is worth a try.  There is a lot in this game, it is just so hard to dig them out.

column8: æ²¡é’±â†’ä¿®ä¸äº†åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½â†’ä¼ä¸šæ— æ³•å‘å±•â†’è®®ä¼šæ‹’ç»åŠ ç¨â†’æ— æ³•å¢åŠ ç¨æ”¶â†’æ²¡é’±

The game attempts to combine city building and politics and fails in both aspects. Both of these features lack proper depth and lack replayability after the first game due to their repetitive nature. The city building lacks proper customisability and when the city gets too large, the game crawls to a very low FPS.

The council is poorly implemented, parties will become defunct in the next era no matter how popular they are within the city. The only real interaction with the council is threatening or spying on them to pass a law.

The game can be summed up in three features: Place a district, change taxes and pass a very linear set of laws every game. The game has a good concept, but a very bad execution.

column8: å¾ˆå¥‡æ€ªçš„è®¾å®šï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰çš„è®¾æ–½éƒ½éœ€è¦æŠ•ç¥¨ï¼Œé—®é¢˜æ˜¯ä¸ç®¡æ˜¯å¦éœ€è¦ï¼Œéƒ½éœ€è¦è·ªèˆ”ï¼Œæˆ‘è¿˜èˆ”ä¸æ˜ç™½ã€‚ã€‚ã€‚ã€‚ã€‚

I want to really like this game; I expected a more indepth and political Tropico 3/4/5. Tropico's politics were tight but felt natural; if you worked at it you could make any voting block your reliable supporters and grow their numbers which also tended to anger their counterparts. Winning elections and not infuriating people into becoming rebels was a seemless part of the challenge of making a profitable island. 

Urban Empire, despite being all about the politics fails to keep things are clear or as simple to grasp as that. In fact I feel that a political party's feeling about anything at any given time is up to luck. There is no way to identify a solid political party that will have your back and who will actually support your re-election seems random.

And let's face the elephant in the room, this game is heavily biased in the Liberal-Socialist wing side of politics since the State Laws are almost exclusively Liberal or Socialist in nature and are clearly railroaded to happen sooner rather than later. Let me return to Tropico; yeah it made sense that Tropico was more on the Socialist end being a banana republic under good old El Pres' but the Capitalists Faction would constantly tempt you to open up and if you didn't they would clearly and angrily oppose you. 

I feel none of that from opposition parties in Urban Empire; once the Edict or Law passes it is untouchable and no one seems to care anymore. No one cares about anything! I feel no passion in anything! It's a dull boring march to becoming a Unionized Heavily Taxed Welfare State and no one in the actual city seems to care! There is no protest or fanfair, no one rallies around a party to counter my changes or gets angry when a bill is voted down! I know politics is dull and thankless but I struggle to believe there are living human beings in my city and not just buses!

Sadly, I knew this game would be a letdown. I had expected the lackluster city management but I always hoped the Politics would be interesting. It is just not.

20 hours and multiple victories in.

Urban Empires is an okay game. It seriously lacks depth once you bite into it and the developers didn't really put much attention into making sure that multiple play styles are competitive. At the end of the day the "best" move is to just go fully socialist liberal since almost all related edicts are totally positive anyway. I'm willing to bet that the overwhelmiongly positive effects that liberal and leftists edicts give is at least partially based on the developers own political opinions. There should be multiple feasible paths to victory even if you don't agree politically. Such a shame really.

Gay rights? Yes. Feminism? Of course! The bonuses are too good to pass. Same for child labor, women's rights, LGBT rights, etc. Rinse and repeat. I get that many of us support these things in real life but in a game each choice needs to have benefits and flaws. The game rewards progressive ideas by removing all flaws.

Furthermore the political parties are nothing more than a simple resource system. They have no agency or personality of their own. The other "players" in the game lack any sense of reason behind their choices. They don't have any clearly seen agenda and this hurts the game immenseley. Yes liberals are more likely to vote for more taxes and conservatives are more likely to oppose them but that's as far as the depth goes. 

My last point focuses on events and the world at large. As you play, diffferent events come to pass on the world stage but ultimatley it doesn't matter what you do or how you react. It always plays out the same way with no real consequences for choices or outcomes of events. It doesn't matter if you support independence or not because at the end of the day it all disappears without explanation when you move to the next era. I didn't even realize we got independence until I saw some random screen with a reference. It didn't even matter. This happens with every event tied to the larger world.

TLDR: The developers hit on a great concept and if the game was 10 bucks I'd say they nailed it as far as liberal progressive SJW style games go. At 40.00 dollars we deserve far more depth and far more meaningful choices/options. Leave your politics at home and just focus on making a good game please devs.

å¾ˆå¤æ‚çš„æ”¿æ²»æ¨¡æ‹Ÿæ¸¸æˆã€‚å¦‚æœï¼Œä½ åªæƒ³ç©åŸå¸‚å»ºè®¾æ¸¸æˆï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆå®ƒä¸é€‚åˆä½ ã€‚

I'm really enjoying this game -- managing relationships with political parties, begging/forcing what I know to be best for the city, trying to not burn so many bridges that I can no longer be re-elected...all while pushing for equal rights for all citizens, advancing technologies, etc.

I also enjoy the deep-dive you can do on stats.  At one point in the year 1914, I discovered that my town of ~3000 people had a whopping 22 movie theaters, and the number one employer of middle class citizens?  Movie production companies.  I'm a burgeoning Hollywood!

The biggest minus is that the game frequently freezes on my laptop, AND THERE IS NO AUTOSAVE ABILITY.  I have to remember to manually save every year or so.

Also, a lot of things are unexplained in the game...even in the tutorial...but I liked trying to learn as I went along.  

I will say I was disappointed to see that things like electricity and plumbing didn't really change the look of my city.  In fact, the technological advances don't seem to actually advance technology at all.  People in my city were driving cars before we discovered the combustible engine which unlocks the automobile.  My entire city was on the telephone grid before we had electricity.  Perhaps most egregious, my character had to win re-election before citizens actually had the right to vote.

But all in all, this is a new kind of game and I'm fully on board with where it's going.  8/10.

Mechanically the game is fairly shallow. The politics are not terribly engaging or intuative, a lot of data seems to exist within the game but many tooltips are missing or otherwise unavailable, leaving a lot of the game feeling arbitrary.

With only three maps for the core game it feels thin. They aren't very large maps, either. And while it may boast 1000~ dynamic events, most of them appear to be very shallow or poorly implimented, and don't seem to have long term effects other than changing one or two stats in a district.

Visually it's not appealing, either, and while that is not what I nor anyone else should necessarily be looking for in a managment/strategy game, the layouts of the roads interfere a lot with how structures are placed and spawn in and create very unappealing environments.

In and of its self, the game seems good, but many bugs and poorly implimented aspects of the game add up, and at the asking price of this game, it just isn't worth the price in its current state. It feels as though it is a mobile game.

edit: While it is true that I only played on and a half hours of the game, I've looked at a substantial stretch of content on the game on youtube before proceeding, which confirmed my suspicions about the game going forward. The game could certainly have used a longer development cycle, I understand that the money could have been needed to finish development and pay people, but there needs to be more communication with the community in a more central place on the situation of the game if that is the case, or otherwise.

I tried to Enjoy this game , but alas it was not to be.

i wanted to enjoy this game , Soft city builder political strategy was up my alley.

What was Good:
Concept
back ground
urm ,,,
K well 

What was Not so Good

Extremely poor and restrictive Camera Controls.
( if a big part of the game is seeing how your decisions turn out graphiclly you better let me see more than a section of it at a time)

Ok so its release but only 4 families and at the end of the day a very linear game no matter what path you took.

I cannot for these reasons recommend this game for the money.

It just does not deliver in 
Depth
Quality ( which isnt bad just not great)
and most importantly

FUN

So if you like me are looking for a good xover politicl strategy story tell builder experiencThis game for $40 does not deliver well on any of these and make it enjoyable.

Buy it when it's on sale. Until they fix some of the major issues with it, the game just isn't worth the 40 dollar pricetag. 
However I do recommend it for a new take on city management games. So much potential. It is RIGHT there.

EDIT 2/19/2017 Changing my review to negative, as they have done NOTHING with the game since my initial review. I had hoped they would take some community feedback and fix the game, but they have not.

column8:
I pre-purchased this game with a Steam gift card I received. I pretty much have all the games I want to play on Steam already so I figured I would try this out. I watched a few pre-release game plays and the game seemed okay.

The game touts itself as a mix of politics and "city-management". It lacks very much of any deviation from what the developers 'intended' the player to go through. It is very mechanical in the way the player just 'pulls levers' and waits to see what happens. The order in which you make decisions for research feels like it makes little difference to the direction of your city. It lacks flavor as the player can only choose a few families to play, three maps without much character themselves, and a lack of politic actions. The political action is to 'make appeals' to the different parties and gets old once you do it 100+ times.

This game could've been so much more (perhaps a mix between Cities Skylines and Crusader Kings?) but it lacks flavor and became monotonous very quickly. Not worth the price tag, even at the 10 or 20% off I bought it at. It reeks of a classic Kalypso game: second tier.

EDIT:
Another small thing that annoyed me was the lack of ability to zoom out further. I felt constrained to look always be looking at a small section of the map. The map up-close wasn't even that 'detailed' so I'm not sure why the emphasis was to be close. It's just something small that I bet could be quickly patched in to allow the player to zoom out further.
column9:

It lacks flavor as the player can only choose a few families to play, three maps without much character themselves, and a lack of politic actions. The political action is to 'make appeals' to the different parties and gets old once you do it 100+ times.

This game could've been so much more (perhaps a mix between Cities Skylines and Crusader Kings?) but it lacks flavor and became monotonous very quickly. Not worth the price tag, even at the 10 or 20% off I bought it at. It reeks of a classic Kalypso game: second tier.

EDIT:
Another small thing that annoyed me was the lack of ability to zoom out further. I felt constrained to look always be looking at a small section of the map. The map up-close wasn't even that 'detailed' so I'm not sure why the emphasis was to be close. It's just something small that I bet could be quickly patched in to allow the player to zoom out further.

Aus den inzwischen knapp 5h Spielzeit kann ich sagen, das Game macht echt Laune. Vom Schwierigkeitsgrad her finde ich das Spiel gerade richtig, speziell am Anfang ist es nicht zu leicht. Man muss erst rausfinden zu welchem Zeitpunkt man sich gewisse Dinge leisten kann und welche die hÃ¶chste PrioritÃ¤t haben. Ich habe dort das ein oder andere Mal etwas danebengegriffen, konnte es jedoch immer wieder ausbÃ¼geln. Fehlentscheidungen werfen einen meist zwar zurÃ¼ck, sind jedoch nicht der definitive TodesstoÃŸ und das finde ich gut. Die ein oder andere Verordnung und ein neuer Bezirk mit MÃ¼he und Not durch den Stadtrat geprÃ¼gelt und die Stadtkasse schreibt wieder grÃ¼ne Zahlen. Meiner Meinung nach gibt es eigentlich immer etwas das man noch Bauen und umsetzen mÃ¶chte. Durch die verschiedenen Forschungen kommen auch laufend neue MÃ¶glichkeiten hinzu was den Spielfluss fÃ¶rdert und die Motivationsspirale antreibt. Nur noch schnell das hier erweiternâ€¦ 
Grafisch finde ich das Spiel sehr gelungen, passt sehr gut zur AtmosphÃ¤re. Auch performancetechnisch kann ich mich aktuell nicht beklagen, wobei ich dazusagen muss dass ich hauptsÃ¤chlich auf 1x und 2x Geschwindigkeit spiele. Aktuell kann ich das Spiel auf jeden Fall weiterempfehlen, macht super viel SpaÃŸ.

Wer sich einen Eindruck verschaffen mÃ¶chte bevor er bei dem doch eher hoch angesetzten Preis zuschlagen will, kann gerne hier vorbei schauen und herausfinden ob einen selbst das Fieber packt =)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eJEw0sHxNIc

While this game has a lot of potential and could be a great experiance, I can't reccomend it because it is currently unfished. The optimization is very poor. I run games such as simcity, Tropico or even BF1 with no trouble, but the game starts really slowing down an hour or so in. There are also obvious problems with saving the game, naming districts and others which should really have been fixed before the game was released. 

Wait until they fix the issues before you buy.

column8:
Family dynasty founds glorious city and leads it into a golden age.. 
City's Citizens enjoy universal free education and health care.. 
City's citizens watch WW 1 happen from their air conditioned apartments on their satellite TV while eating microwave dinners.. 
City enjoys more money in the bank then the whole of the Austrian Empire.. 
Family dynasty is voted out because they would not ban contraception... 

6/10 - Would repress the christian party again.

--
It's on the verge of being a decent game, however most of the mechanic are shallow in regards to actual game play, it basically plays itself requiring little thought and repetitive actions. Little depth to the political game, with very few ways to influence the political parties. 
There are a lot of great concepts in the game, however none of them are flushed out or have any real impact.

-Reconmend waiting to it buy on sale.

Nun ja, kann mich den meisten hier einfach nur anschlieÃŸen. 
Ich mein ich muss zugeben, dass es keine komplette Katastrophe ist. Das Spiel ist immerhin ohne Bugs( hatte bis jetzt zumindest keine) gut spielbar. Aber ein wirklicher Drang zum weiterspielen kommt einfach nicht auf. Das liegt einfach auch daran, dass man (oder zumindest ich) viele Dinge (Entscheidungen und SpielverlÃ¤ufe) nicht nachvollziehen kann. Ich hab immer wieder aufÂ´s neue keine Ahnung, warum jetzt Partei XY plÃ¶tzlich gegen oder fÃ¼r einen Antrag stimmt. Noch weniger Nachvollziehen kann ich die Wirtschaftsimulation und die damit verbundenen Geldeinnahmen/-ausgaben. Mal bin ich ein paar tausend im Plus, mal mehrere tausend im Minus. Warum das so ist, bzw. warum es sich plÃ¶tzlich geÃ¤ndert hat, kann ich meistens nicht nachvollziehen. Auch fehlt mir oftmals etwas die vorraussicht der Parteein. So wollte ich bspw. einen Bahnhof bauen, welcher unter anderem fÃ¼r wirtschaftlichen Aufschwung sorgt. NatÃ¼rlich ist sowas recht teuer und ja, zu dem Zeitpunkt waren die Kassen nicht randvoll gefÃ¼llt. Aber mit etwas wirtschaftlicher Voraussicht kÃ¶nnte man eine solche Investition gut tÃ¤tigen, um die Wirtschaft und die damit einhergehenden Einnahmen langfristig zu steigern. Nun leider interpretiert das Spiel die Situation etwas anders und hat mir die Genehmigung der Parteien verweigert. 

Alles in allem ist das Spiel kein kompletter Reinfall, aber auch nicht wirklich positiv zu bewerten. Werde eventuell in ein paar Wochen nochmals reinschauen in der Hoffnung, dass es dann ein paar neue Inhalte und/oder Verbesserungen gab.

Well this game could be interesting but its overcrowded with informations from the beginning. The "mechanics" are not understandable. column8:
Pros:
- Interesting and somewhat novel concept.
- Events/Side Stories are pretty fun, but get repetitive real soon.

Cons:
- Core Idea is not well implemented as it is pretty shallow.
- Politics lacks depth and any meaning whatsoever, also very linear and no real choices with no impact.
- Parties do not have an opinion. (Left parties wanting to lower taxes for elites)
- Data Views are pretty useless.
- Tech tree is pretty meaningless, at the end of each era you can easily research all techs, no meaningful choices. (Doesnt mattter if you get a building a year early or late.)
- Bugs (missing/wrong texts, graphics behaving not correctly when changing infrastructure, Gets very laggy to the end/ memory leak)

column8:
This is a great idea, poorly implemented.

Aside from the many bugs and general poverty of useful explanation or clarity around the mechanics, it's essentially just quite boring quite quickly and with very little promise of being replayable. There certainly are some nice ideas, and in the short term it's a better political management game than the likes of the Democracy series, but the repetition and the sheer frustration of wondering why the economy is behaving as it is kill your enthusiasm. Perhaps with some essential patches and extensions of clarity and purpose it can be redeemed, but as of now it's not worth your money.

I wanted this to be a good game, but after 23 hours of playtime I can't overlook the big holes in it. 

Ultimatly this game feels like they have sorted the first era, but then ran out of development time/ideas so the other four an pointless and unfinished. Several of the core game mechanics feel broken and in reality this game isn't ready for release. 

This is an example of a great concept, implemented in the worst way possible and their is ovbiously more focus on getting a game out there to a deadline rather than creating something that worked. Kalypo should be ashamed of this and I will most definatly avoid thier titles in future.

I was excited for this game pre realease seeing it as city builder meets mayor sim. In reality it fails at everything, and the cons kill any fun you might get out of it.

Pros
- concept (so wish they had implemented something that delviers on just 1% of this)
- ealry game feels interesting (first 30 mins or so)
- tech tree design and look
- Concept of familty through several eras is nice

Cons
- the game becomes repeataive fast, after you have put down 1-2 districts it reasearch, get things approved reaserach again.
- your choices make very little difference in reality and after a while you get bored with it.
- loads of data tab all usless (they don't help you understand whats wrong or what needs improving), just tabs of meaningless ifno.
- political options are limited and no clear cause and effect.
- money is impossible (raise tax and no-one cares, industry going bush with 0% tax rate???)
- no matter which family you choose the game plays the same
- no matter which map you choose the game plays the same
- income changing for no understandable reason, and therefore imposible the take corrective action
- once you get later in game and have to be voted in for 6 year terms. You spend all you time pushing this, and tech improvements make no difference
- once you get mid game the game starts to lag badly (and I don't see why)
- once you implement district infrastructure you can't dial back to save money, so have little options
- Once your past the first era tech tree improvements have little to no impact.
- decision made around how you bring up a child doesn't seem to impact in the next era

I dislike this game so much I have requested a refund (which is the first time ever). If you are thinking of buying this game don't.

column8:
I have played quite a bit and I can say that this game is in no way worth the price. The concept is interesting, but there is a complete lack of documentation, as to why anything hapens the way it does, why decisions are made by the council and how you can fix it.
 There have been a few "guides" that tell you to tax everyone to the max and roll in money; and then the third age rolls around, elections come and it's "Game Over."
  In my most recent attempt, I was making a small profit, had decent stats among the council and the population, reasonable tax levels, good city services and suddenly I lost the election. 
 Unless this game is patched heavily, mechanics fixed and far more documentation provided, please do not waste your money.

diferente dos outros simuladores que jÃ¡ joguei, aqui vocÃª Ã© o prefeito da cidade, e como qualquer prefeito, nÃ£o pode fazer o que quiser, pois estÃ¡ subordinado a um conselho.

para quem gosta apenas de construir cidades se preocupando somente com o dinheiro, este jogo nÃ£o Ã© recomendado! para ter sucesso aqui vocÃª terÃ¡ que convencer o conselho das suas decisÃµes, como por exemplo: construir uma delegacia de policia, escola, bombeiros, mudar o tipo de ruas de um distrito... entre outros.

O jogo se baseia em distritos (bairros) cabendo a vocÃª escolher como ele funciona: infra estrutura( iluminaÃ§Ã£o, abastecimento de Ã¡gua, seguranÃ§a, saÃºde, escolas....) e com isso vai favorecer uma determinada classe economica (e obviamente enfurecer outra). First,  let's make it clear, this is NOT a city builder like Cities Skylines. It is closer to Democracy 3. 

The concept of this game is a great one in my opinion, though the execution is somewhat questionable:

1. Grab that Cash and Make a Stash. The biggest issue is value for money, $43CAD is a bit steep for the amount of content you get, compared to the likes of lets say Facturio, which is $25CAD. 

2. Same Day Different Ruler. I'w done playthroughs with all the different families and all of their events are scripted and always the same, there is no variation to the outcomes of the same options when you decide on an event. Furthermore the different families play pretty much the same in general with little variations.

3. Click and Wait, Click and Wait! The Council is more of an annoyance than a great game mechanic at this point. It lacks any depth whatsoever. There is little consequence in pissing off your rivals. If â€œgood willâ€ goes negative the only thing is that your pleas/demands/threats have less of an effect. As opposed to, when threatened, causing massive opposition from them, this seems to not happen. Furthermore there is no interaction with the parties on the council other than the voting.

4. Information Boogaloo...Though the game has a myriad of info screens, it somewhat lacks the ability to give you necessary information. You have no way of knowing why businesses are doing poorly or why there are problems in certain areas. The game has lots of visual cues that tell you something is wrong or happening, but nothing to indicate why or what. This is a problem since now you have very little info to figure out how to solve it.

5. Flash Ahaaa, Fastest in the Universe. The pacing seems to be a bit off, you can breeze through the 5 eras in 2-3h or so. This makes the game more of a race to the finish rather than a sit down and rule your city type of deal, if I were to compare it to Crusader Kings II.     

6. Rule and Drool. Since all the events seem to be scripted and there is no randomness or variety in the outcomes of your decisions, the ruling aspect of the game gets old quite quick. Which is a big problem since the ruling mechanic is the main focus of the game. To add insult to injury there is very little to do: plop down a district, raise/lower taxes and pass a few edicts...that's pretty much it. There is very little political intrigue. You can spy on parties, but the result is the same, you get dirt and use it to get the party to vote in your favor...again not a lot of depth.

7. Mayor the Useless. Your character is a bit useless, though you get some bonuses here and there... there is again no depth or necessity for it, unlike Crusader Kings, where your ruler has a major impact on your country's well being.

In conclusion the idea is great, but this game lacks any sort of depth whatsoever. Couple it with the $43CAD price tag and value for money isn't there! It's sad, as these types of games are my forte, was hoping for a more complex city RULER rather than a mobile esque clicker. 

The game has a lot of potential, it just needs to be taped. Maybe with steamworks support and a lot of DLC this could evolve into something great. We shall see what becomes of it. 

If you want a city builder - this is not it.
If you want a city ruler - this is not it...Yet.
If you want a simple niche game...if the price doesn't concern you - give it a shot.

Which is a big problem since the ruling mechanic is the main focus of the game. To add insult to injury there is very little to do: plop down a district, raise/lower taxes and pass a few edicts...that's pretty much it. There is very little political intrigue. You can spy on parties, but the result is the same, you get dirt and use it to get the party to vote in your favor...again not a lot of depth.

7. Mayor the Useless. Your character is a bit useless, though you get some bonuses here and there... there is again no depth or necessity for it, unlike Crusader Kings, where your ruler has a major impact on your country's well being.

In conclusion the idea is great, but this game lacks any sort of depth whatsoever. Couple it with the $43CAD price tag and value for money isn't there! It's sad, as these types of games are my forte, was hoping for a more complex city RULER rather than a mobile esque clicker. 

The game has a lot of potential, it just needs to be taped. Maybe with steamworks support and a lot of DLC this could evolve into something great. We shall see what becomes of it. 

If you want a city builder - this is not it.
If you want a city ruler - this is not it...Yet.
If you want a simple niche game...if the price doesn't concern you - give it a shot.

I have thoroughly enjoyed this game. There was a gap in the sim/strategy market for a balanced political-economic-rts and I think they have really plugged into that gap. That being said, there are a few issues that leave the game needing some polish. I have only had one critical issue which was having the game progressively slow until I had to turn it off and re-open it - haven't had it since. Other than that it's little things here and there: things spelt wrong, descriptions vague and unnecessary, not being able to micromanage the distribution of a district, some things are in the tutorial but critical success points aren't, etc. None of these have taken away from the base simulation which I can say is a lot of fun to play with. Definitely recommend for the genre fanatics (like myself), but wait for a sale otherwise.

column8:
Ich kann zur Zeit nur vom Kauf des Spiels abraten.

Das Spiel ist noch so verbuggt, dass es kaum sinnvoll spielbar ist. So kann man nach kurzer Zeit bestimmte Bezirke nicht mehr auswÃ¤hlen und dementsprechend auch nicht mehr verÃ¤ndern. Es ist mir passiert, dass das Spiel zwangsweise pausiert wurde, weil man eine Forschung auswÃ¤hlen soll, obwohl eine Forschung durchgefÃ¼hrt wurde, welche dann logischerweise nicht weiter ging und das Spiel beendet werden musste. 

Und am nervigsten:
[b]Man kann das Spiel quasi nie speichern[/b], weil einem immer gesagt wird, dass es "im Moment" nicht mÃ¶glich ist. Der "Moment" dauert aber fÃ¼r immer an.

Ich frage mich, ob jemand das Spiel mal irgendwann getestet hat. Solche Dinge mÃ¼ssten sofort aufgefallen sein.

Fazit: nicht kaufen und hoffen, dass eine groÃŸer Rundumschlag mit Patches erfolgt.

Als groÃŸer Fan von Aufbau- & Politikstrategie habe ich mir dieses Spiel vorbestellt und bin nur wenige Tage nach dem Release schon tief enttÃ¤uscht: Das Tutorial ist mangelhaft, ich musste mir dutzende YouTube Videos anschauen, um in die Spielmechanik zu finden, da kaum ZusammenhÃ¤nge erklÃ¤rt werden. Genauso wenig werden die Outcomes bestimmter Event-Entscheidungen vorab erlÃ¤utert, somit verkommt alles zu einem unfassbar anstrengenden Trial and Error Verfahren. Am Ende landet man unweigerlich in der Schuldenfalle, aus der kein Weg mehr herausfÃ¼hrt, da die ErhÃ¶hung der Steuern um die Finanzen aufzufrischen zu einer massiven Abwanderung von BÃ¼rgern und Industrie fÃ¼hrt.

Nach knapp 8 Spielstunden habe ich frustriert hingeschmissen.
column9:
As a big fan of development and political strategy, I pre-ordered this game and am already deeply disappointed just a few days after its release: The tutorial is inadequate; I had to watch dozens of YouTube videos to get to grips with the game mechanics, as they barely explain the connections. Likewise, the outcomes of certain event decisions aren't explained in advance, so the whole thing degenerates into an incredibly exhausting trial-and-error process. Ultimately, you inevitably end up in a debt trap with no way out, as raising taxes to boost finances leads to a massive exodus of citizens and industry.

After just under 8 hours of play, I gave up in frustration.

I will start by saying that I am having a lot of fun with this game. I love the concept, but the execution is a little... off.
Most of the reasons for this have already been stated. The interface should be improved dramatically, it takes too many clicks and submenus to do things that I should just be able to do with one click. I have experienced my fair share of graphical bugs that have caused me to restart the game. The tooltips are not as helpful as they should be in explaining the effects of what's going on. For instance, it will say +1 Change in a certain area. Sounds good, but exactly what change was made? It just says change. That's not helpful at all. I also believe certain things are overpriced, and what exactly does upgrading your infrastructure even do? I've been using dirt roads forever with no problems. What is my incentive to spend all this cash on upgrading then? Speaking of overpriced, $39.99 is a bit much to charge for a game that should be considered early-access at this point. I feel like I am test running a beta version. $29.99 or even $34.99 would be more acceptable to me, and give me more realistic expectations for the game. As it stands, I cannot reccommend the game, however, in a few months when all the bugs are worked out and the interface is improved, I will absolutely recommend it. 

TL;DR Great concept, poor execution.

I really like the game, it does not handspoon you but make you work (and think, and read, and theorycraft) for reaching even the simplest of the objectives. Surely the tutorial is lacking and there are some performance issues but nothing major, at least for me. I honestly suggest reading the manual  that can be found here http://cdn.edgecast.steamstatic.com/steam/apps/352550/manuals/Urban_Empire_Manual_PC_UK_ONLINE.pdf?t=1484935601 because it explains a lot of micro-things that let you connect the dots between actions and reactions you have in the Game World. I really hope that the developers continue on their efforts on making it better. 7/10.

column8: Shallow. You can tell the developers were going for a mix of sim city / EU4, but fell way off the mark in terms of complexity. It feels like I'm pushing a button every couple minutes with minimal impact. Hopefully there'll be a 1.1 that actually adds some agency to my options as a player.

column8:
I'm updated this review to not recommended. Why? The game basically suffers from bugs, lack of certain indicators regarding the economics to understand why something is happening and a major lag near the last era's. All this take a lot of fun out of what would be a rather nice game overall. It seems the developer is not commited to making a lot of updates to address the issues since after plenty of time, none of them were fixed. Also the team doesn't make the community really feel it will address those / is commited to the game, so recommending it is a far stretch. 

My advice would be cheap buy / stay away - until it's properly fixed.  

---

I like this game. It's an interesting new way of dealing with cities and politics. It's in no way a city builder since most of the time you can't build the city you want ( adding to both appeal and frustration of the game - but that's politics ). There are many ways to get way you want though and trying to mayor through the era's it's quit interesting to see how it all develops. 

There seem to be enough replayability trying different strategies ( high taxes vs low taxes, high level of services vs laissez-faire etc ) . 

The main problems are connected with a lack of explanation ( why is a district developing or not is hardly explained ) and not always clear what the choices are the game is trying you to have.  Also hopefully the dev's will look a little at the performance which drops in the later game. 

Tl;dr - Good game, needs a few updates to become really good.

column8:
Ich habe das Spiel etwas Ã¼ber eine Stunde gespielt und mir dann - bevor die RefundmÃ¶glichkeit verfÃ¤llt, ein paar Lets Plays angesehen. Im Grunde ist das Spiel fad und lÃ¤sst jegliche Tiefe vermissen. Man agiert im Stadtrat gegen letztlich gesichtslose Parteien indem man seine Gunst (im Spiel die politische WÃ¤hrung) einsetzt. Dazu ein biÃŸchen Geldmanagement und das wars dann auch schon.

Es gibt leider keinen echten politischen Gegner, keine Personen, jede Abstimmung wird neu auf Basis der Haltung der Parteien und seinem eigenen Einfluss berechnet.

Habe es mir refunden lassen.

Neues Genre - Neues GlÃ¼ck?

Wer sich einen Stadtbau Sim wie Sim City erwartet - falsch
Wer sich eine Diktator Sim wie Tropico erwartet - falsch

es ist eine Mischung aus beiden, jedoch nur im Ansatz.

Lange Rede kurzer Sinn:
Pros:
- Tolle Idee ein neues Genre zu kreieren.
- Guter Ansatz mit diversen Parteien im Stadtrat
- Zusammenhang mit realen Geschichtlichen Ereignissen

Cons:
- Eigene Entscheidungen haben nur sehr wenig Einfluss in der Politik
- alles nur Budget abhÃ¤ngig
- keine verschiedenen Schwierigkeitsgrade
- nicht nachvllziehbare Wahlergebnisse
- oft wiederholende Events

Netter Ansatz jedoch meiner Meinung nach lieber auf einen Sale und paar Patches Warten.

----

Man definiert Bezirke, diese sind unterteilt in 3 Arten. 
Wohnen
Gewerbe
Industrie

Mehr Einwohner, mehr Gewerbe, mehr Industrie = mehr Steuern = mehr Einnahmen

und da kommen wir auch schon zu meiner Kritik:
Der Ansatz mit den diversen politischen Parteien ist sehr gut, jedoch schlecht umgesetzt.
Ist das Budget der Stadt in Ordnung, wird so gut wie allem zugestimmt.
Ist es das nicht wird jeder SteuererhÃ¶hung zugestimmt.

Die ZusammenhÃ¤nge in der Stadtentwicklung und dadurch die diversen WÃ¤hlerstrÃ¶me ist nicht nachvollziehbar.

Genau so wenig werden immer Prognosen fÃ¼r diverse Entscheidungen angezeigt, die wirklichkeit spricht dann plÃ¶tzlich komplett dagegen...

Somit konzentriert man sich auf Dauer nur darauf sein Budget in den grÃ¼nen Zahlen zu halten und die Zeit laufen zu lassen.

Es passieren sehr viele kleine und groÃŸe Events, besonders die kleinen Wiederholen sich jedoch schon sehr hÃ¤ufig.
(DÃ¼rfen Frauen Abends in ein Lokal gehen -  diese Frage hatte ich in einem Spiel gezÃ¤hlte 12 mal...)

column9: Need more maps and models, and a custom family system would be the icing on the cake~

column8: Jeux sens aucunes logiqze d'action vraiment mal fichu!

I like the idea behind the game, I really would like to recommend it, but unfortunately cannot do so now; the implementation is not enjoyable enough. As many people already said, there are too many repetitive actions, and the politics game mode seems too shallow.

Economy is really bad and mechanics behind it are not clear at all.

Same events occur sometimes (in my gameplay I had event "The Bridge" 3 times in a row in ~10 minutes of gameplay).

There are almost no city sounds. I expected to hear a train coming at least when I zoom in to the railroad and see a passing train - no, developers decided that it is irrelevant.

There are some mistakes in words here and there; sometimes in city hall view when you appeal to parties your mayor says confusing things (for instance, I wanted to demand lefties not to vote for Labour Union act, and guess what - my mayor told them that it is "their duty to VOTE YES on that edict"; that was really confusing, since when I used this option I actually made some of party members vote against the law, just the way I wanted).

This one is unconfirmed since I have to play more eras to check this out, but from my current two eras gameplay I've got the feeling that game tries to push you into the leftist way with all these labour rights/equality and other commie stuff (I'm a right-wing conservative myself).

This game has an indie quality and clearly has either to be really remade into a better title, or the price should be way lower, somewhere around 3-5$ would fit nice in its current state.
column9:
I like the idea behind the game, I really would like to recommend it, but unfortunately cannot do so now; the implementation is not enjoyable enough. As many people already said, there are too many repetitive actions, and the politics game mode seems too shallow.

Economy is really bad and mechanics behind it are not clear at all.

Same events occur sometimes (in my gameplay I had event "The Bridge" 3 times in a row in ~10 minutes of gameplay).

There are almost no city sounds. I expected to hear a train coming at least when I zoom in to the railroad and see a passing train - no, developers decided that it is irrelevant.

There are some mistakes in words here and there; sometimes in city hall view when you appeal to parties your mayor says confusing things (for instance, I wanted to demand lefties not to vote for Labour Union act, and guess what - my mayor told them that it is "their duty to VOTE YES on that edict"; that was really confusing, since when I used this option I actually made some of party members vote against the law, just the way I wanted).

This one is unconfirmed since I have to play more eras to check this out, but from my current two eras gameplay I've got the feeling that game tries to push you into the leftist way with all these labour rights/equality and other commie stuff (I'm a right-wing conservative myself).

This game has an indie quality and clearly has either to be really remade into a better title, or the price should be way lower, somewhere around 3-5$ would fit nice in its current state.

Lots of bugs currently but even so the game is playable but overall has very limited play.

There is a learning curve to figure out the politics that the tutorial doesn't explain very well at all.

I have had no crashes. But did get a pop-up with no mulitple choice options (normally they all do) which basicly ruined the game because there was nothing to do to get rip of it. Like so.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=847977508

So once you have your whole land filled with districts (which is very easy to do) and have complete coverage for service buildings, there is not much do but research, and do upgrades of the buildings, and vote. At that point you end playing the game at max fast forward speed.

I wouldn't say it is boring for the game type it is. I just expect to do more.

The game will be playable once the bugs are fixed. But how long will you play is the question. 

I will be playing more to try to get a the last era without a game killing bug but it might be ewasier to wait for a patch.

I really really like the idea of this game and I was very excited to play it. Its supposed to be a strategy/management game where you need to take politics into account. 

After roughly 10 hours and two restarts I finally made it through the campaign. The early game was fun, but it was becoming repetitive in mid and late game. The challenge is completely gone as soon as you figure out that it always pays of if you increase the taxes as long as you keep services up. So the cycle was increase taxes, add services, increase taxes, add services until you had huge amounts of money. The parties almost never mattered, so I stopped paying attention to them. Then in the end of the fourth era I already had everything researched and was focusing on achieving the other goals in game. Some of the goals are hard to achieve, but not because they are difficult, but instead because the mechanics of the game feel random. I did not try the scenarios yet, but I will likely not do that unless they release a serious balancing patch. 

I did not experience any breaking bugs, however the performance of the game got worse drastically in the late game, if you play on speed four on default settings. My rig is beyond the recommended specs with an I7 and a Geforce 980ti.
