column8:
Ich wÃ¼rde jetzt gerne etwas besseres schreiben.
Ich habe mich Monate lang auf das Spiel gefreut und jetzt tatsÃ¤chlich Vollpreis gezahlt.
Leider ist das Spiel aber an allen Ecken ein Rohling.
Der Stil ist zwar im Grunde wunderschÃ¶n, wenn man Ã¼ber schwebendes Gras hinwegsieht und die Tatsache, dass sich durch LÃ¼cken und ungÃ¼nstige Modellkonstellationen nicht so richtig StraÃŸenzÃ¼ge bilden, wodurch das Stadtbild etwas lieblos hingewÃ¼rfelt wirkt. Oder Flaggen, die in unterschiedliche Richtungen wehen. Oder etwas leblose StraÃŸen. Viele Kleinigkeiten eben.
Das Spielkonzept ist trotzdem toll und hat viel Potential.

Das eigentliche Problem ist die Sinnlosigkeit des Forschungs- und Entwicklungsbaumes.
Die ZusammenhÃ¤nge, warum sich gewisse Errungenschaften bedingen, werden nicht ganz klar. So schaltet die Erfindung der Fotografie MÃ¶belgeschÃ¤fte und Theater frei; Kirchen und SchuhlÃ¤den gibt es erst mit der Erfindung des Telegrafen; um "Verbrennung" (Motoren) zu erforschen braucht man Vertretungsrechte etc.
Die politischen Standpunkte der Parteien passen auch oft nicht zu ihrer eigentlichen Position im politischen Spektrum.
Dann tauchen in Pen-And-Paper-Manier zufÃ¤llige Ereignisse auf, die eine politische Positionierung verlangen mit teils weitreichenden Folgen. Die ReaktionsmÃ¶glichkeiten sind dabei sehr unbefriedigend.
Gerade wurde in meiner Stadt von Arbeitern gestreikt und ich kann mich jetzt entscheiden, ob ich den deshalb aufgebrachten Konservativen entgegenbringe, a) sie hÃ¤tten das Recht, b) es sei gerechtfertigt oder c) sie sollten mehr Rechte bekommen. Alles drei kommt eigentlich aus dem selben Spektrum, ist quasi die selbe Antwort.
Es fehlen gegenteilige Aussagen, wie ein feudalistisches "die sollen sich nicht anmaÃŸen, Dinge zu beurteilen, die ihrem Verstand entschweben" oder ein neoliberales "ihre Forderungen gefÃ¤hrden den freien Markt" o.Ã¤.
So kommt gar kein befriedigendes GefÃ¼hl von "ich habe mich fÃ¼r die Rechte der Sozial Benachteiligten eingesetzt" auf.
Ich hatte gar keine Wahl.
Zuletzt fehlen oft Beschreibungen zu Buttons bzw. ploppen bei manchen einfach nicht auf.

Alles in allem wirkt es, als seinen die Scripte in langen Nachtschichten geschrieben worden und voller LÃ¼cken und Fehler.
Ich hoffe, da passiert noch was, dann kÃ¶nnte daraus eines der bedeutendsten StÃ¤dtebauspiele werden.

Its a fun game.  They mixed the ideas of a city builder and politics together very well.  It does take a little bit of play troughs to fiqure out how to make money, and find out how to little quirks work togother.

With that said there are some inprovments needed in the game, (what game doesnt).  Performace in the late game is can be improved. I do lag once I hit the Era 4 and have 30k plus in the city.  And better tooltips would be nice.  But there is no major issue that would prevent me from playing the game.

I didnt have huge expectations because I never heard of Reborn, but Kalypos does push desent games, so the Urban Emprie did surpise me to be better then I thought.  I am really interested to see what dlcs and hopefully what expansion can add and improve into the game.

Die Idee hatte viel Potential, aber die Umsetzung ist nicht gelungen. Ich hatte immer ein bisschen das GefÃ¼hl, dass der Erfolg mehr vom Zufall, als von meinen Taten abhÃ¤ngig sind. Und ab der dritten Epoche schÃ¼chtert man bei jeder Wahl nur noch die Parteien ein. Nicht, weil es SpaÃŸ macht oder einfacher wÃ¤re, sondern weil es die einzig erfolgsversprechende Option ist. DarÃ¼ber hinaus wirft einen das Spiel direkt ins Geschehen und erklÃ¤rt nur wenig.

Abgesehen davon ist aber der Grafikstil, wenn auch veraltet, ganz nett, die Stadtteile, die sich ja quasi selbstaufbauen, sind gut gelungen.

Insgesamt wÃ¼nschte ich mir allerdings, ich hÃ¤tte mir die dreiÃŸig Euro gespart und stattdessen ein spannendes Buch gekauft.

I rarely like to post negative reviews for a title, instead liking to offer encouragement and critical appraisal for developers. However this title was a serious disappointment to me, and coming from a big publisher behind the likes of Tropico, it really needed to be better.

In short Urban Empire is a political simulator, but the sad fact is it never really lives up to that in any meaningful way. All the parties I encountered, despite being placed in what seemed to be a realistic way upon the political spectrum, ended up having little to differentiate each other. With enough bargaining ( the game lets you plead, demand or threaten to change party member's stances on a vote) every party could be persuaded to accept a vote. In two hours of play I lost one vote, and that was because by that time I couldn't really care less about pushing any harder.

This game has potential, but currently it feels highly random. I played for two hours and in that time I rarely felt like there were any major differences between the political parties, other than the fact that the game's scripting told them how they should vote on an issue. The social democrats always seemed to disagree, and need to be persuaded, where as the physiocratics always agreed whole heartedly. By the end of my two hours I was sadly bored stiff.

You might say two hours is a short time, but I saw the second era and I put through quite a number of votes and city infrastructure changes, but by the end of those two hours I felt distinctly like I was (to quote someone else) 'pulling levers and watching how it changed things'. Between votes I would just sit and watch the city, and in the long run it all came down to budget, and a procedure of picking edicts to increase income and forcing votes to up the taxes.

I just couldn't be bothered to force any more votes or try an more edicts because I simpky felt like this 'balancing act' was all I'd be doing for 4 eras. Then, much to my annoyance, I tried to save my city only to find the game wouldn't let me. It appears that unless you have finished all tutorial missions then you can't save. I'm sure that's a bug that will be fixed, but it didn't improve my first impressions of Urban Empire at the time.

Urban Empire is a nice idea, but I feel it lacks too much depth to make it a game I'd recommend to people. I watched much of the game on YouTube before release, and I pre-purchased based on my thoughts. It had looked fun from watching, but playing was not the same experience.

If Urban Empire only had half the humour and detail of Tropico it may have allowed me to get past the monotony of the political system (yes, I do feel it was monotonous), and indeed the only attempt at humour was a reference to Tropico (which I won't spoil). It was a nice touch, but didn't improve on things.

For the first time I feel inclined to refund a title, and for that reason I can't recommend Urban Empire. There is a game here should the developers act to add in a layer atop the political bargaining. An ability to design the layout of your city would be a start, and frankly that is another thing that stopped me finding any real enjoyment in the game. If I could have done a mayor's job and planned the layout of my city, then I might have had something to do whilst waiting for votes to pass and balances to improve. But for some reason the city builds itself, or you at least have no say in road layout and rci placement. You can determine how much industry, commercial and residential is built, but not where. It's almost as if you're playing the role of a mayor with lots of helpers turned on to leave you less to do. You're just public relations for the mayor, really.

column8: Was expecting a tropico like game, got some boring repitive game with poorly thought out districts, and extremely poor graphics, no voice acting is a let down but to be expected at this pricepoint. The game does tend to text spam you.

Kalypso warb damit, dass man eine komplett neue Spielkonzeptidee mit Urban Empire auf den Markt wirft.
Nachdem man ein paar Stunden gespielt hat, fÃ¤llt einem ganz schnell auf, dass dies natÃ¼rlich nicht ganz richtig ist.

First of all - this game SHOULDN'T be compared to city builder games because it has a completely different approach to the city management with more emphasis on the family, politics and different era characteristics. 

You actually kind of macro-manage districts with not much room to manipulate like you are able to in typical city builder games. The game leads you through some of the most interesting eras of modern history, with all the global crisis affecting your little city as well. You develop technologies to boost your industry and commerce, propose edicts to balance out some of the issues you might have in your city, you make taxing changes etc. In my opinion, it all feels moderately complex although it has quite a lot features.

Now the biggest problem that I personally have with the game is the transparency. After a couple of play-throughs I still have no idea why some of the issues appear in this game and I cannot pinpoint the source of the problem in order to find a way to resolve it. I feel like the game is missing more clear UI, explanation of the various stats that your companies have that affect their success, and so on. There should be a lot better advisor system in my opinion.

Overall - the game is fun and it has a kind of a fresh approach to the city game genre. It does make you play it a couple of times which I tend to value the most in games. However it does not justify the price. It should be priced at about 20$ at most because it lacks the complexity to be valued more. 

6.5/10

column8:
Fun game ideas, decent execution on some of them, not-so-good on a lot of them. And then there is the performance problem, or the complete lack of performance. 
If the performance wasn't so god-awful it could be a fun game, if a bit silly and random in its political simulation... But if I can't actually play the game, well, not much fun to be had.

Let's take it step-by-step:

1. Politics.
Fun idea. Fun when it works properly, but often it doesn't. The political compass doesn't translate into sensible parties (sensible as in resembling reality to some degree), and there is no way to tell how you are being placed on that compass... you might think you are a left-leaning liberal, but when mayoral elections come along, all the right-wing centrists support you, and the progressives are the ones that vote against you. Why? No way to find out.
Nevertheless, if you suspend your disbelief, and have don't expect the compass to be anything remotely realistic, it is an interesting barrier mechanic you have to work your way around... Devs should just throw out the realistic names and connotations, and just run with the underlying mechanics.

2. UI and useability
UI itself is decent, if a little action heavy (too many clicks to accomplish some things) not too hard to use, or learn. The problem is there is a big lack of feedback and general information about what is gonig on in the city, and what the consequences of your actions are. 
*Why is the restaurant industry making more money than the next 10 combined, while not having a sales boost or booming demand? No clue. 
*Why are the elite and lower classes unemployed? No clue, the industry tabs only shows middle and working class jobs per category. 
*Why are all these businesses bankrupt in this one district, but not in the one next to it? No clue... I can look at all of them individually, but it only tells me the current situation, not any of the causes.
*Incomprehensible tooltips galore, where figuring out if the +5% figure on a red downwards-arrow accompanied icon is a good thing or not is a matter of trial-and-error. 
*Some decisions in events have no tooltip, but if the previous choice had one, it remains displayed, confusing the player. 

3. Variety and replayability:
Barely any of either. Game is fairly linear, with far too few choices. 
*A grand total of 3 maps are present currently, but since the maps make no difference in how the game plays, there might as well be 300. One of the maps states that the mining industry would be a defining economic force, due to mountains and such... well, that does not in any way translate into game mechanics. I tried all three maps, and had pretty much the exact same industry composition on all of them.
* The 4 families are fun additions, they can make you play somewhat differently. Good idea, expand upon this.

4. And the big bugbear, Performance:
*Specs: i5-4670 @3.4GHz. GF970, 16GB-1866 RAM, 256GB SSD.
*Scenario 1: max quality 1080p, 1914, city of 45K people, era 3 techs all unlocked.
*Result 1: 2-16 FPS on 2x speed, 5-22 on 1x speed, 10-15 second freezes every 3-4 months. Unplayable on higher speeds (freezes every couple seconds).

*Scenario 2: lowest quality 1080p, 1914, city of 45K people, era 3 techs all unlocked.
*Result 2: 15-25 FPS on 2x speed, 20-30 on 1x speed, 5-10 second freezes every 3-4 months. Barely playable on higher speeds.

Having taken a much smaller city (15K people) to 1936, while still having 30-40 FPS on 2x speed, it seems that population increases and number of districts severely limits performance in the game.
This is the one that kills it for me, if I'm doing well, the game becomes unplayable very fast. Until the performance issue is solved, I can't recommend this game.

This game should've been released to Early Access, and sit there for a couple months until it is fully baked, then release it.

column8:
Ok well i thought i would give this game a fair chance, I always feel at least ten hours is neccisary to employ the tactics and varoius control changes that often occur between these types of games. I have played with all four familes and managed to get to Era 5 twice, gave up on Era three once and am currently in Era 2 with my present game. 

Swerve this game at all costs as it really is an I-Pad game nothing more. to say this game repeats it self is an understatment. There are so few options in the game that i have exhausted them all and the game plays the same regardless of which family you choose. Its limited beyond comprehension and any reviews (previews) that were out on this game before it was released that praised it should be ashamed of themselves as its so obvious they take back handers from companys and it shows on games like this.

Its actually everything that is wrong with the game industry, I can not see how the heap of adons this company will make us pay for can make this game any better? Worst game i have purchased in years and agree that Â£9.99 would be acceptable and even then only get it on half price offer. I simply cant play it any more and have 1000s of hours on Civ etc. Which i will add if you have not played the new Civ its the best game i have played in years. Very polished, slick and enthralling, Urban Empire is not even a poor rip off of these games its simply garbage ignore all the attractive screen shots im on ultra HD and its really not that great looking. You alos have no involvment with these buildings and all you do is lay a grid that takes a while just to perfect the layout. 

Best thirty quid i have ever spent as i will never purchase another game by these cowboys.
column9:
Ok well i thought i would give this game a fair chance, I always feel at least ten hours is neccisary to employ the tactics and varoius control changes that often occur between these types of games. I have played with all four familes and managed to get to Era 5 twice, gave up on Era three once and am currently in Era 2 with my present game. 

Swerve this game at all costs as it really is an I-Pad game nothing more. to say this game repeats it self is an understatment. There are so few options in the game that i have exhausted them all and the game plays the same regardless of which family you choose. Its limited beyond comprehension and any reviews (previews) that were out on this game before it was released that praised it should be ashamed of themselves as its so obvious they take back handers from companys and it shows on games like this.

Its actually everything that is wrong with the game industry, I can not see how the heap of adons this company will make us pay for can make this game any better? Worst game i have purchased in years and agree that Â£9.99 would be acceptable and even then only get it on half price offer. I simply cant play it any more and have 1000s of hours on Civ etc. Which i will add if you have not played the new Civ its the best game i have played in years. Very polished, slick and enthralling, Urban Empire is not even a poor rip off of these games its simply garbage ignore all the attractive screen shots im on ultra HD and its really not that great looking. You alos have no involvment with these buildings and all you do is lay a grid that takes a while just to perfect the layout. 

Best thirty quid i have ever spent as i will never purchase another game by these cowboys.

****Update****
Devs abandoned immediately.
Ignore below.


I strongly disagree with most of the bad reviews on this page. I am in no way supporting the game just because I spent money on it. I usually play grand strategy games such as Crusader kings and etc. and also great city building games like cities: Skylines. This is a totally different type of game. It is not action packed in anyway. It is cool that you indirectly lead a city. Your family is a mayor and you can control districts, edicts, and government buildings and it is tough because there are polital parties that have different views and always vote on everything in the city. You work through the eras like this and trying to balance a city and personal budget. It is much slower paced and a different take on city building and management. Please take these into consideration.

column8:
So, I watched Quill18 play this, and decided I wanted this game. Pre-bought it, and have not regretted the decision. 
This is sim city meets civ meets democracy in a sense. 
You build your city like in Sim City, you research like in Civ, and you pass edicts (laws) like in democracy. 
I love how you need to pay attention to the political parties, and how the politics work. Do you try to find a middle ground, or do you try to get one or two parties more popular so you can work with them? 
Do you implement all the laws, or do you move your city in a specific direction?

So, the city council does not want to build another city district, well maybe if you place the new tech'ed radio tower there they will. 
Decisions, decisions.

I have found no major issues with this game, however there are the odd spelling mistake, but those are far between and very easy to work with, and most likely something that will be patched sooner rather than later.

If you expect this game to be a pure city builder where you are all powerful, you will be disappointed, but if you are looking for something where you have to balance the various needs of the city, you will not be disappointed.

8.5/10

So, I watched Quill18 play this, and decided I wanted this game. Pre-bought it, and have not regretted the decision. 
This is sim city meets civ meets democracy in a sense. 
You build your city like in Sim City, you research like in Civ, and you pass edicts (laws) like in democracy. 
I love how you need to pay attention to the political parties, and how the politics work. Do you try to find a middle ground, or do you try to get one or two parties more popular so you can work with them? 
Do you implement all the laws, or do you move your city in a specific direction?

So, the city council does not want to build another city district, well maybe if you place the new tech'ed radio tower there they will. 
Decisions, decisions.

I have found no major issues with this game, however there are the odd spelling mistake, but those are far between and very easy to work with, and most likely something that will be patched sooner rather than later.

If you expect this game to be a pure city builder where you are all powerful, you will be disappointed, but if you are looking for something where you have to balance the various needs of the city, you will not be disappointed.

8.5/10

Not recommended for the full price. I pre-purchased it for 38 â‚¬. It's a fun game in the beginning, rather casual I would say (as in not highly complex so far). A city-ruler game, not a city-builder. 

I liked the first two eras of the game, but after that, it became "click click click, wait for votes, click click click" and nothing really mattered. I had positive income with my city and even if I didn't do anything and didn't change anything, all went well. I've never felt this indifferent about "winning" the game (with a time victory), because it was just so boring getting there. I basically sat it out.

Updated in May 2017 to add: It had potential, but apparently, nothing is being done to this game anymore. So unless you can get it for at least 75 % off, I don't think it's worth the price.

I've never felt this indifferent about "winning" the game (with a time victory), because it was just so boring getting there. I basically sat it out.

Updated in May 2017 to add: It had potential, but apparently, nothing is being done to this game anymore. So unless you can get it for at least 75 % off, I don't think it's worth the price.

This game is actually pretty fun, but the thing right now witholding me from giving a positive review is the performance of this game. I can play like any game on my computer on pretty high graphics, but this game even struggles to keep 60 fps at the lowest graphical option. It seems like it isn't really well optimized and I hope that will be fixed in the future.

Also there is a very weird bug where as you change your graphics option, all the Pre-Purchase DLC houses turn bright blue, lol.
column9:
This game is actually pretty fun, but the thing right now witholding me from giving a positive review is the performance of this game. I can play like any game on my computer on pretty high graphics, but this game even struggles to keep 60 fps at the lowest graphical option. It seems like it isn't really well optimized and I hope that will be fixed in the future.

Also there is a very weird bug where as you change your graphics option, all the Pre-Purchase DLC houses turn bright blue, lol.

column8:
Over-all this game largely met the kind of expectations I had for it. It set out to be a game based around being a dynasty of politically important figures in a city. It gives you benefits for focusing on various aspects, and you usually are restricted in just how much you can do with your city. While it's possible to obtain a strong enough enough economy to achieve multiple goals it seems nigh impossible to do all of them.

This game has a dash of Sim City, Democracy, and even a few key elements of it's own. It's not an amazing game, but it does seem like an entertaining game even if it has a hard time showing exactly how certain aspects impact your city.
column9:

This game has a dash of Sim City, Democracy, and even a few key elements of it's own. It's not an amazing game, but it does seem like an entertaining game even if it has a hard time showing exactly how certain aspects impact your city.

column8:
This game is a good example for a good idea, executed very badly and poor. This is a political/economical city management/"tycoonish" game. 
IMHO: The most important thing in developing a game like this, is game mechanics. Looks like they went for graphics instead. Because the graphics are very good for example. But the game mechanics are terrible. This voting and council system was a very good idea! But for god sake... the votes and the council itself are working like an idiot. 
For example: Sometimes even if you have a lot of money, they don't want to build anything. They vote no to train station, no to new district, no to everything. My first (and probably the last) try in this game was 2.2 hour. In this more than 2 hours i was able to build: 2 district, a police station, a clinic, and gas lamps. Nothing else. I progressed to almost 1900 but i doesn't feel any "accomplishment". Tho voting and council are working very badly and seemingly (other reviews) random. No real simulation or common sense at all. This is the part where this game fails big time. Not mentioned the sometimes inexplicable childish manifestations in game. I'm very sad.. not expected this. And for last but not least: Very overpriced!
If you are fan of the tycoons, manager, simulation, games: Not recommended to buy at all (at any price)!

column8:
I've seen a lot a people complaining about this game. I waited so long for this game but I did not pre-ordered it (it pisses me off). Well, finally after a lot of reading and watching walkthrough, I decided to buy it. Here is what I think :

+ YEAH +
- This game is UNIQUE: politics is the center of this construction game. I've never seen it before. So people complaning about the lack of construction in this game: yeah, you knew it! It was said a lot by the developers. I like politics and this game shows something interesting!
- Long-life game: this game will provide hours of gaming. Each game will be totally different by your actions, your family and what happens. Maybe not totally at the beginning because some reforms are useful for your city ... But when Era II comes, it changes everything.
- Difficulty is gowing slowly more and more difficult ... Era III was a pain in the ass.
- You'll need skills to get your reforms done after Era III because you'll get more parties (up to 6-7) with different opinions, different support of the population (their vote depends about the time but also what your city provides ! More you get schools, the less extremists have chances to get votes).
- You get A LOT OF different events that can TOTALLY have an impact on the city: accepting a Lama from a contry, entering in a group of extremists to help your city become independant, chosing a wife etc... A real diversity which makes every game unique.

+/- Why not but ... +/-
- Didacticial: not so useful. Not mandatory also.
- Scenarios: according to me, I did not find fun about it. It can be appreciated for some of you.

- NO NO NO ! -
- Only 4 families? Seriously? And you ALWAYS begin with the same character ... I would like to get more families and in each family, have a choice of at least 3 different people (because they give bonuses and malus to your city). Seriously, please! -> Be aware that ALL families are unlocked at the beginning of the game so you don't have to play hours to choose.
- Public services: really really expensive. And sometimes I don't get bonuses from them. You say Gas help factories, but I've never seen mine getting more money. You'll get hard times guy to get perfect city quickly by upgrading it! You'll need to wait a long time before getting enough money to invest ... Unless politics accept your idea to raise taxes +10% in a year (they can accept +1/2% sometimes).
- ONLY 3 MAPS! ARE YOU SERIOUS ???


Conclusion:
The game may not be, according to me, worth 45â‚¬. I did not ask for refund because I have fun with it and I hope they'll get us good upgrades (not DLCs guys). I think this game is worth 20/25â‚¬ for the moment (22/01/17). 
There's a REAL potential about this game. It is UNIQUE because of the system: politics before construction which is really good.
I got hope. I give you a 5/7
- ... Well, not so convinced after all.

You're not a god, you're a mayor with your hands tied who has to answer to the city council and the citizens. It's a challenge. Good luck!

Urban Empire has elements of Democracy, Banished, and a little bit of SimCity. But with a lot more variables. 

Yes, you can create districts, plop train staions and ports, or turn on the gas and electricity. But you're not doing any of that without the votes. You need to make decisions that gain you support of the councillors. While making decisions that are prosperous for the citizens and businesses. It's a balancing act.

Although there are several pages of data to ponder while planning your decisions, the feedback is not explained very well. However, after playing more than two or three hours you start to see how it all works together.

The graphics and sound are very nice. The UI is well organized and easy to navigate. I have experienced no bugs and it runs fine on my four year old laptop.

So for those who are patient, with an interest in politics and city planning, give it a try!
column9:
You're not a god, you're a mayor with your hands tied who has to answer to the city council and the citizens. It's a challenge. Good luck!

Urban Empire has elements of Democracy, Banished, and a little bit of SimCity. But with a lot more variables. 

Yes, you can create districts, plop train staions and ports, or turn on the gas and electricity. But you're not doing any of that without the votes. You need to make decisions that gain you support of the councillors. While making decisions that are prosperous for the citizens and businesses. It's a balancing act.

Although there are several pages of data to ponder while planning your decisions, the feedback is not explained very well. However, after playing more than two or three hours you start to see how it all works together.

The graphics and sound are very nice. The UI is well organized and easy to navigate. I have experienced no bugs and it runs fine on my four year old laptop.

So for those who are patient, with an interest in politics and city planning, give it a try!

Reading through some of these reviews, and some of them are pretty heavy handed.  So instead of pros and cons, praises and complaints, expectations vs. realities.  I'll just give you what it is.

[list]
    [*]Macro Manager:  There are very few things that you actually place aside from the district layout and select services.
    [*]Political Player:  Work your way around 3+ political parties who vote on every single decision that you make that requires funds or increasing taxes.  But use your political favors wisely, as eventually you will have to run for reelection.
    [*]Popular Populist:  Meet the needs of your people through six avenues all of which add up to their overall happiness.
    [*] Techological Leader:  Work your way through an expansive tech web that starts with advancements from the 1800's all the way to modern times.  Each tech gives you expansive capabilites and services that you can improve your town with.
    [*] Financial Guru:  This is the most important.  Without profitable revenue, you will go no where.  Which is really easy to do.
[/list]

All these requires a balance to get you through the game.  Some need a lot of attention, while others will sneak on you at the worst possible moment.  My biggest piece of advice is to restart as soon as you get a grasp of the mechanics of the game.  The tutorial goes too slow, and your district building should be rapid in the early game.  

Overall, I recommend this game to those who are curious about the macro style mechanics of the game and do not mind throwing a few extra bucks at a developer who tried to do something new and interesting.

I love city builders. However, games like Cities: Skyline gave you complete unilateral rule like a dictator. Tropico was almost the same replacing certain buildings with the idea of zoning that are prevalent in the other games. What I truly wanted in a game as complex as Cities: Skyline was a council that lorded and hounded at every decision I made through the giant political machine hovering over my fair city.

Urban Empire was supposed to bridge that gap between city builder and political simulator. Marketed as â€œBe a Mayor Playerâ€, whatever that meant, you had to develop the city through different eras and leaders through both physical development and the political challenges. You had to develop the cityâ€™s society through services while balancing the budget with the city councilâ€™s eye on your every move.

Oh, what fun I will have!

Or, was it a disappointment?

Barring you the description of how the â€œWheel of Lifeâ€ (supply/demand for societal expansion) works, let me tell what worked and didnâ€™t.

I love the idea of a city council. Frankly, the only reason for me to get this game is because of the idea of city development through voting in a city council. The simulated cityfolk are still allowed to partake in the cityâ€™s market economy, but certain services in the Wheel of Life requires the city councilâ€™s intervention. Services like fire stations, parks, clinics, opera houses, schools and workshops require that the council vote over the improvement.

I also love that the city council has era-appropriate parties occupying the council. My personal favorites were the existence of three parties: The Freedom Party (aka the Nazi Party), The Pacifist Party (super left-wing and liberal), and the Green Party (same like Pacifist Party, but more environmental). Political maneuvering with various parties with different ideologies isnâ€™t a walk in the park. Liberal policies will be unacceptable to some parties, but with the correct development and policies placed into the city early in the game, you can have conservative parties agreeing with leftists liberal policies. The gameâ€™s city council rewards players who know how to political maneuver themselves through the era with the easement of passing legislation.

However, even with such â€œcoded rewardsâ€ written into the game, it suffers from a very counterintuitive user interface. My anecdote is with the idea of banning prostitution and the failed revocation of that law. While the game works on a dual axis binary of conservative/liberal and left/right which works to describe a political ideology, binary shouldnâ€™t be used for your mayorâ€™s decision on certain laws. Like real life, a law passes or fails through the vote of the city council. 
However, your mayor can only push for a law ahead. If you were to personally revoke a law and convince political parties, they will not push for the revocation. What needs to be worked on are the clarification for the poltical choices of Pleading, Demanding, or Threaten a political party. The developers need to add an additional button to show whether a mayor is pushing to support or oppose if the player makes a mistake.

Speaking of mistakes, the performance of this game slows after building a lot of districts. As my trams in some districts zigzag their way through town, the scrolling speed to and fro the city is hampered as building textures load slowly or having serious graphical glitches. The performance has been problem since Tropico 4. Kalypso and the development team at Reborn Games need to calibrate and fix these issues if they were to create sequels. I understand the simulation games are the ones to usually suffer performance issues (like Cities XL), but albeit the game being playable, it becomes an absolute dread as the game stutters dealing with new simulations to compute. Mind you, I was also running my Performance Monitor next to my game and it is a RAM-eater, taking up 7 GBs of memory to run this game, even after adjusting graphic qualities to its lowest.

In conclusion, the only reason I am recommending this game is due to its uniqueness of it being both a city-builder and a political simulator. However, I would love the developers to start thinking of this game like a Paradox Interactive game, giving us greater freedom in creating a character and the political situation around the player. I would like them to solve the major performance issues that made this game somewhat unplayable in future eras of the game. Personally, I would return to this game again once they have patched some of the performance and UI issues.

Speaking of mistakes, the performance of this game slows after building a lot of districts. As my trams in some districts zigzag their way through town, the scrolling speed to and fro the city is hampered as building textures load slowly or having serious graphical glitches. The performance has been problem since Tropico 4. Kalypso and the development team at Reborn Games need to calibrate and fix these issues if they were to create sequels. I understand the simulation games are the ones to usually suffer performance issues (like Cities XL), but albeit the game being playable, it becomes an absolute dread as the game stutters dealing with new simulations to compute. Mind you, I was also running my Performance Monitor next to my game and it is a RAM-eater, taking up 7 GBs of memory to run this game, even after adjusting graphic qualities to its lowest.

In conclusion, the only reason I am recommending this game is due to its uniqueness of it being both a city-builder and a political simulator. However, I would love the developers to start thinking of this game like a Paradox Interactive game, giving us greater freedom in creating a character and the political situation around the player. I would like them to solve the major performance issues that made this game somewhat unplayable in future eras of the game. Personally, I would return to this game again once they have patched some of the performance and UI issues.

column8:
Just a couple hours in, but I like it for the most part. The dynamics of managing parties and getting the city council to vote are quite well done. Placing districts, doing research, voting, etc., all make sense and are easy to get used to. Overall I'd say this game is Tropico meets Civ 6 or SimCity city planning. 

However, I didn't figure out how to modify existing districts or how to add dervices to districts already populated. Maybe I am missing something here, but why can't I repurpose land and put a school where a house used to be? Also, after reserching tech, how can a district be upgraded to have gas lighting or a swer system? I'm sure these things must be available, but the tutorial mode didn't point them out and I couldn't figure it out on my own.

The one thing I found very annoying was the inability to save my game. Clicking on "save" just prompted the script saying "Saving is not permitted at this time" or something like that. Not sure if the game needs an update to "save game" or if games that have progressed beyonf era 2 can be saved or something???

column9: The economic system is inexplicable, the control feels terrible, the graphics are like a web game, and the playability is average. It can't be compared with other games of the same type. I don't recommend it, at least not at this price!

column8:
Urban Empire  is, unfortunately, not what one could expect from a city management strategy/simulation title of its price. Gameplay is incredibly shallow and repetitive, decisions and mechanics seems trivial, and the narrative is far too simple and sparse to compensate. In general, there is a painful lack of objectives or feedback from the game for any given strategy or outcome- just a quick blip of an event that adds or subtracts stats that have little to no bearing on your experience. You can run your city into the ground, or meticulously balance your budget by hand, but either way, nothing changes in terms of challenge or reward.  A sandbox without the toys, if you will.

On the whole, the game feels like a very early release, minus the performance issues.

As someone who has played 11 hours on this game, had three different campaigns and basically got all the ways to win, and get a victory I must say this game still has must work to do.

[b]It's fun, half-way in...[/b] The tutorial is bullshit, and the RCI demand is a lie; Keep building districts and make sure you keep an eye on taxation, I cannot stress this enough. Like the developers have hinted, this game is [b]NOT a city-builder[/b] but rather, a city-ruler type of game, a new type of sub-genre for strategy games and I think this is a great idea, this game also adds an interactive and engaging storyline for each one of the houses, if the engine decides to give you those events...
------------------------------------ More in Depth â†“ -----------------------------------

[b]Politics:[/b] the Politics in this game are utter garbage, a left-wing "CONSERVATIVE" party like the communists will support increase taxation for lower-class members and less taxation for upper classes. FDP are just a nuscane at the beginning and there is no way you can play this game in a "Conservative way" as the game FORCES you to progress. 

I think the political system is just shallow and lame, needs much more design.. for example the political compass should be Authoritarian - Libertarian (socio-economic compass) instead of Conservative-Liberals. I would also suggest to the Developers to add a "trait" system to parties, which will hinder their like to vote for-or-against different legislation so we don't have commies voting for INCREASING CHURCH FUNDING. Anyways, yes, the politics of this game are engaging but this feels more like "Barriers", these parties have no life to them.

[b]Novel/story:[/b] The story is interesting, and as I said earlier, if you're lucky enough to get the game to give you them.. Sometimes it doesn't, and you start out with a really shitty ruler or you don't know anything about the ruler except what the game gives you every era... Happened to me in Era IV/V. The von Pfilzens are interesting, and so are the Kilgannons, probably my favorite families to play in this game.

[b]City-building aspect:[/b] now I know this is NOT a city-builder but a city-ruler but it does have the city-building element to it, and frankly, its shallow and lame... Its not engaging as I thought it was, you don't have much say in how different grids and spreads are choosen aside from the "Change the spread" of a district thing. Going through Eras it becomes a general burden to upgrade your districts, the game offers no "total district" change stuff, so you have to keep changing infrastructure and roads manually which usually ends up being rejected-or-accepted depending on the parties in control. I wish the devs would put more focus on this aspect and the politics as they did on the story.

[b]Invention (AKA RESEARCH):[/b] The research part is smart, its cool and its engaging, I love it. There's not much to say, I think this is where the game excells in. Different research/inventeions give you different edicts, upgrades and unlocks new stuff (But by Era IV theres nothing new to unlock really except for upgrades).

[b]Engine & Sound:[/b] Sound is great, music is great. Engine, I heard people have had crashes, and that sucks.. I have only experienced one when transferring over to Era V, that's when it moved me back to Era 2 for some reason and It crashed... The game in graphics really lacks, I have a GTX 1070 that can run ARK and other games in probably the highest-res and so on (on 1080p and probably 4k) but somehow this game makes sure that my FPS is below 30 and constantly lags, drops or some other weird shit... Like damn, fix your stuff Rebel.


[b][i]In short[/i][/b] this game had potential, still has... I am not sure what went wrong with the devs, but I have to unfortunately give this game a 50% rating, and this is coming from someone who has 11+ hours in the game and got almost all the victory achievements. I would NOT recommend this game at its current stage, and I fear for the worse; that Kalypso and Rebel Media plan on adding and fixing a lot of these issues in over-priced DLC's...  (Current rating is not recommended, will change if patched and changed over time).

My message to the developers; Please, do not make this a DLC-expanded game, fix your issues and patch the game up before any DLC's!

Anyways, this is my take on the game... Feel free to add me on Steam if you'd like to hear more about my pro's and con's in regards to this game, or if you'd like me to help you out with strategy and development of your cities (If you bought the game).

Really loved the depth in this game ; lots of choice and a lot of political realism ; what I would love to see for an expansion would be more scenarios such as the WWI period and the revolutions that followed.  Maybe stuff in response to the Great Depression and World War Two.  Also I take it the early game is based on the Austro-Hungarian Empire.  Historically the Austrian Social Democrats were Marxists until they were crushed by fascism.  BTW I'm only up to the 1920s so far - so I don't know what comes after.  Sometimes I think I'd rather a scenario based on leading a Party rather than a single Mayor ; But who am I to complain?  This game fixes lots of the problems I once associated with the Genre.  A progressive welfare state is viable without ideological assumptions in the scripting which rule out social democratic strategies.  I really hope expansions and mods follow this ; Its really good so far - but I'm sure it could be better.  One last thing that annoyed me:  I hung on as Mayor in the 1920s but I can't seem to shake the right-wing parties ; I'm still getting good legislation through ; But it would be nice to have strategies capable of turning the tide in favor of the left-wing parties...  BTW the Communists also often play a spoiling role early on - which is not historical...  The self-proclaimed Communists parties arose in response to the split in European social democracy on account of World War One....

column8:
This is one of those games that you really want to love.  I preordered it in Oct and I couldn't wait for it to come out.  After a few hours of playing, I found it repeative and boring.  I was told to build a district and denied.  I don't know why people like one thing v. another.  I understand that the concept is to use politics and stragey to be able to do some things, but I see no rhyme or reason for why some things are approved and others aren't.  

I've updated my districts with technolgy and keep losing money.  I have little desire to contiue to replay until I get it correct.  I honestly think this can be a wonderful game, but they really need to rethink the core with a huge update. 

I would like a free mode to let me just build and see how things grow based on polices and technology.  

I would like to see how many people use/like the structors I've built besides just the political part - like do people really use the transportation system?  Are they getting sick and do we really need more clinics?  Plus 2 up on top for health doesn't really do it for me.

I would like to be able to have more insight on the politics.  Why do we have to vote on everything?  What do the people want more in order to grow?  The demand bars also aren't doing it.

Updates need to happen and then I'll update my status.  Look at your reviews guys and see that we need a change - bit time.  You have a great concept for a game - this can be a winner, but fix what needs to be fixed.

column8:
Feels like a few previously randomly generated numbers from a prexisting game engine were given a fancy (but entirely useless) UI emulating some sense of "decision making". You follow a very fixed path with no real options to deter from history in the slightest.

This really is a dumbed down city-builder marketing itself as something new. It is not.
column9:

column8:
If you are expecting an in-depth political stategy game, THIS IS NOT THAT GAME, Most complaints I have read about this game seem to be glowing praise followed by nit-picking the simplicity of the mechanics. Those who make this complaint, they are clearly forgetting this is a Kalypso game, you know the Tropico game developers. I thought this was actually a lot more interesting than many games in simular genres. 

+ Easy to learn the rules of the game
+ Innovative take on an old genre
+ The Tropico Easter-Eggs/References
+ Potential to become far greater with the DLC that Kalypso is imfamous for.

- A little too simple for City Builder Pros
- Kalypos, overstating the games nature
- The Families are not that different
- Political Parties Don't matter as long as you balace the budget
-If you don't balance the budget, the political parties will stonewall you on everything.

After watching a few youtube videos about the game, I pre-ordered the game...

I have to admit that the tutorials in the game seem broken to me. I find it very easy to break the tutorial steps by clicking on other options within the game.. I 'm current on my third game, which has the tutorial disabled, as the tutorial was asking me to do something, but couldn't figure out what or where i could modify settings and/or adjust rci ratios...  I would click on something other then the tutorial steps and break the progress. Luckily I've watched to preview videos and started a third game with tutorials disabled and I'm enjoying the game. 

My only issue so far is the tutorial for new users, until they fix them, I suggest watching quill18's videos https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m5iHlRr1zBU&list=PLs3acGYgI1-uKuuJBICNWIspMX7ZM2xQF 

I would recommend this game for business/management type tycoon type of players. I love tycoon games, and this is a neat idea and execution of a tycoon game where you don't have direct access to micromanagement a city, but take more of a political view of the game. I love the idea, and so far so good on execution.
column9:
After watching a few youtube videos about the game, I pre-ordered the game...

I have to admit that the tutorials in the game seem broken to me. I find it very easy to break the tutorial steps by clicking on other options within the game.. I 'm current on my third game, which has the tutorial disabled, as the tutorial was asking me to do something, but couldn't figure out what or where i could modify settings and/or adjust rci ratios...  I would click on something other then the tutorial steps and break the progress. Luckily I've watched to preview videos and started a third game with tutorials disabled and I'm enjoying the game. 

My only issue so far is the tutorial for new users, until they fix them, I suggest watching quill18's videos https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m5iHlRr1zBU&list=PLs3acGYgI1-uKuuJBICNWIspMX7ZM2xQF 

I would recommend this game for business/management type tycoon type of players. I love tycoon games, and this is a neat idea and execution of a tycoon game where you don't have direct access to micromanagement a city, but take more of a political view of the game. I love the idea, and so far so good on execution.

column8:
I really wanted to like this game, it has been on my wishlist for months. But ultimately it fell flat on my expectations. 

It is ridiculously overpriced for what it is- I would not be refunding it if it were a $5 or $10 game...but no, it is a $40 game, and that is ridiculous for what it is. On the surface, it gives off the impression of being a "city builder" and being complex, but it is not. Once you have played for an hour, you realise just how repetitive the game is and how lacking in content, diversity, and complexity it really is.

Not worth the asking price.

I was really hoping for a good mayor style sim where you are in control of the town or city without having to micromanage the construction.  What I found it to be is a game where you click buttons and hope it turns out well.  Even in the tutorial I attempted to add a district and was denied over and over by the vote.  I thought having a church in the district would be nice, but apparantly I was wrong.

column8:
This game doesn't feel complete at all.
 
Tutorial is sketchy and superficial , and doesnt explain all the game mechanics to run the city properly. 

The political side of things is ridiculous. Everything runs on goodwill and prestige , which the tutorial conveniently left out on how to obtain it.

The city building side fared better , click to add options to district and buildings.  However ,  what the tutorial neglected to teach was how to generate more money for the city which usually leaves players struggling to build a city they like.  In this aspect , sims like Tropico feels easier to understand. 

Another thing i hated was how boring it became as the the game went on. Things got repetitive fairly quickly. Research new tech , wait forever just to have the money to implement 1 of the perks of the new tech in a part of your city , fight the various political factions to pass through the agreement to build that single building or implement that new tech , which is fairly ridiculous to me. 

This game doesn't feel like it has a end game objective. Sure, there are victory conditions listed in the logbook , be it for campaign mode or scenario mode , but the campaign mode's background story is just that , a background distraction. There is no story or plot whatsoever to immerse in . 

I wouldn't recommend this game at all , unless you have hours to burn and you have really absolutely nothing else to play.

column9: I initially watched Xiaoxiao play this game, then watched the trailer and was blown away by the final line, "You're not qualified to play with me," and the Chinese dubbing, which most games don't have. I immediately pre-ordered it and raved about it to my classmates, who then regretted forgetting to pre-order. Then, I was struck by the sub-20 FPS optimization on the lowest settings with anti-aliasing turned off, the 20-minute loading time, and the incomplete translation at the start. If this game weren't so laggy back then, I'd definitely buy it again.

Je ne suis pas dÃ©Ã§u. Vous devez gÃ©rer une ville, quartier par quartier. Et quand je dis gÃ©rer, c'est passer par le Conseil Communal pour prendre les dÃ©cisions. 

C'est peut-Ãªtre lÃ  que le jeu est rÃ©pÃ©tif: pour chaque dÃ©cision de construction, d'amÃ©lioration, il faut passer par le vote des partis du Conseil municipal. Sauf si vous avez assez d'argent dans votre compte personnel. 

Pour ma premiÃ¨re partie, j'ai "tenu" environ 100 ans avant de voir les partis voter contre ma rÃ©Ã©lection en tant que maire de la ville. CommencÃ©e en 1821, ma partie s'est terminÃ©e au dÃ©but de 1939...

Les points positifs:

I saw a video calling this "Tropico like" but sadly it doesn't seem to have any of the charm (but then again Tropico 5 was a huge disappointment too so maybe it's time to just write off Kalypso entirely).

This game really needs a better tutorial - the tutorial in the game left me going into massive debt with no clue how I can actually affect anything (if you don't massively increase taxes you can barely pay for the school you have to build for the tutorial, never mind the grid upgrades you are later have to build as part of the tutorial).  
You occasionally get asked to make certain decisions, but with no way of knowing the result it might as well be random (e.g. "vienna style" gas lighting vs "french style" gas lighting vs "british style" gas lighting - how the hell am I supposed to make an educated decision about which style of gas lighting is best for my city?).
What's more, despite picking a "campaign" I never saw any objectives or any hint as to what the goal of the game might be (hit some target population? hit some target income? hit some target tech level?). 
It just looks like Simcity with everything removed (RCI is chosen for you, roads are picked for you by the game) with ubiquitous time wasting votes which keep playing time wasting vote count animations every. single. time. 

If there is fun to be had I didn't find it and I am not invested enough to give up my refund to find out.

column8:
My problems are pretty basic with this game: my inputs equal no change. Add gas infrastructure, which is supposed to "boost companies" no change in company income. The same with water/sewer service no change... I can add services to go bankrupt and make no change... business does seem to do better in mixed district rather than seperated so that I can't save on services...

Politics is a joke... Want to raise taxes? Just run a deficit. Doesn't matter how you got there just jack up the taxes. Don't remove whatever you added that ruined the mix. Propose anything they will fight you tooth and nail, oh and count on the party that likes it to be the minority... Let them come to you and it sails through no problem. State laws? it may be unlocked but you cannot propose them and be a trailblazer you just gotta wait until some hidden metric proposes it. 

I can improve the quality of businesses by "promoting" them but gain no income again only for commercial business because industrial business does not benefit from endorsement what?... the tooltips are missing or unintelligible... I can "cheese it up" but the tools that are suposed to have some impact are equivalent to bashing my head against a wall... I was so looking forward to this game I even preordered, which I almost never do, now I am just dissapointed...  I had so much hope for this.

Ok, got enough hours in now to comment. Actually feels like I've seen it all already. I really like management games, just like I like games involving means of manipulation or sneaky means to achieve your goal. The prospect of having to influence the council to get my will really appealed to me. Sadly I have that the way it is executed in this game isn't for me. I will actually start with the Cons on this one:

Cons
- The praised 1000 events are boring with very minor (if at all impact). It's just a popup, you choose an option and get a mostly useless bonus or harmless malus. I had hoped for some event chains, something requiring action and something refreshing now and then. Nothing. 
- Economy often makes no sense whatsoever. The income drops and increases A LOT rather randomly and you don't even get a hint of why. The statistic tab is abismal. Most stuff you can't really read out of it.
- The family choice is bland and rather meaningless. I usually approve roleplay elements like this but this is VERY basic and not fun.
- I really hoped for more of an impact of the world's events on the town. There is (close to) nothing there. That makes absolutely no sense.
- There really isn't much point in optimisation. At times the most profitable districts are the basic ones without any costly upgrades.
- Based on my observations there seems to be only one real way to be financially successful (not spoiling it). All attempts to use other playstyles that based on the data given (demands for residents, commercy, industry) would have made way more sense ended horribly bad.
- I see close to no replay value. The events don't offer any. 

Pros:
- The approach for science is nice and refreshing.
- Living through the changes in history e.g. the rights of women, the privileges initially reserved to few yet opened up over time is quite fun.

column8: So much wasted potential. I really wanted to love this game, but I just can't. It's boring, it really is. I study politics for fun and I find this boring... And what's with the city building parts? Why are services so bloody expensive? Gah, I want to like this so much and I just don't.

This game while entertaining I believe forces a political agenda down your throat expecially when it comes to the progression of your city and its society. I would rather play tropico or cities skylines, I would even rather play simcity 5 than play this again. Things such as LGBT rights and womens rights should STAY OUT of videogames. Videogames should NOT be used as a political stage to push certain agendas. I mean would you put Black Lives Matter into a game? Would you put extreme religion into a game? No. Im sorry but I did one play through, got up to era 5 and I said forget playing another run.

I am extremely disapointed in this game.

column8: A fun little AA city sim.  Part story focused, part city builder, part politics sim, this title aims to do it all.  While not a perfect game due to being too ambitious, I certainly enjoyed the eras and the story of the characters you play as.  I would pick this game up if you want to wittle away the time for awhile building citys and seeing how technoloy changed the eras.

column8: It is NOT a city builder! You are a MAYOR, if you want to take political decisions and spend your time voting / threatening / pleading other politicals paties, this game is for you. It is a strategical game. First time aroud, nobody wanted to vote for me so my city stopped working properly and and lost... 2nd Time around, I was losing more than 50k a month, so I went bankrupt when the mother state stopped giving me money... I guess the 3rd time is gonna be the good one... Or not...

column8: Refund Simulator 2017

So I got this game and I feel that one thing is clear: It gets boring, fast. 

There neeeds to be more things to do in order for me to really enjoy the game. 

Also nearly all the events happen at the same time, so you expect things to happen. 

Great idea, just not fully done yet.

column8:
This game showed a lot of promise, and still could be great, however, right now, its not. There are plenty of problems, inaccuracies, and drawbacks, but ultimately, what sinks this game is taxes. Income is seemingly random, shoots up and down massively month to month, and taxes need to constantly be raised just to keep your head above water. Its not fun to vote on taxes every 5 minutes,  by 1920 I had reached the ludicrously high tax rate of 95%, the maximum, and it still wasn't enough for basic level one services. The way the game handles money in general is annoying and unenjoyable. I love the idea behind the game but it's currently shallow, tedious, and a bit silly. 

I wish the devs all the best, and hope this game can be fixed, but right now I regret spending 40 dollars for 4 hours a gameplay before I decided it was time to move on.

Si le concepte de gÃ©rer une ville par le biai d'un conseil municipale plutot qu'en tant que dieu omnipotent est intÃ©ressant, le fait est que le gameplay est incomprÃ©hensible ! tutoriel vague, aucune information ou explication sur les problemes rencontrÃ©s et comment les solutionner. Vous pouvez avoir une ville qui gagne 50k par mois et d'un coup, tout s'Ã©croule et vous perdez 100k par mois. Sans aucune action, sans aucun changement de population. Ni les habitants ni les entreprises ne vous solicitent pour vous dire ce qu'ils veulent, une icone vous dit juste qu'ils sont mÃ©content ! c'est Ã  vous de deviner !

Sorry, this is Fantasy Gameplay with Functional Problems. You can't acctualy play the game without finishing the Tutorial. But the Tutorial does not allow saving the game. This forces you to finish a Tutorial which may last for hours. But the Tutorial has functional problems. Scrolling and zooming does not work well, and not far enough outward to see the big picture. So to see your whole town and important locations around it, this game fails. Tutorial arrows cover information you need to read. Double pop-up screens occur with ghost images over each other. Loading between different sequences takes a long time. Scrolling any menu makes it "bounce" at top and bottom of the menu selection list. Trying to place the rail station while using the mouse to scroll and zoom disconnects the placement of station command many times. After much trial and error in this Tutorial, you find there is only one fixed location for this station on the map but this is untold to the player, so it is not necessarily near where you placed the town at the start. So you can memorize where this was on the map, and then restart the Tutorial to restart the town closer to this station location. When finding it and successfully placing the station, the town council now votes "against" the station. This makes no sense. Why can the player not be aware of this "opinion" before researching and trying to build? And Why did they vote that way? The council does not explain their objection. Poor game design and mechanics. Also the Game as "history" makes no sense. A proposal for Womens Right to Own Property has approval of all parties, but a train station does not! It is the 1820's. Town development does not follow real town development throughout history. Even when using the Dense Grid the town grows like modern suburbia, not like tightly packed houses around a core or town square. Inventions are not historical. Political viewpoints are ahistorical and the Council disagreements on each invention makes no sense for city development. What does this leave? Pretty graphics and a contrived storyline, and you must always use the same contrived player characters. Besides being technically buggy, when the Tutorial does work it has a strange idea of "history" that borders on "fantasy" in gameplay. Not acceptable all around.

column8:
El juego esta bastante bien. Pese a estar en ingles es bastante comprensible. La estetica es muy elegante. Es tal y como se describe, te dedicas mas a la gestion y planificacion politica que a diseÃ±ar la ciudad (apenas si puedes distribuir las zonas y las calles son automaticas, algunas infgraestructuras como el tren solo puede ir en sitios concretos marcados en el mapa...)

Otra cosa que se echa en falta es mas info sobre las opciones de los eventos que van saltando, que son muy importantes, pero solo ves el resultado tras haber elegido (aunque se podria decir ques mas "realista")

Tambien echo en falta que el juego se autopause cuando hay evento, porque aparecen en la esquina inferior y se te puede pasar por alto.

El tema de votar en el ayuntamiento, manejar a los partidos y tal es muy interesante y entretenido, hay que tenerlos contentos o te echaran atras leyes aunque sean beneficiosas


En general un buen juego, falta espaÃ±ol :D

Diese Spiel bleibt nicht nachvollziehbar. Welche Werte werden wie beinflusst ist wenn Ã¼berhaupt nur Kripitisch beschrieben. Bei gleichbleibenden Werten verschlechtert sich konstant das Einkommen (wieso?) grade am Anfang absolut frustrierend. Wenn mann dann Geld hat kann mann fast alle Entscheidungen durch den Rat bringen. 

Die Grafik ist Ok. Die MenÃ¼s sind Ã¼bersichtlich aber wie gesagt es fehlt hier massiv an Feedback und die Lernkurve ist umgedreht also absoluter Quatsch

Zur Zeit gibt es leider viel zu wenig Informationen wie die Simulation hinter dem Spiel funktioniert. Ich bin jetzt 3 mal bankrott gegangen in Ã„ra 2 und hab erstmal jegliche Motivation verloren. Ohne ersichtlichen Grund schwindet die Wirtschaft stÃ¤ndig da hin... Vielleicht bessert es sich durch einen Patch.

I thought a city ruler style game was what I wanted over a city builder, but I guess I was wrong as this game was not what I wanted. Trust me most people playing this now will get 10 hours MAX out of this game then quit.

By city "ruler" you can raise taxes to the max or not at all and win either way, events are all the same a predictable, the economic system is broken as I can lower bussiness taxes to 0% and no one shows up, but once we give the whole damn city a 50% tax rate with no benefits(editics) everyone is all for investment. There is also little to no content which is why the game itself lacks replayability as EVERY MAP AND FAMILIY PLAYS ALMOST EXACTLY THE SAME, LITERALY NOTHING CHANGES. In addition there is the horrible tech tree (it looks cool, but the system sucks) and there is little to nothing about world events besides the newspaper articles.

Now I know what your thinking, these guys made the Tropico series... yeah, but no
same publisher diffrent devs which is why this is"not" a city builder

This game "is" a city builder game... with the builder taken out... Its literaly just a city that no matter what you do and who you offend on the council, you get everything your way no matter what. I can threaten a party every single month before a vote, telling them I will execute them all, and they will happily grant whatever I want. (note this is the 4th era too...)

All together there was nothing that made me enjoy the game besides the inital start up on when everything was new, after a hour you realize the game is overpriced and nothing special.

column8:
Ich finde dieses Spiel gut, weil erschreckend realistisch (also in den GrundzÃ¼gen). 

Was gerne von einigen der Bewerter hier Ã¼bersehen wird, ist die Tatsache, das man hier nicht zwangslÃ¤ufig eine Stadt aufbaut wie bei Tropico, Anno xyz etc. also hier ein Weizenfeld, da eine MÃ¼hle und dort den BÃ¤cker und alle kullern satt und glÃ¼cklich den Berg hinab, sondern als Stadtoberhaupt einen Stadtteil nach dem nÃ¤chsten aus dem Boden stampfen soll, immer mit der Opposition im Hintergrund, die eigentlich immer alles besser weiÃŸ. 
Soll heiÃŸen, man kann durchaus ein GrundstÃ¼ck als  Wohnviertel, Gewerbepark und ein Industriegebiet zuweisen, aber hat im Prinzip nicht den geringsten Einfluss darauf, was genau das Gewerbe und die Industrie ist (im Gegensatz zu oben genannten  - Volk hungert->her mit dem GemÃ¼sefeld). Bauen kann man nur stÃ¤dtische GebÃ¤ude wie Schule und Polizei sowie Infrastruktur wie Gas, Wasser, Sch... - wenn es denn die Partein zulassen.

Was die Partein anbelangt - wie auch im wahren Leben, nur an sich denkend, wie die Macht und das Wohlwollen des Volkes zu Ihren Gunsten gesteigert werden kann. So wird der Antrag der SteuererhÃ¶hung abgelehnt, nur um einige Monate spÃ¤ter selbst vorgebracht zu werden. Hier liegt auch der einzige Kritikpunkt - weil vorhersehbar - den ich bisher finden konnte - wenn das Geld stimmt, dann wird im Prinzip jeder Antrag angenommen, wenn nicht, dann gibt es eben keinen Strom, der der Industrie zwar Aufschwung und der Stadt mehr Einnahmen bescheren wÃ¼rde, aber es will eben keiner im Stadtrat sitzen, wenn Schulden gemacht werden.

Grundlegende Fehler konnte auch ich nicht finden. Richtig ist, dass es augenscheinlich an manchen Stellen einen Automatismus gibt, der in meinen Augen aber nicht als Bug gesehen werden kann. Wenn der Bahnhof freigeschaltet ist, dann wollen normalerweise alle das Bauwerk - ausser natÃ¼rlich meine Partein - und dann schaut sich der BÃ¼rgermeister nunmal die Baustelle an.

Somit wÃ¼rde ich jedem, der nur ein Stadtaufbauspiel sucht, von diesem hier abraten, da gibt es mehr als genug, die mit Sicherheit dieses BedÃ¼rfnis vollkommen befriedigen. Jenen jedoch, die eine Herausforderung suchen, sind hier genau richtig. Selbst wenn mal keine Entscheidung im Raum steht, verÃ¤ndert sich die Situation stÃ¤ndig. Hier sterben die Einwohner, da schlieÃŸt das GeschÃ¤ft und dort geht die MÃ¶belfabrik bankrott und schon hat man negative Einnahmen, die man im Moment nicht wirklich beeinflussen kann. In meinen Augen ein wirklich interessantes Spiel, bei dem ich teilweise wirklich froh bin, wenn ich mal nichts tun muss und alles lÃ¤uft.

column8:
Great idea, but bad game. It starts with bad performance (and my PC has i7 with GTX1080) then goes on to some shady mechanics - game says "business has low quality" but it doesn't say how to fix that. Or you build service with +7 to security but it doesn't change population security even by 1 point. Game doesn't say why. Then it all goes to miscelaneous bugs and in the end adds some frustration - you can't downgrade, only demolish and rebuild - combined with shady mechanics this leads to trial-and-error being quite painful.
In the end - it's not something I can recommend. Hope this will change in future.

column8: I'm halfway through my first game and enjoying it.  Creative take on city building/ruling with potential.  Takes a bit of trial and error as some of the game mechanics are still too opaque (e.g. sales demand).  But I'm getting the hang of it.  There aren't as many levers as a city builder, but that makes for less micromanagement, and there is still plenty to do.

I recomend this game, but please be aware it isnt for everyone its not like cities skylines, or other city builders out there it is a diffrent take on it and personally that is what i like about it.

I saw some Let's Play videos of this game before it was released and seemed like something I would enjoy.  I had fun with Tropico, and adding additional politics and personal motivations into the game mechanics seems like a great thing.  Sadly, it really doesn't work out that way.

Basically you are playing a choose your own adventure game, inbetween extremely long periods of sitting and waiting for something to happen or constantly having to brow beat the city council.  The game fails to involve you as a player more than getting to pick one of two or three options to a story based event, many of which don't explain the mechanical result of such.  And as far as not explaining, the tutorial is horrible (I will give credit that you can now disable it, which you couldn't for a time) and drags on for ages.  The tooltips are vague at best and just don't work at worse.  The council will always oppose you, just so you have something to compete against, and even if you cater to their needs you still have to burn your goodwill to get votes through.  And if you city ends up stable and making money you are just sitting waiting for the next tech to roll around so you can repeat the same cycle of picking a district upgrade and/or edict and spending your goodwill to get it passed.

All told, if you want a city builder play City Skylines.  If you want a politcal simulator, play Democracy 3.  And if you want more Tropico, just go play Tropico, because Urban Empire fails to be a good game in any of those cases.

Super spannendes Spiel. Viele aktionen sind im Spiel zu Beachten. An der Steuerschrauben muss immer wieder gedreht werden und die Parteien treten dem BÃ¼rgermeister immer auf die FÃ¼ÃŸe. Dazu noch die Infrastruktur im Auge behalten und dazu etwas Geschichte und Technologiewissen mit auf dem Weg zu bekommen ist Top. Ich hoffe auf einige neue Erweiterungen. 
Viel SpaÃŸ fÃ¼r LEute die gerne Aufbaustrtegiespiele spielen, denen dort die Politik gefehlt hat. 
Empfehlenswert!

Terrible game thusfar.  Played 3 hours and like others have mentioned, it gets quite boring very quickly.  The most activity I had was speeding up the game, then pausing to pass votes.  The tutorial during the first campaign offers limited help.  You really can't customize your districts because the add ons cost too much and have too much upkeep.  Can't add new zones for the same reason.  Random events and votes just stop time while you sit and watch the city do much of nothing.  The innovation cloud thing is pointless when you can't really implement the unlocked features.  Got water and gas, but can't install because of the upkeep.  Can't make people happy because I can't upgrade services.

Tried to get a refund and was denied.  Thought this was going to be a better game, but I was sorely disappointed.  Only saving grace for my disappointment was saving 15% on pre-order.

column8:
The game is enjoyable at the beginning, but with the time going, you feel more and more headache in the game. The vital issue  to me is your income NEVER grows with the tech clouds, but your outcome does! That makes tax raising the only solution for the city finance. And at each stage, the game asks to meet some special criterias, which forces to invest huge money on infraustructures or services, but the economic return is merely to see.
So if you want to build a Texas style city - low tax low service, you are better to try your luck in some other games.

I wasnt really sure about this game after I washed a lot of videos on you tube.

Pro

New type of city building special the council part.
Lots of diferent type of events what give you the chance to play that game again and it could have a iferent outcome 
Lot of hystoric background well researched 
lots of goverment and invastructer building 

Cons

Game look like been rushed out many many bug that made the game unstable and not really good to play( buit thanks for the idea how to fix it)
lots of areas have so much potential but have not been really finished punlic transport self deciding where it goes.
plan tool to creat new districts are sluggy and make it sometime really to hard to creat a nice dirstric soecial the roads are not well place on any optin

price for that game is typicly kalipso style and by fare over the top and need at least reduce to 25 gbp 

result 

This game schould be go back in open beta because for me it looks like a godd open beta what need a lot of patching up.
there is high potential in this game and if the game maker stay behind there game than I think this game can be a good game 

I recomand this game for the steam 2 hour trail where you can get refound if you decidet this is not a game for you.
