Eigentlich sehr schade...
ich hatte das Spiel schon lange Zeit vorbestellt und mich schon sehr darauf gefreut mal wieder eine wirklich gute und spannende Simulation zu spielen.

Ich habe das Spiel nach 2h Spielzeit zurÃ¼ckgegeben daher bitte auch gerne Bewertungen mit einer hÃ¶heren Spielzeit eher beachten als meine! Ich kann hier nur aufzÃ¤hlen was mir wirklich extrem gefehlt hat um mich in dem Spiel von Anfang an zurechtzufinden und wohl zu fÃ¼hlen:

Was mir gleich am Anfang aufgefallen ist war die Ã„hnlichkeit der Bauweise von Bezirken und den BedÃ¼rfnissen zu bekannten Spielen wie Simcity oder auch Citys Skylines, die ich beide sehr lange und gerne gespielt habe. Eigentlich war das fÃ¼r mich auch ein Grund warum ich das Spiel eigentlich hÃ¤tte gut annehmen sollen.

Aber genau hier ist der Haken an der Sache. Anders als bei genannten Spielen fehlt Urban Empire einfach alles was man braucht um erfolgreich eine Stadt zu leiten. Es gibt zwar eine Hand voll Bildschirme an denen man BedÃ¼rfnisse von BÃ¼rgern, Parteien etc einsehen kann aber insgesamt ist das Spiel fast schon furchterregend Ã¼berschaubar.

Ich habe zu beginn versucht das erste Scenario ( bei dem man Waffe, SchieÃŸpulver etc  fÃ¼r den Kaiser bauen soll ) zu spielen und bin gleich mehrfach an verschiedenen Faktoren gescheitert.

Die Industrie z.b. ist von mir in folgenderweise beeinflussbar gewesen.
1. Bau neuer Bezirke = der Bau neuer Bezirke muss von Senat verabschiedet werden, was soweit noch nicht das groÃŸte Problem war. Also beantragte ich einen Bezirk der 136k Baukosten haben sollte und 0k monatliche Kosten.....soweit so gut. Antrag wird bewilligt und der Bezirk gebaut ( ohen zusÃ¤tzliche Dinge wie Hospital Schule oder mehr Infrastruktur als nur einfache StraÃŸen wohlgemerkt ). Mein monatliches Budget ging von +8k in nur 2 Monaten nach dem Bau des Bezirks auf -136k.......Also suchte ich in Statistikem nach dem Grund konnte aber nicht so wirklich einen finden.

2. stÃ¤ndig aufploppende Fenster mit 3-4 mÃ¶glichen Antworten wie ich mit verschiedenen Dinge wie explosionen in Fabriken, ausgelaugten Arbeitern oder SchwarzmarktgeschÃ¤ften umgehen will. Ich empfand diese andauernden Es passiert Dies mache Das Situationen eher nervend, da ich nicht wirklich den Eindruck hatte das ich hier wirklich Politik mache...zumahl die Antworten sogar immer den gleichen Einfluss hatten wenn ich gesichert und geladen habe.

Ich hatte zu keiner Zeit wirklich das GefÃ¼hl viel Einfluss auf das ganze Geschehen oder auch die Parteien zu haben. Zu den Parteien an sich ahben andere ja schon genug gesagt.

Vom Aufbau her ist das Spiel ebenfalls alles andere als schÃ¶n. Die Grafik ist statisch und wirklich mangelhaft, auÃŸerdem undetailiert und man hat das GefÃ¼hl immer nur zwischen 2 Bildschirmen hin un herzuhÃ¼pfen weil man zwischen 2 Abstimmungen eh so gut wie nichts zu tun hat. Naja mag sein das sich das spÃ¤ter Ã¤ndert aber ich habe mich noch nie so gelangweilt bei einem Game.

Mein Fazitzusammengefasst:

- schwache Grafik
- Keine AtmosphÃ¤re
- zu wenig ausgebaute EinflussmÃ¶glichkeiten
- zu wenig erkennbare Informationen die einem helfen richtig zu entscheiden
- so gut wie keine Einflussnahme auf die Wirtschaft
- schlecht erkennbarer Zusammenhang zwischen zukÃ¼nftigen Einnahmen und ausgaben

insgesamt Nette Idee ab er "bisher" schlecht umgesetzt

FÃ¼r die Leute die sich vielleicht weniger erwartet haben als ich ( oder gar nichts bestimmtes erwarten ) lohnt sich vielleicht das warten auf Bugfixes, Verbesserungen oder auch Preisminderungen im Sale

They should never release a game with this many bugs.  Thumbs down for that alone...
The spinning screen is simply unbearable making the game completely unplayable.  
The "disconnect all peripherals" recommendation for getting the spinning to stop is ridiculous.
If the game becomes playable, I will re-rate it.  If the bugs preventing the game from running are not fixed with the first update (better be w/in 10 days), I will ask for a refund.

UPDATE:  Not worth it.  Could have been good, development team failed.

column9:
I finished the game in one night, so here's my thoughts. The scenario I used for my first family is pretty much about a small city in the heart of Europe. I didn't fully grasp the first two eras, and the finances were in tatters. I could only write letters to the emperor to mitigate the damage, then cut the budget, raise taxes, and pass a few economic-boosting bills to slowly recover (though it was pretty cool to have the money back after that). By the third generation, things were utterly disastrous, with year after year of deficits, and it wasn't until the fourth generation that they finally recovered (though the plot here is quite realistic; it was the Great Depression of 1933, and everyone knows the consequences). The Senate also gave me a taste of the "character" of that era. Basically, you couldn't pass a single policy without following the Party's policies. Then, in the fourth generation, to fill the gap, they simply cut the tax rate in half. Huh? Not convinced? Just dig up your past bad history 2333, and you'll pass. If you don't have a bad history, just threaten and yell a few times, and that's pretty good too 23333. Then you'll get good at it later. Just wait until 2020 to finish it, and then go to sleep.
(Speaking of which, by the time the fifth generation rolls around, the newspapers will have some gaming news, like The Sims is out, Respawn has a new game, and Respawn's games are the best, etc. 2333. Is that really okay to brag about yourself? Hhhhhhhhh)

It pains me a bit to give this a bad review - it's not as bad as GA: Medieval. 

The problem is that the game play is completely linear and everything else is really just the illusion of choice.

The only way to get new things passed through the legislature is to have tax money coming in, and the only way to get more tax money coming in is to be running a deficeit. So the game is just a constant cycle of purposely building enough to run you into the red so that you can justify raising taxes. There's not a lot that you actually get to choose.

The other big issue is that not enough things are explained. And I'm not even talking about not knowing what the consequences of decisions are before hand. I'm talking about the fact that a lot of the tooltips don't make sense in english and aren't intuitive at all. There's no clear explanation of how things interact with each other.

The devs only created one play style. There don't seem to be any consequences to raising taxes, so tax and spend all day! And heaven for bid you have a different idea you'll just get stuck behind with shit piling on top of you endlessly.

The 1 hour review:

This is not a city building game, its a city management game. So far, money is hard, which is good, compared to games  Skylines. However, at the moment, I find one flaw with it. It feels extremely liberal biased. Playing as a concervitive is hard, because the game punishes you for it. That, or I'm doing it wrong.

5/7 for the Liberal bias.

column8:
To start off, I really like the direction this game takes when compared to other city building games. More realistic in the way it handles creating different aspects of a city.

That being said, in the shape it's in now, I can't recomend paying full price for it.

I personally will be refunding my copy, and most likely picking it up again later down the line after there has been some polishing.

As it stands, a 6/10.

column8:
I wish I could give this a positive, because it is a good game and I do enjoy the graphics, the concept, the watching of my city as it grows, the budget juggling and politics of this story that you play...
...but
...
This is supposed to be a game, though it ends up feeling like a story that you're watching. The political parties in this game can be held back and resisted for a while, you can't control the population to influence the elections, so you're at the mercy of the games random mechanics which are poorly explained, the horrible lack of tooltips giving you -Any- information, about anything and everything, you can't even find out a why business went out of business, or why it's bankrupt, or who works where, or how to help citizens improve... 

and the political parties, eventually you can't do anything but accept their utter rule over you and the policies "You" enact for your city, even if you're highly opposed to them and have been for the entirity of the game. 

I respect that democracy is showcased here, but that's exactly what's wrong with this game. In the hours I've played it, I did have fun and I'll probably continue to have fun, but I don't feel like I'm a part of the game or my city or my leader, I feel like I'm merely watching them play their story. 

It makes me appreciate games where I find myself looking at the clock and realising a few hours have passed because it was enjoyable. 

Wait until it's on sale or the bugs have been fixed and the AI improved.

Thank you for reading and I wish you well.

column8:
I had really high hopes for this game, it looked like an intriguing twist on the city-builder genre. Unfortunately, the twist, i.e. the city politics, is one-dimensional and totally lacking in interaction with the other factions. Your family choice seems to have no bearing on the gameplay, other than the odd event which pops up every couple of years, and the lack of customisation is a shocking misstep (perhaps when basing a game around family dynasties, Kalypso could have looked at the success seen by Paradox with their Crusader Kings II series).

Then there's the gameplay itself. It is completely impossible to run a city at a profit if you want it to grow, or if you want it to have even basic amenities, like schools and police stations. You find yourself raising taxes to ridiculous levels, which has no impact on businesses or people, or begging the Emperor for a loan. For some reason having a port or train station actually loses you money, as if those two crucial pieces of infrastructure were unable to make a profit. Wholly unrealistic.

If those basic things can be changed (i.e. the entire economics of the game), and if the politics can be made interesting, rather than repetitive (i.e. the entire basis of the game), and if more options for customising characters were made (i.e. the entire plot of the game), then this would be worth some money. Currently, it is not, and should never have been released in this state.

Como DEMOCRACY, se conhecer esse jogo, imagine DEMOCRACY, com uma arvore de tecnologia como CIVILIZATION, porÃ©m ao em vez do design minimalista de DEMOCRACY vocÃª tem uma estrutura grÃ¡fica como em PATRICIAN. EntÃ£o Ã© como jogar DEMOCRACY no universo de PATRICIAN. 

-A 2Âª forma Ã© para as pessoas que nÃ£o sÃ£o acostumadas com Tycoons ou jogos polÃ­ticos. O jogo NÃƒO Ã‰ um City Builder, pelo menos, nÃ£o exatamente. Isso foi deixado claro pelos desenvolvedores em diversos devy diaries ao longo do desenvolvimento do jogo (caso nÃ£o tenha acompanhado). 
*VocÃª Ã© um politico, e faz parte de um conselho politico, vocÃª nÃ£o simplesmente constrÃ³i um hospital, vocÃª propÃµe que um hospital seja construÃ­do onde vocÃª o posicionou; Essa proposta entrarÃ¡ em votaÃ§Ã£o em alguns meses durante esse perÃ­odo haverÃ£o reuniÃµes onde vocÃª pode tentar convencer que a construÃ§Ã£o do hospital Ã© uma coisa boa, caso algum partido de direita ou esquerda nÃ£o concorde com vocÃª. 
*VocÃª nÃ£o constrÃ³i casas ou industrias, vocÃª cria distritos e separa a zona de construÃ§Ã£o (como em SimCity [residencial, comercial, industrial]) e claro, este distrito precisarÃ¡ ser aprovado para ser construÃ­do.
*As construÃ§Ãµes para a votaÃ§Ã£o vÃ£o depender da economia, necessidade, despesas que vÃ£o gerar, impacto no distrito, etc... VocÃª nÃ£o vai construir SÃ“ porque vocÃª quer, existe a possibilidade de construir a vulso, mas isso vai custar seu dinheiro pessoal, e se prepare para possÃ­veis represarias de partidos ou impactos negativos na economia por alguma mÃ¡ decisÃ£o que vai fazer vocÃª pensar "Ã© realmente nÃ£o era pra ser construÃ­do"

Para mim as Ãºnicas coisas que me "incomodam" nesse jogo sÃ£o:
-NÃ£o existe muita atuaÃ§Ã£o vocal; isso poderia ser melhor explorado no jogo, poderia ter mais falas e mais efeitos sonoros vocais, em contra partida TODOS os jogos polÃ­ticos geralmente sÃ£o 100% leitura, o que faz o jogo ser bem mais fechado para o pÃºblico, o problema Ã© que quando vocÃª se depara com os grÃ¡ficos que o jogo tem, no fundo-no fundo faz vocÃª achar que algo estÃ¡ incompleto. 
-O sistema econÃ´mico Ã© insuficiente; A informaÃ§Ã£o "Renda" e "Despesas" sÃ£o bem genÃ©ricas o que faz vocÃª ficar sem muito chÃ£o pra pisar quando o problema Ã© melhorar a economia. Para o jogo que Ã© e pelo que o jogo propÃµe acho que uma micro administraÃ§Ã£o de finanÃ§as seria, e ao meu ver Ã©, muito necessÃ¡rio.

Como fÃ£ da Kalypso Media eu venho acompanhando seu trabalho a muitos anos, desde AIRLINE TYCOON em 1998, TROPICO em 2001, PATRICIAN e PORT ROYALE, etc... Entre outros jogos de outras empresas como DEMOCRACY, WALL STREET TRADER 2001, THE GUILD e tantos outros jogos, como jÃ¡ dito para publicos bem expecÃ­ficos que gostam deste tipo de GÃªnero polÃ­tico; Tanto quanto jogos como EURO TRUCK, FLIGHT/TRAIN/FARM SIMUATOR sÃ£o jogos para um publico bem especÃ­fico. 
Urban Empire estÃ¡ tentando levar o gÃªnero polÃ­tico para um novo patamar que nunca havia existido, um jogo polÃ­tico feito com mais verba e profundidade do que jamais feito.
Jeux assez critiquÃ© par sa difficultÃ©.

column8:
So liebe Leute,

nach 13 Stunden Spielzeit erlaube ich mir ein Review mit Bewertung und Fazit zu diesem Titel zu schreiben.
Wie man natÃ¼rlich schon am Thumb-Down erkennen kann, wird dieses Review nicht zum positiven ausfallen.
Was aber nicht bedeutet, dass die Spielidee schlecht ist. Negative Punkte einzelner Themen fÃ¼hrten letztendlich
zu einem negativen Ergebnis. Und los gehts!

[h1][b]Thema- / Genreidee[/b][/h1]

Kalypso warb damit, dass man eine komplett neue Spielkonzeptidee mit Urban Empire auf den Markt wirft.
Nachdem man ein paar Stunden gespielt hat, fÃ¤llt einem ganz schnell auf, dass dies natÃ¼rlich nicht ganz richtig ist.
Die Idee eine Stadt zu verwalten ist nichts neues. Steuern erheben, Steuern senken, Budgetanpassung fÃ¼r Ã¶ffentliche
Dienstleistungen, Nahverkehr...all das gibt es schon. Auch der Stadtrat und seine Parteien ist nicht ganz so neu.
Abstimmungen kennen wir schon aus "Die Gilde" und "Patrizier". Bei "Die Gilde" bestechen wir unsere Kontrahenten mit Geld, bezirzen sie mit ParfÃ¼m oder drohen ihnen einfach nur. Damit wir in "Urban Empire" die Parteien dazu bekommen fÃ¼r unser Vorhaben zu stimmen, mÃ¼ssen wir es fast genauso machen. Entweder wir bitten sie freundlich, fordern etwas oder bedrohen sie. Das bedrohen der Parteien funktioniert fast immer. Sie sind uns gegenÃ¼ber zwar nach der Abstimmung BÃ¶se eingestellt, aber auch das legt sich ganz schnell wieder und wir kÃ¶nnen von vorne anfangen sie dumm zu machen.
Weiterhin mÃ¼ssen wir Zonen errichten und diese Verwalten. Dazu kann man einfach nichts interessantes sagen, da es da nicht wirklich was interessantes zu erzÃ¤hlen gibt.


[h1][b]Stadt und Karte[/b][/h1]

Dazu gibt es eigentlich nicht viel zu sagen. Die ansicht der Stadt ist langweilig und ermÃ¼dend. Es gibt einfach kein richtiges Leben in der Stadt und es hat den Anschein, dass Kalypso an dieser Stelle die besten Grafiker und Programmierer in den Urlaub schickten und die Azubis ran liesen. Das Team von Kalypso war anscheinend der Meinung, dass das Aussehen der Stadt und das stÃ¤dtische gewusel unwichtig sei. StraÃŸenbahnen fahren einfach nur im Kreis ohne einmal anzuhalten, Die StraÃŸen sind so gut wie leer. Wenig Autos die dann auch noch wiederholend die selbe Strecke abfahren. Das Gleiche gilt auch fÃ¼r die Passanten. Einfach nur lieblos gestaltet.


[h1][b]Grafik[/b][/h1]

Und hier sind wir an einem Punkt angelangt, an dem sich Kalypso schÃ¤men sollte ein Spiel auf den Markt zu bringen mit einer Grafik vergleichbar mit Spielen aus den Jahren 2003 bis 2006. Die Grafik ist so grottenschlecht, dass man das GefÃ¼hl hat, dass selbst der Spieleentwickler "Astragon" Games mit besserer Grafik auf den Markt bringt und das Handwerk besser versteht als Kalypso. Ich hoffe hier wird nochmal einiges Nachgebessert. Ich Spiele in Ultrahoher AuflÃ¶sung auf einem 4K Monitor und findes es einfach nur schlecht. Es gibt nichts schlimmeres als wenn man heute noch bei einem Game die wiederholende Terrainstruktur sieht. 

Siehe hier:

[URL=http://www.bilder-upload.eu/show.php?file=ff4f6f-1485022287.jpg][IMG]http://www.bilder-upload.eu/thumb/ff4f6f-1485022287.jpg[/IMG][/URL]

Das einzige was ich hier positiv bewerten kann, ist das Wasser und der Ãœbergang zu Festland. Auf dem Wasser kann man keinerlei Struktur erkennen und es sieht sehr gut aus.
Ich hÃ¤Ã¤te hier einfach nur erwartet, dass die Grafikdesigner Objekte liebevoller und mit mehr Detail versehen gestaltet hÃ¤tten. Eine Grafik wie im Spiel "Cities Skyline" wÃ¤re hier nahezu perfekt gewesen. Auch der Ratssaal ist nicht wirklich der Hit. Einige Politiker, welche hinten sitzen, sind anscheinend Hobby-SolariumgÃ¤nger und fÃ¼r je eine Stunde Sonnenbank am Tag. Auch scheint hier alles so unscharf zu wirken.


[h1][b]Sound[/b][/h1]

Ja geht soweit.
Das einzige was ich hier wieder nicht so schÃ¶n finde ist, dass ich gerne im Ratssaal gehÃ¶rt hÃ¤tte, wenn Politiker mich ausbuhen oder Jubeln. Die Gestiken machen sie ja...aber naja. Wirkt auch hier nicht ganz fertig.


[h1][b]Bugs / StabilitÃ¤t[/b][/h1]

Erstaunlicherweise muss ich sagen, dass ich bis jetzt nicht wirklich Bugs gefunden habe. Auch AufhÃ¤nger/AbstÃ¼rze gab es bei mir in 13 Stunden Spielzeit keine. Einzig eine Sache muss ich bemÃ¤ngeln. Wenn ich eine Partei davon Ã¼berzeugen mÃ¶chte fÃ¼r mein Vorhaben zu Stimmen dann klicke ich ja zum Beispiel auf "fordern". Wenn ich aber dann Ã¼berlege Ihnen vielleicht doch nur eine Bitte rÃ¼berzubringen oder ihnen villeicht zu drohen, dann habe ich pech. Einmal auf einen Button geklickt gibt es kein ZurÃ¼ck mehr. Ich muss etwas AuswÃ¤hlen um da wieder raus zu kommen. Warum das so ist, erklÃ¤rt sich mir nicht so ganz.


[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]

Hier kann ich nichts schlechtes verlieren. Die MenÃ¼s sind meiner Meinung nach Ã¼bersichtlich und nach dem spielen der EinfÃ¼hrung auch selbsterklÃ¤rend. Man findet sich sehr gut zurecht. Hier brauch ich nicht mehr zu sagen. Das wurde fÃ¼r dieses Spiel super umgesetzt.


[h1][b]Fazit[/b][/h1]

Kalypso bringt hier nicht wie angekÃ¼ndigt ein Spiel mit frischer und neuartiger Spielidee auf den Markt.
Jedoch kann man nicht sagen, dass dieses Spiel keinen SpaÃŸ machen wÃ¼rde. Denn das tut es sogar.
Das Aussehen der Stadt wirkt langweilig und fad. Man hat das GefÃ¼hl die Stadt sei Tot und fast ausgestorben.
Mit der Grafik haben sich die Macher hier keine Lorbeeren verdient. Ganz im Gegenteil. Die Grafik erinnert an Titel von vor Ã¼ber 10 Jahren. Mit AbstÃ¼rzen hatte ich keine Probleme und auch Bugs waren so gut wie keine vorhanden. HierfÃ¼r
ein groÃŸes Lob.

Ob ihr das Spiel nun kaufen solltet?

Puh das ist schwer zu sagen! An Eurer Stelle wÃ¼rde ich noch warten bis ich hier melde, dass sich die Grafik durch einen Grafikpatch verbessert hat. FÃ¼r diesen Entwicklungsstand des Spiels, ist es einfach zu teuer und der Kauf lohnt sich auch nicht.

Ich hoffe ich konnte Euch einen kleinen Einblick verschaffen.

This wasn't really what I expected. I don't blame the game for that at all. I wanted a more intricate mechanic based around complex relationships with the city council and citizens that reflectedin votes and decisions. This game isn't that and again that's not the game's fault. 

The concepts in the game are amazing and will probably carry the game for awhile, but after I played for a few hours I wasn't having any fun and didn't feel connected to anything in the game.

The economy was probably the biggest turnoff for me as it is spiradic at best. It appears that the only viable way to offset costs is to constantly raise taxes. I've been a part of city government for many years and it simply doesn't work this way. Several things, including state and federal funding, for infrastructure and services have been left out. The early eras are understandable in this regard however. Though adding sewage to my districts shouldn't cost me 50k per month for 2,000 people. Wtf are they eating that requires that kind of cost for sewage?!

All in all I'm sure this will be an awesome game for alot of people, but it just wasn't there for me. I wish there was a "meh" recommendation on Steam. Maybe Paradox will take a stab at something in this ballpark eventually. Ended up refunding.

Primeras impresiones: De momento son buenas, aunque tambiÃ©n comento que me esperaba otro tipo de juego, sabiendo que el concepto en sÃ­ estÃ¡ genial. Sin embargo, por el momento lo recomiendo a sabiendas que:
- Debes tener un nivel alto de inglÃ©s (hay vocabulario de un nivel C1), o al menos, tenor un traductor cerca para ir comprendiendo la dinÃ¡mica de juego. No estÃ¡ disponible en espaÃ±ol.
- Se trata de un simulador de polÃ­tica, con algunos incredientes de citybuilder. 
- Debes tomarte tu tiempo dentro de un juego al mÃ¡s puro sistema de estrategia.

De quÃ© va: en sÃ­ se trata de escoger una familia, la cual tienes sus caracterÃ­sticas y tendencias polÃ­ticas y/o visiones sobre la vida en general. Dicha familia debe mantenerse en el poder de la alcaldÃ­a o la jefatura de gobierno, intentando mantener el favor (o no) del Cosejo de la Ciudad o una cÃ¡mara de respresentantes votados por los ciudadanos, sabiendo que:
- No tienes decisiÃ³n sobre cÃ³mo configurar las distintas calles (como los clÃ¡sico citybuilders) pero sÃ­ sobre quÃ© tipo de zona debe regir cada distrito que tÃº vas creando (o te dejan crear). 
- Puedes ir seleccionando las distintas tecnologÃ­as que se van investigando y que derivan en mejoras para tu ciudad a nivel de infraestructura y de legislaciÃ³n.
- Tienes decisiÃ³n relativa sobre cÃ³mo gestionar el presupuesto (y digo lo de relativa porque el Consejo de la Ciudad tambiÃ©n estarÃ¡ a favor o no, de subidas de impuestos, pej. etc...)

Eso sÃ­, el precio de salida lo veo un poco caro para lo que se desarrolla en sÃ­. Personalmente me esperarÃ­a a una buena oferta.

So, I know that this isn't a city builder but a city ruler blablabla. However, the gameplay is incredibly shallow in most aspects. The concept is amazing and I think the devs wasted some potential with this game. The main issues I have with the game are, as I said, shallow city sim related gameplay you might be used to get from other games - which in itself wouldn't be a major deal if other aspects of the game would be more interesting. However, there is no real roleplaying aspect other than the occasional trait points you get (or lose), flavour text for characters and houses.

Then there is the "political" side of the game, which is pretty disappointing. You basically have a bunch of political parties that shift in power. Wanna pass a law and parties that support it are in the minority? No problem, just tell the leader of an opposing party that you'll ruin his career or straight out threaten to murder him and there you go, vote passed. Zone out a disctrict or build a police station? Threaten people. Increase taxes, funding for something, strenghten LGBT rights from horrible to kinda horrible or get fucking elected? DO THE EXACT SAME FUCKING THING! Why is there no campaigning for elections? No political intrigues, managing your own party or whatever else politics could have been implemented in this game?

A price tag of ~20 bucks would be acceptable for this game. I'd say factoring in the current price of â‚¬45 for me, I'd give it a 4/10. Disregarding price, a 6/10.

column8:
The game is kind of fun, but gets old really quickly. You burn goodwill to get votes. The only time its difficult is a change to the taxing. Other than that I don't have to do anything, and the vote simply goes through. The political system, the main selling point of this game, is super simplistic. It's cool for the first three hours, after that it gets boring fast. 

I kept trying to like this game, I really did. I just couldn't.

Also, there are some typos and some placeholders in text left over, like when you get re-elected it says "You are the mayor of [city]. Congrats!" (or something to that effect). Thats right, instead of having your city's name, it says "[city]"

Hoping some new content gets released, cause I'm kinda stuck with this now.

column8:
neubewertung vom 08.04.2017:

die bewertung fÃ¼r dieses spiel wurde nun auf negativ geÃ¤ndert, da bis jetzt keine besserungen eingetreten sind und keinerlei inhalt nachgeliefert wurde. ausser einem kleinen hotfix ist seit dem erscheinungstermin nichts geschehen. das ist mir eindeutig zu wenig.
eine kalypso-vorbestellung kommt fÃ¼r mich zukÃ¼nftig nicht mehr in frage, damit hat sich der publisher selbst ins knie geschossen.

hier nun die original erstbewertung vom 21.01.2017:

meine bewertung fÃ¤llt positiv aus, da ich grundsÃ¤tzlich fÃ¼r derartige spiele und simulationen zu haben bin. auÃŸerdem habe ich fÃ¼r diesen titel nur knappe â‚¬ 22,- bezahlt. das mÃ¶chte ich vorab erwÃ¤hnt haben.

zum ablauf:

wer urban empire nur aus ankÃ¼ndigungen und werbungen kennt, kÃ¶nnte im spiel tatsÃ¤chlich rasch enttÃ¤uscht werden. die absolute freiheit und das politische kalkÃ¼l sind vielmehr vorgegaukelt, als fester bestandteil. dass es reiner zufall ist, wie sich der stadtrat bei abstimmungen verhÃ¤lt, merkt man relativ schnell. logik, politische interessen und absichten haben mit den entscheidungen so gut wie gar nichts zu tun. ein beispiel: startet man eine neue kampagne kann die mehrheit des stadtrats fÃ¼r die erste abstimmung ein JA geben. startet man nochmal neu, kommt dieselbe abstimmung und, warum auch immer, der rat stimmt Ã¼berwiegend mit NEIN. warum, lÃ¤sst das spiel hierbei vÃ¶llig offen. vermutlich, weil es keine fundierten meinungen und grÃ¼nde dafÃ¼r oder dagegen gibt, sondern das spiel auf zufall basiert. 
mehrere spielstarts bringen mich gleich zu einem meiner grÃ¶ÃŸten kritikpunkte. egal, wie oft man von vorne beginnt, der verlauf bleibt an sich stets komplett gleich. damit meine ich, dass ja im lauf der zeit geschehnisse eintreten, sowohl global und lokal, als auch persÃ¶nlich. all diese ereignisse passieren auch immer wieder in exakt der gleichen reihenfolge und in der selben zeitfolge. nach dem dritten spielstart bist du nicht mehr Ã¼berrascht, dass deine frau nach der geburt verstirbt. der ganze handlungsstrang ist jedesmal exakt der selbe. diese tatsache kostet wahrscheinlich die meisten punkte, was wiederspielwert oder langzeitmotivation betrifft. ich finde das wirklich stÃ¶rend, da es schnell langweilt, wenn man nach einem vÃ¶llig neuem spielstart schon im vorhinein weiÃŸ, welche ereignisse zu welchem zeitpunkt eintreten werden. es gibt dann keinerlei situation mehr, die einem Ã¼berraschen oder vor ein problem stellen kÃ¶nnte. hat man genug wohlwollen gesammelt (was wirklich nicht schwer ist), dann bekommt man eigentlich so gut wie jeden antrag im stadtrat durch, das wird nur fÃ¼r die wenigsten ein problem sein, die solche spiele bevorzugen. beim ersten spielen, ein WOW!, beim zweiten durchgang ein HAHA-JETZT-HAB-ICHS-SCHLAUER-GEMACHT!, beim dritten ein JA-ICH-WEISS-SCHON-WIEDER-DASSELBE! hat mans also einmal durch, dann wird dich bei nem erneuten start nichts neues mehr Ã¼berraschen, geschweigedem fordern. gefordert ist man ohnedies schon recht wenig, was die werbung eher nicht vermuten lies. natÃ¼rlich gibt es zeitweise jede menge klickorgien, doch bei micromanagement lassen sich solche mechaniken nur schwer vermeiden, wie sollte man es sonst lÃ¶sen? hier und da wÃ¤re feinschliff notwendig, doch im groÃŸen und ganzen ist es schon einigermaÃŸen ok. nur leider auch immer dasselbe, darum wird auch das recht bald langweilig. seine kreativitÃ¤t kann man einzig und allein beim erstellen eines neuen bezirks entfalten, wenn auch nur in Ã¤uÃŸerst geringem maÃŸe. man kann die grÃ¶ÃŸe, die dichte, die form, den namen und die besiedlung festlegen, punkt.

allgemein tut sich im thema wirtschaft auch nicht gerade viel. man ist hier eben kein manager eines unternehmens, dieses thema ist eher lau. grundsÃ¤tzlich forscht man mit wissenspunkten, die deine stadt je nach bildungsstatus gratis von selbst bereistellt und man hebt die steuern, um mehr einnahmen zu generieren. man muss die bedÃ¼rfnisse seiner einwohner befriedigen, was mit den altbekannten theater, polizei, klinik, bibliothek usw zu erledigen ist. diese kann man im entsprechenden bezirk frei platzieren. folgende bedÃ¼rfnisse sind zu erfÃ¼llen: sozialleben, sicherheit, stadtbild (schÃ¶nheit), gesundheitsversorgung, persÃ¶nliche karrierechancen, unterhaltung. mit einer reihe von gebÃ¤uden und der passenden infrastruktur (strom, licht, gas, abwasserkanÃ¤le) stellt das aber keinerlei problem dar. 

zur technik:

auf meiner midrange-maschine spielt es sich in den hÃ¶chsten einstellungen problemlos, es lÃ¤uft flÃ¼ssig, auch wenn sich mein pc zeitweise ein wenig anstrengen muss. trotzdem alles in butter, das funktionert bei mir sehr gut.

bugs:

klar, dass man erstmal in einer art tutorial das spiel und seine mechaniken kennenlernen muss. zum derzeitigen stand rate ich aber jedem, dass er unbedingt ein neues spiel OHNE tutorial und hilfe startet, sobald er richtig loslegen will. sollte das tutorial noch aktiv sein, kann es passieren (wie bei mir und vielen, vielen anderen kunden im forum), dass man seinen spielstand nicht mehr speichern kann. das ist natÃ¼rlich Ã¤uÃŸerst Ã¤rgerlich, wenn man schon 2 stunden in seine schÃ¶ne stadt investiert hat und dann alles futsch ist. ebenso passiert es (auch mir), dass einzelne bezirke einfach nicht mehr anwÃ¤hlbar sind. das bedeutet, mann kann diese in keiner form mehr verÃ¤ndern, modernisieren oder ausbauen. dumm, wenn der noch aus dem 19. jahrhundert stammt und man schon in der moderne angekommen ist. die einen mÃ¶gen gaslaternen nostalgisch oder romatisch finden, doch handel, bewohner und industrie deiner stadt sehen das ganz anders. sie fÃ¼hlen sich unterversorgt und der bezirk wird eine finanzielle und stadtÃ¶konomische dauerbelastung sein.
weitere bugs soll es geben, traten bei mir allerdings nicht auf, ich kann dazu nichts berichten und nur an das forum verweisen.

warum eine positive beurteilung? weil ich sie nach dem 4. start verfasse und es mir noch nicht wirklich zum hals raushÃ¤ngt. es macht mir schon noch spaÃŸ, ich mag solche spiele eben gern. ebenfalls zu erwÃ¤hnen ist, dass ich nur den halben preis (instant gaming, vorbestellung) bezahlt habe und daher ein wenig milder in meiner beurteilung bin. den vollpreis finde ich zum derzeitigen stand des spiels doch eher frech und unangemessen hoch. sooooo viel inhalt und abwechslung ist es dann bestimmt nicht, da ja die story eigentlich stets die selbe ist (egal welche familie man zum start wÃ¤hlt) und die ereignisse sowieso.
allerdings, der erscheinungstermin war gestern und heute kam schon ne mitteilung der entwickler "Known issues and workarounds in Urban Empire version 1.1.1". wenn man also davon ausgeht, dass die entwickler ernsthaft dranbleiben, dann kann man auch bedingt hoffen, dass das unausgeschÃ¶pfte potential dieses spiel vielleicht auch noch genutzt wird. davon hat es nÃ¤mlich durchaus eine ganze menge. es bleibt abzuwarten...

meine empfehlung richtet sich an jene, die ebenfalls eine leidenschaft fÃ¼r dieses genre pflegen und auch so viel geduld haben, um es im sale fÃ¼r die hÃ¤lfte zu kaufen. den vollpreis zu bezahlen, rate ich niemanden, man bekommt dafÃ¼r einfach zu wenig. 
trotz allem ein ganz pfiffiges spiel, das in der vierten runde noch spaÃŸ bringt, hÃ¼bsch aussieht und eine weile beschÃ¤ftigt. nach 2x komplett durchspielen wird es dann vermutlich eher in der bibliothek verstauben, sollte es nicht bald mehr inhalte und optionen nachgeliefert bekommen. 

was mich Ã¼berrascht hat: es funktioniert ganz ohne kalypso-launcher und registrierung!  :-O

FAZIT:

fÃ¼r genrefans eine empfehlung, die verbindlich an einen niedrigeren preis geknÃ¼pft ist. bis zu â‚¬25,- kann man meiner meinung nach dafÃ¼r schon ausgeben.

$40 is too much for this game. I did get it while it was on sale. There is a little bit of replayability due to the different families, which cause different events. This game does not have much to offer. It is a liitle bit fun, but only for so long. If you can get this game for more than half off, then I would say do that. Otherwise, this game is quite repeditive and lacking overall content. Small game, small gameplay, much potential wasted.

column8: I have been fairly excited about this game coming out and I really wanted it to be good.  My instinct was that the current price of $40 was too high.  Unfortunately, this seems to be true. Hard to tell you exactly what's wrong, maybe the votes for even relatively minor district changes, or the lack of information and random impact of your decisions for chance events.  It's not bad and delivers some initial amusement and the concept is cool.  There is something just not quite right.  Came with only one scenerio and 3 campaign maps, but you can see that the expect to have some DLC to sale soon.   I think this is one that you should wait and pick up on sale or when you can't get all the DLC as a package.

column8:
A Refrishing Swim in a Shallow Pond

Pros:
+ Very few titles in the genre
+ What it does, mayoral simulator, it does well
+ Peaceful, layed back gameplay
+ Runs well and looks as good as it needs to be

Cons:
- Not a lot going on, there are times where you're just waiting for the time to tick by.
- The game's politics definitely tend to lean one way moreso than the other
- Difficult to tell what choices makes what changes

Neutral:
o Shallow gameplay. You make choices and hope you have enough clout to sway votes to your side. That's pretty much it in a nutshell.
o There definitely seems to be an optimal way to go about advancing your city and districts.

It's a difficult genre to make a game for as the demand is quite low. Personally I love these types of games and there are very few additions every year that are worth checking out. The problem here is that to appeal to a wider audience they tap into city building and planning elements that are just too shallow for those looking for a city builder. If you know what you're getting into before buying, it should scatch that proverbial mayoral itch.

Disappointing, the politicking is ostensibly designed to provide some challenge but all the purpose it seems to serve is to slow you down (since you can only have one vote up at a time for rezoning/doing new districts/etc), but it doesn't. If you have money your votes will pretty much always pass. If your budget is messed up you can always pass a tax increase, most of the decisions presented to you are meaningless, and traffic, probably the biggest issue in almost any city builder is just not a concern because you don't lay your own roads. Votes are extremely predictable because even with the thinnest of margins visible the neutrals will pretty much always split 50/50.

Might be a little fun but definitely not worth it in its current state. Knowing Kalypso the game will probably never be an actual challenge so I wouldn't hold out if you're looking for that.

column8: Alot of us was expecting more from this game, yet it isn't what most of us thought. While we're unable to get a refund due to the time we have played in game. For those who are interested in this game please read up on the reviews and disscussion boards, before buying I think this will be a 50-50 review game. Now that I'm pass 20hrs, I hope my neg review counts.... It would be a good game if the lag issues was addressed, and the confusing game play when it comes to economical play in this game. I.E I was in the 50s and no hydro, still dirt roads, one grammer school ect. due to placing one item you end up in the Neg. A dev only asking for our system specs, not addressing any of the issues, but hey check this link which has 0 information.

column9:
I know this game must be attracting a lot of attention from those who enjoy city builders like Tropico, SimCity, etc. But be careful: THIS IS NOT A CITY BUILDER!!!

The only thing you have greater freedom to build are the districts, which are automatically populated by the zoning already created. Any changes, such as building schools, clinics, etc., require a vote and convincing groups of people from different political sides (conservatives, those seeking innovation, etc.) to approve your constructions.

Aside from the difficult mechanics, another thing I didn't really like was the number of variables you "have to analyze." It takes a long time to access the buildings (because you have to research them to gain access and then go through the voting process, and if approved, your construction will be in the city), which changes a lot of the variables.

Not the game they describe. This is not a Mayoral sim; it is a very shallow city builder with a political menu thrown in. Yes you can change taxes, edicts, which party is the most of in power, etc. However the only way to do this is through goodwill, no bribes, no actual threats, no assasinations, no political kidnapping (which was still very common in the 1800's), very poor blackmail system, etc. Everything's just horribly over simplified on the surface. You dig deeper and you find out the goodwill system is the absolute CORE of your political career. So an Imperial aggressive play style lands you in hot water fast. Imperials  want the same laws (such as freaking labor unions?!?!?!?!?) as the populists. Why? Because it gives a bonus to the people of the city if you pass it. How about workers safety? Sounds expensive to implement FDA and OSHA regulations right? Nope, implementing it increases sales. What the ever living ****! I mean I'd get more workers would want to work but higher safety should makes your profits go down not up. These devs  put absolutely no effort into a "Real" political system. Then you come into the horrible part, not only is the political system simple, it's also geared to the NPC. Let me explain, let's say an Imperial opposes bills that are trying to be passed by a Populist. You will lose council members (consistent votes) to that party because the people of the city prefer the party that benefits them most. So I allowed them to take power while using large amounts of good will to control their votes and the votes of the other parties. I ended up 6 districts in producing a very consistent 40-60k a month at 13/13 taxes. Then the Populists decide let's tax the people less (6%) and commercial and industrial businesses more (17%). 4 districts went bankrupt within 1.5 years, as I was completely unable to do anything in the council because I had almost no party members and no support. I'll also add that I was playing the way the campaign TELLS you to play. Whether they intentionally run you into the ground or not I'm not sure. Can't afford lights and roads or any institutions as there's a constant fluctuation in income such as making 170k a year then going -31k from everything going bankrupt with no explanation what from.


All I can say is this game failed, and it failed hard. The entire system feels unbalanced, unpolished, unrewarding, and just simply put, not fun at all. Run, run far away. Go spend $5 on The Guild 2: Renaissance and you'll see a simple political system that still has bugs and troubles yet still vastly out performs Urban Empire. This is in no way worth $40, maybe $15 if they fixed...well everything.. But be prepared to wait 2 years.

column8: Don't go into it thinking this is a city builder - it has city builder elements but it leans towards being a "city hall politics simulator", and that makes it a pretty unique and enjoyable game.

column9:
After a day of playing, I've been struggling with the financial deficit.

For me, graphical optimization isn't a problem with this game, after all, I've been playing Paradox's legacy Clausius engine for years.

But my biggest pet peeve is the economic system. Basically, every time you enter the next era, the demands suddenly jump (why can't they be unlocked with technology?)

The result is that I have to build more infrastructure to improve things, but even after planning a new area, I still need infrastructure, and it takes a long time to gradually generate profits. This time is basically idle. Once a deficit appears, it often gets bigger, even if my new area's income continues to increase (I don't know why).

However, the only solutions you can use are raising taxes and reducing some infrastructure investment, but excessively high taxes will lead to widespread bankruptcy, and reducing infrastructure income is a drop in the bucket and will not even meet demand. I also have no idea what the global market for this game is like. Are the economic trends revealed solely through newspapers? I spend most of the game staring at the deficit. Facilities are too expensive, and making money is too difficult. I played through the game once in a day, and many purely residential areas still don't have electricity. Another issue is that this incident is a bit repetitive. My parliament has been holding up the water pollution bill for a while now, and I've seen it voted on at least 40 times, even with only a few votes in between.

The idea of â€‹â€‹the parliament is good, but the results are pretty average to me. Basically, those with good connections beg for mercy, while those with bad connections use gossip to threaten them. Later, they find gossip about the opposing party and spread it, and then they lose their seat in parliament.

I hope they can improve this in the future.

column8:
The idea of this game intrigues me but it Kalypso did not QA it enough as there are many little annoying bugs that make it unplayable as they have already acknowledged, the bane of my experience being the spinning camera glitch. Even with the developers suggested work around it just pauses for a second and then continues spinning, makes me feel sicker than my Oculus Rift does... 

It is not worth a purchase until these issues have been fixed, but the game interests me enough that I won't refund it and will instead just wait for it to get fixed.

If you think you might enjoy this game come back in a few days or weeks and check in then to see if it has improved.

column9:
Chinese subtitles and Chinese voice acting are great [spoiler] The lack of Chinese in the voice acting doesn't really matter to me [/spoiler]

Compared to other city-building games, City Empires adds party support, which has both advantages and disadvantages. More on that below.
I started playing this morning and achieved a time victory (securing the mayoral seat) in under six hours. There's no in-game guide to victory methods; see the achievements for details. After victory, you can choose to continue managing the city. I'm not sure if you can achieve multiple victories simultaneously.

At the beginning of the game, you have four families to choose from. Behind the person at the front are his descendants, and one family changes every era.

I feel like the most important thing in the game is money. It seems that whether or not each party supports your construction depends solely on your wealth, and making money is the most difficult part of the game.

But it doesn't matter. I almost went bankrupt at the beginning, but then I wrote a letter to the emperor and exchanged a lot of reputation for money.

To summarize the money issue:
[h1]The most practical method[/h1] If you're out of money, raise the tax rate. Don't ask why, and don't try to be cunning.

Raise the tax rate as high as possible, no matter who raises it (if it's too high, one party will propose an opposing bill, so you can lower it slightly later).

When raising the tax rate, try to maintain support from two parties and no opposition from any party; this way, the bill will definitely pass. I'm always short of money, so most parties support it.

Long-term high taxes may reduce demand for buildings (pure speculation, I haven't dared to verify it).

If basic buildings can be avoided, don't build them; their maintenance costs are getting higher and higher. [spoiler] I connected to the power grid and immediately regretted it. We've been in deficit for several years straight.[/spoiler]

Infrastructure buildings can be upgraded, but upgrades don't increase maintenance costs.

Don't think about saving money; if you lose money, you can earn it back. If you save money, it's gone in an instant!

Personal funds can be used to skip votes and build directly. Appropriations can be used to increase the amount of [strike] corruption.

Administrative districts can be as large as you want. Maintenance costs are high, but the area is large.

Now, let's talk about parties.

Parties influence all decisions, including elections, construction, legislation, and tax adjustments. The more support you have, the easier it is to pass votes.

There are five eras in the game, and each era sees parties eliminated and new ones joining. There are only a few parties at the beginning, but later there are seven or eight.

Every month, you can communicate with each party (through pleading, demands, and threats) during voting. Each communication will increase your support points by a few points but decrease your favorability, so try to maintain good relations with all parties. I have a good relationship with almost all parties, except Christianity, which is 0. I don't know why.

Party favorability has nothing to do with a party's voting stance. Even if your relationship with them is 10, you'll still oppose them if you should.

I remember being able to monitor a party, supposedly to find flaws and canvass for votes, but after I clicked on the monitor option, I never bothered to do anything.

Parties are so annoying; I'm always clicking.

Finally, a few small questions.

What's the point of the Satisfaction and Security columns? They went negative as soon as I entered the new era, and I haven't noticed any impact for months.

You can always upgrade buildings in the game, even after they're maxed out, which makes it seem like there's more to upgrade.

Fundamentals... every time I spend... It costs 10,000 yuan (10,000 yuan) of personal funds. Clicking on a green circle close to a yellow circle has no effect, but clicking again still deducts money. Many instant voting bills have no effect, and the content is not displayed. Emails can't be moved on the map while building a building. I can't figure out where they go when I right-click and drag. There are opposing parties in the instant vote, but everyone agrees at the start of the vote.

My personal opinion: It's a bit simple. I feel like I won in the middle of the game.

Summary: The game doesn't have road construction, only individual buildings that you need to place on a grid. City design enthusiasts should proceed with caution. The price seems a bit high, and I hope they'll update more. I don't understand why there are so many mixed reviews. I've seen all the good reviews.

If you see this, buy it!

Urban Empire is a city-building political strategy game.   This is not your typical city builder.  The main difference between Urban Empire and more traditional city builders is that most everything is put to a vote, so politics and relationships with parties matter. Districts are placed with zoning layouts, services, and infrastructure support. The city council must approve new districts through a vote.  They also will vote on tax rate changes, modifications to existing districts, edicts, and service funding levels. 

You take control of a mayoral family dynasty and you are required to lead your city and people through 200 years of history (5 eras).  A large variety of events will make each game slightly different. 

Regarding gameplay, you have to establish infrastructure, plan city districts, debate political decisions at the town council, bribe or blackmail your opponents, empower the democratic rights of your people or ignore them and reign unilaterally. 

A research tree contains inventions that unlock new services and edicts. Citizens have needs, such as social life, environment, health, and fun. 

In Urban Empire, you are not only facing problem after problem on how to develop your city, but also how to rule and manage it. Thereâ€™s big political game behind running of the city, you have to solve the problem and plan what you going to do to run the city effectively through the city council.

However, for my taste, the game is too dry.   Determine citizen needs and figure out how to pass it though the city's political power brokers.   I would have liked to interface more with the city, its citizens, and the leaders of the political parties.


It's a BIg Chewy - 6.5/10

A research tree contains inventions that unlock new services and edicts. Citizens have needs, such as social life, environment, health, and fun. 

In Urban Empire, you are not only facing problem after problem on how to develop your city, but also how to rule and manage it. Thereâ€™s big political game behind running of the city, you have to solve the problem and plan what you going to do to run the city effectively through the city council.

However, for my taste, the game is too dry.   Determine citizen needs and figure out how to pass it though the city's political power brokers.   I would have liked to interface more with the city, its citizens, and the leaders of the political parties.

column9: Tragically, my 4G Sophie 4 can't run this game. Let me talk about the game. Time is limited, so I just played it preliminarily. I will add to the rest later. First of all, give it a good review!

totorial is absolutly painful and should be removed alltogether, decisions are unrelistic and all have positive effects ignoring the negatives, lots of the wording is confusiong or inverted, and game gets very stale after a while as there is no real challenges and like i stated before the decisions have no trade offs

column8: Did expect more from the game. It looks nice but the Simulation of politics is very basic and repeat every time. A little bit of a story there but unfortunately there is no real depth in the game. I tried to get a refund after 3,5 hrs of gaming but steam won't let me as there a lot's of graphic issues after a certain amount of time. Sorry Kalypso and sorry Steam. Kalypso can do better, remember Tropico. It is not worth the money, maybe 15GBP. Now I have a game which is buggy, and makes no fun at all and diid not meet my expectations. Great idea Kalypso to try this Genre but you need to put more efford in.

column9:
My personal review and tips for this game

Review: This game is completely different from typical construction and management simulations. Other games focus on choices rather than conditions, and the sense of accomplishment gained by achieving your goals is palpable. This game truly is a political simulation. It really brings home the concept of "City Ruler." This game is about leading, not leading. Like national politics, there's a give-and-take aspect to it.

Tips: 1. Don't bankrupt the government.
Even if you want to focus on the joy of technological advancement and progress, politicians are driven by budgets.
Like Cities: Skylines, even if you want to implement the Four Major Rivers Project and build floating islands like Sebitseom in the rivers,
without money, lawmakers will dismiss any proposals as nonsense.

2. Don't always try to win by a landslide.
If your argument is too strong, the opposition will become even more vocal. Ambiguous stances are also acceptable.
Winning by a 0.5 vote margin is optimal. They'll be more generous with your favors and won't provoke a major backlash from the opposition.

3. Rights are more effective than most buildings.
Bills and unlocked rights are effective, but trying to force their passage will only fuel opposition. If you have no allies in Congress, the game is literally a lost cause. If the majority party supports your bill and opposes it, it's okay to follow their lead. However, never try to manipulate the opposition. If your desired outcome is not met and the bill is rejected, slowly build up favor on political issues and try again. Give and receive.

column9:
Overall, it has a few flaws, but it's incredibly well-made and enjoyable. I hope to see more updates.

I've finished two rounds now. To sum it up, I think many players who've been playing for a while are thinking: Senate, fuck you!

This parliament in this game is a bunch of idiots! It fully demonstrates the sheer idiocy of Western democracy. Even if you're a Japanese-American, you'll probably curse out loud after playing this and start to question the sheer stupidity of humanity. Trust me, this game can be frustrating, but it feels real. Really real, because there's no shortage of hypocritical people like those in the game in the world! Seriously, trust me!

Obwohl meine CPU weit unter den Mindestanforderungen liegt, lÃ¤uft das Spiel bei mir einwandfrei und danke meiner relativ guten Grafikkarte auch bei drei Bezirken auf mittlerer Detailstufe absolut flÃ¼ssig. Ãœber diverse Bugmeldungen wundere ich mich, denn diese sind bei mir zum GlÃ¼ck noch nicht aufgetaucht. Weder fehlende Button, noch falsche Texte oder Ã¤hnliches konnte ich entdecken (Ok, einmal stand dort "City" anstatt mein Stadtname .. geschenkt). Auch AbstÃ¼rze hatte ich nach fast 10 Stunden Spielzeit noch keine. Der Inhalt ist genau mein Geschmack und ich habe Jahre auf so etwas gewartet. Ok, die ersten drei StÃ¤dte habe ich gleich in den Sand gesetzt, weil ich einfach zu schnell zu viel wollte. Dieses Spiel ist nicht fÃ¼r Gelegenheitsspieler, da man sich krÃ¤ftig in die Materie einarbeiten muss und viele anfangs unbekannte Verbindungen erst entdecken und verstehen muss. Der eine oder andere Tooltip wÃ¤re mÃ¶glicherweise hilfreich, aber die meisten Dinge kann man auch durch ein bischen Hirnschmalz verstehen. Einziger Kritikpunkt meinerseits sind die etwas zu kleinen Infofenster. Obwohl genÃ¼gend Platz vorhanden wÃ¤re, wurden lieber Texte abgekÃ¼rzt. Nicht gut fÃ¼r die Ãœbersicht, aber zu verschmerzen. Alles in Allem habe ich seit gestern Abend schon sehr viel SpaÃŸ mit dem Spiel gehabt, dass vom Inhalt sicherlich nicht (historisch) perfekt ist, aber noch sehr viel Potenzial fÃ¼r Erweiterungen besitzt. Wenn man sich erst einmal eingearbeitet hat und dieses Spiel nicht als einen weiteren "Sim-City-Abklatsch" erwartet (denn das ist und soll es gar nicht sein), dann ist man bei Urban Empire genau richtig.

column9:
The economic system is a mess. I was making 150k profit in the first three eras, but it went straight down to negative territory in the fourth.

I can't understand the political system. I'm doing everything right, and my city is making 100k profit, so why does everyone want to impeach me? All the demands are positive, and every district is full of happy faces. Yet, only one or two parties in parliament support me.

Thumbs up to the development team for their innovation and equal treatment of Chinese players.

column8:
ĞœĞ½Ğµ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ½Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°ÑÑŒ! Ğ–Ğ´Ğ°Ğ» Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¾, Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ñ€Ğ°Ğ±Ñ‹ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ²ĞµĞ»Ğ¸. 

Ğ Ğ² Ğ³Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ´ÑĞºĞ¾Ğ¼ ÑĞ¾Ğ²ĞµÑ‚Ğµ Ñ‚Ğµ ĞµÑ‰Ğµ Ğ¿.....Ñ€Ñ‹ ÑĞ¸Ğ´ÑÑ‚.

This game is a fun take on city management. You don't have to micromanage your city building, that pretty much happens by itself. Instead you need to convince the City Council to approve your plans for the city. You need to handle the various political parties, choose to compromise with them or support one of them and aim to help them win the majority of votes. The political simulation is interesting, and the whole game depends on how you handle it. However, there are weaknesses to this system (more on that later)

Also, newer buildings, laws/edicts and upgrades are unlocked through research and a tech tree. The tech tree seems a bit small I think. In 20 minutes gameplay I already went through 1/5th of the tech tree with only 2 schools built (schools generate research points among other things). Nonetheless, the way it's set up is interesting and has good potential for further development.

A big part of the game are events. If you play any Paradox grand strategy games you know what I mean by events. Occasionally something will happen that will require your attention. You will be presented with a problem and 3 solutions (on average). It both gives flavor to the game and allows for roleplaying. It also lends replayability, as depending on your choices you will probably end up going through a much different story each time. Events can serve to introduce new laws and edicts. Further, each technology will give you at least one event while it's being researched, related to it.

So far the game runs smoothly, no bugs or problems. It's a bit slow on loading screens, but that's not such a big deal.

My main issue is that I bought this game because it promises a deep political simulator, but I don't feel it delivers on that. On the surface everything seems interesting and good, but once you get into it, problems start appearing. As advertised, for everything you try to do in the city (new buildings, tax reform, laws/edicts, new districts, introducing gas and electricity etc) you will need the City Council's approval to actually do it. The problem is that political parties hardly exhibit any intelligence. The main factor for their decision making is if the proposed plan will take your city's budget to negative. There is no consideration for projected profit. There is very little adherence to ideologies presented in the political spectrum.

For example, the simplest problem: You need to increase your income. The best way to do it is to build new districts and increase taxes. Tax increases are suprisingly easy to pass but they are not enough alone to let you develop your city. At most you can support 2-3 buildings with a 10% increase in taxes. So you need to build new districts, but this projects a tremendous drain on your budget. With a school, a police station and an electrical grid, the running cost goes to -80K money. With 1 district already built, the best you can do is +20-30K income, for which you need to spend a lot of political power to get. Getting the Council to let you build a new district is nigh impossible and tedious. The only solution is to sit and watch your single district for some time, doing nothing, just so you can gain enough political capital to implement a change. And after that it's again spending a lot of time doing nothing.

There are 3 stances you can take with each party (Plead, Demand, Threaten). Each one will give you some options on what you can do. It seems what each choice does is random. There's little apparent consistency or reason with each choice. Furthermore, whatever you click in this interaction, there's no going back. You can't examine your options for example. If you click Threaten, that's what you'll do. No cancel or go back buttons implemented.

This wouldn't have been an issue if:

a) There were regular methods to regain political power (goodwill) with the various parties and councilmen, instead of waiting for them to tick up. (For example, certain proposals, laws and buildings should be favored by certain parties by default, especially if they cater to their values).

b) The parties actually had more detailed scripted behaviors and they took into consideration the gains each project would confer. (Almost everything is for the sake of money. My councilmembers apparently hate the idea of police stations, street lamps and hospitals because they aren't free).

c) There was a way to bundle proposals together. For example, build a new hospital and accompany it with a tax increase to overcome the budget issues.

My other issue with the game is that it doesn't have edge scrolling. Meaning you can't stick your mouse on the edge of the screen and expect the map to move. You need to click and drag with the right mouse button, or use WASD to move around. It's inconvenient and a weird design decision.

The game also seems to only offer 3 maps to play on, and I don't see any way to randomly generate maps or create a custom game with a custom family. You can only play campaign or narrow scenarios. The lack of customization is disappointing to say the least.

If and when these issues are fixed consider picking up this game. Without these problems I'd highly suggest it. It's otherwise a very fun game, with good atmosphere, well-done graphics, nice music, interesting mechanics and great potential. Until then, I suggest you wait a while and check back later.
column9:
This game is a fun take on city management. You don't have to micromanage your city building, that pretty much happens by itself. Instead you need to convince the City Council to approve your plans for the city. You need to handle the various political parties, choose to compromise with them or support one of them and aim to help them win the majority of votes. The political simulation is interesting, and the whole game depends on how you handle it. However, there are weaknesses to this system (more on that later)

Also, newer buildings, laws/edicts and upgrades are unlocked through research and a tech tree. The tech tree seems a bit small I think. In 20 minutes gameplay I already went through 1/5th of the tech tree with only 2 schools built (schools generate research points among other things). Nonetheless, the way it's set up is interesting and has good potential for further development.

A big part of the game are events. If you play any Paradox grand strategy games you know what I mean by events. Occasionally something will happen that will require your attention. You will be presented with a problem and 3 solutions (on average). It both gives flavor to the game and allows for roleplaying. It also lends replayability, as depending on your choices you will probably end up going through a much different story each time. Events can serve to introduce new laws and edicts. Further, each technology will give you at least one event while it's being researched, related to it.

So far the game runs smoothly, no bugs or problems. It's a bit slow on loading screens, but that's not such a big deal.

My main issue is that I bought this game because it promises a deep political simulator, but I don't feel it delivers on that. On the surface everything seems interesting and good, but once you get into it, problems start appearing. As advertised, for everything you try to do in the city (new buildings, tax reform, laws/edicts, new districts, introducing gas and electricity etc) you will need the City Council's approval to actually do it. The problem is that political parties hardly exhibit any intelligence. The main factor for their decision making is if the proposed plan will take your city's budget to negative. There is no consideration for projected profit. There is very little adherence to ideologies presented in the political spectrum.

For example, the simplest problem: You need to increase your income. The best way to do it is to build new districts and increase taxes. Tax increases are suprisingly easy to pass but they are not enough alone to let you develop your city. At most you can support 2-3 buildings with a 10% increase in taxes. So you need to build new districts, but this projects a tremendous drain on your budget. With a school, a police station and an electrical grid, the running cost goes to -80K money. With 1 district already built, the best you can do is +20-30K income, for which you need to spend a lot of political power to get. Getting the Council to let you build a new district is nigh impossible and tedious. The only solution is to sit and watch your single district for some time, doing nothing, just so you can gain enough political capital to implement a change. And after that it's again spending a lot of time doing nothing.

There are 3 stances you can take with each party (Plead, Demand, Threaten). Each one will give you some options on what you can do. It seems what each choice does is random. There's little apparent consistency or reason with each choice. Furthermore, whatever you click in this interaction, there's no going back. You can't examine your options for example. If you click Threaten, that's what you'll do. No cancel or go back buttons implemented.

This wouldn't have been an issue if:

a) There were regular methods to regain political power (goodwill) with the various parties and councilmen, instead of waiting for them to tick up. (For example, certain proposals, laws and buildings should be favored by certain parties by default, especially if they cater to their values).

b) The parties actually had more detailed scripted behaviors and they took into consideration the gains each project would confer. (Almost everything is for the sake of money. My councilmembers apparently hate the idea of police stations, street lamps and hospitals because they aren't free).

c) There was a way to bundle proposals together. For example, build a new hospital and accompany it with a tax increase to overcome the budget issues.

My other issue with the game is that it doesn't have edge scrolling. Meaning you can't stick your mouse on the edge of the screen and expect the map to move. You need to click and drag with the right mouse button, or use WASD to move around. It's inconvenient and a weird design decision.

The game also seems to only offer 3 maps to play on, and I don't see any way to randomly generate maps or create a custom game with a custom family. You can only play campaign or narrow scenarios. The lack of customization is disappointing to say the least.

If and when these issues are fixed consider picking up this game. Without these problems I'd highly suggest it. It's otherwise a very fun game, with good atmosphere, well-done graphics, nice music, interesting mechanics and great potential. Until then, I suggest you wait a while and check back later.

column8:
If you are looking to get this game hoping for a fun city-builder with intricate politics, you're mistaken. This is not what you're looking for at all. It is a "mayor simulator" but even then, it is not a fun one.

You essentially play as the mayor of an Austrian town. You get to choose between four families. After you choose your family and your starting era (you are locked to 1820 starting date from first playthrough) you then choose the map... there are THREE MAPS. THREE. That's it! There's next to no variation! Extremely dissapointing from a $44CDN title. Moving on.

You get into the game, and within an hour I noticed the absolute lack of content. The hyped up tech tree was very shallow, with maybe 15 techs at the final era. Services are very shallow, essentially you just plop them down and make people happy in a certain radius. City expansion/district placing is very shallow too. You draw a district (it has to be pretty square, too) then decide what percentage is industrial, commercial, or residential. Then, it goes to a vote which comes down to: if you have plenty of money, council votes unanimous yes. If you don't have that much, unanimous no. Then plop, the district is there if the vote passes, and within a minute it just fills up like that. Very underwhelming.

Which brings me to the voting system, the voting is very poorly done. The best way I can describe the political system in this game is if you took edicts and taxes from Cities: Skylines, made them a slight bit more mature, and throwing a shitty voting system in the way, which you have to jump around. Essentially, there are a bunch of council members, a few parties, and you gotta get them to vote your side by threatening (which costs political favours and ALWAYS succeeds in moving them to your side), demanding (which costs political favours and ALWAYS succeeds in moving them to your side), or pleading (which costs political favours and ALWAYS succeeds in moving them to your side). Then the vote passes, or it doesn't and you simply try again. It's a boring system and it's a shame for a game which is nearly entirely built around this bland system.

[b]TL;DR[/b]: Don't buy this game. It is shallow, and does a very poor job with the voting system which it markets so heavily. If you want a decent city-builder, buy Cities: Skylines instead, as this game is not a good city builder nor a good political simulator. It's the worst of both worlds.

Yes i know its not a city builder ,like SOOOO many have said , i know what the game is but boy this disapoints, You start as one ofa number of families all with (slightly) different traits ,WHICH DO PRETTY MUCH NOWT , and you start at 1800 , build your first district , ok so far so good ,thats fine ,shows you the council chambers and voting process , ok yep got it ,errrrr ....ummmmm....thats kind of it.

Yes you can issue a few edicts , the research trees are reasonably interesting ,but again gets boring FAST.

build couple more districts , change density to medium , all pass without any need to threaten parties and boom thats it .i have 39 million in the bank nd all the parties love me so i NEVER need to do anything with the voting , way overpirced for what you get (i smell massivley 10 pound dlc with  just one more family on its way).

Grammar and spelling in the game is truly dreadful , hundreds of typos (quality control anyone?)

music is tedious and boring after 2 minutes , now switched off for good.

only 3 maps to pick from yes i agree all slightly different in terms of difficulty of building a city but as you only need 3 districts set to medium density ,that plays totally no part in anything.

I really was waiting for this game , i wanted to enjoy it and for the first our i did , now i find myslef after 7 and half hours playtime just sitting there waiting for my research to finish and the next mayor election twiddling my thumbs .

Sorry but this is dreadful , another overpriced and overhyped full price release .I respect the work that goes into games i really do (same issue with planetcoaster ,rollercoaster tycoon 3 i played for well over 1000 hours , planet coaster 80 and bored as hell), and i respect that they developers need to make a profit  but jeez i should of known this would not be good.The current early reviews are all pretty much negative to.Do yourself a favour wait for a sale in a years time with all the millions of overpirced dlc on its way thrown in or just avoid altogether .Igave it the benefit of the doubt but when you find yourself falling asleep to a game ,the signs are not good


edit...Now 10 hours into it and as the shuskys family it does change a little bit in era 4 i wont spoil it incase people want to play it , but not enough to dramaticly change gameplay.Reviews still coming in on online sites and are pretty poor .Mixed is fair ,Needs a bit of a re think and some FREEEE UPDATES due to the massive price for a half standard game

column8:
Some people are saying the game is shallow, but the politics only feels easy early. 

The longer the game goes on, the more interests your trying to balance (including your own). And just because the parties will support you doesn't mean that decision is right. I buried my first campaign when my economy began to slide and all parties (regardless of their hate of taxes) supported raising them month over month to save the budget... Which of course led to bleeding my people and businesses dry. 

Every tax I raised led to LESS money in my coffers. 

You can't always trust the politicians, and you have to be intentional and sometimes fight the council with all you have for the good of the city.

This is exactly what I wanted to play.

column8:
Honestly, this is a reluctantly negative review. I like the idea, I like the devs and I for the most part like the game. But there are just too many little niggles.

A list of negative things I noticed, in no particular order,
- The camera movement is strange, it pivots on a point too far ahead of your view (for my liking anyway).
- The game lags badly as you get further into the game.
- The game becomes repetitive and the challenges remain the same as you play through.
-  [strike]There is little replay value as events always seem to have the same outcome. So it becomes a more about memorisation than judgement. [/strike]
       (I was wrong about this, it's not the case.)
- There is a lot of information, but presented in a way in which it's hard to keep a track of.
- There is little to no contextual information or feedback when you make decisions.
- The opposing political parties feel hollow, the game is about balancing numbers, but it shouldn't feel like it as you do it.
- And weirdly, the game hogs computer resources for some time after its shut down.

This isn't to say it's not worth considering, it's a marvellous idea. Much of it is well done, the graphics are pleasant, the game does well to make it feel like you are advancing through time, the economic system is both detailed and robust and the technology tree is particulary well designed.

I do like it, but if I made the choice again whether to buy it, I'd say no thanks.

-------------------------
Edit: More niggles
-------------------------

- There isn't any way to locate a specific industry, you can see if a district has it, but either hovering over a factory type in the list needs to highlight them, or else there at least needs to be some other way to find them, rather than just clicking on every building until you find it.
- In the scenarios there is little feedback to how well you are doing, for example, in the scenario where you have to build x amount of weapons to prepare for war, there is no easily accesible feedback on how many you have actually made or at what rate you are making them.
- Minor events show up in the corner of the screen on a timer, it's easy to miss them if you're not looking at the bottom corner of the screen at the time.
column9:
Honestly, this is a reluctantly negative review. I like the idea, I like the devs and I for the most part like the game. But there are just too many little niggles.

A list of negative things I noticed, in no particular order,
- The camera movement is strange, it pivots on a point too far ahead of your view (for my liking anyway).
- The game lags badly as you get further into the game.
- The game becomes repetitive and the challenges remain the same as you play through.
-  [strike]There is little replay value as events always seem to have the same outcome. So it becomes a more about memorisation than judgement. [/strike]
       (I was wrong about this, it's not the case.)
- There is a lot of information, but presented in a way in which it's hard to keep a track of.
- There is little to no contextual information or feedback when you make decisions.
- The opposing political parties feel hollow, the game is about balancing numbers, but it shouldn't feel like it as you do it.
- And weirdly, the game hogs computer resources for some time after its shut down.

This isn't to say it's not worth considering, it's a marvellous idea. Much of it is well done, the graphics are pleasant, the game does well to make it feel like you are advancing through time, the economic system is both detailed and robust and the technology tree is particulary well designed.

I do like it, but if I made the choice again whether to buy it, I'd say no thanks.

-------------------------
Edit: More niggles
-------------------------

- There isn't any way to locate a specific industry, you can see if a district has it, but either hovering over a factory type in the list needs to highlight them, or else there at least needs to be some other way to find them, rather than just clicking on every building until you find it.
- In the scenarios there is little feedback to how well you are doing, for example, in the scenario where you have to build x amount of weapons to prepare for war, there is no easily accesible feedback on how many you have actually made or at what rate you are making them.
- Minor events show up in the corner of the screen on a timer, it's easy to miss them if you're not looking at the bottom corner of the screen at the time.

This was rushed, but was a great concept. If they had spent a little more time on the game, it would be great.
