column9:
[quote][h1]2017 Political Amateur Mayor Simulator[/h1]

Can a mayor without the support of a political party

continue to build?

Can a mere mortal surpass Taipei

and become a super-Taipei mayor?

Highly recommended by someone.

[/quote]

[h1]Written as "Urban Empire," read as "Political Kidnapping"[/h1]

[*][b] The Correct Political Party Philosophy of the Era[/b]
Each era has its own major political parties.

[*][b] Construction Easier with a Strong Finance[/b]
When you need to build, if your finances are weak, even the political parties that generally support the initiative will oppose it.

[*][b] New Technology Drives Development[/b]
Technology drives the development of administrative districts, improving the standards of housing, transportation, education, entertainment, industry, and commerce. Of course, administrative districts must be changed each time to implement new technology.

[*][b] Voting doesn't require an absolute majority [/b]
Use tactics to coerce certain political parties into voting in favor of your policies, but be aware that using these tactics will only cause them to become dissatisfied with you.

[*][b] A party that ignores you will still ignore you [/b]
When you're being trolled to the point of being smeared, do you still care? Of course, the same applies to political parties in the game. After your favorability rating drops to -8, they'll ignore you. But don't lose heart, time will heal everything.

[*][b] Bugs are everywhere [/b]
Have you ever seen the language automatically switch when you return to the main menu? Luckily, you're lucky enough to see this happen. When you're playing in Simplified Chinese and want to return to the main screen, it'll kindly switch back to English so you can practice your vocabulary. Have you ever seen a dialog box where you can't click options? You're in luck. In this game, when two options windows suddenly appear, there's a chance that the top menu is unavailable.

[*][b] Planning is the only thing you can plan in this game. [/b]
The only things you can plan in this game are administrative districts and grid density. You said you wanted to draw your own roads and plan your own commercial and residential areas? Sorry, this game will disappoint you.

[*][b] The only thing you can plan is politics. [/b]
The biggest feature of this game isn't planning cities. The taxes generated by cities are additional. What you're really playing is politics.

column8:
I'm sorry, I really wanted to like this game. Am a huge Civilization fan. Loved the old Sim City games. I thought it'd be a hybrid of the two. It's not. IF you are looking to buy this and see all the negative reviews are the same, "price too high" and all the positive ones are lacking anything helpful. Hopefully THIS helps you make up your mind. 

In a nutshell, all you do is wait around for something to happen. They should rename this game, "the waiting game"

As Mayor, you control very little. Have to vote on just about everything, with parties that are never adequately represented. You get to "appeal" to them during voting preparation, but no matter what you choose, it feels like a random game of rock, paper, scissors - with no real strategy to be had. 
You can't really design the city. There is very little going on IN the city. You'll hear randomly, "paper industry is booming!" which would be good/bad IF IT MEANT SOMETHING lol. Like say you were investing in papyrus or vellum, and PAPER started to boom. Then...oh, no, well...am screwed. But there is no real depth to anything. All service stuff that never really seems to matter. 

If you want to be hands on and lead something somewhere, play Civ 6 - it's great. IF you want to design a city, well...there are games out there for you. 
IF you want to occasionally click a button, read small print about events that you couldn't care less about as they have no context, then this here game is for you. 

I don't know what the developers were trying to go for with this game, but they missed the mark. Most boring experience I have had short of actually falling asleep.

column8:
Es ist leider ziemlich buggy und performanceschwach. Sobald (oder falls) die Devs das mit einem Update bereinigen, werde ich diese Review auf positiv setzen. Aber leider bleibt ein schaler Nachgeschmack, da es scheinbar zur Regel geworden ist, nicht fertige oder nicht fertig getestete Produkte auf den Markt zu werfen.

Wie kann es sein, dass ein Wert nur in der letzten(!) Epoche bei nur einer(!) Partei gefÃ¼llt wird?!? (Parteidisziplin)

Nachtrag und Fazit vom 26.08.2018: 
Leider immer noch Schrott. Mit hohen Erwartungen eingestiegen und dann selbst nach einigen Patches immer noch ein instabiles Produkt. Diese Review bleibt jetzt permanent auf NEGATIV.

Nachtrag vom 25.06.2019:
Ein negativer Punkt wurde entfernt, der Rest bleibt so.

5 Hours to Boredom, that's how long it took me to "shelve" this game.........No muliplayer...in this day of age?  No interactive elections in a game like this? You can't modify family names from the weird given names?  Is there more to this game?  Only 3 senarios, 1 campaign and no sandbox?  Only 4 families and no ability to modify attributes at all? Slow to load (I7 and 650M card, 32gb) and clunky between screens, less than average graphics, and the font size is so small you can barely see it.  I know there's a fun game in there somewhere?  I'm still working on finding it!  But, this game has some real problems.  The playing of the game starts out interesting up until you figure out just how repetitious it is.  Voting is the high point of the game, and as soon as that gets boring, it's all down hill from there.  I love the subject matter, and I just had to have it.  I hope the modder community will give this game some real time....because it could be a great game, but now, in its current state, it's an, "okay" game.   Am I going to have to wait 2 years for an Urban Empire 2?  Or, buy countless DLC's to finally have the polished game this could be?  NOT worth the price I paid over 30 bucks even with the pre-release special....I would wait until the price drops, because it will...  It's not worth a negative rating, just a bland so/so, "hope it gets modded and added to"  so, it's a 5/10 rating for me.

column9:
After some thought, I'm going to give it a negative review. While it's not unfun, the majority of Chinese reviews are positive, which is clearly overstated. I'd like to offer an objective perspective.

I bought the Victorian version of SimCity for the political parties and class structure. It didn't quite unfold as I imagined... If you want a more regular city-building game, I recommend turning right and checking out Cities: Skylines. It has more content, a more complete system, and a more mature version. Of course, this game still has its unique qualities.

+Experience the changing times.
The game begins in the Victorian era, depicting a world undergoing rapid change. Natural gas, running water, trams, electricity, and telephones emerged from nowhere. Once simple and monotonous industries gradually grew in complexity, the economy flourished, and citizens' living standards soared. The player faces the challenge of piercing an ever-hardening shield with an ever-sharpering spear, while the complex interplay between the spear and the shield requires careful manipulation. The world order of the time is also reflected in the game's setting to varying degrees. From the Austrian Empire to the Austro-Hungarian Empire, to the spread of nationalism within the empire and the subsequent independence of regions, to World War I and World War II, and so on. Of course, these historical settings are currently useless in the game. Aside from the increasing number of political parties in parliament, they seem to have little impact on your operations. Oh, and after a colony becomes independent, you might be dismissed by parliament. Even seemingly obvious developments like "demand for the military industry surged after the outbreak of World War I" and "conservative power waned after the establishment of the Austro-Hungarian Empire" are missing.

+ Family Development.

Each family has a different development path and distinct traditions. For example, the second generation of a banker family has celebrity attributes. Furthermore, each family leader will occasionally encounter various events related to the upbringing of their offspring. Different choices will have different impacts on their descendants, resulting in different styles of mayors. Currently, traits are still too limited, development events are too few, and the development of a trait is too slow, often leaving you with nothing by the time you retire...

+/- Demand System.

Like Paradox's Victoria 2, industrial development is driven by and dictated by demand. As the eras change and the choices you make, the demands of different cities will develop differently. For example, the paper industry will initially flourish, but after a few decades, it will pass its golden age and begin to decline. For example, candle factories are often one of the largest industries in the early stages, but they will decline rapidly after the spread of electricity. These are quite interesting. The game also has a certain degree of class-specific demand. For example, the elite class starts driving cars in the second era, and starts buying high-end appliances in the third era, while the lower classes can no longer afford them. I initially hoped that the class composition of your city would generate different demand for different types and quantities of goods, and develop different pillar industries. Like Victoria 2, where the aristocracy wears fine clothes, sits on yachts among fine furniture, and drinks red wine by the glass, while the working class wears coarse clothes and drinks low-quality spirits in low-end bars. However, the differentiated demands in City Empire are too few, and they will eventually spread to ordinary people, making this system a bit useless. Besides technological progress, there is little need to pay attention to demand during the game.

+/- Political-Economic Control
It's easy to get lost in this game at first. Rapidly enacting laws like factory safety standards and anti-smoking and anti-alcohol laws can lead to a rapid decline in demand, and without raising taxes, you'll end up in a financial meltdown. Once the fiscal deficit collapses, Parliament will essentially refuse to approve further investment even when you're already running a deficit. This is very similar to Victoria 2, and just like in Victoria 2, you have to desperately boost demand. Building docks and train stations, abolishing policies that reduce demand, increasing employment, and so on. You'll even have to resort to counterproductive tactics like "giving money to schools to increase employment, reduce unemployment, increase demand, and increase taxes." Once your cities are established, however, the game becomes dull. With more money than you can spend, you just need to regularly upgrade your roads and randomly approve a few bills to increase happiness. I'm now completely numb and have no interest in watching what laws are being worked on in Parliament. As long as they're passed, peace and prosperity will prevail.

-Party system.
This was what initially captivated me. Flattery, threats, surveillance, balancing power, and bringing your own party to power. However, it's actually quite monotonous... In parliamentary canvassing, the three options of requesting, demanding, and threatening are essentially the same: they all cost you favorability in exchange for votes. You don't have to worry about which party is in power or which needs to be curbed; it doesn't make much of a difference to your operations. Furthermore, if there aren't any major operational issues and no one objects to your actions, the vote is essentially a formality, wasting five months (ten months without the prestige cost). During those five months, you can't make any new plans, which is a real pain. Perhaps the only time partisanship is evident right now is when deciding economic concentration (taxation) and later on, when implementing social welfare. Anyway, I get everything passed except taxes. I easily pushed through bills I thought would be controversial, like gay laws, women's rights, and universal suffrage.

- Complicated operation and unscientific user interface.
I don't understand why so many functions require entering a "renovation zone" to function. For example, building a cross-regional facility like a school or hospital, or something as simple as changing a district name, requires entering a renovation zone and reviewing the district overview before putting anything on the agenda. Combined with the requirement to only plan once every five or ten months, it's incredibly annoying. The game tries to make every planning session more formal, but the experience is simply too cumbersome.

6.5/10

column8:
Dieses Spiel klingt durch "City-Ruler" interessant und das ist es auch ca. die ersten 1-2 Stunden.
Doch anschlieÃŸend wiederholt das Spiel in der Kampagne alles. Immer und immer wieder das selbe.

Forschen - Bezirk bauen/verbessern - AntrÃ¤ge stellen - AntrÃ¤ge durch den Stadtrat bringen

Das Konzept mit dem Stadtrat ist wahrlich sehr interessant. Jedoch fehlt dabei eine Gewisse spannung.
Ich habe bisher Jede Abstimmung zu meinem Gunsten durch den Stadtrat gebracht und das ohne groÃŸen Verlust von Wohlwollen der Parteien.
Es gibt fÃ¼r mich keine Abstimmung, vor der ich angst hÃ¤tte das ich diese nicht gewinnen kÃ¶nnte.

Zudem fehlt in vielen Punkten der Feinschliff des Spiels. Ich fage mich sowieso wie man ein Spiel releasen kann, dass durchaus so vele Fehler enthÃ¤lt.

Fazit:
Guter Grundgedanke mit solider Basis, jedoch fehlt es an langzeit Motivation deutlich, vieles Wiederholt sich immer und immer wieder nach sehr kurzer Zeit. Feinschliff des Spiels ist wohl vergessen worden.

GruÃŸ,
Punkbust3r

This is one of the more interesting city builders I have played. Instead of having absolute authority, you often need to receive council approval to accomplish tasks as mayor. This means you need to plead, demand, threaten, and spy on the political parties to influence their votes. You as the mayor have a resource, 'goodwill', for each of the parties. This represents your political capital and standing with that party. As you cajole, you expend this influence, and if you expend too much goodwill the party will oppose you even if your proposition aligns with their political agenda; they will simply oppose you because they don't like you. As time passes, new technologies are researched, which unlocks new edicts and services that can be purposed to the city concil. 

Solid 8/10.

column8: æ²¡æœ‰éš¾åº¦é€‰é¡¹ä¹ˆï¼Ÿã€‚ã€‚ç©åˆ°ç¬¬å››æ—¶ä»£å°±åŸºæœ¬å°±æ˜¯ç¡¬æ’‘äº†ã€‚ã€‚ã€‚

Enabled Tutorial.  Task is to create a district.  I create a district just like it says, land area is green for proper size, but the "Create District" button stays disabled.  I'm stuck on the first task unable to complete it.  I restart game with tutorial disabled and am able to create a district without any trouble.  Restart the game with tutorial again, do the exact same process, now it works.  There is a bug in the tutorial for this very first step.   

I felt more like a spectator to what was happening than having any control on the outcomes.  After researching Gas Lighting for example I get a screen requiring me to choose between 3 options, A,B,C.  No explanation of the differences of the 3 choices, or even WHAT i am choosing.  I would think gas lighting is gas lightning.  Research complete, install please.  But no, I have to choose option A,B,C. Select option A.  Now I see the effect of that choice being displayed but no way to back up and see what Option B or C does.  My choice of option A is locked in.  This interface makes no sense and no explanation of what or why I am presented with these options. 

The game has great potential but not there yet.  Needs more work.

column8:
Boring.

This is a boring game, which feels like you're pulling 3-4 levers every few minutes to see what happens.  

As background, I like and enjoy complicated strategy games.  Some of my favourites are the Crusader Kings and Europa Universalis series.  I also have sunk many hours into the political and dynasty aspects of The Guild series.  I like these types of games.  I saw a preview and was excited at the idea of a "mayor simulation" with some background politics and influencing political parties.  Sounds like a fantastic idea for a game.

This game is none of that.

1.  You'll see a lot of negative reviews with respect to the town planning.  I can appreciate that it is not a city builder.  It wasn't meant to be; however, town councils (county councils), etc have planning offices and engage in town planning.  This is nothing like that.  It's very basic, akin to what you'd find on a mobile phone app.  

You select a district and you can only use % to determine whether it's industry, business or residential. You don't select where the individual neighbourhoods are.  So which "blocks" in your district are I B or R, is really up to the game and not you.  This is a weird design choice.  

You put some important buildings, eventually, like police station or courthouse and you can wire it up for gas or sewers, for example, but this is mostly done by just clicking a "tick" and hoping the council agrees with you.  It's very basic and not at all enjoyable to watch your city grow, because you've had little to do with it.  This is the opposite experience of the town planning aspect of "Banished" for example (which is rather fun to watch the town grow.)

2. You don't create your family.  Yes, this was discussed in the previews so this is only a minor criticism.  Yes, they said it was pre-scripted.  It's worth noting though, that when they say pre-scripted, they mean it.  It has so-called 1000 dynamic events, but none of this really seemed like it couldn't have been done without creating your own family and style.  CK does it.  Anyway, doesn't matter, just poorly thought out in my opinion.

The families you choose are typical tropes.  So you have the villainous and cruel aristrocat party, which of course has "von" in the name.  You've some weird stage-irish sounding name and that's the family that's all into working class and unions.  You've the mysterious Russians and then you've a family that's all about science.  How many science dynasties have you read about?  Anyway, it's just trope and as bad as it sounds (the specifics of the families, as in how stereotypical they were actually going to be, was not in the promos.  It's worse than anything you've read.)  I find this to be an immersian killer, your opinion may vary.

3.  The political parties in this fictional town are irritating and seemingly pointless.  Yes, they sit on the spectrum of conservative/liberal and right/left and some mish-mash inbetween.  They have histories that you won't care about.  They are name.  You won't interact with any party leader, for example, as everything is abstract.  

Most of your interactions will be with three buttons.  "Plead/Demand/Threaten".  That's it.  You click one and then a dialogue menu comes up.  Once you click one, even if you don't like the dialogue, that's tough.  You have to make a choice of the options, which is 1-2, 1-3, or sometimes 1-4.  What the options do, seems to be an arbitrary mystery.  Sometimes the tooltip popup says, most the time it doesn't.

In any event, it's bizarre.  Let's say a topic of Child Labour arises and one of these parties puts the edict to outlaw child labour before the council.  You will get a pop-up that essentially asks if you will support or oppose this edict.  Let's say you pick oppose.  You then will contact all the political parties, through those 3 aforementioned buttons.  Here's a great example of a lazy design choice...

I'm opposing this.  I want the edict banning child labour to be voted down.  YET all my interactions with the political parties will ask the parties to vote YES.  Like one of the options is "YES WE NEED THIS", where I am actually saying "no".  If you click it, it behaves like you're asking them to say no and the sliders adjust accordingly, but the actual strings that appear lazily still have the positive messages.  The whole game is like this, which makes it a pain to play.  So I'm asking the parties to vote no, but all the options are telling them to vote yes, but when I click on them it behaves as if I was asking them to vote no.  Clever huh?

The interactions are very abstract.  You can bully them, but it doesn't do anything more than move a slider.  It doesn't feel like I'm being a jerk mayor or hard-line bully.  I don't feel like I'm Mayor Daly from Chicago.  None of that.  It's abstract.  The way the numbers work, everything regresses to the mean, so as long as you're not constantly a bully, you're swiftly forgiven.

4. As a mayor/political sim this is the most boring game I have ever played.  There's nothing to do of any interest.  It's just tedious.  

It tries to insert child-like humour into an otherwise seriously presented game.  I hate that when developers think that's clever.  Certain developers can pull it off, such as in Fallout or Baldur's Gate, because it's cleverly done.  Here's an example:-

I'm trying to get an edict passed, and one of the threats to the conservative party is to say to them "Agree with me otherwise you'll be known as the conservaTARD party."  Classy.

5.  This feels primarily like running a business sim on a phone app.  It's cosmetic and veneer feeling.

6. Nothing you do is very exciting.  I pressure the council to try to get a train station built in a pre-determined location.  They say no.  I wait about five minutes and I ask them again.  This time my bullying suceeded.  Uhm, yay?  It was seriously just clicking a couple buttons, with no actual strategy or interest.   You're bullying a nameless and faceless lever.

7. Eventually one of the parties will have a split and you'll have the "old" and "young".  They don't really seem to remember how you treated them before.  As I said, everything regresses to the mean.

This game is worth maybe â‚¬9.00 for value, as a mobile app, in its current state.  Maybe DLC will fix things, but I'm not sure how, given the design, this could be made more interesting.

The Bad:

- I can't save the game. 
- Very repetitive boring music. 
- Not much to do other than empty talk in city council. 
- Events don't do anything other than adding or subtracting a few modifiers. 
- Cannot customize anything in the game other than district names.
- Camera controls are extremely difficult.
- User interface is buggy.

The Good:

- There are political parties.

Ce jeu m'avait semblÃ© intÃ©ressant au premier abord. Il nous proposait de suivre le destin d'une dynastie Ã  la tÃªte d'une ville, de l'air industrielle, jusqu'Ã  l'air contemporaine en y ajoutant une dose de gestion politique. En effet, votre personnage est membre d'un parti politique qui doit lui-mÃªme se battre contre d'autres partis politiques pour imposer ses idÃ©es.

Dans ce jeu donc, les dÃ©cisions que vous prenez doivent passer par le conseil municipal qui doit dÃ©cider de vous suivre ou non, en fonction de leur inclinaison politique. Ainsi, un parti de gauche sera plus enclin a accepter un vote pour l'augmentation des impots qu'un parti de droite.

Tout cela se complexifie avec le temps puisque d'autres partis Ã©mergent en fonction de l'avancÃ©e des Ã©poques.
Un arbre technologique est d'ailleurs disponible et vous permet de dÃ©couvrir de nouvelles inventions et de nouvelles "lois/dÃ©crets" a mettre en place (sic!). Pas mal, n'est-ce pas? Ouais mais en fait non!

Simuler un systÃ¨me politique est d'une incroyable complexitÃ©, tant la politique est plus une affaire d'hommes/femmes avec leurs propres convictions/interactions qu'une histoire de blocs homogÃ¨nes avec des idÃ©es bien arrÃªtÃ©es.
Mais ici, on se retrouve avec un systÃ¨me qui ne fonctionne pas trÃ¨s bien. Pourquoi?

a) la politique est "linÃ©aire" dans ce jeu, pour moi qu'est-ce Ã  dire? En rÃ©alitÃ©, il est assez facile de convaincre un parti politique de changer de bord et de suivre argumentation. Suffit de les pousser un peu et vos rÃ©formes passent sans soucis, mÃªme auprÃ¨s des partis historiquement opposÃ©s au vÃ´tre. Il n'y a pas de motivation complexe, Ã§a ce limite Ã  : je suis gauche, tu es droite, moi pas voter pour toi bisous.  Pas de personnages qui reprÃ©senteraient un parti qui auraient chacun leurs motivations et dont on pourraient se jouer. Non, ici, les partis sont des blocs sans visages, des machines a pensÃ©es, le systÃ¨me politique thÃ©orique Ã  la Hobbes, ou Ã  la Platon. Un ensemble de variables qui influencent si oui ou non, une rÃ©forme va passer. Des variables dont vous ne comprenez pas le sens ou la portÃ©e . 

b) Aucun sens: je veux augmenter les impÃ´ts : je vais voir le parti nationaliste pour qu'il aille dans mon sens, je lui sort (parce qu'il y a des choix de rÃ©ponses dont je ne suis pas sÃ»r de l'influence sur le rÃ©sultat final): "les citoyens veulent cette rÃ©forme des impots"...et Ã§a marche, il abonde du coup dans mon sens...j'Ã©tais mort de rire. et la suspension d'incrÃ©dulitÃ© a volÃ© en Ã©clat, je ne pouvais plus prendre le jeu au sÃ©rieux.

c) trop lent: la moindre rÃ©forme des quartiers demandent un vote. TrÃ¨s rÃ©aliste en soi mais si je voulais voir la rÃ©alitÃ© politique, j'entrerais en politique. La lourdeur du systÃ¨me rend le jeu chiant.

d) aucune concurrence: pas de dynastie concurrente sur la carte qui vous mettrait des baton dans les roues, vous Ãªtes seuls sur la carte.

e) Une campagne risible: une carte, des fonds propres, une sÃ©rie d'objectif a accomplir sur la carte, assez longs et difficiles, c'est tout. C'est pas un mode campagne, c'est un mode libre, revoyez vous dÃ©finitions les mecs, les objectifs ne sont mÃªme pas contraignants, vaque Ã  tes occupations si Ã§a te chante, pas de soucis).

f) 3 scÃ©narios, aucun mode de difficultÃ©.

g) Le choix du personnage n'a quasi aucune influence, vous pouvez en tant que membre d'une famille conservatrice, faire passer des lois progressives, tout le monde s'en cogne. Quel interet de choisir alors? Certes, les personnages ont chacun un petit bonus de ci de lÃ  qui leur sont propre, mais rien de majeur.

h) C'est moche et la musique est une insulte aux oreilles, en esperant que le thÃ¨me change lorsqu'on change d'Ã¨re technologique, sinon il y aurait en tout et pour tout, un thÃ¨me musical pas trÃ¨s long qui plus est.

i) Le jeu n'explique pas ses diffÃ©rentes variables (soins, Ã©ducations, sÃ©curitÃ©, environnement, loisirs...) quelles sont les influences de chacune sur votre quartier/ville? Qui s'en soucie?

Ce jeu ne conviendra ni aux gens qui aiment le city bulding car le vote est trop contraignant et le jeu n'offre aucune possibilitÃ© crÃ©ative a ce niveau. MAis il ne conviendra pas non plus aux gens qui aiment mettre en place des stratÃ©gies, tactiques et complot tant le systÃ¨me politique est nÃ©buleux et au final simpliste (pas de concurrence, pas de motivation personnelle, pas de rÃ©volte du citoyen mÃªme si on passe les impÃ´ts de 10 Ã  25 % d'un coup). Puis, Ã§a se prend trop au serieux, si au moins le jeu avait pris le parti (lol) de l'humour, j'aurais bien plus acceptÃ© ses dÃ©fauts mais non. J'ai juste envie de rejouer Ã  Tropico, qui mÃªme si il a beaucoup de dÃ©fauts, prend le virage de l'humour et Ã§a lui rÃ©ussi pas mal.

Le seul avantage que je vois au jeu? Une bonne entrÃ©e pÃ©dagogique pour expliquer Ã  des Ã©lÃ¨ves l'Ã©chiquier politique, les diffÃ©rents courants de pensÃ©es et la gestion des lois et des dÃ©crets. Une bonne activitÃ© d'introduction Ã  un cours d'introduction Ã  la science politique en somme. mais a 44 â‚¬, j'ai mieux fait d'acheter des manuels.

The good: the game has a brilliant idea. You have either governance games (Paradox) or city builders, but this one marries the two ideas into a hands-on governance game. Few games such as this exist (best one being probably Tropico 4). I think this goes even beyond Tropico in terms of depth, with the existence of formal votes and political parties, so kuddos to the creators for thinking about such an interesting concept.

The bad: well, the game gets repetitive very fast, as the political mechanics do the same thing over and over again. There is no sandbox mode per se at this stage, and the optimization is poor. Without the graphics or the underlying mechanics being something to go "wow" about, the game runs slowly and camera controls are wonky. Tropico 5 runs faster and has even better graphics, and larger maps.. Lastly, the interface is horrendous, non-intuitive and difficult to master. Fonts are small, and many players (myself included) had trouble saving the game (due to the insistence on a new save name) or in-game actions due to poor instructions. 

Sadly, on top of a fairly high cost (at â‚¬45 I expect this game not to become a DLC rally point), the poor features make me go for "no" for this game, and I intend to request a refund.

column9: As for the good reviews, I believe most of them are for the Chinese language and dubbing. As for the game itself, whether it is worth 100+ is debatable. I was forced to exit after playing for 10+ minutes. Well, I guess I was unlucky. When I went in again, the early events seemed very familiar??? Where are the promised 800+ random events? The gameplay is really bad. The seemingly complex algorithm actually has nothing to do with you, because the unlimited demands of the citizens cannot make a profit at all. The parliamentary system that seems to be a breakthrough and innovative is so useless? I wonâ€™t say much about the game graphics. The only advantage is that the houses are quite exquisite. Friends who want to buy it can think about it carefully. Letâ€™s wait and see how the game updates (this is my only bad review on Steam. I even gave encouraging praise to No Manâ€™s Pit, which worked hard to update. But this game is not a beta version, but it gave me the feeling of a test, which made me very unhappy = = I will never believe in pre-sales again)

column8:
Edit:
After further playing the game through more families and on all 3, yes 3, maps. I can't say this is a decent buy anymore, especially since i can't get my money back. The designs become extremely repetative once you've done a single playthrough that it just feels like slugging through a routine instead of planning ahead for mistakes or getting tripped by a new event or party. At first i felt that the party interaction was fine enough, but again, after a first playthrough, it feels so cheap. All the parties interact the same way and you have near limitless supply of forcing them to do what you want as there are almost no consequences to your actions unless you have somehow made the city broke. For a mayor simulator/city builder, this game capture nothing good of either side. The politics are too weak and simple to call a political simulator and the city building is checking boxes and placing districts and special buildings wherever you want. No in depth design or challenges or personalization that would actually make it a good city builder.
If you thought this would be a more political Tropico, don't buy it, If you thought this would be a decent city builder, don't buy it, if you thought this would be an over priced mobile game that requires basic thought and simple skillsets of reading numbers and are ok with that, the wait till it goes on sale or get a fremium game on your phone first

Original~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
A good game in theory. It has all the pieces and ideas and expansive nature of a new and innovative city builder. Problem is that the late game gets easier and easier as the main challenge of the game comes down to whether you can get your council to approve new districts and expansions rather than actual policies or challenges to your rule.
The different starting points are all unique and the families have actual stories, again all great ideas, just not fully capitalized on. All the family decisions are one shot 3 part choices that have little effect on the actual story. You will next to always have a kid, your family will continue whether you have a child or not. Your choices and dilemmas will always be the same no matter your actual actions. Trying to be a liberal elite? No problem, no changes needed. Trying to be a conservative researcher. No problem, just be a cruel trait asshole.
Honestly i love the style and progression of the game the best. It holds up well to other city builders, but falls far short of other titles' charm such as Tropico or SimCity. A great way to pass time and test your patience and knowledge of politics, but I would tell anyone interested to wait till it goes on sale as they hid most of the late game for a solid reason, they didn't flesh it out well

column9: Paradox's SimCity is quite challenging to get started with. The only source of income is taxes, but there are so many places to spend money that you can't afford to build infrastructure. Even if you put in a few public buildings, the budget is almost negative, so you have to keep building new districts or raising taxes. I was originally quite interested in this type of game, but after playing for a while, I found it's not what I expected. I look forward to future updates, and for now, I give it a thumbs-up.

column8: qwq æ¸£é…ç¬”è®°æœ¬æ²¡çœ‹æœ€ä½é…ç½®ç»“æœGGå¸¦ä¸åŠ¨äº† å‡†å¤‡ä¸‹ç½‘å§ç©è¿™æ¬¾æ¸¸æˆ æ¯•ç«Ÿå·²ç»ä¹°äº†

Interesting premise, but poorly executed and certainly not worth Â£35.

For anyone looking for their next city-building fix, this isn't it. It's very much more of a political simulator in the vein of Democracy or Fate of the World. However, I'm not sure that works entirely well with the city building aspects as they don't give you the flexibility to make the kind of decisions you'd like to make. For example, you build (or rather, seek permission to build) service buildings like schools and clinics which have an effective radius. But you can't choose specifically which blocks are residential, commercial etc, only the proportion spread within a neighbourhead, which means you end up placing services in less than optimal positions.

The evolution of the city through the ages is a nice touch, as it the way the politics changes with the times. Unfortunately, it basically plays out exactly the same way with each playthrough, and other than a few shorter, limited, scenarios you ultimately have to play the same Swarelia story. I guess this will be supported with future DLC but at Â£35 already this is a bit of a rip-off, especially without a simple sandbox mode.

The game also has a few bugs; and the economic model doesn't entirely make much sense. You'll be spending a lot of time just waiting for things to happen...

Overall, if you can get this for Â£10 in a sale, it's worth a playthrough as the game is definitely original, but there's nowhere near enough here to justify a full price title.
column9:

The game also has a few bugs; and the economic model doesn't entirely make much sense. You'll be spending a lot of time just waiting for things to happen...

Overall, if you can get this for Â£10 in a sale, it's worth a playthrough as the game is definitely original, but there's nowhere near enough here to justify a full price title.

column9:
After a few initial attempts, I felt the difficulty was quite high. I stopped at the third generation the first time. Furthermore, the tutorial isn't comprehensive, requiring me to experiment to figure out many things. I'd appreciate a more detailed explanation of the various attributes. For example, I'm not sure if the so-called satisfaction buffs for each class function the same way as amenity in Civilization.

Also, the cost of developing administrative districts to meet the needs for water, electricity, and communications is prohibitive. A linear or time-bound technology tree would be better. Developing these three key areas too early or too late is disastrous! For example, by 1860, I might not have fully installed my water pipes because my budget was insufficient. However, once the necessary technologies are acquired, factories will need them, otherwise they'll go bankrupt in a matter of seconds.
What's a bit puzzling is that cities are so fragile and prone to deficits, so you can't build too many buildings to boost citizen satisfaction. I didn't even dare build a theater in 1865, relying on random events to boost my entertainment, not to mention banning xx.

I also can't understand why the tutorial lets you build a train station so early on. 20 million is hardly impressive, and it's all gone in a flash just opening a new district!

The parliamentary system, a key selling point for this game, seems a bit useless now. Correct decisions are generally passed unless you deliberately try to sour relations. Disagreements can be passed with a bit of bluffing. It's more like a routine, and maybe by the fourth or fifth era, there'll be some indiscriminate disruption. Overall, the level of freedom is too limited, and at this stage it feels more like EA. It doesn't even have the crucial random map mode that's crucial for business simulations! I hope to ease the learning curve. The early stages are a bit rigid, otherwise it's easy to run into deficits. I suggest waiting and watching for those who haven't bought it yet!

column8:
Pros:
Deep economic siulation.
Interesting look at inventions and social policies in the time periods the game covers.

Cons:
Somewhat easy Political system.  Having watched Quill18 and his struggles it may just be my own personal politics just melds well with the game.  I've rarely ever found a need to have to persuade the partries to do anything.  Its also possible Ill have more trouble in later eras.   If so maybe the late game will add more complexity to the council system.

TestÃ© quelques heures ce matin.
Je m'attendais Ã  beaucoup mieux.
Au final le jeux est plutot chiant Ã  jouer. Chaque construction ou modification dans la ville necessite de faire voter par le conseil le changement ou l'ajout. Le conseil vote un peu n'importe comment avec quelques petites possibilitÃ©s de les influencer mais cela reste trÃ©s lourd comme systeme et pas fun du tout.
Si vous aimez les vrais citybuilders vous serez, je pense, dÃ©cu par ce jeu.

The good: the game has a brilliant idea. You have either governance games (Paradox) or city builders, but this one marries the two ideas into a hands-on governance game. Few games such as this exist (best one being probably Tropico 4). I think this goes even beyond Tropico in terms of depth, with the existence of formal votes and political parties, so kuddos to the creators for thinking about such an interesting concept.

The bad: well, the game gets repetitive very fast, as the political mechanics do the same thing over and over again. There is no sandbox mode per se at this stage, and the optimization is poor. Without the graphics or the underlying mechanics being something to go "wow" about, the game runs slowly and camera controls are wonky. Tropico 5 runs faster and has even better graphics, and larger maps.. Lastly, the interface is horrendous, non-intuitive and difficult to master. Fonts are small, and many players (myself included) had trouble saving the game (due to the insistence on a new save name) or in-game actions due to poor instructions. 

Sadly, on top of a fairly high cost (at â‚¬45 I expect this game not to become a DLC rally point), the poor features make me go for "no" for this game, and I intend to request a refund.

I really like the idea behind the game.

I don't like the huge number of bugs (some are game breaking: in the political screen when I want to see what my options are, (in the pleading, demanding, threathening submenu there isn't any way to return to the previous menu and you are forced to choose something), missing tooltips, ...

The society has not reacted to anything I did nor do I really have any options to sway their opinion.
(There are some minor events that influence the popularity of some specific political party but that's about it. 

I find myself doing the exact same thing over and over again and can't help feeling some major features are missing.
Especially in the political system, it is just too simplistic.

Don't buy the game until it has been finished and gone through quality control. This is a disgrace. There are more complete games in early access...

Bad...
Just build lots of district and money will flow.
I am in 1923 and I have never been denied anything by the council once, all vote are major win without I do any action. in 9hours I did not have to do any demand/threat and I did only 5 plead. 
I just arrived at era 3 and I am already searching tech from era 4, game is too easy and heavily broken.

Also, game is laggy. I get 1s freeze every 3s now. My computer is very good (i7-6700k/gtx970/32gb). I do not want to go any further, what will it be in 2020 ?

The game is shallow when it comes to the political wheeling and dealing that is supposed to be its main premise, and the simulation side leaves much to be desired. After struggling to make an economically viable city several times - it's quite hard to get anywhere near a balanced budget - I got bored with the simulation. The interface also leaves much to be desired: the game expects a lot of attention, but the interface is too abstract to accommodate this kind of playing. 

Urban Empire does have a novel premise, but it fails move beyond it. Those looking for entertainment will get bored after a couple of hours, and those looking for a challenge will be frustrated by its interface and unbalanced simulation.

column9: I guess many people are complaining about the parliament, so I'd like to add some comments.

column8: Played 8 Hours... I can most definately say this game is not finished. Many minor bugs and simple things left out of the game like undo buttons or easier ways to lay out districts.. Dont get me wrong it works but its not perfect. The game overall though I can already say is boring and repetative ... Yes you can change families and start new games make new laws and do things differently, ultimately your doing the same thing over and over on the same land and cant truly expand a big city as the land is extremely restricted. Same size as the starting block on Cities Skylines without buying other land to expand.. So its small ... Hopefully they will be active in making changes to the game so I can change this review... Was expecting more!
column9: Played 8 Hours... I can most definately say this game is not finished. Many minor bugs and simple things left out of the game like undo buttons or easier ways to lay out districts.. Dont get me wrong it works but its not perfect. The game overall though I can already say is boring and repetative ... Yes you can change families and start new games make new laws and do things differently, ultimately your doing the same thing over and over on the same land and cant truly expand a big city as the land is extremely restricted. Same size as the starting block on Cities Skylines without buying other land to expand.. So its small ... Hopefully they will be active in making changes to the game so I can change this review... Was expecting more!

column8: å‚»é€¼è®®ä¼šå»æ­»å§

Refunded because game crashed every half hour

Economies in game isnt really challenged and isnt well systemized you'll mostly go bankrupt for the most part.
There are not much to build or plan. It is much like Simcity with politic function but less on others.

Graphic is bad
So far not really an enjoyable game for $20+ I would say $15-

This game feels unfinished and crude. The tutorial offers no help in understanding how the game mechanics really work. All I have found is that lots of debt and threats against city council members are the only ways to get by. I wish that I could get my money back.

column9:
The early stages are relatively simple. With the Emperor, you can spend as much as you want. But starting in the third generation, you have to run for mayor. I ended up losing the game because I neglected to run for mayor. Hahaha~

The later stages are filled with too many political parties, and it's so troublesome. Even raising taxes takes a lot of points. The citizen benefits aren't necessarily that high, but taxes keep rising. Everything has to be voted on in Parliament. Twice, even with a clear majority in favor, it failed by a single vote. It's absolutely awful. It's amazing how good a one-party system is. You can fix anything you want. The Communist Party in the game unanimously opposed the ban on pornographic comics. Haha, I'm so confused.

The downside is that the core of the game is battling Parliament. The modes are too narrow, and there are very few maps. The background music is too monotonous, and the lighting and shadow effects, even at the highest setting, are still mediocre. The building models haven't changed in three eras... I didn't notice any difference in the pre-release architectural styles. There were also relatively few random events, often repetitive. However, the character portraits and family crests were quite good. The controls weren't very simple, with no shortcuts needed. There were also many confusing stats with no explanation. After entering the campaign, returning to the main menu would return to English, but restarting would fix it. You can really enjoy wrangling with the council for a long time, but I wouldn't recommend it if you don't have the patience. Based on the current content, it's not worth the money. Stay tuned!

First off, I am a HUGE fan of the Tropico series, so I may be a bit biased. That said, this is easily one of the most addictive games that I've played in a LONG time.

You really have to give it a chance, though. The first half-dozen playthroughs, it can feel like it is just unbelievably hard. Then I realized that I didn't need to wait for the game to tell me to add another district. Once your first district fills up, make sure your cashflow is positive, and build another district. That will set you back in the short-term, but then you'll get into a rhythm of building new districts, adding services, waiting until they fill up with industry/commercial buildings - and then rinse, and repeat.

The real meat comes in the way that you choose to develop the tech, and add services or stockpile wealth. Will you try to up your salary early, so that you can bypass votes and build freely? Will you let the council do what they will, and save your points for a rainy day?

I did, and that's where I really started having fun with it. It sort of feels like you're "winning" if your city has electricity before the 1800's are out. I unlocked contraception and womens' right to choose around 1860 in one game, and it felt like I had created a cultural Mecca out of nothing.

Of course, I blew it in the next era by adding services more quickly than I was sourcing revenue or adding new districts, and had to start over. But now, I enjoy every restart, because I have new ideas for how to develop my city. This time, electric early and straight to assembly line. Oh, but I added electric lights in my first district too early, and now we're broke? And I spent all of my political capital getting here, and two of the parties are pissed at me?

Time for a fresh start!


TL;DL : Released today (yesterday?). Haven't slept, brain hurts. 10/10, Would disturb sleep patterns, again.

column8:
So far, I really like this game. I've now gone into Era 3 with 3 of the 4 families, played on each of the maps, and I'd definitely say that there is a good base for replayability. I've seen it mentioned here that there are some choices that you're just going to want to make regardless of what you're doing, owning to general buffs, and that's true. It's the most limiting factor to the game's replayability. But I 1) don't think it's as prevelant as some are saying and 2) imagine that will be addressed in coming patches.

That leads me to: yes, this is going to be one of those games that really is going to need more work in coming patches before it has enough staying power to warrant sitting down and playing it for ages. Depending on what studios you're used to (Paradox, anyone?) you may already be used to that sort of thing and are willing to be patient.

I do agree though, $40 seems a bit steep at the moment. Still, I usually can't wait very long to try out new games in the genre, and I ultimately thought it was worth it.

TL;DR Dont waste your money hoping that they fix it eventually or have the balls to sell you a DLC that implements what should have been in the core game


This game is great in concept, and very very poor in implementation. I have played to completion a few times, and can say this:
1)	LLAAAAAGGGGGG - Regardless of others saying "it plays fine", if you are a successful mayor and get 10-15k population by around Era 3, the game will CRAWL. I have SSDs, 32GB RAM, and a 6 core CPU with HT. And it is literally single FPS by the time you hit Era 5. There is no way they didnt notice this in development, and yet they threw it out there anyways. Unacceptable.
2)	This appears to be based on some designers idea of how politics work. Choices you make may or may not do what you think they do, and there is no information denoting what the overall effect might be. I donâ€™t need the game to let me min/max, but I would like to at least understand who supports various initiatives, and what they are likely to vote for. It feels like there is some formula, but it is very unclear what that is. This makes every decision very frustrating.
3)	When information is presented, it is done in an awkward and confusing manner. For example there are lots of stats about each district available, but none of them cover â€œwhat does this district need?â€ or â€œHow do I address problem X?â€ So even when there is info available, it is still frustrating just trying to make sense of it.
4)	The engine designer must have done the UI also because the way things like bonuses are presented is horrible. â€œSales Bonus! Demand -10%!â€. Even if the engine calculated a bonus as -10% for something, why in the world would you present it like that. Its just backwards.
5)	Citizen desires, which they call The Wheel of Life are presented as offsets to the current era target. So you have a hard time understanding how much better you need to make things. They should just show it as â€œ11/15â€ instead of â€œ-4â€. Even then, once you learn to understand what it means, how to solve that issue is unclear.
6)	Nothing has any consequence. It doesnt matter what youve done or how you treat the parties. Vote for the most liberal policy available, have money in the bank and the coucil will love you.
7)	Citizens dont care if its the modern era and they have no utilities and dirt roads. It makes no difference whatsoever. You can buy off the vote and people still drive around on dirt roads. If the game lets you see details, you could see people checking stuff out on their ipads while walking along next to the cow droppings. Luckily the game doesnt let you zoom in ( or out ) enough to notice.
As I said, this game could be really good and after playing it a few times I can see where they were going with it. But the developer just did a very bad job of putting it into action in a way that makes sense to most people. Sure you can learn how to read their numbers, but I should have to work at learning the strategy, NOT at figuring out how to read their statistics. 
This is a $10 game with more polish than you would expect from that price range and a big publisher. For $40 its early access at BEST, and honestly, Im very skeptical of how deep the game would be even if it didnt have the litany of bugs. There are literally mobile games with more complexity, and better UIs!

column8:
Ever thought about running a city? 
Enabling trickle-down economics?
And worrying about re-election?

A great way to have hours of fun. Multiple ways to screw over a party or even the population by enabling various laws.

column9:
I've been playing for three hours now. Some parts feel a bit monotonous, and some parts feel awkward. Overall, I'm bullish on this game. When I first started, it reminded me of Tropico! I still don't know how to solve the fiscal deficit problem. It's much more tiring than Tropico, and I'm still confused. I've encountered tutorial bugs and the sudden change to English. But the Chinese subtitles and audio provided by the developers make me think they've put a lot of effort into it.
Well, I still hope the developers can optimize the gameplay and fix the tutorial bugs, otherwise I really don't know how to play this game.

Hat man Geld wird jeder Bauantrag von allen unterstÃ¼tzt, auch wenn man eine private Fehde gegen eine Partei hat...

Not quite House of Cards, but a pretty good game regardelss; but could use some polishing and unique DLC (i.e., adding new families/political parties, enhancing the political features, etc.). A must buy if you enjoy management/city builders (although this isn't quite a builder), and most definitely satiates the political void that is lacking in other similar-style games. Love the easter eggs from Tropico and others. 

10/10 will enjoy simulating Trumpenreich.

column9:
I excitedly started playing this game early this morning. I spent about six hours, making it through the fourth generation with some rough patches. The game feels like a decade old game, with both the graphics and the UI brimming with browser-based game flair.

Putting that aside for now, the game itself has its fair share of issues. The single source of money doesn't seem to balance expenditures with income. The combined costs of getting electricity, water, gas, and transportation to a city are over 100,000, but how much can a city collect in taxes, not to mention hospitals, police stations, and so on? By the end, it felt like Don't Starve, with a perpetually negative balance. If it were Tropico, you could adjust taxes to get by, but here, you still have something called a parliament to thwart your efforts. The idea is good, but the balance, gameplay, and optimization aren't what you'd expect from a 2017 game. Of course, there's room for improvement. I hope to incorporate islands and other SimCity-style games to increase income, and perhaps the gaming experience will be better. The game itself is 5/10.
Music is 8/10.
Graphics is 2/10.
I hope the developers can learn from others' strengths and make this game even better.
All in all, the current version of Urban Empire probably isn't worth the extra 100 bucks.

column8:
I have been looking for a game like this for some time. The Game play is fun and puts it into focus about nothing is easy about running a city and that in some ways it is a balacing act. Love how it combines building a city with the poltics of it.So it combines two of my favorite games.. Demoracy and City skylines into one very fun game

Recommend it for everyone !. Its well worth it.

column8:
One of the political parties that didn't like me much said that I was cheating on my wife. I countered that they were having orgies! Where else can you give a response like that in a game. Oh and my long lost pal, Peniltimo sent me a llama! 

Acting as mayor; you are at the whim of the city council. This is a different take if you think about Cities XL, Cities: Skylines, and Sim City as you are more concerned with governmental mayoral things rather than creating a city. I like this game but it won't keep me in it much. For those that are old enough to remember the choose your own adventure books (I;m carbon dating myself), at one point it's exciting but then the next you start feeling bored and wishing you can call early elections and send the City Council packing. The council doesnt like when I rezone and at times create another district. The zoning tool is a little bit of a mess. It tells you your zone is too small and/or illegal angle thinking you want to save money and not build a huge zone; nope. It has to be really big and of course suck your avalable money rather quickly.

My system meets the minimum requirements but not the recommened requirements yet everything is pretty smooth on very high settings. If I could give a maybe vote; I'm torn in between. I would definately watch how this game evolves. 

For those where money is tight; I would wait for this to go on sale. For those looking for a different take as a city mayor; it's not bad but gets boring and repetive quickly. Starting a new game just gives you the same "scenarios.". Still playing so I will edit as I move along. Right now the City Council can't stand me. I threatened all of them and I;m digging dirt on one group. I blocked their vote so ha! I told them I would oppose their next vote that they brought fourth, I showed them lol. They weren;t impressed.

column8:
In the mere 12 hours that I've owned this game, it has crashed 4 times, 3 of those crashing the whole PC, one to blue-screen.  That would be a pretty severe indictment of an early alpha release, and terrible for a beta version, but Urban Empires is supposedly a full release, ready for prime time.  There's no way on earth I could recommend this software while it is so unstable as to crash a well-specced Win 10 PC so continually even if it were a free game, so I certainly encourage everyone to resist actually paying to have their PC crash, data lost, etc.

If the game interests you, as it obviously did me, then I strongly urge that you wait for a more stable and fixed version.

Lost on the edge to the thire era. I played civ5 6 and simcity and cities skylines. I thought it would be a sort of simple combination of both genres until I was fuked by the council votes and insufficient funds to run any services. The money part is kinda like cities skylines though.

Lots of issues and questions:
1. I changed the resolution, the game exits full screen mode and never come back. As a result, I can't click on the bottom buttons like creat new district. I have to restart the game.
2. Some icons have a tag or explanation when I move the mouse cursor on it, but other don't. 
3. I need to know why a 5% increase in "expenditure" would show up in green instead of red.
4. What does "sales demand" mean? I know what is sales and what is demand, but what it means when you phrase it as "increase 5% sales demand on xxxx"? 
5. Is there a local need over general need even put aside the influence of traffic? I have positive demand for shops, so I changed the percentage of shops in one or more districts. Shops appear, the demand doesn't go down; then the shops bankrupt. Even though some survived, there are still more availble space for ALL of residential, commercial and industrial needs but nothing more show up.
6. The font size is too smal. I don't want to read the stories after 2 hours of playing. And that's why I tried to change the resolution to see if it makes the letters look bigger. Of course it fails

Even though some survived, there are still more availble space for ALL of residential, commercial and industrial needs but nothing more show up.
6. The font size is too smal. I don't want to read the stories after 2 hours of playing. And that's why I tried to change the resolution to see if it makes the letters look bigger. Of course it fails

I bought this thinking it was a city building game, and there hasn't been many good ones for a long time. However this game is [b]not really a city building game]/b]. Rather it is [b]a city management game[/b].

So in city building games you have money, build house (plots), production builds, security, etc and collect taxes and trade to make money back. This game is definitely not that.

In current city management games (like Cities Skylines or Sim City) you have money, place zones and the game simulates citizens filling those plots, which you then collect taxes from. This income is then used to pay for services. These often have more tax options and possibly zoning options but it is still very much what you do. This game isn't that.

In this game it tries to portray eal city management. You can't just place plots or build structures, there is a city council that has to weigh the benefits of an option. If you want to expand the city, you need to design a zone, then propose that to the city council. A political party or more may oppose this, but you can appeal to them. However if you have bad finances don't expect the vote to pass. Almost every action goes to a vote.

The game is set in a pseudo-realistic time, and as time passes new technologies are invented (game explains that technologies that you unlock are from you importing them to the city). The newspaper that pops up includes references to things that happened in that year in the real world.

This is a slow game, and you end up having to struggle to balance the budget. The politics can also get quite intriguing. So be prepared, if you don't like slow games with lots of reading then stay away.

The game itself runs fine for me, no issues there.

Hallo erstmal,

In der Regel erstelle ich keine Reviews, selbst bei Spielen, die ich extrem gerne zocke. Der Hintergrund hierbei ist, dass diese in der Regel sowieso mit Reviews geflutet werden. 
Bei diesem Spiel, welches ich mal als Randerscheinung betiteln wÃ¼rde, dachte ich mir jedoch, mache ich es dieses mal, da es wie gesagt, kein Mainstream Titel ist.

Kurze Zusammenfassung worum es geht:
Man startet in einem von mehreren (BÃ¼rgermeister) HÃ¤usern und versucht seine Stadt und sich selbst erfolgreich zu halten. Hierbei muss man sich A eine Stadt aufbauen und B diese entsprechend gestalten und wirtschaftlich, sozial (und einige andere Werte mehr) florierend halten. 
Die Krux hierbei ist, dass es nicht wie bei "normalen" Citybuildern eine Alleinige Entscheidung ist, sondern dass man sich mit den aktiven Parteien einigen muss. Dies kann dann durchaus mal zu absurden Situationen fÃ¼hren. 
Hinzu kommen noch ein Tech-Tree, Spionage, PartnerstÃ¤dte und BÃ¼rgermeisterwahlen, ab der 3. Periode. Und ja, die BÃ¼rgermeisterwahlen sind nicht immer einfach, vor allem, wenn es der Stadt nicht gerade (finanziell) gut geht.

Grafik:
+ FÃ¼r das Genre, eigentlich schon fast zu gut. Es ist wirklich hÃ¼bsch anzusehen, auch wenn diese Effekte in der Regel nicht den Status der Stadt anzeigen (Beispiel Verkehr, dieser ist schlicht zur VerschÃ¶nerung)
+ Die MenÃ¼s sind ebenfalls hÃ¼bsch gemacht
- Einige Grafik Effekte sehen nicht schÃ¶n aus (Fahrzeuge, welche durch sich selber fahren, Sonnen Auf und UntergÃ¤nge, die teilweise sehr unschÃ¶n wirken)

Story:
+ Nun ja, Sie ist ok und durchdacht. Nichts Ã¼berwÃ¤ltigendes, aber jede Familie hat seine eigene Geschichte, mit eigenen Problemen und Bonis. 
- Ein kleines Minus: Ich hÃ¤tte mir hier auch gerne mehr MÃ¶glichkeiten gewÃ¼nscht, die Grundstory zu verÃ¤ndern und nicht nur einzelne Skills. So ist es rein Storytechnisch nicht wiederspielenswert.

Funktionen: 
Ich zÃ¤hle jetzt nur die Main Funktionen auf.
+ StÃ¤dtebau bzw. Stadtteilbau.
+ Abstimmungsverfahren. (Teilweise nicht nachvollziehbar, hier wÃ¼rde man sich teilweise etwas mehr Input wÃ¼nschen) 
# Familiendynastie. Naja, wegen mir hÃ¤tte es die Funktion nicht geben mÃ¼ssen, siehe auch Kritik in der Zusammenfassung. Ich sehe hier beim ersten mal Spielen der Parteien evtl. etwas "Spannung", danach ist es eigentlich recht egal bis hin zu leicht nervig.
+ Skillbaum. Der Begriff ist falsch, aber ich bin mir nicht sicher, wie ich es umschreiben soll. WÃ¤hrend des Spiels wird man vor Entscheidungen gesetzt, die je nachdem zu einer Steigerung oder Senkung eines Skills beitragen kÃ¶nnen. / Zum Beispiel "Sanf"t / "Grausam" usw..
+ Statistiken ohne Ende, bei solch einem Spiel sicherlich notwendig. Diese sind eigentlich hÃ¼bsch aufbereitet und gut zu lesen.

Negativ: 
- Zum aktuellen Zeitpunkt ist es so, dass noch einige Ãœbersetzungen und Tooltips in der deutschen Ãœbersetzung fehlen, diese werden hoffentlich mit dem nÃ¤chsten Update nachgereicht. 
- Einiges wirkt seltsam. Beispiel: Episode 2, bin ich irgendwann soweit dass ich 2 reine Gewerbegebiete habe und es wird immer noch nach mehr verlangt, wÃ¤hrend 2 reine Industrie auf Minus Zahlen stehen. Dabei hatte ich wie bereits geschrieben, 2 reine Gewerbegebiete und 2 Mischbezirke mit Bewohnern und Gewerbe. 
Es war somit eine totale GewerbeÃ¼bermacht gegeben und dies sollte ich laut Spiel weiter ausbauen. Der Rest stand weiterhin auf Minuszahlen. Dies war auch nicht nur 2 oder 3 Runden, dies war dann fast 15 Jahre so.

Fazit:
Vieles sehr gut gemacht, eine hochinteressante Idee und ein bisschen Klimbim, den ich (persÃ¶nlich) nicht gebraucht hÃ¤tte. 
Ein paar Bugs im Bereich Balancing sind am Tag 1 auf jeden Fall verschmerzbar, ebenso die kleineren Bugs, welche noch nachgepatcht werden kÃ¶nnen und hoffentlich auch werden.

Wer somit sich gerne mal in der Politik versuchen mÃ¶chte, mit dem AnhÃ¤ngsel eine Stadt zu bauen, der kann hier getrost zugreifen!

The game is fun up to a point. But if you make one little mistake it sets off a snowball reaction that is absolutely impossible to to recover from. Your punished for raising taxes, your punished for lowering taxes, your punished for building infrastructure, your punished for everything. Rewards are few and far between. Game is horribly balanced. Further more the random events for you to make a decision but give you no information to make an informed one. I was asked once in game to decide which person had a better idea about something, 0 data on what their idea was, what effect it would have, nothing! Add all this to no mod support and you have a game that could have been great but ended up a dud. When asked about mod support the devs said it would be too costly, yet mods could fix this game and make it great. Very disappointed.

column8: What an amazing game.  It has blown away all expectations and is quickly becoming my favorite city builder.  The politics and council system in the game adds an entirely new dynamic that makes this game much more than just placing buildings and zoning areas.  This game brings out the political science nerd in me for sure.

Bom para pessoas que, assim como eu, gostam de um simulador polÃ­tico. Apesar disso, nÃ£o se engane, o foco do jogo Ã© na administraÃ§Ã£o e nÃ£o na construÃ§Ã£o de cidades, portanto esteja ciente que Ã© bem diferente do estilo SimCity antes de comprar.

UPDATE: Having beat the game, I wouldn't recommend it at any price. The novelty wears off towards the second half of the game (only a few hours in, it's a short game) and it just becomes boring. Somehow it becomes even easier, but more tedious. Not to mention the complete lack of an epilogue (you get a pop up that says you win and asks if you want to continue playing or exit to the main menu.)


Interesting game with a mix of city building and political simulation, though both are very simplified. The game is incredibly easy, I'm not sure that it's possible to lose. If you lose your re-election, you can always override the decision (it's treated like a council vote) for a few prestige points, which you are undoubtedly overflowing with. I would recommend picking this up during a Steam sale. $40 is too much for this game, but for $20 it would be a good deal.
column9:

Not to mention the complete lack of an epilogue (you get a pop up that says you win and asks if you want to continue playing or exit to the main menu.)


Interesting game with a mix of city building and political simulation, though both are very simplified. The game is incredibly easy, I'm not sure that it's possible to lose. If you lose your re-election, you can always override the decision (it's treated like a council vote) for a few prestige points, which you are undoubtedly overflowing with. I would recommend picking this up during a Steam sale. $40 is too much for this game, but for $20 it would be a good deal.

Fazit nach einem kompletten Durchspielen und ja, ich musste meine erste Rezension "Ã¼berarbeiten".
Es ist schlicht und einfach langweilig. Ich war auch einer der Writing-Bulls Lets Plays begeistert gesehen habe. Dort ging es mir auch schon so, dass ich manchmal zweifelte. Doch nun ist es klar. Man kann Forschen und etwas bauen. Muss schauen, dass die Kohle passt und immer und immer wieder durch den Stadtrat peitschen. Das ist ziemlich Ã¶de.
Ich gebe zu, die ersten 2-3 Spielstunden machte es wirklich SpaÃŸ und die Idee sehr gut.
Aber nun bin ziemlich enttÃ¤uscht, weil es keine Langzeitmotivation mit sich bringt.
Daher meine Empfehlung von ja auf nein.
Es ist einfach nicht klar, wieso die Industrie dauernd wieder mehr Bereiche braucht und teilweise verstehe ich die Reaktionen der Parteien nicht. Opposition gibt es so gut wie keine und 95% der AntrÃ¤ge laufen locker durch solange man Geld auf dem Konto hat.

column9: It's definitely not worth the 40,000 won price tag. It's like trying to capture both Civilization and Cities: Skylines at the same time, but it's a complete waste of time.

column8: I got all the way to act III only to have a bug stop my game.  The event "hated leader" has no options and when I go to exit to main menu the game freezes.  I've also noticed that state laws aren't working correctly.  Instead of advancing to the next law, it redoes the same level 1 event.  The game is very buggy and I hope it will be fixed soon.
column9: I got all the way to act III only to have a bug stop my game.  The event "hated leader" has no options and when I go to exit to main menu the game freezes.  I've also noticed that state laws aren't working correctly.  Instead of advancing to the next law, it redoes the same level 1 event.  The game is very buggy and I hope it will be fixed soon.

column9:
I've been playing for a while now, and overall, it's a well-crafted game with every detail. In my opinion, the core gameplay is the laws, and the most important ones that change the game's trajectory are the laws. Taxes have the biggest impact on your economy, but if you mindlessly raise taxes in the later stages out of economic pressure, you've already lost.

You have four families to choose from at the start. As a witness to history, I chose the working class without hesitation. After all, we workers are powerful. The game starts off relatively smoothly, and the tutorial is detailed, though not comprehensive. It doesn't warn against the rash creation of new administrative districts and the planning issues involved; if you don't coordinate well, you'll end up losing five or six million. Don't ask me how I know that. The development speed is also quite moderate; it feels like it takes about half a day to complete the final game. It reminds me of the Civilization series, but the two are completely different games. Later on, you can research munitions and other things, and there will probably be war scenes. It's a good way to kill time.
A particularly interesting aspect is the hereditary system (son-grandson succession). First, you'll inevitably have a son (what the heck?). As he grows up, you'll make choices about his life, which will influence his personality. The game is divided into five eras, each with a new mayor: your son, grandson, etc.

The game itself is quite challenging.
1. More and more political parties appear in the later stages.
2. Extensive infrastructure and high maintenance costs.
3. Sometimes mysterious deficits and collapses occur.
4. With each era, there are more and more research directions.

But the difficulty is still quite enjoyable. As the introduction suggests, there are a ton of events, from big-picture city planning to the everyday life of everyday life. The content is quite rich. Different families have different events. For example, the working class will criticize their origins, while the nobles don't. The game is quite replayable, and different scenarios unfold differently.

Those who haven't bought it yet should consider it. The game is new, and I feel like there's still a lot of room for expansion and optimization. I look forward to the author's updates.

Enough talk, I'm off to solve the 5 million dollar crisis (life is hopeless)

column8: é¢„è´­çš„è¿™æ¬¾æ¸¸æˆï¼Œç©äº†1ä¸ªå°æ—¶ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸æ˜¯å¾ˆæ¨èï¼Œæˆ‘ä¸å¤ªå–œæ¬¢2Dçš„åœ°å›¾ï¼Œçœ‹ç€æœ‰ç‚¹å‹æŠ‘ã€‚

I reccommend Everyone to watch one of the lets plays a few videos before deciding to buy. If you watch a lets play and like myself decide you want it, then you will enjoy it very much! It's everything you see in the lets play.

You will spend lots of time in the City Counsil screen, just about as much as the city screen. It's very different from most city builders with the politics systems in this game.

I like that i don't have to place all the roads and try to micromange traffic. Not that i did not enjoy this in city skylines, this game just focus's on other aspects of ruling a city.

It would be nice to be able to attach multiple districts to a vote to pass say electricity in all of your current districts. Otherwise so far i have no problem with the game i knew i was buying!

Edit: after playing longer i will say that it does get laggy later on even on a decent gaming rig. there are some things that are a little hard to tell what it means aswell. some people say it is to broken to play. i am not having any game breaking issues myself but be warned they are out there to some.

if you are on edge because of the bugs and problems. maybe wait some time with any new game and see if there is any changes later you enjoy.

First let me say the idea of a Mayor sim is a great idea. Problem is that the game plays less like a sim and more like a story board that your stuck following. Still not a bad attempt and I still find the story interesting. 

Sadly there are bugs. The map one that seems to affect alot of people. I got one where I had a pop up that wouldnt go away. Ended up alting out without being able to save my game. 

Other problem is its performance later in the game. At the beginning you can spam build your city and grow the whole area of the map a couple years. In all the gameplay videos it showed more a thought process. This isnt true. Spam away and 2-3 years city is as large as yo ucan make it. Sadly around 1860 the map starts to freeze up and lag. At 1900 it stutters enough its distracting. I have a super computer....around 32 gigs of ram ...and nothing ever lags. So its the game not me.

Sadly there are bugs. The map one that seems to affect alot of people. I got one where I had a pop up that wouldnt go away. Ended up alting out without being able to save my game.

It's just okay, with good reviews from officials. They've been battling the council the entire time. Is this the kind of "death cooking" you like?

The maintenance costs for various facilities are too high. Water, electricity, and gas are all at a loss. It's better not to build it.

column9:
I've been eyeing this game for a long time. I added it to my wishlist right after it came out and then pre-ordered it. I've played it for three hours, so here's my thoughts.
First, I haven't encountered any of the bugs others have mentioned, such as the optimization issues and the English-switched main menu upon exiting. My computer isn't particularly powerful, with just a 960 2GB GPU. The graphics can be set very high, so while some details may not be as sharp when zoomed in, the overall graphics are quite good. After all, I don't think simulation games are about graphics quality (I can handle full pixel count).
As a simulation game enthusiast, I've played many others, but this one is significantly different from other simulations because you're the decision-maker, not the builder. Every action you take is a decision-maker, and the only decision you can make is where to build. Therefore, building enthusiasts shouldn't buy this game. Every decision must be voted on by the council, which is the game's innovation. This makes it a game that emphasizes skill. It's not just about building anything you can afford. Some people complain that money is hard to come by, and that without it, the council won't listen. My secret is to take it slow. When you have little capital, slowly accumulate it. This game requires patience, and don't expect every decision to pass. Some decisions aren't very meaningful, so you can just agree to them and let them run their course. If they don't pass, you won't lose anything. As long as the parliamentary system tilts in favor of approval, the final vote is passed, and you don't have to dwell on it. For decisions you want to pass, you can use all three communication methods as appropriate. After all, if your favorability decreases, it will return after a while if you don't ask them for anything. With economic development, increasing tax revenue significantly increases your chances of passing taxes, so remember to raise taxes frequently to avoid running into a fiscal deficit.

Perhaps because it's a campaign, the game is quite repetitive. For example, some events are guaranteed to happen, and after playing through the same campaign multiple times, you always know what's coming next, which can feel a bit lacking in novelty. I strongly recommend the developers add a sandbox mode for increased replayability.

The game isn't particularly addictive, but it's challenging and not very casual, but I still enjoyed it. The game is fully in Chinese, with a fairly high level of translation. Great review! After all, this is only the first day of release, and there is still a lot of time to modify and add more elements. I am still optimistic about this game (how can this kind of game be considered complete without adding more than a dozen DLCs!)

column9:
I'm quite disappointed. The gameplay is baffling, and the relationships between various stats are unclear, leaving me constantly at a loss.

Infrastructure is pointless; anyone who messes with people's livelihoods will perish. The optimization is also terrible. My 970 is trembling.

The gameplay is basically a case of "the more you do, the more mistakes you make; the less you do, the better." I've found the most stable gameplay so far: mindlessly staking out territory in the early stages and then drifting with the flow.

Honestly, if you add automation, this is just an idle game.

While the Chinese localization is commendable, Steam doesn't have a "neutral" rating. A game's rating is ultimately determined by its gameplay. Sorry, Whisper.

Unfortunately, refunds are not available.

column8:
The game feels most like a politics simulator - or as the pitch says, a city ruler (not a city builder).

If viewed as akin to Democracy 3, but with a city planner added on, its a good game.

But if you're looking for a city builder, you're like to find the building too light.
column9:

If viewed as akin to Democracy 3, but with a city planner added on, its a good game.

But if you're looking for a city builder, you're like to find the building too light.
