column9: They've been playing around with deficits, playing around with political parties bickering with each other, playing around with all kinds of negative numbers. These untouchables! These damned rebels! Bring me my tiger-head guillotine!

column8: ä¸å¥½ç© ï¼Œ

So this is another economic simulator by Kalypso. This one however, is different for a change than most of their others. The idea of being a mayor, and trying to run and build a city, while appeasing council members is a novel idea. It does cause plenty of frustration, when you are turned down on a proposal that will turn your city around from going to downhill, but that is life I suppose. The game has an advanced idea, but a very simplistic implimentation of the game mechanics. Once you have figured out the way the game does things, and why the council votes no on different things, which almost always comes down to money, the game becomes very easy. Being easy, doesn't mean it is less fun though. 

 I know I put a "No" for would I recommend this game, which is kind of weird considering I do not think this game is bad, nor do I think it has any game breaking bugs that makes it unplayable, and all the bugs I have seen are so minor, they are barely noticeable. My only issue is the monotony of the gameplay after an hour or so, and what happens in Era III going forward from there. 

I only played for like 5 hours or whatever, and I do not know if things change in the 5th era, but the problem in Era 3, being forced to use most of your party support to just get re-elected, instead of on proposals you support, create an issue with gameplay. You do no need to be elected the first 2 eras, as you are appointed by the Emperor, but in Era 3 you must run for election, and convince the council to vote for you, the same way you do for any proposal. I spent far more support for the different parties in convincing them to vote me back in, every 6 years, than I ever could in advancing my city. My city literally came to a stand still for anything the council didn't wholeheartedly agree with already.

One top of this main problem, that I think needs some balancing to help players, I believe the game is not priced properly. This game should be $19.99, and at that price I would say it would sell two or three times as many copies, more than making up the difference in price they are charging, and I would recommend it to everyone. But at this price point, I think too many people would give up on the game after Era 3 and feel ripped off on such an expensive game. I really think these problems are extremely small on one hand, but too big for more to ignore, and recommend this game to anyone. If Kalypso were to get wise, and price the game better and adjust how elections are handled from Era 3 going forward, I would put this game above nearly all other city builder sims.

This game is very unique.
I have never seen another game where you try to tell people that even though we would be going in to debt shorterm it would be best in their best interest, but they do not listen. If you have ever studied much up on politics, watched political discussions or debates then this is very realistic. I rage quited when the people would not listen to me, which in my opinion is very realistic for being a political sim. 

For those people that give it a negative review because you spend most of your time begging, that is not true. If you know how to rule your city properly you should not need to negotiate with them all the time. But even still most of what politics are is negotiating and on that front this game does an outstanding job and shows you what politics is really like!

This game is not for everyone.  I cannot stress this point enough.  It is not Cities Skylines or Simcity or whatever else you want it to be.  As a political ruling simulator, it is successful in its purpose.  If that is not something you are interested in, please do not buy it, as you will feel disappointed and review this game poorly because your expectations were not met.

Wanted to like this game and give it a fair chance, but I'm gonna have to take a pass. 40$ was an outrageous price tag for this everyone can agree to that. I'm sure they will still make millions though.

What I like about this game is that it adds more of a realistic feel to it than other games for example SimCity. In this you have to fight for what you believe for witht he city coucil. Its not supposed to be a you say it goes type of game and I like that, it brings a new combination of city bulider, simulation and stratgey. A mix that we don't see much of in the gaming world. We grew tired of seeing SimCity after Simcity, F1 after F1 (simualtion- kinda) and all of the tycoons. This adds a new mix to entice us. The Devs knew what the gamers wanted. Especially in this field of games, you always see Black Ops and Battlefield in other fields, this is exactly what we wanted in the stratgey/ city bulider field. The game is unpredictable and I like. For example I play through era 2 and I create 5 new districts with all the support I needed. I play through it again and I have to ask the empire for money. Great game totally worth $40, no doubt. Amazing game Devs. LOVE it.

column8:
This game needs 3 things very urgently. 1 more interaction with the emporor. 2. make the tools players have to increase income more powerful/consequential. 3. Make the power  a player's action count more towards rewards&punishment.
    As of now what can a player do towards helping the economy is too insignificant compared to the random draft, the newspaper is reporting news irrelavent for the player such as what party wins election, instead of news of economy trends that the player can possibly make use of by adopting using tools available. The use of prestige is also very little that it's hardly even a resource to be considered.
   And what really happens if you screw up the economy(the only way you can possibly screw up is over expanding btw, since the game omits so much detail for city development)? hardly anything, you just keep watching the unchanging city and wait for your income to sort out itself, passing acts/edicts hardly changes anything, speaking of the acts, they are so numerous, and inconsequential, especially inconsequential withregard to economy which is what a player would care most about, since money decides how much you can do in the game(the other is good will of party, which is meaning less, it's gonna recover over time and brings no threat). And what can you do when you are in a economy quagmire? not much besides maybe re-preportion the district, which is btw FREE by choosing the "use personal funds option".For the most part, you just sit and watch it sorted out. There isn't much you can do, nor is there any pressure for you to do anything, you might as well keep a small district and no one will come punish you as is the case for other strategy games where competition of other players or A.I. players constantly present threat and reminds you what you do counts. 
    The game seems striving to combine strategy game with city planning, but it fails to be the first due to reasons above and it fails to be the second because it tries to be the first and therefore simplifies all the micromanage details you'll run into in games such as Skyline.

Actuellement je suis plutÃ´t mitigÃ© avec tout de mÃªme une tendance positive.
On nous livre ici un jeu trÃ¨s original et il est important de le souligner. Il ne s'agit pas d'un city builder comme pourrait l'Ãªtre un Cities Skyline mais bien d'une gestion de ville principalement axÃ©e sur l'aspect politique que cela demande. L'idÃ©e est excellente et donne envie.

Premier point interessant, le jeu est en franÃ§ais. Ca peut sembler bÃªte mais c'est un point qu'il faut souligner, il y a tout de mÃªme beaucoup de lecture Ã  faire pour comprendre les dÃ©crets, les lois, les diffÃ©rents partis politiques, les technologies...
Traduction trÃ¨s bien rÃ©alisÃ©e.

La partie construction n'est pas le point central du jeu mais reste tout de mÃªme prÃ©sente, elle est basique et peu de choix possible autre que la construction d'un quartier, mais c'est normal donc ce n'est pas un point noir. Vous dessinez un quartier et vous aurez diffÃ©rentes actions possibles, de plus en plus nombreuses au fil du temps sur ce quartier. D'ailleurs, au dela d'une gestion de ville, c'est aussi et surtout une gestion de plusieurs quartier qui ensemble, forment votre ville.
Vous aurez accÃ¨s Ã  des statistiques prÃ©cisent et nombreuses pour chaque quartier. Vous pourrez leur ajouter des bÃ¢timents publics comme un Ã©cole, la police, les pompiers. Vous pourrez aussi leur donner accÃ¨s Ã  l'eau, aux Ã©gouts bref Ã  beaucoup de choses suivant votre avancÃ©e technologique.

L'interface reste propre, simple et efficace mais a tout de mÃªme quelques soucis comme des textes tronquÃ©s car trop long et aucune tooltip nous donnant le mot complet au passage de la souris. Il y a d'ailleurs parfois certaines icones, dans les bonus qu'un dÃ©cret apporte par exemple, qui n'ont pas de tooltip et nous savons donc pas toujours ce que le bonus apporte. Les Bonus d'ailleurs qui ne sont pas toujours clair dans leur comprÃ©hension.

J'en arrive aux deux points principaux, la gestion Ã©conomique et politique.
La gestion Ã©conomique consiste tout simplement Ã  avoir suffisement d'argent dans les caisses de la ville pour financer de nouveaux projets et idÃ©alement rÃ©ussir Ã  maintenir votre budget mensuel dans le positif. Alors y a du trÃ¨s bon et du moins bon mais je vais tout de mÃªme mettre mon manque d'expÃ©rience sur le jeu en avant pour ce que je considÃ¨re comme moins bons. C'est difficile, presque ridicule, les constructions sont trÃ¨s chÃ¨res et leur coÃ»t d'entretien mensuel sont titanesque. Mais je le redis, ce point est Ã  prendre avec des pincettes, plus d'expÃ©rience sur le jeu rend les chose je pense plus abordable. Une chose dont je suis casi sur, c'est qu'il y a de vÃ©ritables choix Ã  faire car vous ne pourrez pas mettre une ecole, l'eau, le gaz, une clinique les yeux fermÃ©s, vous n'aurez pas le budget, il va falloir y aller doucement en comptant bien chaque centimes qui sort des caisses de la ville et Ã§a c'est trÃ¨s agrÃ©able. 

Nous en arrivons Ã  l'aspect politique du jeu et je suis tout aussi mitigÃ©. L'idÃ©e est excellente, plutÃ´t bien rÃ©alisÃ© dans son ensemble. Il faut faire preuve de finesse, accumuler du capital politique reprÃ©sentÃ© avec la reconnaissance que vous pourrez parfois dÃ©penser pour demander du soutien Ã  tel ou tel parti. Il ne va pas falloir tirer trop sur la corde au risque qu'on finisse par vous rire aux nez et qu'on ne vous Ã©coute plus. Bref c'est vraiment cool. Oui cool, les premiÃ¨res heures.
On se dit "Ha ouai c'est sympa", on apprend a comprendre le systÃ¨me, on est pressÃ© de voir arriver une nouvelle dÃ©cision Ã  prendre, faire voter un projet de loi, un decret, mais aprÃ¨s plusieurs heures, on se rend compte d'une chose, c'est qu'en rÃ©alitÃ© il n'y a pas vraiment de choix. DÃ©jÃ  il n'y a casiment jamais aucune raison d'Ãªtre contre un projet.

- Interdiction aux enfants de travailler avant 10 ans ? Ba oui
- Protection des animaux ? Ba oui
- Droit pour la femme d'Ãªtre propriÃ©taire ? Ba oui

Vous n'avez mÃªme pas besoin de faire pencher la balance, de jouer de votre influence, les decrets passent naturellement.
Quand bien mÃªme vous voudriez Ãªtre contre ces lois, vous le pouvez, et vous pouvez mÃªme arriver en effet Ã  ce que le conseil municipal s'y oppose, mais il n'y a aucun interÃªt Ã  le faire.

En vÃ©ritÃ©, si on regarde dans la rÃ©alitÃ©, pour une question posÃ©e, il y a toujours des bonnes choses ET des mauvaises choses pour les OUI et pour les NON. Tu pÃ¨ses justement les pour et les contres et tu prend une dÃ©cision. Mais lÃ , si tu fais passer la loi, tu as des bonus, et si tu ne la fais pas passer, bon t'as pas les bonus du OUI, mais t'as pas ni malus ni bonus du NON donc autant dire oui. Bref il y a aucune raisons qui te motive Ã  te battre pour le oui ou pour le non.

J'ai une comparaison qui me vient, dans des city builders qui ont integrÃ©s la politique comme les dÃ©crets via un systÃ¨me trÃ¨s basique, on coche une case et hop le decret est appliquÃ©. Dans Urban Empire c'est pareil en rÃ©alitÃ©, juste qu'au lieu de cocher une case, on nous demande si on veut la cocher ou pas, on attend une minute que le vote se termine auprÃ¨s du conseil et voilÃ  tu as ton dÃ©cret.

Alors je vais tout de mÃªme terminer sur une derniÃ¨re prÃ©cision. Je reste convaincu qu'au fil des Ã¨res que le jeu propose, cela se complexifie, il y a plus de parti qui se crÃ©e, il y aura plus de choix et de vrai choix j'en suis convaincu. Je suis aussi convaincu qu'il y a des modificateurs cachÃ©s, que nos actions ont un poids auprÃ¨s des partis sans forcÃ©ment qu'on le sache, qu'il faut donc peser le pour ou le contre de temps en temps. Je suis convaincu qu'il faut parfois la jouer fine mais si j'ai raison, il est vraiment regrettable que le jeu ne nous fasse pas ressentir ce jeu politique dÃ¨s le dÃ©but.

 C'est pourquoi je le recommande tout de mÃªme, il reste trÃ¨s original, trÃ¨s plaisant les premiÃ¨re heures, je n'ai pas encore assuez de recul pour valider dÃ©finitivement certain de mes points nÃ©gatifs. Il y a du challenge, c'est un bon jeu dans l'ensemble quand bien mÃªme l'avenir me donnerait raison concernant ce que je lui reproche. Maintenant comme toujours c'est mon ressenti, Ã  voir le votre.

I wish I could recommend this game, but I don't see any way to get to that point with what we currently have to play.  There's zero strategy involved, it's essentially impossible to lose.  As long as you do bulk upgrades of districts when they go up for vote, you'll always have plenty of goodwill.  As long as you raise taxes regularly, you'll never be short of money.  No matter how unhappy your people are, it never actually reflects in the game itself.  It took me an hour on speed 4 to get to age 3, and the only differences were slightly different building names that essentially do the same thing as prior buildings.  Once you factor in the increasing demand from successive ages the new buildings do almost literally the exact same thing, since their higher bonuses are offset completely.  If you had some idea what most actions would do, it would help considerably.  Instead you normally have no idea what any option will do, although occasionally you'll have a tooltip for one or all of the options, although this is rare.  It's just currently not fun at all, and I deeply regret my pre purchase.

column8:
4 hours played and i really like this game , it's repetitive , but i like it. this game keeps you thinking all the time. 

I'l do a more indepth review after i play more. 

Pros : 
-Fun
-Choices (Lots)
-Great game play , no crashes 
-Easy to learn game
-Keeps the mind going

Cons :
-Repetitive 
-Music is annoying as BEEEEEEP
-Alot of reading , wish it was voiced more rather than reading
-Kinda wish the choices you made were more yours (I feel like you have to answer the right way to progress)


Other than that , i like this and i rate this a 8 / 10 

As i said , i'll update this as i play more and get a better feel for this game. 

--- I Recommend ---

column8: Pretty damn good--a little sluggish on my machine, but mostly when first loading it, about as much as civ 6 takes in the same circumstance. Actual gameplay is really interesting. Only real gripes are 1. a few unclear names/tooltips, or lack of tooltips, though nothing critical. and 2. in general it can be hard to realize what is going wrong or right with some systems...though thats likely just the fact that i've only played it a short while and haven't learned the ins and outs of the game.

I was really hyped about this game when I first saw it, but it turned out to be disappointing and overall I don't think it's worth 40+ euros. My recommendation - play Tropico instead, it has better music too.

1. The tutorial doesn't quite help in instructing what to do. I was asked to create a new district, but the proposal didn't go through, so I had to wait some time to create the said district. All peachy, but now what? I've played for 20 more years, but no other pop-up to tell me what else to do. And of course there was no goal mentioned anywhere, however, I couldn't fully utilise all the features, because the institutions were locked (even though I've researched both the port and train station). So I had to start over the campaign.

2. The map is not fully displayed, not even as a minimap, nor can you move around by moving the cursor to the edge of it, so creating a new district or placing a service turns out to be quite hard to do, since you have to right click+drag to have visibility. 

3. Things get repetitive after a while - All you do is plead the council to approve your proposals and select choices on random events.

4. Technology vs city approvals - Ok, you have the electricity, water and gas unlocked, but your council is constantly REFUSING to adopt these technologies in the districts. No matter how much you plead, demand or threaten. So what's the point of having them, if you can't use them?

5. No clear explanation on how the economy works. You are just told in the tutorial that you can see the city data. But that's all. So you end up with bankrupt companies without explanation and the point mentioned above doesn't help either, since the companies can't expand/function due to the lack of resources. 

I wish they had released an early access game, at least to have the satisfaction of knowing they'll improve it. 
Think twice before you buy it.

column9: This game isn't a city-building simulator, although it does allow you to indirectly change the appearance of your city, adding services and specialized buildings. It's a pleasant, rather original, meditative mayoral simulator with a very low entry barrier. One of its main advantages is the time period from 1820 to the present day. Watching a city develop from the pre-industrial era is very interesting. It's surprising that not a single renowned city-building simulator has yet implemented this feature. Even if the timeline begins in the 19th century, we are usually shown a modern American village with the obligatory running water and power plant. Here, everything is more logical. Electricity and sewerage were quite expensive and sometimes unnecessary for citizens in the mid-19th century, but the opening of a theater becomes the event of the century. Among the fun features, it's worth noting the ability to play as a Russian dynasty of bankers, philanthropists, and patrons of the arts. A solid 4. Recommended.

Why you should buy this game:
- Roleplay element in SimCity game let you soak in a little more, is fun to lead a family generation after generation)
- Graphics are decent
- Simple to play, but complex to understand
- The vote system makes the game more interesting
- Balancing your income is kinda fun when you try to min-max the gameplay
- District upgrade system
- Some nice events with humor (sadly less and less later in game)
- Technology tree is simple but fun

Why not to buy this game:
- Serious performace issue later in game (30fps? you wish, this must be patched or the game is not playable)
- Politycal parties do not make sense when voting (for example, before voting the game shows you that all parties are strongly against women right to vote base on their idealogy, it is 1800 so you know... but when voting they like 90% for it)
- More or less pointless edicts system (not enough information what is going on)
- Small maps (comparing to City Skyline it is like building on 1 plot out of 9)
- Technology tree is not clear enough

I would recomend to buy this game for 25$ or less, it is more or less how much I have payed. The game is fun, but need some serious work and optymization. 
Also this is small studio project, so I expected NoManSky2. That's probly why I kinda like this game, my expectations aren't to big for it.

column8: æ¸¸æˆå¾ˆå¥½ç©ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯æœ‰ä¸ªå°é—®é¢˜åˆ›å»ºæ¸¸æˆä¹‹åå†è¿”å›æ¸¸æˆç•Œé¢ï¼Œä¼šå˜æ”¹å˜è¯­è¨€ï¼Œä¸çŸ¥é“æ˜¯å¦åªæœ‰æˆ‘ä¸€ä¸ªæ‰ä¼šè¿™æ ·ã€‚

If you like niche games, you've come to the right place. The game plays out as promised - you get to be the mayor of a newly founded city, and you struggle to have your dynasty keep control thourgh almost 200 years of history. 

As per release, i'm not sure i would recommend it. I did fairly enjoy the game so far, but it feels repetetive and somewhat voyeur. The engine hasn't been optimized, and so, perfomance is somewhat dissappointing, even on low graphics. I realize that this means more to the maisntream gamer, which is also why this is marked as "not recommended".

But credit goes where credit is due - the politics system works quite well. You feel that you can actively make a change. Parties can become more popular if you support their agendas, and edicts make a noticable impact on your city's economy. There is a lot of different ways for a campaign to play out, even on a single map. I don't regret buying the game, but it's not one that i would shout praises for without hesitation.
column9:

As per release, i'm not sure i would recommend it. I did fairly enjoy the game so far, but it feels repetetive and somewhat voyeur. The engine hasn't been optimized, and so, perfomance is somewhat dissappointing, even on low graphics. I realize that this means more to the maisntream gamer, which is also why this is marked as "not recommended".

But credit goes where credit is due - the politics system works quite well. You feel that you can actively make a change. Parties can become more popular if you support their agendas, and edicts make a noticable impact on your city's economy. There is a lot of different ways for a campaign to play out, even on a single map. I don't regret buying the game, but it's not one that i would shout praises for without hesitation.

column9:
The graphics are average, and the optimization isn't as high as I'd hoped. The official specs are clearly a bit exaggerated.

The game's verbal attacks are a bit overpowered, and the parliament doesn't play a significant role.

The game has a developmental element, and you decide what the next generation of city rulers will look like.

Inventing takes up the majority of the city-building effort, but the construction element is a bit low. You can only plan a single administrative district, but the specific details are beyond your control.

I've only played for about an hour, but overall the game is quite enjoyable, though it needs some major updates.

Additional review:
After all this time, and with no major updates, I can only say I don't recommend buying it. At least this isn't a game like the popular island game. It's a rather depressing experience. Even though I enjoy that kind of game, it's not for everyone.

There's just something about this that feels.....shallow.  I like the idea that you're basically playing as a mayor of a town and are limited by what the legislature says (aka what happens in most towns in western societies with a mayor and council governing system)....but.....something is off.

For one, the UI system is a bit crowded and overwhelming.  It's in sad need of being overhauled.  Don't get me wrong, I'm not trashing it because it's complex.  Complex is good if it's organized (aka Europa Universalis IV) but this is just a mess.

Maybe this can be fixed in patches?  Then again, maybe not.  For now, what a shame.  This could have been something new and fun.

The game brings aspects of politically-driven and city-building games that come together to create a unique experience. Utilizing a district zoning method with other controls (such as adjusting the density of the district to be sparse or tight-knit, or changing the amount of lots dedicated to residential, commercial, etc.), you are able to plot out the literal squares of your city. However, the thing that caught most people off guard is that you don't manually place buildings except for municipal services (like schoolhouses, clinics, or fire stations). Most of the changes that impact the city and change the outlook of things take place in the senate where you propose tax hikes/cuts, adjust funding, and issue edicts for approval. Depending on the relationship between the mayor (player) and present political factions and their spot on the political compass, they will ultimately decide if you are able to carry out your plans. The game is mostly a balancing act where you try to weigh it to your side. From time to time, the game will pose events that impact your contstituents and need your input, like if you support or want to abolish child lavor, support alcohol liscenses, or if you should enstate anti-pollution laws.

I for one enjoyed what the game had to offer, and would recommend this game to any individual who wants a game to simulate real political functions and to also revel in making personal decisions about the citizens you reside over.

If I had any critques about the game, I'd say that a neater user interface would be better, and to make alerts to the player more visble and last longer. Secondly, have the tutorial go more in depth about companies and how to make revenue.

EDIT: Has been pushed out and abandoned for a quick buck. Sad...

Needs a coat of polish and a price drop, but this scratches an itch for a niche that hasn't ever been filled.  I'm a student in Land Use and Government Law (among others) and I've been waiting for a game that makes you less of a "God Mayor" simulator where you design a city without limitation, but more of a "county supervisor" simulator, where even small actions are political and costly beyond just the bottom line of the city.  This is that game... it just needs a bit more work.  Kalypso has a history of releasing games that have great core ideas but need a bit more work, and this is another example of the same.  The game needs a few more rounds of optimization, as it shouldn't be causing my computer so many problems.  The UI needs work and just EVERYTHING needs Paradox style tooltips to explain what it does and how it plays into the city as a whole.  Finally, the political simulator needs a bit more difficulty thrown in (or the economy does).  But still, if this is a game that will receive a lot of post-release support, than it could easily become a long-time favorite.  $40 is a bit steep for the state it is in now, though.

TL;DR This game is a indirect city management game with politics that takes some time to figure out and is deceptively complex.

This is a fairly unique management simulation.

You are a mayor who is one of several stereotypical dynasties who has been granted control of a city.

You take no direct hand in building it but must manage the city indirectly though successful political maneuvering of the council.

The game has a very familiar city-builder-esque cycle:
1. Choose and Object to build
2. Wait for budget to be positive enough to sustain it.
rinse, repeat

It adds a few other things to the cycle:
Petition the council for funding of your project or fund it yourself.
Intorduce laws and get them passed.

In between all this you must regularly make decisions on various events both random and othewise presented to you. These events can have bigger consequences than they first appear.

Early on in this game; I felt like all the options they give you in manageing the political parties were just different shades of the same flavor but the political system is actually much more subtely complex than I thought.

Another thing that ended up being more interesting than it first appeared is the economy.

If you enjoy games like Crusader Kings 2, Victoria 2 (really any paradox grand strategy or grand strategy games in general) You will probably like this game. If you want an outlet for your creative outbursts this will probably end up frustrating and boring you.

column8:
Sad state of affairs.

Let me stress that the game ain't all that bad. The idea and the gameplay of this title is pretty fun. In theory.

The execution is less then stellar though as is the support, which is non existant for the most part. The main problems in this game is of a technical sort. The most annoying one is the lag at the endgame which ruins pretty much the whole experience. The second real issue is that the balance/moneymaking is just wrong in this game. It's really hard to make money and to keep your city nice and modern and if you do manage to make money you can't really do anything else.

A shame really as it could have been a real rough gem. Now it's just a sad ugly looking rock.

It's really hard to make money and to keep your city nice and modern and if you do manage to make money you can't really do anything else.

A shame really as it could have been a real rough gem. Now it's just a sad ugly looking rock.

Al fin llegÃ³. Al fin. El juegazo del puto aÃ±o. Desde Julio o Agosto esperÃ¡ndolo. Y bien pagadito por adelantado en esos meses. Pero, da igual. Â¡Viva la Pepa! Ha mÃ¡s de un mes que he visto a alguno espaÃ±ol jugar a Ã©l. Pero bueno es que vayamos mentalizÃ¡ndonos de que, precomprar el juego en verano no te da la categorÃ­a que tiene un youtuber con sus buenos 20000 suscriptores, por asÃ­ decirlo. He puesto el jueguito del puto aÃ±o a descargar a las seis de la tarde en punto. A los que no somos nadie, nos mata el ansia viva. Poco ha descargado, dirÃ­ase. PareciÃ³me ver que poco mÃ¡s de 2 Gigas. Bueno, es un city builder, no el buen Sandbox que se tercie, tan de moda. Inicio el juegazo absoluto o absolutista, es TrÃ³pico V pero en el Imperio AlemÃ¡n, o Swadiano, lo llaman( a ver el buen copyright de Mount and Blade por eso de Swadia dÃ³nde estÃ¡) ahora. Lo inicio como he dicho, sale una pantallita de presentaciÃ³n muy hermosa. Elijo un personaje que es una mezcla entre el Kaiser y Otto Von Bismarck y, alguna regla establecida que he roto por derechista y ansioso o, simplemente que, un producto que hemos pagado por adelantado y que, otros han disfrutado antes que nosotros, pobres muchedumbres mortales; simplemente, digo, puede ser que sea una mierda absoluta y una estafa. No deberÃ­a, me digo, si ha dos meses que los grandes profetas lo estÃ¡n jugando. No, o sÃ­. La muestra que le han dado a los profetas, estÃ¡ bien pulidita, es propaganda, no vamos a anunciar mierda. La mierda, para los tontos que lo han pagado por adelantado y que esperen hasta Enero, de aÃ±adidura.
Ya me la hiciste con TrÃ³pico 5, Kalypso. Pero Ã©sta, ya no te la paso. VerÃ¡s cÃ³mo implemento yo ahora mi puto Urban Empire, pero en la realidad.
No hay forma de jugarlo, damas y caballeros. Tal vez, primero os encontrÃ©is con el problema ese del crasheo al iniciarlo. Se pone la pantalla negra y ni pa atrÃ¡s, ni pa alante. Dicen que es porque no aguanta resoluciones superiores a 1080, en mitad del 2017, no en 1917, Kalypso. Bien, buena explicaciÃ³n, salvo que yo lo tengo a 1080. Cuando consigÃ¡is hacerlo andar, os va a maravillar cuÃ¡n bien funciona. Se iniciarÃ¡ y la cÃ¡mara empezarÃ¡ a dar vueltas y vueltas y vueltas. Ya no hace falta colocarse ni nada, para que todo te dÃ© vueltas. Pon este jueguito y lo verÃ¡s. Y de la mala hostia, te darÃ¡ vueltas todo el exterior, tambiÃ©n. IrÃ¡s al foro y pondrÃ¡: desconecta todos los controladores. Lo harÃ¡s y seguirÃ¡ todo de esa suerte.
ConclusiÃ³n: gran simulador social ultrarrealista. A continuaciÃ³n, procederÃ© a desinstalarlo y, despuÃ©s, pedirÃ© el reembolso a Steam. Y, en cuanto se pueda, llamarÃ© al organismo correspondiente y les expondrÃ© el caso que les interesarÃ¡ cuanto menos. Â¿Veis? Gran simulaciÃ³n social. Y realista. Muy recomendable.
column9:
It's finally here. Finally. The game of the fucking year. I've been waiting for it since July or August. And well paid for in advance in those months. But, whatever. Viva la Pepa! I've seen a Spaniard playing it for over a month now. But hey, let's start to realize that pre-purchasing the game in the summer doesn't give you the status that a YouTuber with a good 20,000 subscribers has, so to speak. I've set the game of the fucking year to download at six o'clock in the evening sharp. For those of us who are nobodies, the urge to download it is killing us. It hasn't downloaded much, so to speak. I thought I saw just over 2 GB. Well, it's a city builder, not the good old sandbox game that's so fashionable. I'm starting the absolute or absolutist game; it's Tropico V, but in the German Empire, or Swadian, they call it (let's see where the good copyright of Mount and Blade is, because of that Swadia thing). I start it, as I said, and a very nice little splash screen appears. I choose a character who's a cross between the Kaiser and Otto von Bismarck, and some established rule I've broken because I'm right-wing and anxious, or simply that a product we paid for in advance and that others have enjoyed before us, poor mortal crowds; simply put, I say, it could be absolute crap and a scam. It shouldn't, I tell myself, if the great prophets have been playing it for two months. No, or maybe it is. The sample they gave the prophets is well polished, it's propaganda, we're not going to announce shit. The shit, for the fools who paid in advance and can wait until January, to top it off.
You already did it to me with Tropico 5, Kalypso. But I'm not letting you have this one. You'll see how I implement my fucking Urban Empire now, but in reality.
There's no way to play it, ladies and gentlemen. Maybe you'll first encounter that crashing problem when you start it. The screen goes black and there's no going back or forward. They say it's because it can't handle resolutions higher than 1080p, in the middle of 2017, not 1917, Kalypso. Well, good explanation, except I have it at 1080p. When you get it working, you'll be amazed at how well it works. It'll start up and the camera will start spinning around and around and around. You don't need to position yourself or anything to make everything spin. Launch this game and you'll see it. And, to my chagrin, the whole exterior will spin around too. Go to the forum and it'll say: Disconnect all controllers. You'll do it, and everything will continue like that.
Conclusion: great ultra-realistic social sim. Next, I'll uninstall it and then request a refund from Steam. And, as soon as possible, I'll call the relevant agency and explain the case, which will be of interest to them at least. See? Great social simulation. And realistic. Highly recommended.

column8:
I'm a huge fan of the Tropico series, by Kalypso, so naturally I was excited to see this title coming out.  I pre-ordered it, and almost right away I could tell this was not the game for me.

Basically, all they had to do was give us a more polished version of Tropico, with a more in-depth political model.  They attempted to kind of do that, but then changed the building process (and ease of).  For instance, in order to even build your city, you basically have to build "wards" and plan out their outlines.  And interesting concept, but totally un-needed and annoying.  Then the game is basically goes into auto mode, building it's own houses and such, where it wants to ... which totally disrupts your plan for city buildings such as police stations, schools, etc.

On top of that, after you place a "ward," it's then broken into different zones, residential, industrial, etc.  From what I can tell, it just randomly assigns these zones, depending on the terrain.  Again, totally annoying and screws up the building process.   30 minutes in, and I still can't figure out how to place the Train Station.  It really shouldn't be this difficult or clumsy.

Tutorial is a joke.
Luckily I a got a refund.

So TLDR:
Clumsy, complicated building and planning
Control taken out of players hands/ distributed by random assignment
Politics not really engaging  
All we needed was a polished and engaging build-off from Tropico ... but they threw the best parts of Tropico out
Music and sound, meh.

column8:
[i] [h1] TL;DR [/h1] [/i]
I'm not very happy with the game in its current state.
It's lacking a real challenge, and the political parties feel like regular obstacles to make it harder. For me, it also lacks more options for "perfectionists" like me to "micro-manage" the city to the final and last detail, like for example managing the road grids, instead of just three options for it. The price I also feel is too much for what it is now. If updates bring more, I'll maybe buy it again and see if it makes a difference.


I really don't know what to say about this game.... A part of me likes it, and a part of me doesn't.
The main reason is because this game was much more "lean back" than I expected, it automatically builds road grids, and automatically decides where and how much to put industrial, residential etc. I expected a much more Cities: Skylines type of thing, with political implementations. Instead what I got, was a boring "don't worry about this we'll do it for you!" type of game. No challenge at all, hardly anything to do, and things become repetitive quickly. I also noticed the graphics of the buildings degrade a lot when you're not zoomed in on them, they literally become white squares with black windows (played on ultra).

I'll list some of my Pro's and Con's.

[h1] Pro's [/h1]
- Game was fun and intriguing for the first hour.
- Feels and [i] is [/i] different from other city management/builders.
- The soundtrack is amazing.

[h1] Con's [/h1]
- Graphics could be better.
- Price tag is drunk, even the 35â‚¬ pre-order price I paid for it.
- Game becomes dull quickly.
- The AI is as dumb as me.
- The UI is confusing, and the "benefits" from doing things are poorly explained. 5% Sales demand = ?.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
I wish Steam had an option that was in between "Yes" or [b] "NO" [/b].
If you like really easy city management/builders with close to no manual control over the layout with political implementations, this might be for you. If you're willing to pay 45â‚¬.
I think a more fitting price would be around 15 - 20â‚¬.
For now, I'm going to give this a no. I'll probably try to get a refund.
If updates supposedly improve upon the game, I'll maybe buy it again and try it out.
But again, for now, I'm not happy with the game in it's current state. 


[b] Should you buy it? [/b]
Maybe, I think a price reduction would make it worth it. The game is still getting updated, so hopefully they'll add something to make it better.

[h1] [b] 4,5/10 [/b] [/h1]

He jugado por mÃ¡s de 15 horas a Urban Empire, y en lo personal este juego se diferencia de gran manera de los demÃ¡s citybuilders; como sabrÃ¡n, incluye elecciones a la hora de aprobar decretos, subir o bajar impuestos, construir nuevos distritos, etc. Lo que eso significa que tendrÃ¡ algo de dificultad para mantener a los partidos a tu favor; obviamente, la mayorÃ­a de ellos serÃ¡n aprobados dependiendo de tu situaciÃ³n econÃ³mica en ese momento.

Tiene en total 2.500 eventos aleatorios que pueden ir surgiendo a partir de las nuevas o viejas partidas que tu tengas; en lo personal, es un juego que recomiendo mucho..

Lo malo:

No esta en espaÃ±ol por el momento.
Aveces se nota que le falta optimizar un par de temas, pero no es nada grave.
Y muchas otras pequeÃ±eses... por que todo el tiempo que llevo jugado, no me ha dado errores ni me ha sacado del juego.
Luego de un largo tiempo puede que se te vuelva repetitivo.
Pocos escenarios. (En lo que a mi respecta)

Lo bueno:
Tienes bastantes horas garantizadas por dÃ­a, con la inmensa cantidad de eventos aleatorios que tiene.
Varias familas, cada uno con un posible heredero y sus propios rasgos.
Distinta variedad de edificios; aunque en este tema le doy un 8/10.
Y muchas otras cosas que puedes descubrir tÃº mismo.

Esperamos que los chicos de Kalipso saquen nuevas actualizaciones optimizando un poco mÃ¡s el juego y agregando el espaÃ±ol, pero eso no quita que te puedas aventurar a jugarlo un poco en su idioma original y aprender algo de inglÃ©s.

Dont buy it. I am nuts for political sims in any shape, and enjoy tycoon kind of games and played this game for 4 hours just to realize how lacking it is.... I was deceived by the idea behind this game (which sounded marvelous). However the game is very, very shallow... It is only a council voting simulation, with very few options and even less logical on the issues and parties. The votation on the council is the heart of the game (in fact it is the game, everything else gravitates this, for example you put light on the district , for almost no effect in playablility and then you have to approve it on the council, exactly as you would do to approve womans rights, exactly in the same way and with no logic on it). If you played The Guild 2, and was at the council of the city election, you will have much, much more fun and logic abou it..  I just asked for the refund, The game was not what was promised.

column8:
Edit: The original review was written under the assumption that a lot of the minor bugs would be fixed in the weeks after launch. However, the game seems to be published with a fire and forget attitude. Therefore i can't reccomend it anymore. 

------------------------------

Urban Empire is not a city building game. 

In Urban Empire your main goal will be to stay in control. If you want to place something as trivial as a police station, you have to be able to pay for it, pay the service costs, have your political allies and enemies approve it during a vote and be sure that the running costs don't kill your city long time. 

Personally, i didn't have any technical issues but there's some reports in the Forums you might wanna check out. The overall gameplay is fine but feels lacking in some aspects and now and then it's not exactly clear how some things play together until you've done some trial and error. However, overall it still makes for a good and unique game. 

If you're looking for a relaxing city builder, there are better options available. If you're looking for something you have to work into but is quite rewarding this might be for you. It's certainly not for everyone - but that's what steam refunds are for.

column8:
City builder with the political aspects of games like Democracy 3, and a Penultimo cameo.

I rather enjoy it, because with the political aspect, you need to pick and choose your battles. Always strongarming the council into getting your way WILL backfire on you.
Build new districts when the economy is booming, increase taxes when it's in the red and always keep at least 10X the city's income in the treasury for cases where the economy turns around.

The council is remarkably reasonable as long as you don't strong arm them. They will go against their own political compass if the economy is threatened or if it's booming and play to the approval of the public. If your city has high education, even the conservatives are likely to vote yes on progressive matters to avoid loosing approval.
And if you have trouble getting something trough the council, like expanding infastructure in a district? Do it in steps as it's much easier to get trough.

However if you try to play it like any other city builder and constantly strongarm even your political enemies.. you're going to have a bad time. So don't do it. Go with the political flow and try to focus on a healthy economy with your own ideals for the city being secondary.

Doing as described above, I was able to expand the city into 6-7 districts before the first era was over and with a few 100k in income, which I managed to expand into over a million by the third era. As a result I only ever had to persuade or strongarm the council in 1 or 2 matters so far, and where the vote didn't go my way or I needed to get it trough despite the council makign it impossible, I just overturned it instead of trying to strongarm every party and move them into negative approval as i seemed to take a much lower hit from overturning the vote and the good will bounces much faster back from a 1-2 hit accross the board than from a 5-8 hit on a few parties.

Also if you have trouble starting off and expanding, then start out by raising taxes 3-4% and as soon as you're in the positive after building the first district, zone another before you start adding services. It'll give you a bigger starting population & industry which will help keep your economy strong and make it much easier to continue expanding after adding services.

Doing as described above, I was able to expand the city into 6-7 districts before the first era was over and with a few 100k in income, which I managed to expand into over a million by the third era. As a result I only ever had to persuade or strongarm the council in 1 or 2 matters so far, and where the vote didn't go my way or I needed to get it trough despite the council makign it impossible, I just overturned it instead of trying to strongarm every party and move them into negative approval as i seemed to take a much lower hit from overturning the vote and the good will bounces much faster back from a 1-2 hit accross the board than from a 5-8 hit on a few parties.

Also if you have trouble starting off and expanding, then start out by raising taxes 3-4% and as soon as you're in the positive after building the first district, zone another before you start adding services. It'll give you a bigger starting population & industry which will help keep your economy strong and make it much easier to continue expanding after adding services.

column8:
Sowohl von der "Wirtschaftssimulation" als auch von der Politik hatte ich mir mehr versprochen. Schade...die Idee war gut.
Die Politischen Parteien sind vollkommen falsch aufgestellt. So war damals eine Konsevative partei und eben auch der Adel niemals fÃ¼r linke Politik. Das Gesetz zur Legaliesierung von Gewerkschaften wÃ¤re niemals mit den Monachie treuen konsevativen umzusetzen. AuÃŸerdem saÃŸen sie damals in der Mitte des Parlaments ;) und nur die Nationalisten am rechtem Rand.
Das Parlament ist sehr lieblos annimiert. Alle bewegen sich gleich und eine hitzige(gerÃ¤uschvolle) Debatte wÃ¤re echt stimmungsvoller. Allgemein findet fÃ¼r das Auge wenig statt. Die StraÃŸen sind leer . Also ein langweiliges Parlament und auch bei der Stadtabbilung ist wenig ansprechendes zu sehen. Man muss sich schon stark auf die Texte konzentrieren.
Damals wurden demokratische Gedanken erst heimlich publiziert durch illegale Druckerpressen(die dann hochgenommen wurden) und schlieÃŸlich auf der StraÃŸe ausgetragen.
Allgemein kÃ¶nnte man da noch Demos und jubelnde Massen die auf die politischen Ereignisse reagieren hinzufÃ¼gen.
Ich fasse zusammen : 
- falscher Kontext
- lieblose Annimationen
- total oberflÃ¤chliche Zeitgeistsimmulationen
- wenig wirtschaftliche ZusammenhÃ¤nge

von der Idee her nicht schlecht aber mies umgesetzt und garantiert keine 40 Euro wert.
Auch wenn das, dass erste Spiel seiner Art ist.
Schade! Hab mir schon lange diese Kombination gewÃ¼nscht!
Bei Urban Empire 2 macht ihrÂ´s hoffentlich anders.

Fails to deliver politically. User Interface feels outdated, clumsy and stale with endless little stats that do not appear to influence the game at all, nor are they under control via policies or editcs. Game basically consists of clikcing through 3 major screens and watching the town evolve rather randomly. Surely one of worst value propositions in my library - applying for refund.

column8:
This review will be updated as more information is gathered. [Updates at bottom]

TL, DR: In a game espousing political wrangling, manipulation, and development there is only one political path available and it will happen whether you pursue it or not; the other parties will eventually pass every edict that is beneficial/required (unions, child labour laws, etc.) without any need for input. There are no significant historical decisions to make, as history is single-tracked (so no alt-history fun), your decisions are irrelevant and coercing the political parties is pointless anyways because there is only one outcome no matter who you play as. Tropico had more political influence and shaping than Urban Empire does.

The Tropico from the 1990s. 


=====Normal Review Follows=====
The citybuilding element of this game is simplistic (not bad) and a little awkward at times (having to modify/improve infrastructure on each small district individually): it's serviceable, given that the game is focused on the political landscape.

Unfortunately this is where the game (from what I've seen so far) falls flat. Playing a technocratic mayor I found that the only social progress I would ever meaningfully make was towards the ideals of the modern left; nearly all of the conservative ones seemed to have drawbacks whereas liberal ones were purely beneficial. Why would this bother me, given that I am (for want of a better term) liberal? Because there was no teeth to the opposition. There was no temptation. The populace inevitably voted left-wing and thus all edicts were effortlessly passed to support their policies, while the conservative groups languished, ineffective, in the background. Was it because I educated my populace that they so overwhelmingly supported such efforts? It's impossible to tell, since education is required just to keep the population content.

To compound matters a selling point of the game is marching onward through the eras with the political tribulations that followed. Unfortunately these matters seem to have almost no impact on anything you do in-game. A recession hit and I lost some income but recovered regardless. The Emperor was deposed and fled to my nation but no apparent benefits, drawbacks, or gameplay mechanics followed. Russia gets invaded by bloody France and there is no evident impact on my city. There's no alt-history, as has been confirmed by others, and there doesn't seem to be any way to influence politics or even be influenced _by_ politics, at least from what I have currently seen.

Next playthrough we'll see if a nationalistic luddite will actually change the way the game goes, or if it's all just kicking and screaming into the mundane future without regard for the possibilities that would emerge from quirky alt-history antics.


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

So far, so bad. Only way to progress is through unions, rights, etc. Spent the entire first two parts of the campaign resisting Unions (despite them having no mechanical downside and, I believe, being absolutely necessary to upgrade your economy/income), but ultimately it's futile. 

While you can use underhanded means to usurp other political parties there doesn't seem to be any reason to do so. Over time they'll want to pass various laws that will only improve your society/income/etc. As previously stated, these edicts are almost exclusively left-leaning and there are no means to, say, create a human rights abusing society like China. 

In a game where the entire draw is the political wrangling and manipulation, why is there only one political route to pursue that offers any success and is met with minimal resistance regardless of which parties you court? Hell, the conservative (or just abusive) policies I try to set offer me little but political gain with the party I already associate with, while the liberal/human rights ones give political capital, popularity, and economic advantages.

I feel like I'm railroaded into playing the game only one way. Despite having four "Dynasties" a tthe start (which, too, are preset) and the tagline being the option to influence decisions such as womens' rights and child labour, there is literally no reason to oppose any of it. Whether you pick the human rights advocate or the tech-hating luddite conservative it all ends the same way and trying to change it does nothing but prolong the inevitable.

Urban Empire espouses choices that matter but so far... none of my choices matter.

column8:
If the game was priced at 20-25$ i would recomend it. At its current state its little more than a threatening simulator. The politics are boring and when it comes time to afford somthing just raise taxes and threaten everyone. The game is too basic for the price.

Here is a simple pro/con
 
PROS
No game like it out there
Interesting gameplay "for a short time"

Cons
Lag after 5-8 districts
Gets repetitive even after 2 1/2 Hrs.
Costs and taxes are way to basic and the costs for certain buildings are way overboard.

All in all wait for a sale or for the devs to lower the price.

telement decu du jeu j'attendais vraiment quelque chose de mieux mais en 1h de jeu je tourne deja en rond les projet de loi telement facile a faire passer

je recommande pas du tous le jeu

Decent game but not without its flaws. I really enjoy the hands off approach to city building because I always felt that Simcity and similar titles gave too much free reign as the mayor in my oppinion. The game seriously lacks good explanation for what your actions are going to accomplish and in a few cases there aren't even ways to back out of a decision so that you can check the other options available to you. In general, it feels as though the upkeep cost of improvements are entirely too high especially there's no easy way to get a feel for or really impact the financial health of your city. Most of the issues plauging this game can be easily fixed with a patch, and as I said, balance and explination are my only two real gripes with this game. Oh, and before I forget, the political system also needs to be explained better with the different parties acting as they should (there have been multiple times I've encountered a party proposing something and when you go to the vote screen the proposing party is voting against the bill).

Urban Empire is a failing pile of garbage.  Playing this game genuinely annoyed me.  The people who made this embarrasment should be ashamed of themselves.  It's not a city builder.   It's an "irritation simulator."

column8: Not what I expected at all. I expected a more immersive experiance. The tropes of histoic politics are ingrained in each city from the start. So if you want to make democratic moves of the 21st century you better be prepared to fail hard. The game is not a builder at all, its more of a political childrens game. I even pre purchased the game, not impressed with the graphics at all.

EDIT: Not Recommended now as the coat of polish I referred to below never appeared and it looks like it was abandoned.  Great concept but poor execution.  With even a modicum of optimization the game would be great.

Needs a small coat of polish, but otherwise a great city builder with a unique twist; you need to have most everything approved by the city council.

A game of city building AND politics.  Think Sim City + Democracy.

column8: Macht Laune und lÃ¤uft bei mir bisher ohne Probleme. Endlich mal von der Idee etwas anderes.

This game has a good premise and a good twist on the city builder genre, but unfortunately it just does work in the way it should.
The first problems is that anything you want to happen to the districts has to go through the council and wastes time (in my opinion) .
Secondly it the tutorial takes for ever to get through and slow down progress.
Thirdly there are thing that you have to do to advance time, like setting research(which costs money and can set you into debt)

Overall, not a bad game but has alot of flaws that put me off continuing playing this game.
column9:

column8:
Anyone can build a city - not many can RULE a city.  Fair warning, this isn't another SimCity or Cities: Skylines - this is the political game BEHIND the running of the city, with a little smattering of city building and planning mixed in.  Where you would plan to build a police station, and how to route roads was the bread and butter of city planning games - how to get the city to run effectively through city councel politics is this games focus.  This also means that you have to learn the political game of schmoozing, pleading, walking the fine line between love and hate - and not making enemies.

Pros:
+ Different approach to a genre that has recently enjoyed an upswing
+ Making friends and influencing people really has an impact on things, versus just making money the primary factor in something failing or succeeding.
+ Different political families present something to latch onto as the player - you are playing a role, not just some invisible semi-god making decisions about things affecting everyone else.
+ The different eras allow you to see how progress affects decision-making.
+ Tool-tips on many concepts allow you to grasp the games concepts without digging out a PDF manual (or printing them off, if you are 'pen and paper' kind of ruler...)

Cons:
- Some of the random events seem to not be well described - so choices seem arbitrary.
- Difficulty lacks granular controls to allow you to ease into this new hybrid genre of a game, you either catch on and succeed or you don't - and you end up restarting when it all goes to ****.

I think the game would be worthy of a good 70-78% approval rating.  Good roots, but needs some smoothing over in spots to really make it a knock-out.  Definitely worthy of the pre-order cost, a good choice with a small 'wait-and-see' recommendation at full retail price.  Kalypso always seems to iron out the wrinkles in their games, and they will likely do so with this one as well.  

Just remember - ruling the city requires politics, politics is playing nice with others, if you don't play nice with others - this game is going to be really hard for you.

column8:
0/10 <-- Hopefully I can change this after they patch the game, but lazy QA testing has become modern PC game cancer so this is my rating as of now.  

I'd like to actually give a review mostly talking about the gameplay, but as it stands I can't really play the game (unless I want to put up with a headache inducing resolution, and frame rate) since I have a modern computer, and I guess the game simply doesn't function correctly on them even with the work around which just kinda sorta fixes the issue.  Aside from the  idiocy of creating a game that forces you to run it with an older OS (which it still runs poorly on), I'd think anyone could see that the game underwent almost no OA testing at all, and this is likely due to the fact that they wanted to get the game out by the 20th so it would go along with innaguration day.  If they wanted to simulate poltics then I guess they did that by having a massive scandal.  They need to fix this issue very quickly, or it's likely that they'll end up being in quite a few "worst games of 2017" videos by the end of this year.

Pro: +
ğ™¸ - Tiefgehende Politsimulation mit Einer Menge Potential

Neutral: ~
ğ™¸ğ™¸ - Schwer Ã¼berschaubare Bewegungen in Gewerbe und Wirtschaft. 
ğ™¸ğ™¸ğ™¸ - Das Tutorial ist unintuitiv und hÃ¤lt damit die Lernkurve extrem flach.

Contra: -
ğ™¸ğš… - Tooltips und direkte Informationen zu Ereignissen/Symbolen sind eine RaritÃ¤t, was fÃ¼r solch ein komplexes Spiel ein No-go sind.


Initialpost:
(ğ™¸)Als Tropico 4- und Tropico 5-Besitzer habe ich bisher einen recht positiven Eindruck davongetragen. Bin direkt mit Beginn der Downloadfreigabe mit am Testen und kann im Augenblick keinerlei grÃ¶bere Bugs feststellen.

Einziger "Bug" bisher ist, dass ich Info erhalten habe nach einem von meinem Charakter bestÃ¤tigtem Eisenbahnprojekt, dass 'er an der Baustelle des Bahnhofs vorbeispazieren wÃ¼rde um die Bauten zu inspizieren', was zu dem Zeitpunkt eigentlich unmÃ¶glich war, da ich das Bahnhofsbauprojekt noch gar nicht umgesetzt hatte. Doch ganz im Ernst... das sind kosmetische Feinheiten, keine Gamebreaker o.Ã¤.
Falls meine Wenigkeit darauf stoÃŸen sollte, wird das hier prompt nachgetragen, aber bisher haben wir hier ein gemÃ¼tliches Politik-StÃ¤dtebau-Spielchen.

Folgender Kritikpunkt nach den ersten 3 Stunden:

â€¢ Tooltips(ğ™¸ğš…) - Sollten wirklich Ã¶fter bei Mouseover erscheinen und mehr Hintergrund zum einzelnen Icon anzeigen(Siehe Screenshot unten):
So habe ich zum Beispiel beim Erfolgreichen Umsetzen des Arbeiterschutzgesetzes drei Punkte(Symbole) untereinander, die mit dem "Nachfrage steigt"-Symbol(danke an dieser Stelle fÃ¼r den Tooltip) versehen sind, jedoch neben drei (vermutlich Rohstoffproduktionen?) Symbolen, alias Bereiche, die davon beeinflusst werden, welche ich so nicht wiederfinden konnte. Somit bleibt einem in dem Moment eine gelupfte Braue und ein "guuut" auf den Lippen kleben, wenn man sich gern Ã¼ber die Auswirkungen schlau gemacht hÃ¤tte.

Screenshot-Showcase:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=846664607
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=846883659

[u][Review-Update 1: "bAnalitÃ¤ten"][/u]

Folgende(r) Kritikpunkt(e) nach den weiteren 6 Stunden:

â€¢ MusikstÃ¼cke - Wirkt auf Dauer sehr repititiv. In geistigen VorgÃ¤ngern wie Tropico fiel dieser Punkt weniger auf. In dem Fall ist es wohl den recht markanten, klassischen StÃ¼cken zuzuordnen. Ich musste zwischenzeitlich einfach artverwandte MusikstÃ¼cke im Hintergrund anwerfen, damit man nicht schon zu Beginn zu viel von den gefÃ¼hlt drei MusikstÃ¼cken bekommt. Nichts fÃ¼r ungut, es sind schÃ¶ne, passende Tracks, aber die werden nach dem 100sten Mal leider nicht mehr besser. ;)
Musikstil ist ironischerweise eine Mischung aus Die Sims Einkaufsmusik, Sims Mittelalter und Gilde 2. Mittendrin ertappt man sich doch dabei, einen neuen Einrichtungsgegenstand besorgen zu wollen...

â€¢ Kosten/Nutzen-Effekt Ingame(ğ™¸ğ™¸) - Es scheint im Moment doch sehr schwer kontrollierbar und schwer einsehbar, welche ZÃ¼ge man beim GebÃ¤udebau an den Tag legen muss, um Gewinn einzufahren.  Mittlerweile scheint es gar so, als wÃ¤ren durch Erlasse erteilte "Steuern", wie Alkohol- und Tabaksteuer ein relativ unbedeutender Faktor in Sachen "Einnahmen". Ebenso gestaltet es sich mit dem "regulierten GlÃ¼cksspiel", welches meines VerstÃ¤ndnisses eigentlich wie in der staatlich kontrollierten Lotterie Einnahmen zur HÃ¤lfte der tatsÃ¤chlichen Investition der BÃ¼rger erzielen sollte. Doch auch hier ist der Impact kaum bemerkbar. FÃ¼r mich scheint sich alles auf die Besteuerung von BÃ¼rgern und Industrie hinauszulaufen, welche scheinbar kontinuierlich anzusteigen hat.
Auf der anderen Seite sitzt der monatliche Kostenfaktor von meist mehreren tausend K(ronen?). Bedeutet also, dass es fÃ¼r jedes Infrastrukturupgrade, jedes DienstleistungsgebÃ¤ude und nicht standard-Zonenbesiedlungsdichte hohe, monatliche aufkommen, welche sich stets nur mit einer Methode wieder in den grÃ¼nen Bereich der Einnahmen bringen lassen: der Steuerschraube. Es wirkt beinahe unglaubwÃ¼rdig, wie sehr sich Industrie und BÃ¼rger das auf Dauer stetig gefallen lassen, aber vielleicht Ã¤ndert sich das mit hÃ¶heren Epochen ja noch.

Screenshot-Showcase*:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=846887085  

â€¢ Tutorial generell(ğ™¸ğ™¸ğ™¸) - Das Tutorial selbst scheint sich am Prinzip "learning by doing" zu ergÃ¶tzen, was im Grunde positiv wirkt, da unaufdringlich und beilÃ¤ufig, doch die Schwierigkeit hierbei ist, dass es teils auf einen GlÃ¼ckstreffer hinauslÃ¤uft, ob man wieder ein tutorialwÃ¼rdiges Ereignis triggert oder nicht. Hier wÃ¤ren etwas klarere Grundinstruktionen hilfreich gewesen. Etwas, das klar macht, dass man besser auf Verteilungsauswahl forschen sollte, welches unter der Erfindung "Telegraph" zu finden ist. Ohne die kontrollierte Verteilung von Wohn-, Gewerbe- und Industrie-FlÃ¤chen in einem Stadtviertel ist es wie ein WÃ¼rfelspiel, wie sich die drei Faktoren gerade zusammensetzen. Ich persÃ¶nlich hatte lange Zeit einen viel zu hohen Anteil an UnbeschÃ¤ftigten, da die Wohnhausanteile hÃ¶her waren als Gewerbe oder Industrie, aus eben jenem Grund, weil ich den Telegraphen leider erst recht spÃ¤t erforscht hatte.

Screenshot-Showcase*:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=846881961


â€¢ Interagieren mit Parteien bei Abstimmungen(ğ™¸ğš…) - Auch hier wÃ¤re es um einiges einfacher, hÃ¤tte man Tooltips, die eine gewisse Prozentanzeige offenbart, wie wahrscheinlich eine Partei auf ihre Bitte/Forderung/Drohung/[spoiler]Erpressung[/spoiler](<= durch Forschung freigeschaltet) reagiert.

Screenshot-Showcase*:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=846894681

[u][Review-Update 2: Liebloses Tutorial bei einem Spiel mit groÃŸem Potential!][/u] - 23.01.17

Jemand, der das Spiel noch nicht besitzt, mÃ¶chte sich fragen, wie das Fortschrittsempfinden in dieser Politik-Sim ist. DafÃ¼r gibt es einen recht einfachen, bildlichen Vergleich:
- Man stelle sich ein wildes Pferd vor, dem man als Laie beibringen mÃ¶chte, dass es gehorchen muss und einen nicht permenent vom Sattel werfen sollte. Ein Pferdedompteur(alias Tutorial) kÃ¶nnte einem dabei eine solch groÃŸe Hilfe sein, wie ein Lift einem GepÃ¤ckwagen, der das Stockwerk wechseln muss. Nun. Dieser Dompteur steht allerdings eher an der Ecke der Koppel und raucht genÃ¼sslich eine und winkt einem zu als wÃ¤re alles was da gerade passiert normal, wÃ¤hrend sich der Reiter(Spieler) vielmehr in der Luft und am Boden, als auf dem Pferd wiederfindet.
Man muss also auf die harte Tour die Details des Spiels kennenlernen, sich einleben und dann nach Instinkt Dinge auf den Weg bringen, in der Hoffnung, dass nicht im nÃ¤chsten Moment die Ã¤usserst fluktuierende Wirtschaft [u]ohne ersichtlichen Grund[/u] bankrott geht - GeschÃ¤ft fÃ¼r GeschÃ¤ft...


Dieses Informationsvakuum ist ein Kernkriterium und sollte in den nÃ¤chsten Patches behoben werden. Sollte sich abzeichnen, dass hier die Politik von Battlefront und co gefahren wird, dass Kritische LÃ¼cken nur mit DLC-KÃ¤ufen gefixt werden kÃ¶nnen, wird diese Empfehlung hinfÃ¤llig werden! Wenn man sich so unbekÃ¼mmert unverschÃ¤mt wie EA, Ubisoft oder Blizzard verhÃ¤lt, sollte man nicht dem Trugschluss unterliegen, dass das der SchlÃ¼ssel zu einer langen Firmenexistenz ist - man siehe Jowood, Freunde des kapitalistischen Augenkneists...

Great politics + city-builder simulation game. It has everything I have ever wanted in a city-building game. For me it is quite entertaining and capitivating; although some people may not be interested in managing a city's taxes and electrical grid while trying to balance a budget, to me it is very fun.

There are a few bugs and some inconsistency with regards to tooltips, but I'm sure they will get patched away quickly. 

All in all, great game and I look forward to seeing it grow and develop, and for my city to grow and develop!
column9:
Great politics + city-builder simulation game. It has everything I have ever wanted in a city-building game. For me it is quite entertaining and capitivating; although some people may not be interested in managing a city's taxes and electrical grid while trying to balance a budget, to me it is very fun.

There are a few bugs and some inconsistency with regards to tooltips, but I'm sure they will get patched away quickly. 

All in all, great game and I look forward to seeing it grow and develop, and for my city to grow and develop!

column8: Nu stiu cum au trecut 2 ore.Foarte intuitiv si tutorialul explica foarte bune ce trebuie facut.Sfat: nu incepeti sa construiti prea multe districte la inceput ci axati-va sa fiti pe + cu toate cele.Practic nu puteti face nimic fara votul politicienilor ca in viata reala.Puteti discuta cu seful unui partid sau cu toti sau puteti afla diverse lucruri mursare despre vre-un parlamentar.Deciziile pe care le iei sunt extrem de importante.La fel si felul in care pozitionezi cladirile.Voi incerca sa fac un review mai detaliat cat de repede pot pentru ca joc e fenomenal.Singura problema ar fi pretul...dar daca stiti de unde sa il luati nu e problema

Erwartet wurde ein Wirtschaftsspiel in dem man seine Familie mit/gegen andere Familien Ã¼ber 200 Jahre vertritt und sogar die Option hat als BÃ¼rgermeister gewÃ¤hlt zu werden... 

TatsÃ¤chlich spielt man gleich als BÃ¼rgermeister, unterschiede der Familien spielen sich lediglich in den anfangs Boni wieder.
Also ein SimCity in den 1800tern. Erlasse und Verabschiedungen sind der HÃ¶hepunkt, zu erwarten sind etliche Stunden als Stadtverwalter. Keine Spur von Wirtschaftssimulation. MÃ¶glich das ich in die Trailer und Berichte zu viel interpretiert habe, ein Spiel ala Gilde gegen 3-5 andere Familien in einer Stadt mit Politik und Wirtschaft wÃ¤re der Hit gewesen. 
Meine Meinung.

This Game has a texture bug and Compatibility problems. You have to wait 10-15 Miniutes for it to load and even on medium graphics quality it feels like you are walking through mud. Can't get it to go full screen-because i wanted to personalize the graphics and now i can only see half the screen. i havent even created my first district yet. Wait untill the price drops and they get it patched. They made an open beta is what im saying. Get it patched developers-my condolences to everyone else to pre-ordered.

Note: Some antivirus software like 360 â€‹â€‹will report an error, so please be careful when launching the game.

Although the game has been localized to Chinese, there's currently a bug where the interface appears to be a mix of Chinese and English.

Also, this game is desperate for money. For the sake of city development, should we raise taxes?!

The council rejected your proposal, and the city is currently tens of millions in debt.

column8: Was really looking forward to this game, but I suppose because of high expectations it's unfortunately turned out to be a big dissapointment. Not really a city builder at all except for drawing districts, rather it requires a lot of political micromanaging which gets boring pretty quickly because it doesn't feel lke it gives any real depth to the game. If a game is going to hook someone it should do so in the first hour, and I really can't say that I'm hooked.

column8:
I just dont think it's worth the 40$, maybe 20$. I like the game and the concept, feels shallow, needs to be felshed out someome. I would like to use personal funds and city funds to build, like a half/half combo, I would also like more info on some screens. More parties and the growth of the number of people in parties as in population growth. More grid options, Diffrent mayor governments would be nice. Overall it's fun but I felt like I was doing the same thing everytime.Also mod support would make this game amazing. 

P.s People are mad that I think the price is too high? I like the game, just needs more stuff for that price.

column8:
the game is amazing i have been playing since the release 20.01.2017.

Pros:
+ Game is not that big to download
+ keeps you at your toes all the time due to the politics changing allot after what you do ingame.
+ like the district building system.
+ good tutorial for the starters.

Cons:
- starting to getting very complex to get past Era 3

I just hit the 2 hour mark on this game and I had to review it.

This game is a great mashup of city builder and political strategy. Sort of a mix between Cities: Skylines, Democracy, Crusader Kings, and Civilization.

The game is easy enough to work with, the basics are well explained though I've started over 2 times already because boy does it present a challenge.

Growth is limited by both your bank and your political prowess, if you're too against the grain right off the bat anything you try and get done is going to be voted out while if you appease the parties you get some clout that you can use to push your own agenda.

One issue that I have run into is the camera, it is much easier to use the keyboard controls for it than to use the mouse ro else you'll end up spinning the camera around wildly and never really get it into the right spot.

Placing of buildable areas, called districts, is by far one thing that is really nice. With other city builders every road and zone was placed by hand, now you control how much of what zone type (typical RCI) you want and they are auto placed with roads already there.

Want to build a park or a church? You can, using services, though the coucil will need to vote on any changes that are made, unless you're paying for it out of your own pocket. And yes, here you have personal funds as well as city funds and you get paid every month.

If you like city builders, strategy games, or political strategy games this is a game you will probably get a lot of enjoyment out of.

This game is a great mashup of city builder and political strategy. Sort of a mix between Cities: Skylines, Democracy, Crusader Kings, and Civilization.

The game is easy enough to work with, the basics are well explained though I've started over 2 times already because boy does it present a challenge.

Growth is limited by both your bank and your political prowess, if you're too against the grain right off the bat anything you try and get done is going to be voted out while if you appease the parties you get some clout that you can use to push your own agenda.

One issue that I have run into is the camera, it is much easier to use the keyboard controls for it than to use the mouse ro else you'll end up spinning the camera around wildly and never really get it into the right spot.

Placing of buildable areas, called districts, is by far one thing that is really nice. With other city builders every road and zone was placed by hand, now you control how much of what zone type (typical RCI) you want and they are auto placed with roads already there.

Want to build a park or a church? You can, using services, though the coucil will need to vote on any changes that are made, unless you're paying for it out of your own pocket. And yes, here you have personal funds as well as city funds and you get paid every month.

If you like city builders, strategy games, or political strategy games this is a game you will probably get a lot of enjoyment out of.

column8: The game crashed the first two times I tried to load it, so I reduced all of the graphics settings, got it to work, and started playing.  An hour and forty minutes in, it crashed, lost all of the data.  I started a new game, reduced the graphics setting further, and it crashed again half an hour later when I tried to save.  It's seems like a good game, but it's too buggy to play right now; come back to it when the developers release a patch.

column8:
Ok please bare with me i will update this later but just a little review for thoose pondering wether to buy, so far i am only on ear 1 - this reveiw will change.

So Far so good, its fun if not a little on the repetitive side! This might just be the way i have choose to play as im not really to bothered about the votes. Most of them seem to go my way without me really trying, watching the city grow is nice and the modifying of districts to help them evolve is super cool. its a slow paced game and if you try to speed it up manally you end up in all sorts of trouble.

except for the odd dilema and the reasearch the game kinda slowly pushes you forward there isnt much to do it but make some choices sit around waiting for income to come in, make some more choices. 

overall, a well made interesting concept, if you like city builders i would recomend this,  i think at the moment its just a tad repetitve  and easy, i seem like im cluelessy playing and doing pretty well for someone just 'giving it a test run'.

Mixed feelings - the idea/concept behind the game is sound, unfortunatly the only real success here is the great concept. On paper it all sounded so good. 

In reality, the developers have failed to making a meaningful simulation, your input is slight, the excitement never raises the bar above normality. Interaction is limited, sense of achievement low.

Had this been a android/ios release, at say Â£4.99 would recommend without hesitation. Unfortunatly for a pc release, with a much higher price tag, i find it really hard to recommend.

The politics have not been fleshed and, and as expected the city buidling limited. Ultimately making the game limited in fun and appeal. Fun to be had in limitation. Should be much cheaper

I got it on sale, but for $40? An overpriced boring game. 

1) There's not much depth at all. Proven by the game manual of a few pages of things you already knew from any "Lets Play" videos on youtube. If you've seen one video on this game, you saw 100% of the gameplay besides late game eras. And no--- it doesnt save itself by then.

2) The UI is clunky -- having to toggle between too many panels to do simple actions. 

3) Use dense grid. Always dense grid. Theres no strategy in which zones to use. Infact, using sparse grids will cost you more by far  as you have to cover all that space with extra services. 

4) For a political game, it misses the point entirely. Hell, its not even a politcal game. Its a voting game. Theres no real replay value to govern as liberal or consertative --- a tryannt or a benovolent hero ---- it all means the same thing. For example a liberal will want pass unions as much as conserative, just simply because its BUFFS all your services.

5) Overpriced.

Just for refrence on my current playthrough im a couple hours in, everything is passing without effort, and im sitting on my ass wondering what to do with my hands as a third of this game is paying attention to random events and picking a choice. Another third is researching tech, sitting on my ass, and picking what I want my lamps to look like. The last third is voting, and acting like you give a crap as you give a district some cobblestone roads for some enivorment boost. Yay.

Now I can place a new district! Rinse and repeat.

They should've just taken this idea of game and combined with a new Tropico to revitizle the franchise. So that way when Im bored out of my mind I can at least kill all the council members and actually have a game to play.

column8:
The game is BORING is a game about clicking many many times to get something aprove and watch the city grows itself.

Unlike tropico you do nothing, there is no building and every edict is about clicking many times the mouse bottom to get it approve.

Unlike City skylines you set a district and have no management or control on were the different zones will be and just watch it grows (do nothing else).

for $40 dollars you can get tropico or city skylines or both and save youself some money and actually have fun playing a good city building game.
