column9:
I think this is an interesting take on a city-building strategy game. I don't see any optimization issues, and the graphics may not be the best, but that's not what the game is about. The graphics look very decent. This game is for those who want to feel like a mayor.

7.5 out of 10 sessions

column8:
[b]TL;DR:[/b] An interesting idea for a novel genre that sadly does not manage to keep my interest.


Urban Empire tries to mix story-telling aspects with city-building and strategic maneuvering in politics.
I watched let's plays of this before release and I am not terrible shocked to find that the strategy part is a bit shallow and the city building is not the focus of the game. So maybe we should understand this as political story-telling game?

Unfortunately those aspects are not presented in a way that makes me want to find out more. The political maneuvering I found very straightforward and while this might get more difficult later on, nothing I've seen in any of the previews suggests that the way to handle the different parties changes significantly. I think the system might work quite well in a role playing playthrough where you stick with one ideology and try to press it through regardless of what the council thinks though.
Which brings me to the storytelling aspect. Unfortunately none of the political parties feel alive enough to make for good stories and your personal story as the mayor character is restricted to a few largely inconsequential events

The graphics are well done and follow a coherent style. However, the rest of the presentation definitely feels subpar. Let's just say multiple missing or wrong tooltips and spelling errors just in the first hour of the game doesn't leave a good first impression.

So in summary a great and novel idea that sadly falls flat in the execution and does nothing to make me want to play more. I guess there might be some potential in here as a political role playing simulator, but I just find the core game play not very engaging.

column8: The game has a texture bug that causes no textures to be created if you use a resolution higher than 1080.  I'm sure it will be fixed promptly but that is just inexcusable in a game being launched in 2017.  I have not been able to play the game as a result because I refuse to play it in a small box window as other users have reported that once it goes to windowed mode its nearly impossible to get it back to fullscreen.  Playtime is a misnomer as I left the game running while I researched the issue and did some other assorted things around the house, so again, I have been totally unable to play the game because of a texture bug.

column8: Wow what a disappointment for the money!  Can you imagine investing an hour of your recreation time to play this game and not much happens under your control?!  One, lots and lots of waiting while you are waiting go out for diner,  take a drive,  walk the dog,  walk your kids,  go make more coffee anything return and yet what nothings happened click click click click goes the mouse sadly the mouse had more fun than I.  Point is nothing happens just wait wait and more waiting even at the fastest speed of the game.  Now I love the concept of the program just wish a bit more to do with my time than wait around what seems like forever.  Conceptually a great game in theory guys theory is suppose to be the part on the drawing table not the end product!

Hard Locked entire system.Runs at less than 30fps on a system that can run Witcher 3 max np m8.

Unengaging, unchallenging gameplay. Conservative parties serve no purpose but to give the illusion of challenge. Every edict I wanted to pass went though no issue with the occasional plead. 

UI is atrocious. Too many vague and undefined terms. +5% sales demand = ???. No real breakdown of interpretation of your actions into how it affects your city.

Plays like a choose-your-own-adventure game. Think of all the events from CK2 or EU4, but having no clue what they do before and often even after you click an option.

Praise the idea. Wouldn't have been interested otherwise, and following Quill's sponsored LP. However, with steam's 2 hour window for refunds, gotta make a call. Might revisit in the future, but just feels too amateurish for the price-tag, and too full of questionable design decisions.

Played the game for 58 minutes.... I have played city builders before, but this one is well beyond my skill; it's just so clogged up that for me it's imposible to play. The tutorial is iffy, the building placing it's missing a placement tool ( you have no ideea that a train station has to be placed miles away from where your district is, or that the pollice station can only be placed in the residential area ) . Requested a refund, and I would advice you to buy, keep an eye on the  clock and if in 50 minutes the game dosen't make sense to you, stop playing it and get your money back.

column8: I was looking forward to playing this game for a while. I downloaded it and started a new campaign with the tutorial on. Once in the game, my screen just kept spinning. The only way I was able to stop it from spinning is holding the opposite screen rotation key. I have tried different scenarios, turning off the tutorial, changing the key bindings to rotate the screen and it still keeps spinning. I am going to request a refund since I haven't been able to play.

column8: 7970å¤–æ˜Ÿäººä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆç©èµ·æ¥ä¸€å¡ä¸€å¡å“’....å¿§ä¼¤

Pretty good game, but not yet great. Only on my first playthrough, but it scratches a lot of the itches I have in gaming. 

- It has a simplified citybuilding part, which I welcome as it has a clear place in the game.  
- It has political simulation. This is also a bit simplistic at parts. You basicly buy votes with goodwill, there is not that much to it so far, if you have enough goodwill, you can swing votes in your favor, and goodwill goes to a default state which depends on you general standing in the city. So far I haven't done anything in particular to make this good and I have not had any problems getting what I want. I will update this review if it turns out that the system is deeper later in the game. 
- It has dynasty building. I love this, you have choices to make about your son, who you get to play later. 
- it has a pretty large research tree with narration when something is discovered, a bit of Civilization feeling. 

So to me it seems it has elements of Sim City, The Guild, Civilization and Crusader Kings. I don't think they are just mashed together without thought. I think they work just fine. 

I only have two complaints so far. The first is what I already said, the political system should be a bit more complicated. I just know when I've spent enough goodwill to get the vote, because it tells me how many will vote yes and no and so far there hasn't been any surprises. Everything is a bit simple, but that's not necessary a bad thing as the game has many layers and if all were complicated it would get lost in them. However the main attraction should be a bit deeper (unless it's depth is gradualy introduced, in which case as I said I'll update the review). 
The second is technical. I wish it was possible to increase drawing distance. I don't have any technical problems or glitches, it works fine, but objects dissappear very soon. 

I'm having fun so far, hope replayability won't be a problem. So far, recommended. 

(To be honest, I thinks it's too early to review at all for anyone, but already the "I play on an abacus and it crashes after a few minutes" "reviews" popped up, and it's a much better game than to deserve failing due those, so here is my honest opinion after a but more than an hour.)

Update: It really starts to get much better in the 3rd era. It is now kind of democratic, you are elected and have to fight to stay in power. Your council is also elected, which makes it possible to attack your problems with them from different angles. 
For example in my last term I had a really hard time, I made some bad zoning decisions and the town was bleeding money. By the mayoral elections we were deeply in debt. To remedy this until the unused zones get back in shape I tried to raise taxes, but the freedom party and the communists always stopped it, also making them my mortal enemies by the time the mayoral elections arrived. 
I was going to lose it badly, but I had one chance, I had a lot of dirt on those two. The communists were easy, at the first sign of trouble they yielded and gave me full support. The Freedom Party on the other hand would rather have me out them, but refused to cooperate, so that's what happened. I had enough of the goodwill of the other parties to win the election by a very small margin. 
Then another term went by, the economy was still bad, but the communists started to like me as we agreed on a lot of proposals. I still couldn't raise taxes, and I didn't want to use my goodwill to do so as the mayoral elections looked like a disaster. Then came the elections for the council, and the Communist party won big time. The freedom party however was reduced to almost nothing due to all the bad stuff that were revealed during the last mayoral elections. This gave me majority support in the council, so I'm still in game, the taxes are raised, so the budget is recovering and population is rising again. 
It could still be more complicated, but it already strikes all the right chords with me.

column8:
As it stands the game feels fairly shallow, I appreciate it's hands off as you're a mayor but be prepared to spend most of your time begging the council to at least let you build a new district, if you fail that vote you get to stare at your one district with essentially nothing to do.

Oh top tip, don't install basic utilites like street lights. It will econimically ruin the empire and you'll have to ask the Emporer himself for more funds. For your lamps.

Wait for some patches and a price drop. This is a Â£15 game, not Â£35.

Edit.

To clarify, the game feels shallow as the political mecahnics feel almost meaningless. They seem to simply serve as a difficulty barrier. For example, if you are economically struggling, you need to build industry. To build industry, you need to ask the council.

Council say no.

It then doesn't offer up any reason as to why, job creation doesn't float any political groups boat for some reason.

You then stare at the screen unsure of how to increase funds while the council do nothing. It's like the game NEEDS you to be hands on, but won't let you at the same time.

Also, researching technologies unlocks new types of buildings, clothes shops for example. Yet you have no way to place these as it's a hands off appraoch. Meaning you just have to assume there is a clothes shop some where in the city now.

Like I said, this game lacks depth. It's not horrific just don't buy it now. It will go down in price.

column8:
To start; 

HUGE EDIT;

Well after pver 44 hours played, the game plays well, and is fun. Gets very laggy late game with depth flowing to 32fps. Our system specs are below and are not outdated to say the least. It gets very demanding.
When tested on a top line quality laptop, same drop on fps. Seems to bog down greatly.
On an older laptop, its simply is horrible. If your laptop is not a quad core or better, with a near recent video card, forget it, you can play the first quater of the game and then just sit there and play thumb wars. LOL
We will keep you posted as this game gets better developments for late game playability.
****************************************************************************************************
OLD REVIEW BELOW BEFORE OUR ENDING REVIEW IS BELOW;

Looking at this game we figured that it would be boring, and be limited. We decided to give it a go because Kalypso's reputation with Tropico and other games and their huge amount of content and fun.
We are so glad we did!
The spin instead of being a city builder, your a Mayor. But not a Mayor on God Mode. You can not raise taxes, change things without going thru city council to start. Basically you have to lobby each area of govt. before voting.
While doing this you must maintain the city, your reputation to get re-elected, and keep the gorvening bodies and relations balanced or you will not get anything passed when improving your city. No improving your city means, no more you. Edicts, building, reasearch, so much to juggle like in real politics. Then add you pushing your views on what you feel your city will be and sell it to each council member.

EDIT; HOLY SH*T FIRE! Now the original parties in the game are splitting into more parties. SON OF A **TCH! Now the Emperor at 8 hours in is starting some crap with the govenor. The Govenor is a moron and wants my support. The Emperor has plans for me but he can not be trusted.
OUR CHOICE IS TO PUT OUR HEAD BETWEEN OUR LEGS AND KISS OUT A$$ GOODBYE!
This game just got real... and intense. WE LIKEY! COME TO DADDY!

EDIT; Got thru this and that... your spoiled... your fat... I like your kids... your kids should not be in public they are so ugly... and so on... but wow... this game just keeps getting better. In Hour 17 and well things have not dropped off one bit!

This game already has replayability in the plethora(many) choices in every area.
Research is not a grind, and instead of getting one thing for research you get bundles.

Heck, I want to slap some of these politicians, just now while writing this for pissing on my propsal to ban crapping in the streets. He must be the one that pissed on my shoes yesterday and thinks its funny to crap in the town hall park.
They are as stubborn as a mule some of the people and politicians while others are nice. Then you have the A-hole in every crowd, but he is your a-hole and friend when you really needed his support. 
But like in real life, peoples opinions change, with each decision, just depending how you covey that message and choose to side when they want to bring their own changes to your changes and you have to fight them. 

You can plea, bargain, threaten, or talk to the papers, behind closed doors, in a group or to the whole city council... ect ect. Just a ton of ways, like in life, to get the job done or undone.

EDIT; STILL NO OPTION TO BI**H SLAP! Damn.

It has been bug free for our first two hours. Still only have one district to manage, god help us trying to expand.

EDIT; Still bug and glitch free after 17 hours.

The tutorial is fantasic, we had to do it twice because we got a little impatient the first time and starting exploring on our own... don't do that! Go at their pace your first go. You will thank us later.

In closing;
This is a terrific spin on a city management/builder game. You don't build, you as to build. You don't bully or you get bullied. You can spend your own money to help the city for your passions. There is so much content, its gonna take many play thrus to get it down to any pattern which is ever changing.
Yes you read that right, CHANGING like the seasons so no run thru is alike. People change as they get older, you ban prositiution you may loose your male base and gain women favor. Allow alcohol and then you have the men back but now battered women or theft ect. 

You pick one faction, all having different benefits and cons, which all have different levels thru hisorical accurate development as you progress. We have yet to expand after two hours, because you can not rush.  IT is a chill and take your time game. The voting is intense and exciting. Especially if you really need XYZ and you pissed someone off last vote or recall on an edict. Heck we can not even get power because our finances took a hit building our first school, we raised taxes to pay for it and now people are throwing SH*T at us. Really... loads of it.... then I wanted to pass the No Pee In Public Ordiance. Naturally, they didnt agree because the city fun went up from SH*T tossing.

This is all we can provide so far in our first two hours.
EDIT; 8 HOURS IN. Wow.. just wow... if your impatient this game will add a new element. If your not in a hurry and can go with the swings... this game is immersive now.

Glitch and bug free so far, running at 61-64 FPS which is great with peak settings.

As stated prior still bug and glitch free after 17 hours.

Running NVidea Card 900 series with a Intel quad core.
1.1G Download on Solid State Drive
Game has run smooth in our first two hours without a hitch or bug.
Great Tutorial and Graphics thus far, and music is to each period which is nice and changes when the intesity of the situation changes. We really enjoy the political city hall forum and the feeling of being on Capital Hill.

Get the game, you will not regret it. 
They are also adding content as it was launched 1/20.
It is made by Kalypso, so you know your getting your money's worth.
The humor is in it, not just a challenge, just like in Tropico series and El Presidente. 
But your El Mayor-ente?... and you don't rule, you try to win the hearts and minds of your people.
You try to be political and enjoy that bs process of kissing babies and spanking their mommies while getting daddy's drunk to make a buck to build the school you need so you do not have a street full or ? running around.

We will add more once we get a few more hours in.
Funny, serious, challenging, and replay-able.
SOLID BUY! So glad we gave it a chance.



Our gear;

Running at 61-63 FPS
NVidea GTX 960
Intel I-7
Dual Samsung Monitors 
DDR3 12GB

All views are based on positive-only feedback as we are in no position to criticize anyone's craft, just current states of development and progress at the time of our participation. If we offend anyone with our content, it was not us! Our review was hacked!

column8:
david cameron simulator

Kidding aside, if you're into political games (aka Democracy 3 and Nation States) that involve choosing policies and seeing how your decisions shape the place you rule (and also you look forward to the political aspects of the game rather than the city building ones), I think that you would appreciate it. The unique thing that differenciates this game from the other titles I mentioned is that one, it provides an actual visual representation of that location rather than just text descriptions and two, it features a historical storyline (with the political decisions reflecting the time period).

Do not buy this game if you're looking for a city builder because that will just disappoint you since that is not the game's focus (considering the high price as well). If that's what you want, just get Cities Skylines and look for some Industrial Revolution themes/mods for your city. However, buy this game if you're looking for a good, in-depth <<political simulator>>.

Eigentlich wollte ich nie wieder ein Kalypso-Spiel kaufen, aber das Genre und erste Videos hatten es mir dann doch angetan.

Leider ist das Spiel jedoch dermaÃŸen von Bugs geplagt, welche nicht nur das Spielerlebnis an sich zerstÃ¶ren, sondern auch das Spiel. So kann ich beispielsweise nicht mehr auf meine Bezirke zugreifen, nicht neue Bezirke benennen und wenn ich es doch versuche, dann verschwinden diese plÃ¶tzlich.

Ich kann nur vom Kauf abraten, bis irgendwann ordentlich gepatcht wurde - kann mir beim besten Willen nicht vorstellen, dass so etwas nicht bei Tests vorher zu sehen war.

Des Weiteren ist z.B. das Feature, die Parteien zu beeinflussen reine Augenwischerei. Man klickt einfach immer das Gleiche - ich sehe da keine Freiheit oder Transparenz dahinter.

Nach den EntÃ¤uschen und TÃ¤uschungen bei MudTV, Tropico 5 und Omerta definitiv mein letzter Kauf bei Kalypso. NIE WIEDER!

Actually, I bought this game after listening to a program on Jihe. It's a way of supporting the Chinese culture of gaming, I guess.

I've always liked this type of game, so I immediately waited for its release to download and try it out.

Unlike purely building games like SimCity and Megacity, this game leans more towards strategy, incorporating party elections and voting into city building. The concept is quite novel, but for someone unfamiliar with electoral systems, it took me a while to get started. I'll need to carefully follow the tutorial.

I'm still experimenting with the gameplay, difficulty, and overall gameplay, and since I haven't had much time to play, I won't comment much.

column8:
So, I'm really sort of on the fence with this game. Its built off a great concept and it runs smooth and looks good.... But I don't quite think $40 is the right price tag for this. 

I have low playtime atm, because i'm debating a refund. Again, not because its necessarily a bad game, but I just dont know if i see getting $40 worth of fun out of it. If i decide to keep it, i'll update this review.

__________________________________________________________________________________

Played it a bit more, and decided to keep it. It really is more of a political simulator then anything else, still not worth $40 in my oppinion, but I dont regret keeping it.

People must undderstand this is a political game snd thats why i Love it. The political game for those who want a visual parliment type game. You must  gain the support of the people living in your city in order to boost your party numbers. Grid lock fights over new districts. I would like to an easier break down of details or a better explanation, but so far im loving the game. Sorry the review is so short....have to leave for work

IF U WANT TO JUST BUILD A CITY THIS IS NOT THE GAME FOR U. It's a political parliament game. The whole point is to have to deal with political parties and fight with them. When your party is in power- it's easy- when your party is the minority-  your bills arnt going to pass

This game is exactly what they say it is - a mayor + city STRATEGY GAME / SIMULATOR.  It's not really a city builder, and the reviews dinging it because of that are nothing short than people not understanding what the developers have created.

If you enjoy strategy / simulator games and have always wanted to create a long lasting family dynasty this game is for you.

column8:
I didn't like it at all.

Pros:

- Good concept

Cons:

- The UI is a mess and far from being intuitive. For example, when you are going to put a Townhall, the big button to confirm does nothing. You have to guess that you should click in a tiny button to enable you to place the damn hall.

- The Ui is horrible really.

- The game do not have font configs so, if you does not have a sniper's sight, you will have a bad time. ( Obs: i have a 42' pol monitor )

- The price is too high for it, totally.


Asked for a refund, there is no way to play this game. These guys really needs to improve their way to do stuff.

This is a game I've been really looking forward to; it's truly amazing.
It's a city-building and political simulation experienceâ€”that's the feeling you get from playing it. Unlocking new technologies makes for noticeable changes. Highly recommended!

In the campaign mode, youâ€™ll lead a mayoral family from 1820 until (hopefully) 2020. Although the general mechanics play out the same each time, a large variety of events make each game slightly different. The main difference between Urban Empire and more traditional city builders is that most everything is put to a vote, so politics and relationships with parties matter. Districts are placed with zoning layouts, services, and infrastructure support. The city council must approve new districts through a vote; they also will vote on tax rate changes, modifications to existing districts, edicts, and service funding levels. Goodwill can be spent persuading parties to vote your way. A research tree contains inventions that unlock new services and edicts. Citizens have needs in several areas (such as social life, environment, health, and fun) that can be fulfilled by placing services. Urban Empire is a challenging game: it is difficult to consistently turn a monthly profit and still satisfy the needs of the citizens, and getting votes passed requires balance and skill. With an injection of meaningful political considerations, Urban Empire stands out as a city management game.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uVWNtTeZUQ8
